column2: GOLDSTEIN--Roslyn Louise. Roz died April 25, 2016 in San Francisco, CA, days after celebrating her 90th birthday. She is survived by her daughter Judith; son-in-law Richard (Purkey); grandchildren Stacy (Mazor), Melissa (Mazor), Sarah (Purkey), Jeremy, and Hannah (Purkey); great- grandchildren Lucas (Mazor) and Adina (Bowman); and brother Ernest (Rubenstein). She was preceded in death by her daughter, Joan (Mazor), son-in-law, Lawrence (Mazor), sister, Lillian (Barrer) and husband, Seymour. Roz was devoted to her family and had a remarkable lifelong capacity to make and keep friends. She will be deeply missed by all who knew her. Memorial contributions may be made to the charity of the donor's choice. 1/3

McELWREATH--Dorothy Uehlinger (nee: Karthaus). of Long Beach, NY on April 23, 2016. Devoted daughter of the late Edward and Regina. Dearest sister of the late Edward, the late Robert, and the late Eileen Donovan. Loving wife of the late Gerard P. Uehlinger and the late Robert J. McElwreath. Beloved mother of Marijane, Timothy, Edward (Mary Elizabeth), John (Ann), and Gerard Jr. Caring stepmother of the late Robert Jr., Maureen, Edward (Leslie), and Patricia (Dennis) Donohue. "Grandma Dot" to fifteen grandchildren, step-grandchildren, and six great-grandchildren. Lifelong friend and cousin to Eileen B. Muirhead and family. Reposing at Macken Mortuary, Rockville Centre Chapel, 52 Clinton Avenue, Thursday 7-9pm, Friday 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass St. Ignatius Martyr RC Church, Long Beach, NY, Saturday, 9:15am. Interment at Cemetery of the Holy Rood, Westbury, NY. www.mackenmortuary.com. 1

LEEDS--Dalia. The Board and staff of NYJTL deeply mourn the passing of Dalia Leeds, our treasured friend. Our sympathy and deepest condolences to her beloved husband, Laurence, and the entire Leeds family. NYJTL Board and staff 1/3

NUSSBAUM--Pauline. October 10, 1922 - April 26, 2016. Died peacefully at home in NYC. USMC WWll Sgt. Widow of Morris Nussbaum. Leaves behind daughter Suzy and loving grandsons Max and Austin Gengos. 1/3

WHEELER--Dr. Barbara A.,81, former Professor of Anthropology and Director of Africana Studies at Kean University transitioned peacefully on April 25, 2016, at her residence in Union, NJ. She will be remembered as a pioneering International Pan Africanist who developed the "African Disapora Travelearn" Course at Kean University. Formerly Deputy Director of Black Studies at the City College of New York, and a founding member of African Heritage Studies Association. She is survived by her children, Roni L. and William G. Wheeler, Jr.; one grandson, three great-grandchildren; two sisters and one brother and a host of family and friends spanning the globe. Reflective Viewing Services will be held at Metropolitan Baptist Church, 149 Springfield Ave., Newark, NJ 07103 on Friday, April 29th, 6-8pm and The Celebration of Her Life; Saturday, April 30th at 9am-1pm. Interment will be at Hollywood Memorial Park, 1500 Stuyvesant Ave., Union, NJ. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to "Dr. Barbara Wheeler Scholarship Fund" c/o Professor Tobi at Kean Univ. mtoby@kean.edu. Professional services are provided by Islamic Burial Services, Funeral Director, Hawwah Karim 973-484-1494. 1/3

LEEDS--Dalia, cherished Godmother to Claire, Leslie and Randy; lifelong best friend to Roy and Barbara Goodman and their families: your motherly warmth, caring, generous spirit, elegance, and many talents will be missed deeply and never forgotten! With heavy hearts we send our profound sympathies to Larry, Ashley, Tracy and their families. 1/3

DENNY--Margaret McGuinness, died peacefully on April 23, 2016, at her Park Place Nursing Home, after an eight year struggle with Alzhiemer's Disease. She turned 80 years old in March. Margaret, known as "Ticky," was born and raised in Chestnut Hill, PA. After graduating from Springside School and the Rhode Island School of Design, she married John H. Denny and resided in Princeton, NJ for 55 years. Margaret was a longtime member of the Bedens Brook Club in Skillman, NJ and the Ausable Club in the Adirondacks. Her father, Dr. Aims C. McGuinness was the Under Secretary of Health, Education, and Welfare (1957-1959) in the Eisenhower administration. Margaret is survived by her husband, John; her brother, Aims C. McGuinness, of Littleton, CO; her daughter, Elise Anderson, of Manitou Springs, CO; her son, John, Jr. of Princeton, NJ, and six grandchildren. A small service for family and friends is planned for early July in the Adirondacks. 1/3

BENSON--Irving. Our wonderful friend Irving Benson, passed away Sunday. A beautiful, big hearted, warm, generous and loving man, Irving was our original board member, championing the very idea of Performa from its inception until today. As Treasurer on the Performa Board, he never missed a board meeting. He will forever be our guiding spirit. RoseLee Goldberg, Founding Director, the Performa Board and staff 1/3

BASHOVER--Beatrice Claire (nee Dansiger), was born May 6, 1926 in Newark, NJ, the middle of three daughters of Harry and Sarah Dansiger, hardworking immigrants from Poland. She died April 21, 2016 in Lantana, FL. Beatrice was predeceased by her devoted husband of 64 years Albert Bashover and her sister Riva Schonborn. She is survived by her younger sister, Isabel Adler of Springfield, NJ. Beatrice was the mother of Paula Segall (David), Dr. Mark Bashover (Linda), Judith Rubinstein (Dr. Ronald), and Dr. Matthew Bashover (Dr. Diane). She was the loving grandmother - Bubba - of Rebecca, Steven (Allison), Rachel, Michael, Benjamin (Cheryl), Max (Amelia), Jacob, Anna, Eva, David (Erica) and the great- grandmother of Brianna, Jaxon, and Cameron and the aunt to many nieces and nephews. Beatrice obtained a college degree in an era when few women did so, a Masters in special education and had a long teaching career with B.O.C.E.S. on Long Island. She was the past president of her unit of the National Council of Jewish Women. She and her husband, Albert, were active in musical productions in their community and traveled the world in their retirement. Beatrice will always be remembered as a wife, mother, grandmother, and great- grandmother, who put her family first, gathering all to share homemade meals, songs and laughter. She will be greatly missed. 1/3

LEEDS--Dalia Benary, of New York, passed away at NYU Langone Medical Center surrounded by her loving family on Wednesday, April 27, 2016 at the age of 85. She is survived by her beloved husband of 60 years, Laurence C. Leeds, Jr. (Larry) and her devoted daughters, Ashley Leeds (Christopher Harland) and Tracy Leeds (Evan Marwell). She was predeceased by her son Laurence C. Leeds, III (Cary) and her brother Oded Benary. Also surviving are her six adoring grandchildren: Samuel, Michael, and Benjamin Harland and Nicholas, Olivia, and James Marwell. Dalia, the daughter of Zvi and Belina Benary, was born in Tel Aviv. She attended school in Switzerland and English Girls College (El Nasr Girls' College) in Alexandria, during an era when young Jewish students from what was going to be the state of Israel crossed the border to attend school in Egypt. After visiting the United States several times, she moved to New York City where she met and married Larry on October 16, 1955. Dalia was a fine painter and sculptor and, during her early days in The United States, worked at the Art Students League and attended the Traphagen School of Design. Dalia became a legendary figure of the New York social scene. Her extraordinary beauty and grace, along with her wonderfully warm and sensitive personality, charmed almost everyone she met. She was kind and compassionate and, as a result of these attributes, she had an unending number of admirers and friends. After the tragic loss of her son Cary, she worked tirelessly and successfully to help build the Cary Leeds Center for Tennis & Learning, dedicated to improving the lives of thousands of young girls and boys in the Bronx. Dalia also served on the boards of The Council for a Beautiful Israel, the Israel Anti Drug Abuse Foundation, and The American Friends of the Israeli Philharmonic Orchestra. Dalia never forgot her roots and loved her native Israel. She would travel there at least twice a year until her recent illness. It is the end of an amazing life. A private family service will be held graveside. The family will be sitting Shiva Sunday, May 1st, Monday, May 2nd, and Tuesday, May 3rd from 5:00pm - 8:00pm at their residence in New York City. A memorial service in celebration of Dalia's life, will be held at a future date. In lieu of flowers, donations in Dalia's name may be directed to the Cary Leeds Center for Tennis & Learning and sent to The New York Junior Tennis League, 58-12 Queens Blvd, Woodside, NY 11377. For further information, please call 212-922-5530 or 917-536-5792. 1/3

FELDMAN--Anne G.,86, died peacefully at home in Brooklyn on April 27. Beloved wife of 58 years to Eugene, devoted mother of Simon, Nancy and Josh (Nancy B.); cherished grandmother of Howie, Rachel, Jacob, Clara, and Rose. Anne's tireless energy, intellect, and unwavering commitment to justice will be missed by all who knew her. Services at Congregation Beth Elohim, Brooklyn, 274 Garfield Place, on Monday, May 2, at 9:45am. 1/3

LEEDS--Dalia. The Board and staff of NYJTL deeply mourn the passing of Dalia Leeds, our treasured friend. Our sympathy and deepest condolences to her beloved husband, Laurence, and the entire Leeds family. NYJTL Board and staff 1/3

LEEDS--Dalia. Darling Dalia, You were the most beautiful woman who ever crossed the threshold of my vision. Not only were you gorgeous, you were incredibly intelligent, sensitive, kind and caring. You represented everything that any man would ever desire in a wife and partner. I thank you for having chosen to marry me and for giving me the confidence and strength to pursue our dreams together. Dalia, you were a magnificent mother, and you so nurtured our wonderful children Cary, Ashley and Tracy, providing an enduring example of the true meaning of family. Your six grandchildren Sam, Michael, Ben, Nicholas, Olivia, and Jamie adored their Grandma Didi and will hold you forever in their hearts. Dalia, I will mourn, miss and celebrate you for the rest of my life. Thank you for the gift of 60 wonderful years together. I love you always. Larry 1/3

ARIDA--Gloria, died peacefully on April 26, 2016. Beloved sister to Lila Bandon (Arida), Gladys Schondorf (Arida) and the late Edward. Cherished aunt to many and dear friend to all. Services are entrusted to McLaughlin and Sons Funeral Home, Brooklyn, NY. 1/3

LAUTERSTEIN--Henry Weil, 86, on April 27, 2016. A longtime resident of Stamford and graduate of Milton Academy, Harvard College and Columbia University Law School, Henry joined his father, Leon Lauterstein in the law firm, Lauterstein & Lauterstein, where his clients included Kobrand Wine & Spirits and The Metropolitan Opera. His valued advice resulted in him joining the Met as in-house counsel in 1981 until his retirement. A lover of nature, opera, baseball, an avid fisherman and frequent visitor to Maine, Henry readily shared his knowledge and passions. A beloved husband, father, grandfather and life partner, Henry was predeceased by his wife, Katherine Mebane and his son, David. He will be dearly missed by his daughters Dorothy Doppstadt and Margaret Mandell, his partner Fred Wyatt, his son-in-law, Jonathan Mandell and his grandchildren, Lucas, Emily, Daniel and Natalie. 1/3

FLASTER--Norma Summers, on April 27, 2016 at 88 years of age, after a long struggle with Parkinson's Disease. Beloved wife of Alvin, loving mother of Lynn Flaster Paul (John) and Richard. Adored grandmother of Scott Alvord (Sandra) and Julie Alvord. Great-grandmother of Eleanor and Thomas. Daughter of the late George and Sadie Summers. Sister of the late Allan Summers. She was charming, intelligent, beautiful, and had a great sense of style. We will miss and love her forever. Services 10:30am, Sunday, May 1, 2016 at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY, (516) 487-9600. 1/3

ANDERSON--Margaret Emily, of Easthampton, MA, 83, formerly of New York, died April 17. She taught at the Brearley School, was a former member of Abingdon Square Painters, First Presbyterian Church, and the Church of Gethsemane. Services being handled by Ahearn Funeral Home, Northampton MA. 1/3

LIGHT--Kate, 56, died April 13 in Manhattan of cancer. A longtime violinist with the New York City Opera and an acclaimed poet, Kate united these two passions in becoming an opera and musical theater lyricist and librettist. She will be missed by her many friends and loving family. Kate was preceded in death by her father, Martin. She is survived by her mother, Dorothy, sisters Judith (Charles Wannan) and Betsy, and brother Steve (Kathryn Rand). Memorials to be announced. 1/3

LINTON--Robert E. Robert E. Linton, former CEO and Chairman of Drexel Burnham Lambert, Inc., died April 26, 2016 at the age of 90. During the early 1980s, Mr. Linton served as the head of the storied investment banking and securities firm that pioneered the use of high yield (or "junk") bonds. Robert Linton was born in New York City on May 19, 1925 to Helen and Adolph Lichtenstein, a specialist on the New York Stock Exchange. During his senior year at Phillips Exeter Academy, Linton enlisted in the Army, eventually serving in WWII as a navigator and bombardier and achieving the rank of 2nd lieutenant in the Army Air Force. In 1946, Mr. Linton joined Burnham & Co., a small investment bank as the eighth employee, starting as a runner delivering stock certificates around Wall Street. Hard-working and ambitious, Bob attended night school to earn his stock broker's license and later, his commodities broker's license. Linton worked in virtually every department of the firm, forming the company's Corporate Finance and Commodities departments. By 1976, the firm had become Drexel Burnham Lambert. Mr. Linton was eventually named to head the firm by founder I.W. Burnham II, and in the early 1980s under his leadership, Drexel grew to become the most profitable firm on Wall Street. When Mr. Linton retired, DBL had 10,000 employees in worldwide offices. During his time on Wall Street, Mr. Linton was Vice Chairman of the Board of Governors of the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD, 1980), a director of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE, 1983-1987), and served as Chairman of the Securities Industry Association (SIA, 1983). Mr. Linton served two terms as a member of the National Council of Consultants to the Small Business Administration, was an expert witness before the Congressional committees drawing up the SBIC legislation and testified twice before the Senate Banking Committee against the repeal of the Glass-Steagall Act. Linton was a founding member of the American Business Conference, Inc., a coalition of growth companies. Mr. Linton was also an active and longstanding supporter of the social sector, serving as a founding member of the Board of Directors of Lincoln Center Theater from 1984 to 2015 and then as the organization's first Director Emeritus; and as a Director of the Board of the School of American Research, Santa Fe, NM (now known as School for Advanced Research) in the 1990s. In 1987, Linton was appointed Chairman of the Advisory Board of the Sol C. Snider Entrepreneurial Research Center at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. After retiring from Drexel Burnham Lambert, Mr. Linton partnered with Cy Leslie, founder of Pickwick International to form Leslie Linton Entertainment, an investor in entertainment companies and properties, including Red Sky Entertainment, a creator, developer and marketer of family entertainment properties. Mr. Linton was an avid sportsman, enjoying tennis, golf, fishing and skiing, and took pride in winning a NASTAR ski race gold medal at the age of 72 in Taos, NM. Mr. Linton is survived by his wife of 63 years, the former Margot Tishman; a sister, Marion Benson, of Beverly Hills, CA; four children including Roberta L. Bennett, of Warren, VT; Thomas N. Linton of Santa Fe, NM; Jeffrey R. Linton (and his wife Judith), of Rye, NY; and Elizabeth M. Linton of Berkshire, England; and five grandchildren. Funeral Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., NYC, Monday, May 2nd at 11:30am. 1/3

WHEELER--Dr. Barbara A.,81, former Professor of Anthropology and Director of Africana Studies at Kean University transitioned peacefully on April 25, 2016, at her residence in Union, NJ. She will be remembered as a pioneering International Pan Africanist who developed the "African Disapora Travelearn" Course at Kean University. Formerly Deputy Director of Black Studies at the City College of New York, and a founding member of African Heritage Studies Association. She is survived by her children, Roni L. and William G. Wheeler, Jr.; one grandson, three great-grandchildren; two sisters and one brother and a host of family and friends spanning the globe. Reflective Viewing Services will be held at Metropolitan Baptist Church, 149 Springfield Ave., Newark, NJ 07103 on Friday, April 29th, 6-8pm and The Celebration of Her Life; Saturday, April 30th at 9am-1pm. Interment will be at Hollywood Memorial Park, 1500 Stuyvesant Ave., Union, NJ. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to "Dr. Barbara Wheeler Scholarship Fund" c/o Professor Tobi at Kean Univ. mtoby@kean.edu. Professional services are provided by Islamic Burial Services, Funeral Director, Hawwah Karim 973-484-1494. 1/3

RAYLESBERG--Daniel. The board of directors, president and members of the Contemporary Freudian Society note with sadness the death of our former president and founding member, Daniel Raylesberg. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. 1/3

LINTON--Robert. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center Theater are deeply saddened by the death of our Honorary Trustee, Robert Linton. Bob was a devoted LCT Board Member for more than 30 years. He was a lively presence at meetings, often expressing original points of view and sharing theatrical anecdotes. He loved the work on our stages and was an enthusiastic supporter of our magazine and education program. We send condolences to his wife, Margot, and his children and grandchildren. J. Tomilson Hill, Chairman Eric M. Mindich, President Andre Bishop, Producing Artistic Director 1/3

CLARK--Lawrence David, Jr. passed away at his home in New York City on April 27, 2016 at the age of 72. He was born in East Rochester, NY to Lawrence David Clark, Sr. and Josephine Furman Clark. He graduated from Harvard College in 1965, magna cum laude and as a member of Phi Beta Kappa and the Harvard College Glee Club. He graduated from Harvard Law School in 1968 and moved to New York City to practice law. He was recognized as a leading attorney in the trust and estates field. He served as a fellow of the American College of Trust and Estate counsel and was named a Best Lawyer and a Super Lawyer. He is survived by his wife of 49 years Carolyn Cochran Clark and his sons Gregory David Clark of Chattanooga, TN and Timothy Rogers Clark of Austin, TX, a brother Mark F. Clark (and wife Susan) of Belmont, MA, a sister Mary Clark Hess of Acton, MA and a first cousin Stephanie Harris of Rochester, NY. David served on the board of the Professional Children's School. He belonged to the University Club in New York City and the Maidstone Club in East Hampton, NY. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, May 3, 11am at All Souls Unitarian Church, 1157 Lexington Ave. (at 80th Street), New York City. Burial will follow in the Cedar Lawn Cemetery in East Hampton, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions to the Professional Children's School, 132 W. 60th St, NY, NY 10023 Attn: Mr. Chris Haley. 1/3

HURLOCK--James Bickford, died peacefully with family by his side on April 27th. A beloved husband, father, grandfather, sportsman, and sailor, Mr. Hurlock led a distinguished forty-one-year career at the law firm of White & Case, where for twenty years he served as Managing Partner overseeing the firm's global expansion. He was a Director and Chairman of Orient Express Hotels, Deputy Chairman of Acergy, and Interim CEO of Stolt-Nielson Transportation Group. He was a founding board member of the International Development Law Organization and served as Chairman from 2001-2004. He was a Trustee of the Corporation of Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, New York Presbyterian Hospital, and the Parker School of Foreign and Comparative Law at Columbia University, where he served as Chairman. In 2010 the New York State Bar Association bestowed on him its Root/Stimson Award for exemplary commitment to community service. Mr. Hurlock was born August 7th, 1933 in Chicago, Illinois to James Bickford Hurlock and Elizabeth Charls Hurlock and grew up in Cleveland, Ohio. He attended the Hawken School and graduated from Western Reserve Academy before attending Princeton University from which he graduated in 1955. At Princeton he received the Pyne Prize and was awarded a Rhodes Scholarship to Oxford University where he attended Magdalen College. He graduated from Harvard Law School in 1959 and joined White & Case the same year. He is survived by his wife of fifty-five years, Margaret Lyn (Holding) Hurlock, and three sons and their wives, James Bickford III and Kathryn Buck Hurlock, Burton Charls and Olivia Bruce Hurlock, and Matthew Hunter and Severa Imperiali Hurlock, and eight grandchildren. Mr. Hurlock spent a dozen years of his career living and raising his young family abroad, in Paris, Brussels and London and was a long time summer resident of Siasconset, MA, which he visited for the first time in 1942. He loved fishing and hunting and sailing with his family, and completed a transatlantic race and seven Bermuda races, the first in 1962. He was a scholar, a gentleman, an inspiring leader, and a loyal friend who will be greatly missed. A memorial service celebrating the life of James B. Hurlock will be held at Christ Church, 254 East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich on Thursday, May 12th at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, 86 Water Street, Woods Hole, MA 02543 or the New York Presbyterian Fund, Inc., Office of Development, 654 West 170th Street, New York, NY 10022. 1/3

BASHOVER--Beatrice Claire (nee Dansiger), was born May 6, 1926 in Newark, NJ, the middle of three daughters of Harry and Sarah Dansiger, hardworking immigrants from Poland. She died April 21, 2016 in Lantana, FL. Beatrice was predeceased by her devoted husband of 64 years Albert Bashover and her sister Riva Schonborn. She is survived by her younger sister, Isabel Adler of Springfield, NJ. Beatrice was the mother of Paula Segall (David), Dr. Mark Bashover (Linda), Judith Rubinstein (Dr. Ronald), and Dr. Matthew Bashover (Dr. Diane). She was the loving grandmother - Bubba - of Rebecca, Steven (Allison), Rachel, Michael, Benjamin (Cheryl), Max (Amelia), Jacob, Anna, Eva, David (Erica) and the great- grandmother of Brianna, Jaxon, and Cameron and the aunt to many nieces and nephews. Beatrice obtained a college degree in an era when few women did so, a Masters in special education and had a long teaching career with B.O.C.E.S. on Long Island. She was the past president of her unit of the National Council of Jewish Women. She and her husband, Albert, were active in musical productions in their community and traveled the world in their retirement. Beatrice will always be remembered as a wife, mother, grandmother, and great- grandmother, who put her family first, gathering all to share homemade meals, songs and laughter. She will be greatly missed. 1/3

WEINSTOCK--Leon, 93, died April 29th, peacefully at home. Predeceased by his beloved wife Elaine. Survived by his loving family, daughter Laura Estersohn (Glenn), son Robert (Risa), grandchildren Matthew (Elizabeth), Amy, Emily, Grace, great-grandson Ethan, and dear friend Rita Rodin. Funeral Sunday, 1pm, Gutterman Funeral Home, Hackensack, NJ. 1/3

LINTON--Robert E. Robert E. Linton, former CEO and Chairman of Drexel Burnham Lambert, Inc., died April 26, 2016 at the age of 90. During the early 1980s, Mr. Linton served as the head of the storied investment banking and securities firm that pioneered the use of high yield (or "junk") bonds. Robert Linton was born in New York City on May 19, 1925 to Helen and Adolph Lichtenstein, a specialist on the New York Stock Exchange. During his senior year at Phillips Exeter Academy, Linton enlisted in the Army, eventually serving in WWII as a navigator and bombardier and achieving the rank of 2nd lieutenant in the Army Air Force. In 1946, Mr. Linton joined Burnham & Co., a small investment bank as the eighth employee, starting as a runner delivering stock certificates around Wall Street. Hard-working and ambitious, Bob attended night school to earn his stock broker's license and later, his commodities broker's license. Linton worked in virtually every department of the firm, forming the company's Corporate Finance and Commodities departments. By 1976, the firm had become Drexel Burnham Lambert. Mr. Linton was eventually named to head the firm by founder I.W. Burnham II, and in the early 1980s under his leadership, Drexel grew to become the most profitable firm on Wall Street. When Mr. Linton retired, DBL had 10,000 employees in worldwide offices. During his time on Wall Street, Mr. Linton was Vice Chairman of the Board of Governors of the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD, 1980), a director of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE, 1983-1987), and served as Chairman of the Securities Industry Association (SIA, 1983). Mr. Linton served two terms as a member of the National Council of Consultants to the Small Business Administration, was an expert witness before the Congressional committees drawing up the SBIC legislation and testified twice before the Senate Banking Committee against the repeal of the Glass-Steagall Act. Linton was a founding member of the American Business Conference, Inc., a coalition of growth companies. Mr. Linton was also an active and longstanding supporter of the social sector, serving as a founding member of the Board of Directors of Lincoln Center Theater from 1984 to 2015 and then as the organization's first Director Emeritus; and as a Director of the Board of the School of American Research, Santa Fe, NM (now known as School for Advanced Research) in the 1990s. In 1987, Linton was appointed Chairman of the Advisory Board of the Sol C. Snider Entrepreneurial Research Center at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. After retiring from Drexel Burnham Lambert, Mr. Linton partnered with Cy Leslie, founder of Pickwick International to form Leslie Linton Entertainment, an investor in entertainment companies and properties, including Red Sky Entertainment, a creator, developer and marketer of family entertainment properties. Mr. Linton was an avid sportsman, enjoying tennis, golf, fishing and skiing, and took pride in winning a NASTAR ski race gold medal at the age of 72 in Taos, NM. Mr. Linton is survived by his wife of 63 years, the former Margot Tishman; a sister, Marion Benson, of Beverly Hills, CA; four children including Roberta L. Bennett, of Warren, VT; Thomas N. Linton of Santa Fe, NM; Jeffrey R. Linton (and his wife Judith), of Rye, NY; and Elizabeth M. Linton of Berkshire, England; and five grandchildren. Funeral Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., NYC, Monday, May 2nd at 11:30am. 1/3

LAUTERSTEIN--Henry Weil, 86, on April 27, 2016. A longtime resident of Stamford and graduate of Milton Academy, Harvard College and Columbia University Law School, Henry joined his father, Leon Lauterstein in the law firm, Lauterstein & Lauterstein, where his clients included Kobrand Wine & Spirits and The Metropolitan Opera. His valued advice resulted in him joining the Met as in-house counsel in 1981 until his retirement. A lover of nature, opera, baseball, an avid fisherman and frequent visitor to Maine, Henry readily shared his knowledge and passions. A beloved husband, father, grandfather and life partner, Henry was predeceased by his wife, Katherine Mebane and his son, David. He will be dearly missed by his daughters Dorothy Doppstadt and Margaret Mandell, his partner Fred Wyatt, his son-in-law, Jonathan Mandell and his grandchildren, Lucas, Emily, Daniel and Natalie. 1/3

LAWRENCE--James Vinton, of Norfolk, CT died April 9 of complications from acute leukemia which he fought hard to overcome. Vint is survived by a huge extended family, town committees he enlightened and enlivened, an impossibly large archive of his political drawings, paintings and works-in-progress, dozens of carefully labeled cans of bolts and nails, 16 raised beds, two grieving Labradors and friends who have sustained his wife and two daughters with glorious remembrances. GOLDSTEIN--Roslyn Louise. Roz died April 25, 2016 in San Francisco, CA, days after celebrating her 90th birthday. COFFIN--Edmund (Ned), of Strafford, VT, entrepreneur, political activist, beloved father of five and grandfather of thirteen, died peacefully on April 18. Born in New York City in 1921, Ned attended Yale, served in the Navy in WWII, and launched businesses in post-colonial Nigeria. He and his late wife of fifty-eight years, Violet Bodman Coffin, moved from New York to Strafford, where he founded a wind-energy company, and the couple became indefatigable organizers of Vermont Democratic Party politics. Ned is survived by his sister Margot Lindsay, sister-in-law Randy Wilson Coffin, widow of the late William Sloane Coffin Jr., children--Judy, Doug, Tad, Cris, and Andy--and their families, many nieces and nephews, and dear friend of many years, Lou Hance. A memorial service will be held May 15 at 1pm in Strafford, VT. 1/3

CALLO--Dominick F.,beloved husband, stepfather, and friend, passed away on April 28, 2016, at the age of 85, with his adoring wife, Mary Loving, by his side. A lifelong New Yorker, Mr. Callo was a veteran of the Korean War and retired lieutenant with the New York City Fire Department. He earned a law degree from Brooklyn Law School and maintained a successful private practice for more than five decades. He was admired for his humor, extraordinary rhetorical skill, and devotion and loyalty to friends and family. The son of the late Giocondo and Eleanora, Mr. Callo is survived by his wife and stepchildren Alex and Cameron, granddaughter Sydney, brother-in- law Jerome, sister-in-law Cathy, cousins Anny and Franco, and extended family here and in Italy. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue (81 St.) Tuesday 5-7:30pm. Services, Wednesday 10am at funeral home. "Salute." He did it his way. 1/3

GARR--Alice R. With deep sadness, we mourn the passing of Alice Ring Garr, 90, in Newtown, PA on March 17, 2016 after a battle with cancer. Alice was the devoted and proud mother of Emily, Jim, Patty and Tom, sons-in-law Milt and Paul and daughters-in-law Lisa and Darlene along with her nine grandchildren, Eric, Marc, Michael, Sam, Jocelyn, Allison, Bradley, Jeremy and Justin. She leaves behind her devoted sister Madeline Kent and her beloved companion Joel Flaks. Alice graduated as one of only two women Physics majors from Cornell University in 1947 and worked as a spectroscopist for several years at Bell Labs in New York. Twenty years later, Alice attended Hofstra University to obtain her Masters' degrees in Teaching and Administration. She was a math teacher at Shelter Rock Jr. High School for 30 years and chairman of its Math department. Alice was a nationally recognized author for the Merrill Math Textbook Series and tutored hundreds of students and young teachers throughout her career. After retirement, Alice continued to teach, working with non- violent prisoners to help them gain their GED. Alice was a life-long adventurer, traveling the globe learning about animal life and diverse cultures. She was a past President of the Pennswood Village Community Association and an active member of her community. She was a leader and friend to many, and a family matriarch who will be sorely missed. 1/3

LIGHT--Kate, 56, died April 13 in Manhattan of cancer. A longtime violinist with the New York City Opera and an acclaimed poet, Kate united these two passions in becoming an opera and musical theater lyricist and librettist. KOFFMAN--Milton, whom was born September 10, 1923, the son of the late Barney and Eva Koffman, died on April 25, 2016, in Palm Beach, Florida. He was raised in Binghamton, NY, before graduating from The Ohio State University in 1945. He served in the Army and was accepted into the Officer Candidate School but was discharged when the War ended. He was predeceased in 2001 by his wife Barbara DeYoung Smith whom he married in 1947. He is survived by his wife, Dr. Shirley Cohlan, whom he married in 2003, his children Jack and Janice, and two grandchildren. Milton worked with his brother Harry and nephews Bud and Richard Koffman in Public Loan Company and other related businesses based in Binghamton. He was also a devoted member and officer of Temple Israel. His many passions included music, tennis, movies and Ohio State football. Any contributions may be made to the Temple Israel Building Fund. Please visit ParsonsFuneral.com to offer your condolences. 1/3
SKOLNIK--Theodore M.,died on April 21, 2016. He lives on through all the good he did in this world. 1/3

KAHN--Dr. Roy Max, died on April 19, 2016, at the age of 89. A devoted father and husband, Roy was also gracious, witty, and exceptionally thoughtful. Born in 1926, he attended Little Red School House and the High School of Music and Art, and later became a clinical psychologist. MIRON--Marina I. (Ionescu). Age 69, passed away March 24, 2016, with family at her bedside. Born August 6, 1946, in Targoviste, Romania, high school Valedictorian, graduate of the Bucharest Polytechnic Institute, M.E., 1969, worked for many years as Quality Control Engineer designing thermic and nuclear powerplants. She arrived in Michigan in 1991 with her young daughter, to reunite with her political refugee husband and young adult son. She worked as translator for Refugee Services, and later as Project Engineer at General Motors with her husband in the same Engine Design Powertrain group in Flint, Warren, and Pontiac, MI, retiring in 2004. She organized benefit concerts raising thousands of dollars when she heard of deep, unmet needs within the Romanian community. For the building fund of the Dormition Monastery in Rives Junction, MI, Ms. Miron took Mother Benedicta's mission as her own: to build a Romanian Orthodox Monastery on American soil. Later, she heard of the need for waterproof covers to protect the new mattresses donated by a foreign charity to the Tuicani Children's Orphanage. With the funds raised, she herself found and bought the right size covers for all the new mattresses, and sent them to Romania. She was truly loved, and she showed all who knew her what it meant to love: unconditionally, with fervor and passion, with fierceness and loyalty. Predeceased by her parents Emil and Ileana Miron (Sendrea), she is survived by her husband of 47 years, Ernest C. Ionescu, her children Alex (Mihaela) Ionescu and Marina Ionescu (Matthew) Heos, her granddaughter Julia Cristiana Heos, her sister Roxana Miron, cousin Mike Miron, M.D., and nephews Dragos Rosca, Mihnea Miron, and George Miron. Online condolences may be left for Ms. Miron's family at: estesleadley.com/?p= 21001 1/3

LEVINE--Rosalie Bernstein On April 29, in Princeton, NJ, a week after her 88th birthday. Predeceased by her beloved brother Bill and sister Isabel Rader. Survived by Ted Levine, her loving and devoted husband of 62 years, her daughter Carol (Tim), her sons Alex (Joyce) and Jim (Lisa), seven adoring grandchildren, five great-grandchildren, and friends and relatives around the country. Rosalie was a whirlwind at work and at home. A graduate of Erasmus Hall High School and Brooklyn College, she took great pride in being Professor Harold Groves' first female Ph.D. student in the Economics Department at the University of Wisconsin. She went on to a long career at C.W. Post College, where she was respected as a superb teacher and, later, as an able and farsighted administrator. In retirement, she worked with countless boards, commissions, committees and volunteer organizations large and small, often mentoring younger colleagues. Her love of her large extended family showed in her five decades of hosting innumerable parties in Manhasset, Shelter Island, Manhattan and Princeton. It now takes a large team to pull off the Thanksgiving and Passover meals that she made all by herself. She traveled widely with curiosity and joy, and was a longtime supporter of the New York City Ballet. We will miss her terribly and remember her fondly. Services Monday, May 2 at 11am, at the Star of David Chapel, 40 Vandeventer Ave, Princeton, NJ. 1/3

CLARK--Lawrence David, Jr. passed away at his home in New York City on April 27, 2016 at the age of 72. He was born in East Rochester, NY to Lawrence David Clark, Sr. and Josephine Furman Clark. He graduated from Harvard College in 1965, magna cum laude and as a member of Phi Beta Kappa and the Harvard College Glee Club. He graduated from Harvard Law School in 1968 and moved to New York City to practice law. He was recognized as a leading attorney in the trust and estates field. He served as a fellow of the American College of Trust and Estate counsel and was named a Best Lawyer and a Super Lawyer. He is survived by his wife of 49 years Carolyn Cochran Clark and his sons Gregory David Clark of Chattanooga, TN and Timothy Rogers Clark of Austin, TX, a brother Mark F. Clark (and wife Susan) of Belmont, MA, a sister Mary Clark Hess of Acton, MA and a first cousin Stephanie Harris of Rochester, NY. David served on the board of the Professional Children's School. He belonged to the University Club in New York City and the Maidstone Club in East Hampton, NY. HAMMER--Roy A.,of Boston died on April 26, 2016, at age 81. A revered lawyer and trustee, Mr. Hammer is survived by his wife of 60 years, Sylvia, their daughters, Julie Hammer and Beth Isa Hammer, and their grandchildren, Matthew, Jennifer, Benjamin and Jack. Born in New York City, Mr. Hammer did his undergraduate work at Yale before earning a masters degree from Columbia and his law degree from Harvard Law School. He was also a veteran of the United States Army. Mr. Hammer was a retired senior partner at Hemenway & Barnes in Boston, where he spent his entire professional career, focusing first on business and corporate law, before concentrating on trust and estate matters and work as a professional trustee. He was deeply committed to the legal profession, to the pursuit of justice and to safeguarding the rights of the individual. His commitment to justice saw Mr. Hammer serve as President of the Massachusetts Bar Association, President of the Massachusetts Bar Foundation, President of the Civil Liberties Union of Massachusetts, a member of the American Bar Association's Board of Governors and a longtime member of the ABA House of Delegates. In 2011, the ABA honored him with the Robert F. Drinan Award for Distinguished Service for his leadership in protecting and advancing human rights, civil liberties and social justice. A student of the law, as well as a practitioner, Mr. Hammer was a member of the American Law Institute and a Fellow of the American College of Trust and Estate Counsel. After formally retiring from Hemenway & Barnes in 2006, he continued in an of counsel role at the firm and remained involved in many activities, including work with the ABA Center for Human Rights project on human trafficking, which maintains educational resources for use by lawyers and other advocates representing trafficking victims; works to develop uniform state anti-trafficking law; and seeks to enhance communication between the civil and criminal sides in trafficking cases. Roy Hammer was deeply engaged in the Boston community, both as a committed volunteer and philanthropist, serving as a member of the Board of Governors of the Handel & Haydn Society and as a Trustee of the Longy School of Music. He was also a retired member of the Board of Directors of Dow Jones & Company, and was engaged in the affairs of Dow Jones for many years. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in Roy's name to a charity of your choice. While funeral services will be private, a gathering in remembrance is scheduled for Friday, June 3 at 11am at the Colonnade Hotel, 120 Huntington Avenue, Boston, MA.Levine Chapels, Brookline, www.levinechapels.com 1/3

CUCCI--Cesare E.,M.D., died at his home on April 29, 2016. Born in Spoleto, Italy on December 22, 1925 to Anna Morelli and Ottorino Cucci, he graduated from the University of Perugia Faculty of Medicine and Surgery and did his medical training in London and New York. DuBOIS--Howard T.,90, of Westwood, MA and formerly of NYC died peacefully on Friday, April 22, 2016 surrounded by his family in Westwood, MA. He was the beloved husband of Peggy K. Howard was an executive at the former Trinity Plastics and Paper of New York for many years. He was an avid tennis player and enjoyed wintering in Longboat Key, FL. In his later years, Howard and Peggy moved to the Boston area to be closer to their daughter and grandchildren. In addition to his wife, he is survived by his children, Gail DuBois of Southborough, MA ; John DuBois of Miami, FL; a sister, Janine Blum of CA; his grandchildren, Lauren and Heather DuBois. HURLOCK--James Bickford, died peacefully with family by his side on April 27th. A beloved husband, father, grandfather, sportsman, and sailor, Mr. Hurlock led a distinguished forty-one-year career at the law firm of White & Case, where for twenty years he served as Managing Partner overseeing the firm's global expansion. He was a Director and Chairman of Orient Express Hotels, Deputy Chairman of Acergy, and Interim CEO of Stolt-Nielson Transportation Group. He was a founding board member of the International Development Law Organization and served as Chairman from 2001-2004. He was a Trustee of the Corporation of Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, New York Presbyterian Hospital, and the Parker School of Foreign and Comparative Law at Columbia University, where he served as Chairman. In 2010 the New York State Bar Association bestowed on him its Root/Stimson Award for exemplary commitment to community service. Mr. Hurlock was born August 7th, 1933 in Chicago, Illinois to James Bickford Hurlock and Elizabeth Charls Hurlock and grew up in Cleveland, Ohio. He attended the Hawken School and graduated from Western Reserve Academy before attending Princeton University from which he graduated in 1955. At Princeton he received the Pyne Prize and was awarded a Rhodes Scholarship to Oxford University where he attended Magdalen College. He graduated from Harvard Law School in 1959 and joined White & Case the same year. He is survived by his wife of fifty-five years, Margaret Lyn (Holding) Hurlock, and three sons and their wives, James Bickford III and Kathryn Buck Hurlock, Burton Charls and Olivia Bruce Hurlock, and Matthew Hunter and Severa Imperiali Hurlock, and eight grandchildren. Mr. Hurlock spent a dozen years of his career living and raising his young family abroad, in Paris, Brussels and London and was a long time summer resident of Siasconset, MA, which he visited for the first time in 1942. He loved fishing and hunting and sailing with his family, and completed a transatlantic race and seven Bermuda races, the first in 1962. He was a scholar, a gentleman, an inspiring leader, and a loyal friend who will be greatly missed. A memorial service celebrating the life of James B. Hurlock will be held at Christ Church, 254 East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich on Thursday, May 12th at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, 86 Water Street, Woods Hole, MA 02543 or the New York Presbyterian Fund, Inc., Office of Development, 654 West 170th Street, New York, NY 10022. 1/3

HURLOCK--James Bickford. NewYork-Presbyterian mourns the death of our esteemed Life Trustee James Bickford Hurlock, Esq. Elected a Trustee of The Presbyterian Hospital in the City of New York in 1986, Mr. Hurlock served Presbyterian Hospital and later NewYork- Presbyterian Hospital for thirty years. Mr. Hurlock was an active Trustee who chaired or served on numerous Hospital and Medical Center committees. A brilliant lawyer with the highest standards of excellence, Mr. Hurlock contributed his legal expertise and business acumen for the benefit of the Hospital. NewYork-Presbyterian is very fortunate that during his busy and accomplished life, Mr. Hurlock was a devoted and wise steward of our institution. We will miss him. We extend our deepest sympathies to Mr. Hurlock's wife, Lyn, his sons James, Burton and Matthew, and the entire Hurlock family. Frank A. Bennack, Jr., Chairman, Board of Trustees Steven J. Corwin, M.D., President and CEO NewYork-Presbyterian 1/3

STANIFORD--Rockwell Simpson. Age 96, died peacefully at his home in Vero Beach, FL, April 22, 2016. Survived by his wife of almost 70 years, Frances Ingersoll Staniford (Cricket), daughters, Carolyn Staniford Sollis, Martha Staniford Myers and Virginia Staniford Reid, grandsons, Edwin Bryant Sollis II, Jonathan Gardner Sollis, Alexander Rockwell Reid and numerous nieces and nephews. Born in Brooklyn, NY, Rocky was a WWII veteran serving in the Pacific arena in the US Coast Guard as Capt. of the LST 168. He spent many years in Westhampton Beach, NY and his working life in Rochester, NY where he was an active volunteer and Capt. of the Brighton Fire Dept. He retired to Fenwick, CT and Vero Beach. DONN-- Anthony, M.D. Died April 22nd in East Burke, VT. He was 90. A Veteran of World War II, Dr. Donn went on to study at Yale and Columbia, where he later served as the Harkness Professor of Ophthalmology, Department Chairman and Director of the Edward S. Harkness Eye Institute. In 1955, he travelled to England for postgraduate work in corneal physiology at the Institute of Ophthalmology, London, as assistant to the Queen's Ophthalmologist, Sir Stewart Duke-Elder. Specializing in diseases of the cornea, Dr. Donn pioneered the development of now routine techniques, including intraocular lens implantation following cataract surgery and specular microscopy to monitor the endothelial cells lining the back of the cornea with David Maurice, Ph.D. He earned international recognition for Columbia's corneal research program, leading to major funding from the National Institutes for Health in 1964 for a Corneal Center. After his retirement, the Anthony Donn Professorship in Ophthalmic Science was endowed in his honor to recognize his half century of contributions to Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons. He is survived by his wife Linda, children Michael and his wife Gulbahar, son Alex and his wife Anat and daughter Cassin and her husband Geoffrey and grandchildren Aliya, Ashraf, Phoebe, Amos and Barnaby. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests that memorial contributions be made to the Northeast Vermont Regional Hospital. 1/3

CZAJKA--James Vincent, 65. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of the gifted architect who for more than two decades designed and oversaw construction of many beautifully renovated spaces in the Academy's home on Audubon Terrace, including the Childe Hassam Gallery, the Members' Portrait Gallery, and the delightful Glass Link that provides access to a recently acquired adjoining building where he designed new exhibition galleries and the meticulously recreated Charles Ives Studio. Our thoughts go out to his family in Buffalo, NY. For information on a memorial in late May, contact: academy@artsandletters.org 1/3

LEEDS--Dalia. Darling Dalia, You were the most beautiful woman who ever crossed the threshold of my vision. Not only were you gorgeous, you were incredibly intelligent, sensitive, kind and caring. You represented everything that any man would ever desire in a wife and partner. I thank you for having chosen to marry me and for giving me the confidence and strength to pursue our dreams together. Dalia, you were a magnificent mother, and you so nurtured our wonderful children Cary, Ashley and Tracy, providing an enduring example of the true meaning of family. GOLDSMITH--Dolores. May 2, 2009. I Am Not There. Do not stand at my grave and weep, I am not there I do not sleep, I am a thousand winds that blow, I am the diamond glints on snow, I am the sunlight on ripened grain, I am the gentle autumn's rain. When you awaken in the morning's hush, I am the swift uplifting rush of quiet birds in circled flight, I am the soft stars that shine at night, Do not stand at my grave and cry, I am not there, I did not die. 1/3

LEEDS--Dalia Benary, of New York, passed away at NYU Langone Medical Center surrounded by her loving family on Wednesday, April 27, 2016 at the age of 85. She is survived by her beloved husband of 60 years, Laurence C. Leeds, Jr. (Larry) and her devoted daughters, Ashley Leeds (Christopher Harland) and Tracy Leeds (Evan Marwell). She was predeceased by her son Laurence C. Leeds, III (Cary) and her brother Oded Benary. Also surviving are her six adoring grandchildren: Samuel, Michael, and Benjamin Harland and Nicholas, Olivia, and James Marwell. Dalia, the daughter of Zvi and Belina Benary, was born in Tel Aviv. She attended school in Switzerland and English Girls College (El Nasr Girls' College) in Alexandria, during an era when young Jewish students from what was going to be the state of Israel crossed the border to attend school in Egypt. After visiting the United States several times, she moved to New York City where she met and married Larry on October 16, 1955. Dalia was a fine painter and sculptor and, during her early days in The United States, worked at the Art Students League and attended the Traphagen School of Design. Dalia became a legendary figure of the New York social scene. Her extraordinary beauty and grace, along with her wonderfully warm and sensitive personality, charmed almost everyone she met. She was kind and compassionate and, as a result of these attributes, she had an unending number of admirers and friends. After the tragic loss of her son Cary, she worked tirelessly and successfully to help build the Cary Leeds Center for Tennis & Learning, dedicated to improving the lives of thousands of young girls and boys in the Bronx. Dalia also served on the boards of The Council for a Beautiful Israel, the Israel Anti Drug Abuse Foundation, and The American Friends of the Israeli Philharmonic Orchestra. Dalia never forgot her roots and loved her native Israel. She would travel there at least twice a year until her recent illness. It is the end of an amazing life. A private family service will be held graveside. The family will be sitting Shiva Sunday, May 1st, Monday, May 2nd, and Tuesday, May 3rd from 5:00pm - 8:00pm at their residence in New York City. A memorial service in celebration of Dalia's life, will be held at a future date. In lieu of flowers, donations in Dalia's name may be directed to the Cary Leeds Center for Tennis & Learning and sent to The New York Junior Tennis League, 58-12 Queens Blvd, Woodside, NY 11377. For further information, please call 212-922-5530 or 917-536-5792. 1/3

FLASTER--Norma Summers, on April 27, 2016 at 88 years of age, after a long struggle with Parkinson's Disease. Beloved wife of Alvin, loving mother of Lynn Flaster Paul (John) and Richard. Adored grandmother of Scott Alvord (Sandra) and Julie Alvord. Great-grandmother of Eleanor and Thomas. Daughter of the late George and Sadie Summers. Sister of the late Allan Summers. She was charming, intelligent, beautiful, and had a great sense of style. We will miss and love her forever. Services 10:30am, Sunday, May 1, 2016 at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY, (516) 487-9600. 1/3

WARBURTON--Dorothy. Columbia University Medical Center and NewYork-Presbyterian celebrate the life and mourn the passing of Dorothy Warburton, Ph.D., professor emeritus of Clinical Genetics and Development, a pioneer in her field, and a member of our faculty since 1964. She joined Columbia as a research assistant in the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, and from 1969 until 2005 served as Director of our Genetic Diagnostic Laboratory. Her contributions to the field of human genetics - particularly to fetal chromosomal abnormalities - are unrivaled. Dr. Warburton was the recipient of one of the highest honors in the cytogenetics field, the 2014 Distinguished Cytogeneticist Award, and the 2006 William Allan Award, given by the American Society of Human Genetics, to recognize substantial scientific contributions to human genetics carried out over a sustained period of time. She was a beloved colleague, generous mentor, and trusted friend, and she will be greatly missed. We offer our condolences to her family and her colleagues. Lee Goldman, M.D., Executive Vice President and Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences & Medicine, Chief Executive, Columbia University Medical Center; Steven J. Corwin, M.D., President and CEO, NewYork-Presbyterian 1/3
COHEN--Ralph. 1935-2016. My oldest friend and an all around good guy. Condolences to Nancy, Leslie and Jeff. Jerry Ballan 1/3

STOCKMAN--Henry Charles, Jr. Died peacefully April 21st at "Meadow Ridge" in Redding, CT. He was 97 years old. He was predeceased by his loving wife of 70 years, Jeanne, in July, 2015. The couple lived in Locust Valley and Glen Cove, NY. Henry was born in Englewood, NJ and graduated from the Wharton School in 1939. In WWII, he served in the United States Air Force, where he was a specialist in Japanese and Soviet aircraft. He attained the rank of Lt. Col. and was awarded The Army Commendation Ribbon. He co-authored two books, "Soviet Aircraft" and "Tanks and Armored Vehicles." He was a principal in an employee-benefit consulting firm, Crandon & Stockman, until his retirement in 1987. He served on the board of the Glen Cove Hospital and the Matinecock Zoning Board. Henry and Jeanne raised six children, Helen Stovell, Mina Pell, Jeanne Wullschleger, Henry Stockman III, Robert Stockman and Mimi Wainwright. Their children, 14 grandchildren and 11 great-grandchildren survive them. Henry was a member of the St. Nicholas Society and Piping Rock Club. A private burial is planned on May 12th. In lieu of flowers, the family asks you take a moment to enjoy the melodies of songbirds, one of nature's wonders Henry loved. 1/3

LINTON--Robert. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center Theater are deeply saddened by the death of our Honorary Trustee, Robert Linton. Bob was a devoted LCT Board Member for more than 30 years. He was a lively presence at meetings, often expressing original points of view and sharing theatrical anecdotes. He loved the work on our stages and was an enthusiastic supporter of our magazine and education program. We send condolences to his wife, Margot, and his children and grandchildren. J. Tomilson Hill, Chairman Eric M. Mindich, President Andre Bishop, Producing Artistic Director 1/3

Honored with Lifetime Achievement Award by New York City Trial Lawyers Association. Professional distinctions include Martindale- Hubbell, Best Lawyers in America, New York Super Lawyers. LAFER--Norma, 80, formerly of Parsippany, NJ, passed away peacefully on February 12, 2016 in Boca Raton, Florida. Norma, daughter of Jack and Clara Rosen, was born in NYC on September 22, 1935. She was raised in the Bronx, and moved to Long Island before marrying David Lafer, and moving to New Jersey. She attended Hunter College in NYC, and ultimately graduated Cum Laude from William Paterson College in New Jersey. Norma was the business partner in Linders French Cleaners, in Bernardsville, New Jersey along with her husband David. They retired to the Polo Club in Boca Raton, Florida in 1998. Norma is survived by her husband of 60 years, David; daughter Jamie of Santa Monica, CA, son Jason and wife Stacey of Basking Ridge, NJ and their children, Georgie and Ava; sister Mona Abrams of Boynton Beach, Florida and nieces Nicole, Lauren, Sherri and Joan. 1/3

FOLEY--Joan (Coleman). 87, passed away on March 30th in Florida after a brief illness. Mrs. Foley was born in Rockville, CT on February 10, 1929, a daughter to the late Francis and Kathryn Coleman. She was predeceased by her husband of 63 years, Joseph Foley and her sister Judith Bailey. Mrs. Foley graduated Clinton High School in 1946 and Barry College in 1950. Mrs. Foley is survived by her brother Francis Coleman and wife Susan of Clinton, MA, brother-in-law Charles Foley and wife Marie of Florida; several nieces, nephews, and many dear friends who will forever miss her kindness, humor and generous spirit. Mrs. Foley and her husband Joe owned and operated The Foley Literary Agency in New York City for over 50 years. The two enjoyed life in New York City and especially cherished time with friends and family. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated in St. Patrick's Lady Cathedral, Saturday, May 14, 2016 at 10am. A reception will follow at Langan's Restaurant, 150 West 47th St., New York, NY 10036. 1/3

FALKSON--Dr Eric J.,84, passed away on Monday, April 25th, at his home. A Memorial Service will be held at 1pm on Sunday, May 1st, at the Brotherhood Synagogue on Gramercy Park South. DIAMOND--Paul M. It is with great sadness we announce the passing of Paul M. Diamond on Wednesday, April 27, 2016, after a brave struggle with pancreatic cancer. Paul was loved by many and will be missed deeply by all who came in contact with his charm, humor, and generosity. Our lives will never be the same without him. He is survived by three sons, Craig, Eric, and Michael Diamond; a brother, Jay Diamond; a sister-in-law, Inez Diamond; a daughter-in-law, Vivien Diamond; a granddaughter, Samantha Diamond; two cousins, Lenny Pudt and Helene Pudt; and seven nieces and nephews. Services were held Sunday, May 1st at Gutterman's chapel, Woodbury, NY. Memorial contributions may be made to the Lustgarten Foundation for Pancreatic Cancer Research. 1/3

CALLO--Dominick F.,beloved husband, stepfather, and friend, passed away on April 28, 2016, at the age of 85, with his adoring wife, Mary Loving, by his side. A lifelong New Yorker, Mr. Callo was a veteran of the Korean War and retired lieutenant with the New York City Fire Department. He earned a law degree from Brooklyn Law School and maintained a successful private practice for more than five decades. He was admired for his humor, extraordinary rhetorical skill, and devotion and loyalty to friends and family. The son of the late Giocondo and Eleanora, Mr. Callo is survived by his wife and stepchildren Alex and Cameron, granddaughter Sydney, brother-in- law Jerome, sister-in-law Cathy, cousins Anny and Franco, and extended family here and in Italy. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue (81 St.) Tuesday 5-7:30pm. Services, Wednesday 10am at funeral home. "Salute." He did it his way. 1/3

BLANK--Robert Saler, died peacefully with family by his side on April 30th. A beloved husband, father, grandfather and friend, Bob had a distinguished 45 year career as a senior partner at Whitcom Partners, a company that owned and operated newspapers, magazines, TV and radio stations and cable systems. He had a special love for their newspaper holding Chesapeake Publishing. He graduated from Cornell University in 1962 and obtained his J.D. from the University of Pennsylvania. From 1965-1968 he was an Assistant U.S. Attorney in Philadelphia and Washington, DC. He spent the next three years in the Mergers and Acquisitions Department of Goldman Sachs before joining Whitcom as a partner. He was a director of Toll Brothers, Inc. and a former director of a number of publicly held corporations as well as the privately held International Herald Tribune (now the International New York Times). He was an Emeritus Trustee of the University of Pennsylvania, the Wharton School Board of Overseers, Penn Law Board of Overseers and a Trustee of Penn Medicine. He was the recipient of Penn Law's Distinguished Graduate and Alumni Achievement Award. Bob was born November 28, 1940 in Philadelphia to Ruth Saler Blank and Samuel Allen Blank. He is survived by his wife of 42 years, Nancy, his children Wendy, Samuel and Matt, son-in-law Lee, daughters-in-law Lindsay and Taryn and seven treasured grandchildren Grace, Charles, Cecily, Katherine, Eli, Lila and Noah. Bob was a man of warmth, dignity, humility and courage who will be greatly missed by all who knew him. The funeral will be held Wednesday, May 4th at 1pm at Temple Emanu-El in New York City. Contributions can be made in his memory to Memorial Sloan Kettering or New York Hospital. 1/3

CLARK--Lawrence David, Jr. passed away at his home in New York City on April 27, 2016 at the age of 72. He was born in East Rochester, NY to Lawrence David Clark, Sr. and Josephine Furman Clark. He graduated from Harvard College in 1965, magna cum laude and as a member of Phi Beta Kappa and the Harvard College Glee Club. He graduated from Harvard Law School in 1968 and moved to New York City to practice law. He was recognized as a leading attorney in the trust and estates field. He served as a fellow of the American College of Trust and Estate counsel and was named a Best Lawyer and a Super Lawyer. He is survived by his wife of 49 years Carolyn Cochran Clark and his sons Gregory David Clark of Chattanooga, TN and Timothy Rogers Clark of Austin, TX, a brother Mark F. Clark (and wife Susan) of Belmont, MA, a sister Mary Clark Hess of Acton, MA and a first cousin Stephanie Harris of Rochester, NY. David served on the board of the Professional Children's School. He belonged to the University Club in New York City and the Maidstone Club in East Hampton, NY. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, May 3, 11am at All Souls Unitarian Church, 1157 Lexington Ave. (at 80th Street), New York City. Burial will follow in the Cedar Lawn Cemetery in East Hampton, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions to the Professional Children's School, 132 W. 60th St, NY, NY 10023 Attn: Mr. Chris Haley. 1/3

LEVINE--Rosalie Bernstein On April 29, in Princeton, NJ, a week after her 88th birthday. Predeceased by her beloved brother Bill and sister Isabel Rader. Survived by Ted Levine, her loving and devoted husband of 62 years, her daughter Carol (Tim), her sons Alex (Joyce) and Jim (Lisa), seven adoring grandchildren, five great-grandchildren, and friends and relatives around the country. Rosalie was a whirlwind at work and at home. A graduate of Erasmus Hall High School and Brooklyn College, she took great pride in being Professor Harold Groves' first female Ph.D. student in the Economics Department at the University of Wisconsin. She went on to a long career at C.W. Post College, where she was respected as a superb teacher and, later, as an able and farsighted administrator. In retirement, she worked with countless boards, commissions, committees and volunteer organizations large and small, often mentoring younger colleagues. Her love of her large extended family showed in her five decades of hosting innumerable parties in Manhasset, Shelter Island, Manhattan and Princeton. It now takes a large team to pull off the Thanksgiving and Passover meals that she made all by herself. She traveled widely with curiosity and joy, and was a longtime supporter of the New York City Ballet. We will miss her terribly and remember her fondly. Services Monday, May 2 at 11am, at the Star of David Chapel, 40 Vandeventer Ave, Princeton, NJ. 1/3

STOCKMAN--Henry Charles, Jr. Died peacefully April 21st at "Meadow Ridge" in Redding, CT. He was 97 years old. He was predeceased by his loving wife of 70 years, Jeanne, in July, 2015. The couple lived in Locust Valley and Glen Cove, NY. Henry was born in Englewood, NJ and graduated from the Wharton School in 1939. In WWII, he served in the United States Air Force, where he was a specialist in Japanese and Soviet aircraft. He attained the rank of Lt. Col. and was awarded The Army Commendation Ribbon. He co-authored two books, "Soviet Aircraft" and "Tanks and Armored Vehicles." He was a principal in an employee-benefit consulting firm, Crandon & Stockman, until his retirement in 1987. He served on the board of the Glen Cove Hospital and the Matinecock Zoning Board. Henry and Jeanne raised six children, Helen Stovell, Mina Pell, Jeanne Wullschleger, Henry Stockman III, Robert Stockman and Mimi Wainwright. Their children, 14 grandchildren and 11 great-grandchildren survive them. Henry was a member of the St. Nicholas Society and Piping Rock Club. A private burial is planned on May 12th. In lieu of flowers, the family asks you take a moment to enjoy the melodies of songbirds, one of nature's wonders Henry loved. 1/3

KRAKAUER--Ronald, Esq.,born August 10, 1945 and formerly of North Caldwell, NJ, died on Saturday, April 30, 2016 at his home in Palm Desert, CA after a short illness. He was surrounded by his loving and caring family at the time of his death. Ronald served over two years in the US Navy, but law was his passion and calling. After attending Brooklyn Law School, Ronald was admitted into the law profession and served in New York and California for over 45 years. Some professional accomplishments include being featured in New York Magazine as a prominent attorney in New York City. He also was twice honored in the front of the New York Law Journal. Ronald is predeceased by his son, Jordan Krakauer and survived by his family Fran Boller, Rudy Gintel and Ernest Gintel. In lieu of flowers, please honor both Ron and his son Jordan's memory by donating to the Jordan Krakauer Memorial Scholarship Fund at www.jordanmemorial scholarship.com 1/3

LARMETT--Linda, nee Magnani, July 12, 1946 - April 25, 2016. Survived by her husband of 23 years, James C. Larmett, her sister-in-law Nora Doyle Magnani and nephews Brian and Marc Magnani. Services were private. 1/3

LINTON--Robert E. Robert E. Linton, former CEO and Chairman of Drexel Burnham Lambert, Inc., died April 26, 2016 at the age of 90. During the early 1980s, Mr. Linton served as the head of the storied investment banking and securities firm that pioneered the use of high yield (or "junk") bonds. Robert Linton was born in New York City on May 19, 1925 to Helen and Adolph Lichtenstein, a specialist on the New York Stock Exchange. During his senior year at Phillips Exeter Academy, Linton enlisted in the Army, eventually serving in WWII as a navigator and bombardier and achieving the rank of 2nd lieutenant in the Army Air Force. In 1946, Mr. Linton joined Burnham & Co., a small investment bank as the eighth employee, starting as a runner delivering stock certificates around Wall Street. Hard-working and ambitious, Bob attended night school to earn his stock broker's license and later, his commodities broker's license. Linton worked in virtually every department of the firm, forming the company's Corporate Finance and Commodities departments. By 1976, the firm had become Drexel Burnham Lambert. Mr. Linton was eventually named to head the firm by founder I.W. Burnham II, and in the early 1980s under his leadership, Drexel grew to become the most profitable firm on Wall Street. When Mr. Linton retired, DBL had 10,000 employees in worldwide offices. During his time on Wall Street, Mr. Linton was Vice Chairman of the Board of Governors of the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD, 1980), a director of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE, 1983-1987), and served as Chairman of the Securities Industry Association (SIA, 1983). Mr. Linton served two terms as a member of the National Council of Consultants to the Small Business Administration, was an expert witness before the Congressional committees drawing up the SBIC legislation and testified twice before the Senate Banking Committee against the repeal of the Glass-Steagall Act. Linton was a founding member of the American Business Conference, Inc., a coalition of growth companies. Mr. Linton was also an active and longstanding supporter of the social sector, serving as a founding member of the Board of Directors of Lincoln Center Theater from 1984 to 2015 and then as the organization's first Director Emeritus; and as a Director of the Board of the School of American Research, Santa Fe, NM (now known as School for Advanced Research) in the 1990s. In 1987, Linton was appointed Chairman of the Advisory Board of the Sol C. Snider Entrepreneurial Research Center at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. After retiring from Drexel Burnham Lambert, Mr. Linton partnered with Cy Leslie, founder of Pickwick International to form Leslie Linton Entertainment, an investor in entertainment companies and properties, including Red Sky Entertainment, a creator, developer and marketer of family entertainment properties. Mr. Linton was an avid sportsman, enjoying tennis, golf, fishing and skiing, and took pride in winning a NASTAR ski race gold medal at the age of 72 in Taos, NM. Mr. Linton is survived by his wife of 63 years, the former Margot Tishman; a sister, Marion Benson, of Beverly Hills, CA; four children including Roberta L. Bennett, of Warren, VT; Thomas N. Linton of Santa Fe, NM; Jeffrey R. Linton (and his wife Judith), of Rye, NY; and Elizabeth M. Linton of Berkshire, England; and five grandchildren. Funeral Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., NYC, Monday, May 2nd at 11:30am. 1/3

He had a long and distinguished career in advertising where he most recently served as a Director of Media Strategy, Marketing and Communication for Northwestern University in Qatar, Doha. PAPPAS--Dean Clement. 76, philanthropist and former CEO and chairman of Clement Pappas and Company, Inc., a South Jersey food processing company, on April 30, 2016 in Philadelphia. Born in Atlantic City, New Jersey, Mr. Pappas graduated from Dickinson College in 1962 and immediately took over as president of Clement Pappas & Company, Inc., a small vegetable canner started by his father. Over the next 50 years, Mr. Pappas, in partnership with his late brother Peter, transformed the Company to one of the leaders in the industry with five manufacturing plants and 600 employees. In 2011, the Company was sold to Lassonde Industries. In recognition of his achievements, Mr. Pappas received the Lifetime Achievement Award from Grocery Manufacturers Association, the highest honor of the primary trade group for the food industry. Later in his career and after his retirement, Mr. Pappas and his wife, Zoe, became more active in philanthropy, establishing the Visiting Scholars Program at Stockton University and making countless other charitable gifts. Mr. Pappas had served as the Chairman of Stockton University, a Trustee of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, a Trustee of Blair Academy and on the Board of the Philadelphia Film Society. Mr. Pappas is survived by his loving wife of 46 years, Zoe Sarbanes Pappas, his two children, Dimitri (Stephanie Marudas) and Aleni (Anthony Kyriakakis), and four grandchildren. Dean is also survived by his sister Marina Zazanis as well as six nephews and three nieces. For online condolences, please visit: chandlerfuneralhome.com 302-478-7100. 1/3

SHEA--Francis P. Beloved husband of Lois. Longtime NY Times Stereotyper. Incredible father of Lois, Maureen, Mike, Tim, Brian and Willie. Rest in peace, Dad. 1/3

KLEINBERG--Norman Charles, beloved husband of Marcia; devoted father of Lauren and Joanna and father-in-law to their husbands Darren and Daniel; loving grandfather of Margot, Charlotte and Jake; and valued colleague of the partners of Hughes Hubbard & Reed, passed peacefully in his sleep on May 2, 2016. Norman graduated from Tufts University in 1968 and from Columbia Law School in 1972. Following his graduation, Norman clerked for the Honorable Charles M. Metzner, United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, until 1974. He then joined the law firm of Hughes Hubbard & Reed in Manhattan, where he worked until 2012 when his failing health prevented him from continuing. Norman was always in motion. He was an ardent traveler and reveled in planning adventurous journeys with his family. Norman was also an accomplished trial lawyer with many notable trials that led to his selection as a fellow of the American College of Trial Lawyers. He was passionate about his work, devoted to his clients who chose him as their advocate, and loyal to his colleagues, training and inspiring a generation of attorneys at Hughes Hubbard & Reed where he chaired the litigation department. He loved to win, and nearly always did, while always adhering to the highest standards of the profession. Adversaries whom he had bested and judges who had presided over his cases remembered him with fondness and admiration years after their cases with Norman were over. His determination on behalf of his clients inspired those who worked for him to find reserves of stamina, persistence and creativity that they never knew they had. Norman had those qualities in abundance, and a magnificent ability to translate the hard work of the team into a devastating cross- examination or a winning argument to the court or jury. As devoted as he was to his profession, Norman was even more committed to his family, originally the three women in his life, then expanding to include his sons-in-law and grandchildren. Those who worked with Norman remember that even at the end of a long day preparing for trial, he never failed to call home to help with homework assignments or review college applications. And, just a few years ago, following another courtroom win, an Illinois jury was passing around pictures of his first grandchild. His vibrancy and courage live on in our hearts. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell - The Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Avenue on Wednesday, May 4, at 1:30pm. 1/3

BLANK--Robert S. The Trustees, faculty, and staff of the University of Pennsylvania are deeply saddened by the death of our great friend and Emeritus Trustee Robert S. Blank. An alumnus of Penn Law, Bob was devoted to the University, serving for many years as an Overseer for both the Law School and the Wharton School, as well as on the Penn Medicine Board. Bob was the son of Penn graduates and was proud to continue his family legacy at Penn through his three children, all alumni. He devoted his time and expertise over many years to ensuring the University would hold inspiring promise for future generations of scholars. Together with his wife, Nancy, he endowed professorships, provided student financial aid, and generously supported the Law School and Wharton, among other areas of the University. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Nancy, their children, grandchildren, and extended family and friends. Bob's warmth and devotion will be deeply missed by the entire University community. David L. Cohen, Chairman Andrea Mitchell, Vice Chair Amy Gutmann, President Geoffrey Garrett, Dean, Wharton School J. Larry Jameson, Dean, Perelman School of Medicine Theodore Ruger, Dean, Penn Law 1/3

BERRIGAN--Daniel. The law firm of Kellner Herlihy Getty & Friedman mourns the passing of Daniel Berrigan, S.J. We were proud to represent him and his fellow members of the West Side Jesuit Community for many years. "Start with the impossible. Proceed calmly towards the improbable." 1/3

GIUFFRA--Robert J.,Sr. Of Bronxville, New York and Otis, Massachusetts. Beloved husband, father and grandfather, Bob died on April 30, 2016 surrounded by his family and in the loving arms of his wife of 57 years, Dr. Mary J. Giuffra. Born in Brooklyn, New York on August 28, 1930, Bob was the son of Severino and Teresita Giuffra, immigrants from northern Italy. He was a graduate of St. Augustine's High School, St. John's University School of Law (LL.B.), and Brooklyn Law School (LL.M.). He served overseas in the United States Army during the Korean War. After the war, Bob joined what is now known as Dougherty, Ryan, Giuffra, Zambito & Hession. For many years, he was the Firm's senior partner. A leading member of the admiralty, insurance and products liability bars, he had an extensive trial and appellate practice in federal and state courts. He practiced law into his eighth decade. He mentored many young lawyers, including three of his children. He served as a member of the Departmental Disciplinary Committee and Committee on Character and Fitness of the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court, First Judicial Department. He also was a member of the Board of Trustees of The Berkeley Institute. Bob was most devoted to and proud of his family. He is survived by his beloved wife Mary, a psychotherapist, member of faculty of the New York University School of Nursing, and founder of the Nursing Program at the College of Mount St. Vincent; four children, Robert Jr. of New York City, Mary Elizabeth of Paris, Lisa of Bronxville, and Thomas of Scarsdale; eight grandchildren, Gabriela, Alessandra, Olivier, Elizabeth, Claire, Caroline, Robert III, and Thomas Jr.; and his sister, Alice Brusati. The Funeral Mass will be held on Wednesday, May 4th, at 10:45am, at The Church of Saint Joseph in Bronxville, New York. The family is receiving friends on Tuesday, May 3rd from 2pm to 4pm and 7pm to 9pm, at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, 20 Cedar Street, in Bronxville. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to The Robert J. Giuffra 53L Scholarship at St. John's University School of Law. 1/3

BUTLER--Jane Hays. Lifelong Greenwich Village resident, died April 27, 2016, age 91. Mrs. Butler graduated City and Country School and attended Syracuse University and Vesper George School of Art. She served as Chair of the International Choral Festival for Lincoln Center, Vice Chairman of Friends of Channel 13 (WNET), and consultant/guide at the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Mrs. Butler was the daughter of Aline Davis Hays, artist and textile designer, and Arthur Garfield Hays, co-founder of the ACLU and general counsel starting in 1920. She was wife of William J. Butler, who argued the "school prayer case" before the US Supreme Court. Mrs. Butler is survived by her husband, her son Arthur (Dr. Judith Childs) and daughter Patricia Whitehill (John), and grandchildren Caitlin and Sean Butler (Emily De La Cerda) and Cassandra Breneman (Zachary), and several nieces and nephews. 1/3
