SKODNEK--Jack. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of Jack Skodnek of Palm Beach, FL. He was a longtime leader of the ATS Palm Beach Chapter, and a Life Trustee of the ATS National Board of Regents. A Technion Guardian who had reached the highest level of support, Mr. Skodnek was awarded an honorary fellowship from the Technion in 2006. He and his beloved late wife Jean established the Jack and Jean Skodnek Immunobiology of Aging Research Laboratory, and the Jack and Jean Skodnek Student Eastern Village Dormitory, and generously supported numerous other Technion projects. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Mr. Skodnek's sons, Drs. Richard and Kenneth Skodnek, his sister Estelle Dermer, and the entire Skodnek family. BLANK--Robert Saler, died peacefully with family by his side on April 30th. A beloved husband, father, grandfather and friend, Bob had a distinguished 45 year career as a senior partner at Whitcom Partners, a company that owned and operated newspapers, magazines, TV and radio stations and cable systems. He had a special love for their newspaper holding Chesapeake Publishing. He graduated from Cornell University in 1962 and obtained his J.D. from the University of Pennsylvania. From 1965-1968 he was an Assistant U.S. Attorney in Philadelphia and Washington, DC. He spent the next three years in the Mergers and Acquisitions Department of Goldman Sachs before joining Whitcom as a partner. He was a director of Toll Brothers, Inc. and a former director of a number of publicly held corporations as well as the privately held International Herald Tribune (now the International New York Times). He was an Emeritus Trustee of the University of Pennsylvania, the Wharton School Board of Overseers, Penn Law Board of Overseers and a Trustee of Penn Medicine. He was the recipient of Penn Law's Distinguished Graduate and Alumni Achievement Award. Bob was born November 28, 1940 in Philadelphia to Ruth Saler Blank and Samuel Allen Blank. He is survived by his wife of 42 years, Nancy, his children Wendy, Samuel and Matt, son-in-law Lee, daughters-in-law Lindsay and Taryn and seven treasured grandchildren Grace, Charles, Cecily, Katherine, Eli, Lila and Noah. Bob was a man of warmth, dignity, humility and courage who will be greatly missed by all who knew him. The funeral will be held Wednesday, May 4th at 1pm at Temple Emanu-El in New York City. Contributions can be made in his memory to Memorial Sloan Kettering or New York Hospital. 1/3

CZAJKA--James Vincent, 65. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of the gifted architect who for more than two decades designed and oversaw construction of many beautifully renovated spaces in the Academy's home on Audubon Terrace, including the Childe Hassam Gallery, the Members' Portrait Gallery, and the delightful Glass Link that provides access to a recently acquired adjoining building where he designed new exhibition galleries and the meticulously recreated Charles Ives Studio. Our thoughts go out to his family in Buffalo, NY. For information on a memorial in late May, contact: academy@artsandletters.org 1/3

BLANK--Robert S. We send our love as well as our deepest condolences to Nancy and the entire Blank Family. Bob was a very special friend and his passing is a great loss to all who knew him. We will miss him enormously. Ann and Charley 1/3

LINTON--Robert. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Robert Linton, who leaves behind a loving family who will carry on a tradition of exceptional Jewish philanthropy. We extend our condolences to Robert's beloved wife, Margot Tishman; his sister, Marion Benson; his children, Roberta Bennett, Thomas, Jeffrey, and Elizabeth; his grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3

ROKITO--Michael Barry, O.D. On May 1, 2016 at the age of 80, of Roslyn, NY. Beloved husband of Evelyn. Loving father of Andrew (Susan), Steven (Jodi) and Alyssa (Robert) Unikel. Adored grandfather of Shelby, Ariel, Lindsay, Jackson, Ryan, Josh and Matthew. Cherished brother of Andrea (Harvey) Kaplan. Dear brother-in-law of Gilda and the late Richard Schwartz. Optometrist for over 45 years, respected and loved by his patients. Services Wednesday 11:30am at Temple Beth Torah, Westbury, NY. 1/3

BLANK--Robert Saler, died peacefully with family by his side on April 30th. A beloved husband, father, grandfather and friend, Bob had a distinguished 45 year career as a senior partner at Whitcom Partners, a company that owned and operated newspapers, magazines, TV and radio stations and cable systems. He had a special love for their newspaper holding Chesapeake Publishing. He graduated from Cornell University in 1962 and obtained his J.D. from the University of Pennsylvania. From 1965-1968 he was an Assistant U.S. Attorney in Philadelphia and Washington, DC. He spent the next three years in the Mergers and Acquisitions Department of Goldman Sachs before joining Whitcom as a partner. He was a director of Toll Brothers, Inc. and a former director of a number of publicly held corporations as well as the privately held International Herald Tribune (now the International New York Times). He was an Emeritus Trustee of the University of Pennsylvania, the Wharton School Board of Overseers, Penn Law Board of Overseers and a Trustee of Penn Medicine. He was the recipient of Penn Law's Distinguished Graduate and Alumni Achievement Award. Bob was born November 28, 1940 in Philadelphia to Ruth Saler Blank and Samuel Allen Blank. He is survived by his wife of 42 years, Nancy, his children Wendy, Samuel and Matt, son-in-law Lee, daughters-in-law Lindsay and Taryn and seven treasured grandchildren Grace, Charles, Cecily, Katherine, Eli, Lila and Noah. Bob was a man of warmth, dignity, humility and courage who will be greatly missed by all who knew him. The funeral will be held Wednesday, May 4th at 1pm at Temple Emanu-El in New York City. Contributions can be made in his memory to Memorial Sloan Kettering or New York Hospital. 1/3

KLEINBERG--Norman Charles, beloved husband of Marcia; devoted father of Lauren and Joanna and father-in-law to their husbands Darren and Daniel; loving grandfather of Margot, Charlotte and Jake; and valued colleague of the partners of Hughes Hubbard & Reed, passed peacefully in his sleep on May 2, 2016. Norman graduated from Tufts University in 1968 and from Columbia Law School in 1972. Following his graduation, Norman clerked for the Honorable Charles M. Metzner, United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, until 1974. He then joined the law firm of Hughes Hubbard & Reed in Manhattan, where he worked until 2012 when his failing health prevented him from continuing. Norman was always in motion. He was an ardent traveler and reveled in planning adventurous journeys with his family. Norman was also an accomplished trial lawyer with many notable trials that led to his selection as a fellow of the American College of Trial Lawyers. He was passionate about his work, devoted to his clients who chose him as their advocate, and loyal to his colleagues, training and inspiring a generation of attorneys at Hughes Hubbard & Reed where he chaired the litigation department. He loved to win, and nearly always did, while always adhering to the highest standards of the profession. Adversaries whom he had bested and judges who had presided over his cases remembered him with fondness and admiration years after their cases with Norman were over. His determination on behalf of his clients inspired those who worked for him to find reserves of stamina, persistence and creativity that they never knew they had. Norman had those qualities in abundance, and a magnificent ability to translate the hard work of the team into a devastating cross- examination or a winning argument to the court or jury. As devoted as he was to his profession, Norman was even more committed to his family, originally the three women in his life, then expanding to include his sons-in-law and grandchildren. Those who worked with Norman remember that even at the end of a long day preparing for trial, he never failed to call home to help with homework assignments or review college applications. And, just a few years ago, following another courtroom win, an Illinois jury was passing around pictures of his first grandchild. His vibrancy and courage live on in our hearts. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell - The Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Avenue on Wednesday, May 4, at 1:30pm. 1/3

SYLVAN--Eleanor Glasberg, 85, of Boca Raton, FL and Woodmere, NY, passed away on May 1, 2016. Loving mother of Bonnie Fuchs, Lisa Glasberg and Andrea Kantor and grandmother of Jennifer Kantor and Casey Fuchs. Despite battling the affects of Alzheimer's, we're sure she's now showing everyone in heaven how to do the New York Times Crossword Puzzle in ink and to play a fierce game of Bridge. A graduate of Adelphi University, Eleanor was also passionate about teaching. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Alzheimer's Association. 1/3

GOLOMB--Dr. Solomon. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of our friend and supporter Dr. Solomon Golomb, of La Canada, CA. A member of the ATS Southern California Board of Directors and the Technion Board of Governors, Dr. Golomb was awarded a Technion Honorary Doctorate in 2011, and was a frequent visiting professor. A University Professor and Distinguished Professor of Electrical Engineering and Mathematics at the University of Southern California, he held the Andrew and Erna Viterbi Chair in Communications. He was recognized for his pioneering achievements with the National Medal of Science in 2013. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology; Zahava Bar-Nir, President; Scott Leemaster, Chairman of the Board; Jeffrey Richard, Executive Vice President; Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Emeritus 1/3

MILLER--Mary Fried, on May 2, 2016 surrounded by her family. She was the beloved wife of 59 years of Charles H. Miller. She is survived by their children, Cathy Castaneda (Mario) of Acton, MA, Steven of Summit, NJ and Jennifer (Michael Grady) of Warwick, RI. She is also survived by her brother, John L. Fried (Roberta) of Milwaukee, WI, her beloved niece Sally Reiner (Larry), and her nephews Alan, Edward, Billy, and Michael. Her greatest joys were her children and her eight grandchildren - Kenny, Andrew and Matthew Miller, David, Mark and Peter Castaneda and Emily and Julia Grady. She left them with many wonderful memories and enough love and laughter to cherish for a lifetime. She was adored and admired by one and all, as well as by a host of friends in White Plains, Milwaukee, the Berkshires, and elsewhere. Mary was born in Milwaukee on June 25, 1930 to Dan and Belle Fried. After college, she moved from Milwaukee to New York and worked for A&S and Gimbels. She later earned a B.A. degree from Manhattanville College, and subsequently a Masters Degree in counseling. She was a career counselor in the Career Development Office at SUNY Purchase, for more than 20 years, where she initiated and developed an internship program for undergraduate students. Mary was an active volunteer in a broad range of activities; she was co-chair of the PTA, a docent at the Neuberger Museum at Purchase College, a volunteer with the pastoral care department at White Plains Hospital, and one of the founders of Aging in Place in White Plains. She was an avid tennis and bridge player, travelled extensively with her husband, family and grandchildren, before and after retirement, and was passionate about all forms of culture, including art, music and theatre. Her enjoyment of these arts was greatly enhanced as a result of her thirty-six summers in the Berkshires. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that memorial contributions be made to Make a Wish Foundation of Central New York, or the White Plains Beautification Foundation. A Memorial Celebration of her life will be held in the near future. 1/3

BLANK--Robert S. A dear, warm, wonderful man who enriched the lives of all who knew him. There is nothing he wouldn't do to help his many friends. We will never forget you and all the great times we shared together. We will miss you terribly. Our thoughts and love go out to Nancy and the family. Beth and Earle Yaffa 1/3

BLANK--Robert S. A terrible loss for all of us. Bob was a unique friend-affectionate, uncommonly generous and always wonderful company. We are fortunate to have so many memories in New York, Aspen, Connecticut and Rhode Island. Our love to Nancy and their wonderful children and grandchildren. Marilyn and Bill Frank 1/3

BLANK--Robert. There was no better friend than Bob Blank. So kind, so generous, so smart--he was totally devoted to family and friends and the institutions that meant a great deal to him. We miss him tremendously and send much love to Nancy and the Blank and Chaikin families. The Aaron Family 1/3

KLEINBERG--Norman C.,marathon runner, Bergdorf cashmeres, slipped off his Rolex before jury trials, 50 gifts for Marcia's 50th--with limousine stops up Madison Avenue, lured us to the Cipriani in Venice, the Taormina in Sicily, sedia di rotelle, the movies, Divino, loyal, fun friend; to Marcia our deep admiration for the courage you exhibited in your extraordinary care of a much-changed Norman these last few difficult years, we salute you. David and Carole Gaunt 1/3

SCHACK--Hon. Arthur M. Beloved husband of Dilia. Loving father of Elaine (Todd) and Douglas (Gina). Proud grandfather of Olivia Grace and Robert Joseph. Dear brother of Burton. Past President of the Brooklyn Counsel of Boy Scouts. History teacher at Bay Ridge High School from 1968 to 1981. Former Counsel for the Major League Baseball Players Association from 1981 to 1998. Current Supreme Court Justice for the State of New York and President of the Nathan R. Sobel Kings County Inn of Court. Services today, 12 noon at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to either the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society or the Boy Scouts of America. 1/3

PEARDON--Thomas Preston Jr.,of Bridgewater, Connecticut died April 21, after a long battle with illness. He was 77 years old. Born in New York City, he was the only child of Professor T.P. Peardon Sr., a history and political science professor at Barnard College, and Celeste (Comegys) Peardon, a well-known writer of books for children learning to read. Mr. Peardon attended The Trinity School in New York City and graduated from Harvard College with the class of 1960. While at Harvard he was a member of the DU Club and The Hasty Pudding Society. Immediately after college he joined his family's firm, Brunschwig et Fils, importers of high-end French fabrics and furniture for the interior decorator trade, with showrooms in New York City and in major cities throughout the U.S. and abroad. Rising through the ranks to CEO, he retired as Chairman of the Board in 2007. He was a member of the Union Club of New York City, the Harvard Club of New York City and a proud veteran of New York's famous 7th Regiment of the New York National Guard. Although a geology major in college, he was, like his father, an avid reader of history, his favorite pastime. Fluent in French, Mr. Peardon traveled often in France visiting his company's many suppliers. In 1968, in the midst of France's national strike against President Charles De Gaulle, he celebrated his marriage to his wife Eveline Le Jemtel at her family's chateau in Normandy, right next to Omaha Beach of D-Day fame. In later years he and his wife bought and remodeled a house in Bayeux on the Normandy coast where, after retirement, they spent many happy months during the year. Mr. Peardon leaves his wife of 48 years, Eveline, his son Thomas Olivier and his wife Susannah and two young granddaughters, of Greenwich, CT. A service honoring his life will be held at St. Mark's church in Bridgewater at 2pm on May 6. 1/3

AARON--Daniel. The trustees and staff of the Library of America are saddened by the death of Life Trustee and founding president Daniel Aaron. The Library of America - a nonprofit cultural institution created in 1979 to publish authoritative editions of America's best and most significant writing for a wide audience of general readers, scholars, and students - embodies Dan's conviction that American literature is the key to understanding the nation's history and character, and worthy of being preserved and celebrated. Elizabeth W. Smith, Chair of the Board; Cheryl Hurley, President 1/3

BERRIGAN--Rev. Daniel J.,S.J., on April 30, 2016. Reposing at the Church of St. Francis Xavier, 46 W. 16th Street, New York, NY 10011 on Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at the Church of St. Francis Xavier on Friday, 10am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Northeast Province of the Society of Jesus, 39 E. 83rd Street, New York, NY 10028. Interment at the Jesuit Cemetery, Auriesville, NY. For information, contact Farenga Bros. Inc., Directors, (718) 654-0500. 1/3

SILVER--Thelma, 95, died peacefully at her Jamaica, NY home on Tuesday, May 3, 2016. Happily married for more than half a century to the late Arthur, she was cherished by three generations of family--Eric, Ellen, Stevie, Matthew, Dee, Andrew, Melinda, and Ruthie-- and countless friends. She worked for more than a quarter century as an editorial proofreader at Queens College. Services will be held on Thursday, May 5 at 11:00am at Sinai Chapels, Fresh Meadows, Queens, 718-445-0300. 1/3

KLEINBERG--Norman. Esteemed colleague; brilliant attorney; giving husband, father, and grandfather; game travel companion; discriminating shopper; gifted blackjack player. Most of all, loyal friend. We will never forget the good times. Our hearts go out to Marcia, Lauren, Joanna and their families. The Scherers and the Fuersts 1/3

LORD--Barbara Stuart Hartley (Bobbie), age 92, passed away peacefully on Saturday, April 30, 2016 with her family beside her. Born on July 28, 1923, she lived an extraordinary life, growing up in Southampton, New York, with her parents, George Inness Hartley and Agnes de Montpellier Hartley, who predeceased her, as did her brother George. Her sister Marguerite (Bebs) survives in New York City. Barbara was a direct descendant of 19th century painter George Inness. Barbara went to Foxcroft School in Middleburg, Virginia, graduating in 1941, and went on to become a housemother and secretary to the founder of Foxcroft, Charlotte Haxall Noland, a dear friend and mentor. In fact, Foxcroft honored Barbara just this past month with its Distinguished Alumna Award. Barbara and James Couper Lord were married in Southampton in 1948 at St. Andrew's Dune Church, to which she and her family were devoted. They moved to Buffalo, NY, where she raised her family for over 30 years and where their four children were born: James Couper Lord, Jr. (deceased), Mary-Louise Lord Gillespie (husband David), Barbara Hartley Lord Edwards (husband Jim), and Ruth Lord (deceased). In Buffalo, Barbara served on the Boards of Buffalo General Hospital and Elmwood Franklin School, was an active member of Trinity Church and was President of the Garrett Club. Barbara and Couper retired to Southampton in 1980 where she continued her community work. She was President of the Southampton Nursing Home, a position she held for more than twenty-five years, was devoted to St. Andrew's Dune Church, where she served as head of the Altar Guild until she retired at ninety years of age and was appointed Trustee Emeritus, and was President of the Southampton Garden Club, for which she supervised numerous flower competitions and presided at a Garden Club of America zone meeting on the very day that her fifth granddaughter was born. Upon retiring from the Southampton Garden Club, she was honored to receive the Garden Club of America's Medal of Merit in recognition of her "inspirational and wise leadership". For many years Barbara served as an active member of the Village Improvement Association of Southampton, a local organization founded even before the incorporation of Southampton Village. A beloved mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother, she taught her children life's lessons of compassion for others and working within one's community. Her 'understanding heart' and empathy for the less fortunate was a gift she bequeathed to everyone about her, regardless of where she lived. Barbara is also survived by five granddaughters, whom she called her "pearls"--Hartley Gillespie Wenger, Lorrie Edwards, Eleanor Gillespie Strumolo, Caroline Cook Edwards, Courtney Matson Edwards--and six great-grandchildren--Noah, Walter, Henry, Jack, Sophie, and Lily--with all of whom she celebrated her 92nd birthday. Barbara Hartley Lord guided her family, relatives, and countless friends in their accomplishments, inspiring everyone to make the world a better place. All of them loved her deeply and will dearly miss her. God rest her blessed soul. A memorial service will be held in July at St. Andrew's Dune Church in Southampton. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to St. Andrew's Dune Church, St. John's Church in Southampton, or the J. Couper Lord, Jr., Dialysis Fund at Southampton Hospital. 1/3

KLEINBERG--Norman C.,marathon runner, Bergdorf cashmeres, slipped off his Rolex before jury trials, 50 gifts for Marcia's 50th--with limousine stops up Madison Avenue, lured us to the Cipriani in Venice, the Taormina in Sicily, sedia di rotelle, the movies, Divino, loyal, fun friend; to Marcia our deep admiration for the courage you exhibited in your extraordinary care of a much-changed Norman these last few difficult years, we salute you. David and Carole Gaunt 1/3

FLOR--Dr. Richard V.,retired research chemist with U.S. Customs, died March 22, 2016 at the Villa Rosa Nursing and Rehabilitation Center in Mitchellville, MD. He was 75. Richard Flor, the son of the late Ricklef and Minna Flor, was born in New York City and grew up on City Island. The long time Cheverly, MD, resident graduated from New York University in chemical engineering and earned his doctorate in chemistry from City University, New York. He also had a masters' degree in special education. He made his career in government service with U.S Customs both in New York City and Washington, D.C. Earlier, Dr. Flor, was a principal investigator developing a patented chemical process for metallic coatings. He was also adjunct professor at York College in Queens, New York and at Montgomery College in Silver Spring, MD. He is survived by his sister Janet (Flor) Dell and his brother-in-law Leonard Dell. He was the loving uncle to Geoffrey Dell and Susan and Robert Eberhart, and grand-uncle to Anthony and Bryan Dell and Matthew Eberhart. He will be remembered as a loving, caring and generous person, who was known for his support of many animal rights organizations. His family, friends and neighbors will miss his wit, intelligence and friendship. A memorial service was held at Gasch's Funeral Home, PA, Hyattsville, MD, on April 23, 2016. Donations in his name may be made to the North Shore Animal League, 25 Davis Avenue, Port Washington, NY 11050. 1/3

LOBBATO--Vincent, M.D.,on May 3, 2016. Beloved husband of Maria Moreno, M.D. Devoted father of Stephanie Lobbato-Lobron. Cherished grandfather of Derek and Zoe. Loving son of Ruth and the late Vincent. Visitation Thursday, 4 to 9pm at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Funeral Mass will be Friday, 10am at St. Paul the Apostle Church, 405 West 59th St. and 9th Ave. 1/3

BLANK--Robert S. We send our love as well as our deepest condolences to Nancy and the entire Blank Family. Bob was a very special friend and his passing is a great loss to all who knew him. We will miss him enormously. Ann and Charley 1/3

TURK--Abner Issac, of Weston, FL, formerly of South Orange, NJ, passed away peacefully on May 3, 2016. Abner was born in Newark, NJ on April 17, 1926. Abner attended Princeton, Texas A & M and graduated from Rutgers University. After working at New Jersey Electric Supply, he moved to Florida in 1973 and became owner of Chuck's Backhoe Service of Pompano Beach. He is survived by his wife of 65 years Arleen Frankenberg Turk, four children, eight grandchildren and 11 great- grandchildren. 1/3

WEISS--Dr. Bernard. Our Dad, grandfather and great-grandfather, Dr. Bernard Weiss, died peacefully surrounded by family in New York on May 3, 2016 at the age of 93. Born to Dr. Samuel and Ella Weiss on February 9, 1923 in New York, NY, Bernie became known in his family, the Horowitz-Margareten Family of matzoh bakers, as "Uncle Doctor." Bernie was beloved for his compassion and warmth. He practiced old fashioned, hands-on medicine, having learned from working with his father, also a doctor. He charged patients whatever they could afford to pay. Bernie's entire immediate family served in World War II, including his two brothers, his father and even his mother, who headed the local Manhattan Red Cross office. He enlisted in the United States Army Air Force before he was 18 years old. After the War, Bernie attended New York Medical College on the GI Bill. He loved his family and enriched their lives with his gentle manner and great sense of humor. The love of his life, his wife of 51 years Doris, sadly predeceased him in 2003. During summers in Atlantic Beach, his joy was gardening and barbecuing for family and friends - smoked capon was the family favorite. Bernie was loved by many and will be missed deeply by all who knew him. He is survived by his daughter Wendy and son-in-law Judd Meltzer, his daughter Cathy Zises, grandchildren Samantha and Jonathan Firestone, Joshua and Ali Meltzer, Aaron and Blake Zises, Samuel Zises and fiance Cassie Shulman, Benjamin Zises and Natalie Zises, great-grandchildren Charlotte and Hudson Firestone, sister-in-law Marie Rosen, nephews and nieces Jonny and Caroline Rosen, and Billy and Suzy Rosen. He also leaves behind a brother Jerome, many cousins and other nieces and nephews. Marie Rosen holds a most special place in his heart. She was like a sister, especially since Doris passed away. Shira Levin has been an esteemed extended member of the family. We thank her for her sage counsel, and most importantly, her love. The family thanks Ketty Suarez for her many years of devoted service. With her sister Eloise, they took the best care of Dr. Weiss. The family will have a private service and funeral. 1/3

WEINER--Walter H. We mourn the loss of Walter, a wonderful friend of more than 50 years. He influenced our lives in many ways great and small. Heartfelt condolences to our close and loving friend Nina and to the entire family. Paulette and Joe Rose 1/3

BELFER--Norman C.,of Palm Beach, FL, formerly of Great Neck, NY passed away peacefully on May 3, 2016. His 93 years captured the beauty, joy and tragedy of our time. Norman rebuilt a life shattered by the Holocaust, focused on his wife of 64 years, Elinor; his four children, Andrew and his wife Karen, James (of blessed memory), Lauren and Carolyn and her husband Jonathan; and his seven grandchildren, James, Jason, Adam, David, Samantha, Jennifer and Jordan. Norman was a brilliant businessman and a master builder of significant real estate projects in five states, a generous philanthropist and a man of great strength and character. He faced monumental challenges with a calm, optimistic, loving, forgiving and humble spirit. He touched the lives of many and will be sorely missed. Donations in his memory may be made to the American Society for Yad Vashem and the American Technion Society. Funeral service was held on Friday, May 6, in Great Neck, NY. 1/3

LEIFMAN--Rabbi Morton M. The Jewish Theological Seminary joins the family in mourning the loss of Rabbi Morton M. Leifman, former vice president of JTS and longtime dean of its Cantors Institute (now the H. L. Miller Cantorial School). He was an esteemed scholar of Jewish liturgy whose immeasurable service to JTS spanned decades. A gifted teacher, a valued colleague, and a wise leader, Rabbi Leifman's tremendous impact on our institution and on Jewish life continues to be felt. We extend our condolences to his cherished wife, Vera, and to their beloved children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Arnold M. Eisen, Chancellor Alan Levine, Board Chair 1/3
CAMPBELL--William Isaac. 11/29/26-5/7/2011 The we of us. A seeker of truth who was the center of my life for 54 glorious years. John V. Hilton 1/3
BLACK--Rickey. 6.27.1951 - 5.7.2013 Three years gone but still cherished in the many hearts touched by his magic! Robin, family, and friends 1/3
WINTER--Marvin S. We remember you each day with love. Your Family 1/3

CHOU--Yi-an. The MacDougal-Sullivan Garden Association mourns the loss of its longtime member Yi-an Chou. Yi-an was an active figure in the life of the Garden, generous of effort and friend to many. Our thoughts and sympathy are with the Chou family. 1/3

von MEHREN--Robert B.,The last surviving lawyer in the infamous Alger Hiss trials of the late 1940s, died Thursday at his home in Manhattan from congestive heart failure, according to his wife, Susan Heller Anderson, a writer and former reporter for The New York Times. Mr. von Mehren was 93. As a young lawyer for the firm that is now Debevoise & Plimpton, Mr. von Mehren served on the defense counsel team representing Mr. Hiss, a highly regarded former government official, during his two trials for perjury in 1949 and 1950. Mr. Hiss, then president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, was told in August, 1948, that Whittaker Chambers, an editor at Time magazine, had testified before the Committee for the Investigation of Un-American Activities of the House of Representatives and had accused Hiss of being a spy for the Soviet Union while working for the U.S. government. Newspapers labeled the proceedings "the trial of the century." Richard M. Nixon subsequently became nationally famous for his pursuit of Communists, specially Mr. Hiss, and 20 years later, in 1968, was elected president. He revealed later, in the Watergate tapes, that he had mounted a systematic campaign of leaking information that would turn opinion against Hiss. Among the many positions Mr. von Mehren held outside the law firm were legal counsel to the Preparatory Commission of the International Atomic Energy Agency, which composed the guidelines for the United Nations' agency that exist today; consultant to the Rand Corporation on disarmament; consultant to the Hudson Institute on international law, and senior lecturer in law at the Wharton School. An active proselytizer of arbitration, Mr. von Mehren taught and lectured all over the world. He pioneered international arbitration among American lawyers, serving in more than four dozen arbitrations after he "retired" from Debevoise. His pro bono positions included chairman, vice chairman and/or president of the International Law Association, the Practicing Law Institute, the American branch of the International Law Association, several committees of the City Bar Association of New York and the Harvard Law School Association of New York. He was an honorary member of the Commercial Bar of London and the Singapore Bar. He was also on the board of the American Arbitration Association; a fellow of the American Bar Foundation; the vice-president emeritis of the Axe-Hougton Foundation, and a member of the Council on Foreign Relations, the Century Association and the University Club. Born in Albert Lea, Minn., he won a national scholarship to Yale University, from whence he graduated summa cum laude, then magna cum laude from the Harvard Law School, where he served as president of its Law Review. Upon graduation he became associated with Debevoise, where he spent most of his career until he became an international arbitrator. He clerked for Judge Learned Hand at the Second Circuit Court of Appeals and Supreme Court Justice Stanley F. Reed. An avid sailor, Mr. von Mehren raced his beloved Mariner Phalarope, on Martha's Vineyard, where he owned a home that he bought from James Cagney in 1957. In addition to his wife, Mr von Mehren is survived by his loving children: a son, Carl; three daughters, Katharine, Jane and Margaret, and Philip D. Anderson, his stepson. He was predeceased by his first wife, Mary Katharine; his younger son, John, and his identical twin, Arthur T. von Mehren. A celebration of his life is to be held in the fall in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made in his name to the Sherriff's Meadow Foundation, 57 David Ave., Vineyard Haven MA 02568. The family will receive friends at their Manhattan apartment 4pm-8pm on Sunday, May 8, and 6pm-8pm on Monday, May 9. 1/3

LESSER--Herb, in Houston, on May 5. Beloved husband of Linda (nee Farfel) for 55 years; father of Larry (Laurie Davis) and Lori (Daniel Shuchman); grandfather of Judah, Aaron and Ariela. Born in Ft. Worth, TX in 1937; Rice University, Fulbright Scholar and Princeton PhD in chemical engineering. Careers in energy (Exxon, Mitchell Energy) and finance (UBS). President of Seven Acres Jewish Senior Care Services. Loved travel, opera, museums, financial news, Houston sports teams (fair or foul weather), nature, math and science, dining with friends and entertaining his grandchildren. Amateur genealogist, photographer and astronomer; frequent search engine for Internet humor. Above all, a truly kind and decent man who enjoyed life. He will be sorely missed. Donations may be made to Seven Acres: sevenacres.org. 1/3

KATZ--Ernest, 98, born in Germany, a Holocaust Survivor, passed away peacefully on May 6, surrounded by his beloved wife Ellen (nee Strauss), two sons Gary and Jeff, their wives, Leslye and Phyllis, grandchildren Dori (Mike), Adam (Nicole), Eric, Michelle and Danny (Lena). WEINER--Walter H. The ISEF Foundation Board of Trustees joins with ISEF's thousands of supporters, students, and alumni to mourn the passing of founding Trustee Walter Weiner. Together with ISEF Founders Edmond J. Safra z"l, Lily Safra, and his beloved wife, ISEF President Nina Weiner, Walter played a key role in establishing ISEF in 1977. With his stalwart leadership and support, ISEF has empowered some 7,000 young Israelis to rise out of immigrant backgrounds, earn degrees from BA to PhD, and become leaders in their fields. In 2011, Walter received ISEF's Lifetime Achievement Award for his enduring role throughout ISEF's history. We are eternally grateful for his dedication to educating underserved Israelis, and saddened at the passing of a man whose force of personality was exceeded only by his greatness of heart. May his wife Nina and all his family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. The ISEF Foundation Board of Trustees, Carlos Benaim, Chairman 1/3
DICK--Marion Pokoik. Always loved, always missed, especially on this Mother's Day. Your Daughter, Gail 1/3

SCHLESSEL--Walter "Wally" (92). February 29, 1924 - May 6, 2016 Died from a full and loving life well lived. Famously humble, funny, generous, caring, gracious, gentle and strong. A class act and a gentleman to the end. He will live on in the many people he touched but none moreso than his loving family. He is survived by his beloved and beautiful wife of 70 years, Marilyn, his two loving sons, Derek and Bobby and his cherished grandson, Ryan. Funeral services will be held at Gutterman Warheit Chappel, 7240 N Federal Highway, Boca Raton, Monday, May 9 at noon. A private graveside service will be held Wednesday at Beth Moses Cemetery in New York. 1/3

WEISS--Dr. Bernard. Our Dad, grandfather and great-grandfather, Dr. Bernard Weiss, died peacefully surrounded by family in New York on May 3, 2016 at the age of 93. Born to Dr. Samuel and Ella Weiss on February 9, 1923 in New York, NY, Bernie became known in his family, the Horowitz-Margareten Family of matzoh bakers, as "Uncle Doctor." Bernie was beloved for his compassion and warmth. He practiced old fashioned, hands-on medicine, having learned from working with his father, also a doctor. He charged patients whatever they could afford to pay. Bernie's entire immediate family served in World War II, including his two brothers, his father and even his mother, who headed the local Manhattan Red Cross office. He enlisted in the United States Army Air Force before he was 18 years old. After the War, Bernie attended New York Medical College on the GI Bill. He loved his family and enriched their lives with his gentle manner and great sense of humor. The love of his life, his wife of 51 years Doris, sadly predeceased him in 2003. During summers in Atlantic Beach, his joy was gardening and barbecuing for family and friends - smoked capon was the family favorite. Bernie was loved by many and will be missed deeply by all who knew him. He is survived by his daughter Wendy and son-in-law Judd Meltzer, his daughter Cathy Zises, grandchildren Samantha and Jonathan Firestone, Joshua and Ali Meltzer, Aaron and Blake Zises, Samuel Zises and fiance Cassie Shulman, Benjamin Zises and Natalie Zises, great-grandchildren Charlotte and Hudson Firestone, sister-in-law Marie Rosen, nephews and nieces Jonny and Caroline Rosen, and Billy and Suzy Rosen. He also leaves behind a brother Jerome, many cousins and other nieces and nephews. Marie Rosen holds a most special place in his heart. She was like a sister, especially since Doris passed away. Shira Levin has been an esteemed extended member of the family. We thank her for her sage counsel, and most importantly, her love. The family thanks Ketty Suarez for her many years of devoted service. With her sister Eloise, they took the best care of Dr. Weiss. The family will have a private service and funeral. 1/3

CHOU--Yi-an, wife of composer Chou Wen- chung, passed away peacefully at home on April 12, 2016 after a short battle with pancreatic cancer. She was born in Shanghai in 1927 to Chang (Han) Siang-mei and Chang Hsin-hai, a scholar and China's ambassador to Czechoslovakia, Poland and Portugal from 1933-37. She spent her early childhood in Eastern Europe. She began studying the piano at age eight in Warsaw and continued her studies in Los Angeles, where her family moved in 1941. Mrs. Chou made her concert debut with Leopold Stokowski and the Hollywood Bowl Symphony during her senior year of high school, and later moved to New York City to study with Olga Samaroff at The Juilliard School on a fellowship. In 1956, she received grants to perform in Europe, where she studied with Walter Gieseking and Marguerite Long, and gave recitals in England, France, and Germany, where the Hamburg Evening Newspaper called her "...altogether an amazing pianist and musical talent." She married Chou Wen-chung in 1962 and retired from performing to care for their two sons. Her passion for flowers later led to a second career as a floral designer. Her arrangements caught the attention of the Parsons School of Design where she was invited to teach Parson's first class in floral design in 1979. For twenty-five years, she taught both Western and Ikebana styles, and the Floral Design program became one of Parsons's most popular certificate programs. She was former president of the New York Chapter of the Ohara School of Ikebana, and a member of Ikebana International. Yi-an is survived by her husband, sons Luyen and Sumin, daughters-in-law Rachel and Kiersten, and three grandchildren. She was predeceased by her brother, David P. Chang. Her laughter, friendship and joie-de-vivre are missed dearly by all who knew and loved her. Donations in Yi-an's memory can be made to the Visiting Nurse Service of New York or Doctors Without Borders. 1/3

von MEHREN--Robert B. The Board of Trustees and staff of Practising Law Institute (PLI) mourn the passing of long time Trustee, Board Chairman, Executive Committee Chairman and Chairman Emeritus, Robert B. von Mehren. Robert was an active contributor to PLI, co-author of PLI's "American Arbitration: Principles and Practice", speaker at PLI programs and an ongoing supporter of continuing legal education. We will miss his wise counsel and wisdom. Our sympathies to his family at this time. William P. Frank, Board Chair Samuel W. Seymour, Executive Committee Chair Anita C. Shapiro, President 1/3

Funeral, Monday, May 9 at 1pm, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., NYC. Donations to YIVO, JSSA Hospice, Rockville, MD, or a charity of your choice. 1/3

TESTA--Andrew H. of Sunrise Hill Circle, Orange, CT and Palm Beach Gardens, FL, formerly of Stamford, CT, passed away Friday, April 22, 2016. He was the devoted husband of Doreen (Zlotnick) Testa and the proud father of Marc and Alan. Interment was in the Agudath Sholom Cemetery, Stamford, CT. 1/3

CHAPLIN--Hugh, Jr.,M.D., of Westwood, Massachusetts, formerly of St. Louis, Missouri, died peacefully at his home on April 29, 2016 at the age of 93. Hugh was born in New York City on February 4, 1923 to Hugh Chaplin, Sr., M.D., and Virginia Deems Chaplin, and was preceded in death by his two sisters, Barbara Stewart (of Wyckoff, New Jersey) and Virginia Atkinson (of Toledo, Ohio). He graduated from The Hill School (Pottstown, Pennsylvania), Princeton University (A.B., 1943), and the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons (M.D., 1947). While in college and medical school, he served in the U.S. Navy during the final months of WWII. He performed his internal medicine residency at the Massachusetts General Hospital, serving as chief resident in his final year. He entered an academic career through a research fellowship in the US Public Health Service at the National Institutes of Health and pursued additional research training at the Medical Research Council Blood Transfusion Research Unit in London. He joined the faculty of Washington University School of Medicine in St. Louis in 1955 and served several leadership roles including Associate Dean, Director of the Irene Walter Johnson Rehabilitation Institute, and later Director of the Barnes Hospital Blood Bank. A hematologist, research scientist, and professor of medicine, Hugh authored over 140 scientific articles and was recognized internationally for his work on sickle cell anemia, autoimmune hemolytic anemia, transfusion reactions, and blood banking. He served on the national board of the American Association of Blood Banking and was honored by the Association's Emily Cooley Memorial Award and Lectureship. In 2003, in honor of his longest- living sickle cell patient and research colleague, Hugh self-published the memoir, "Lenabell: A Doctor's Memoir of a Remarkable Woman's Eighty Year Battle with Sickle Cell Disease." In his retirement, Hugh worked extensively for BJC Hospice in St. Louis, both as a volunteer visitor with the dying and as the organization's pain management consultant. Hugh travelled extensively throughout his life, including three sabbaticals in England. His day visiting Mother Teresa in Calcutta in the early 1970s remained one of his most profound life experiences. Despite travelling throughout the world, however, his favorite spot was the longtime family home in the Catskill Mountains. Every evening at dusk, he could almost always be found enjoying the changing light and view of the mountains from what he called his "psychotherapy spot" on the upstairs back porch. An avid fly-fisherman, Hugh spent many happy times casting for trout in the Ozark Mountains of Missouri. His trout pancakes with caper cream sauce were an epicurean experience. Despite declining health in his latter years, Hugh remained deeply appreciative of his many blessings--a loving family, dear friends--old and new--a strong faith, and the ability to enjoy some of life's simple pleasures: art, the beauty of nature, and the joys of a classic glazed donut. He will be greatly missed by all who had the privilege to know him. Hugh is survived by his four children and their spouses (Kate and Roger Woodward, of Surrey, England; David and Jane Chaplin of Birmingham, Alabama; Monique Chaplin and Mary McCartney of Arlington, Massachusetts; and John Chaplin and Jill Adams of Delmar, New York), eight grandchildren and their spouses (Adrian and Leanna Gonzalez of Charlestown, Massachusetts; Sebastian and Josie Gonzalez of Canton, Massachusetts; Vernon and Cathy Chaplin, of Pasadena, California; Rosalind Chaplin of San Diego, California; Daniel Chaplin of Birmingham, Alabama; and Benjamin, Wesley, and Clara Chaplin of Delmar, New York), and three great-grandchildren (Daniel Gonzalez, June Chaplin, and Madison Gonzalez), whose arrivals brought a most special joy to his final years. Hugh was preceded in death by two beloved spouses, Alice Dougherty Chaplin (mother of his four children, who died in 1996 after 52 years of marriage) and Lee Nelken Robins, PhD (with whom he enjoyed 11 years of marriage before her death in 2009). A memorial service and burial at All Souls Church, Onteora Park, Tannersville, NY, will be scheduled at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations to the National Down Syndrome Congress would be a most appreciated tribute. 1/3

EHRENHAUS--Roslyn (Razele bat Malka). Born October 22, 1925, in Philadelphia, PA, passed away from a brief illness on May 1, 2016. Joined in heaven with her beloved Philip Ehrenhaus. Will be surely missed by Stewart and Isobel Ehrenhaus, Henry and Lisa Rubin and all her grandchildren. 1/3

CUEVAS--Louis, July 26, 1928 - April 10, 2016. "Lou," Broadcast pioneer, died from complications following open heart surgery. Son of Joseph and Estelle Cuevas of the Bronx, Lou was a graphic artist on NBC's "Today." Featured as a creator on the 60th Anniversary Show in 2012, Lou also drew "Rebus" puzzles for "Concentration" and retired at 80 from ABC's "Good Morning America" and "Nightline." A Korean War Army veteran, Lou was married to Catherine Nicastri from 1965 until her death in 2013. Lou is survived by daughter Caroline Keck and son-in-law Albert, four grandchildren Lexi and husband Kyle, Julie, Paul, and Carlin, and by cousin Rex Phelps and family. On his wife's side, Lou is survived by brothers and sisters-in-law, Dr. Tony and Ann Nicastri, their four children Ruthann Pennybacher, Tina McKenzie, Dr. Cathy Dickhuth, and Dr. Dan Nicastri, their spouses, and eight- grandnieces/nephews. Lou will also be missed by companion Sue Rothberger and many extended family/friends. A lover of life and witty conversationalist, Lou made lifelong friends everywhere. The single common denominator this diverse group shares is a deep love and admiration for the unique character known as Lou. A Memorial will be held at 1pm on Saturday, June 25 at Manhattan Penthouse on Fifth. 1/3

MALONE--Dr. Charles Anthony, child psychiatrist, teacher, mentor, colleague, leader, jazz-lover, Giants fan, rabble-rouser and advocate, adored son, beloved and loving husband, father/step- father, grandfather, in-law, uncle, cousin, and friend, died on April 24th, 'round midnight, having given his all to living. He was 88. A memorial service will be announced. In lieu of flowers, please consider donating to a candidate or cause of your choice, or, better still, get out and pound the pavement. He did. 1/3
CHARNELLE--Phyllis and Leonard, MD. With love and remembrance. Susan and Marshall 1/3

BELFER--Norman C.,of Palm Beach, FL, formerly of Great Neck, NY passed away peacefully on May 3, 2016. His 93 years captured the beauty, joy and tragedy of our time. Norman rebuilt a life shattered by the Holocaust, focused on his wife of 64 years, Elinor; his four children, Andrew and his wife Karen, James (of blessed memory), Lauren and Carolyn and her husband Jonathan; and his seven grandchildren, James, Jason, Adam, David, Samantha, Jennifer and Jordan. Norman was a brilliant businessman and a master builder of significant real estate projects in five states, a generous philanthropist and a man of great strength and character. He faced monumental challenges with a calm, optimistic, loving, forgiving and humble spirit. He touched the lives of many and will be sorely missed. Donations in his memory may be made to the American Society for Yad Vashem and the American Technion Society. Funeral service was held on Friday, May 6, in Great Neck, NY. 1/3

de MICHIELL--Robert Lawrence, Jr. A Celebration of Life will be held on Sunday, May 15 at New World Stages, 340 W. 50th Street, New York, with a cocktail reception from 5pm to 7pm, and a tribute presentation at 7pm. Robert passed away October 12, 2015 in Manhattan after a three year battle with cancer. He was one of the most prolific commercial illustrators of his time, with a distinctive style that was synonymous with sophisticated New York City-based entertainment and culture. His work appeared frequently in the New York Times, The New Yorker (including the cover in March, 1993), Entertainment Weekly, and Premiere Magazine's "If You Ask Me" column for 12 years. Additionally, he created signature art for many Broadway and Off-Broadway shows, including "Oliver" (1984), "The Wind and the Willows" (1985), "Arsenic and Old Lace" (1986), "The Most Fabulous Story Ever Told" (1998) and "La Cage aux Folles" (2004), as well as numerous posters for Broadway Cares/Equity Fights Aids, including the organization's annual Easter Bonnet, Gypsy of the Year, Nothing Like a Dame, Broadway Flea Market and Broadway Barks events. His illustrations have appeared in The Wall Street Journal, Readers Digest, TV Guide, Hartford Courant and hundreds of newspapers and magazines around the country. His corporate work includes images for American Express, Absolut Vodka, and many others. He married Jeffrey M. Wilson on March 25, 2012, and their wedding was profiled in the New York Times. He is also survived by his mother Nan DeMichiell; sisters Gail DeMichiell and Lynn Lynch and her husband Brian, of Waterford, CT; nephews Matthew Lynch of Waterford and David Lynch of New York City; niece Jessica Harran of Waterford; uncles Ronald DeMichiell of Waterford and Dr. Bernard F. McEvoy and his wife Barbara of Schenectady, NY and his cousins. His father, Robert DeMichiell, Sr., passed away in 2014. Donations can be made in Robert's name to The Actors Fund, 729 Seventh Ave., New York, NY, 10019 or to Calvary Fund (Calvary Hospital Hospice), 1740 Eastchester Rd., Bronx, NY 10461. 1/3
BLACK--Rickey. 6.27.1951 - 5.7.2013 Three years gone but still cherished in the many hearts touched by his magic! Robin, family, and friends 1/3

AMSTEIN--Charles A.,died in New York City on April 7, 2016. He was 82 years old. A native of Kansas, he served two years in the US Army before entering Union Theological Seminary. Ordained as Presbyterian Minister in 1962, Rev. Amstein served churches in Indiana and Wisconsin. In 1977 he became the Associate Pastor of the Madison Avenue PC in New York City. After retiring in 1995 he was active at the Rutgers PC. A memorial service is planned for June 11 at 4pm at Rutgers Church. 1/3

KAUFFMANN--Howard C.,93, beloved husband, father, and grandfather, passed away peacefully at home in Atlanta, GA on May 3rd, 2016. He was born February 25, 1923 in Tulsa, OK, the son of Howard C. Kauffmann and Polly Ethel (Myers) Kauffmann. He received a degree in mechanical engineering from the University of Oklahoma in 1943. After graduation, he served as an officer aboard the cruiser U.S.S. Cleveland in the Pacific until the end of World War II. After the War he began a long career in the petroleum industry when he joined an affiliate of Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, which later became Exxon Corp. (now ExxonMobil). He worked with several domestic affiliates of the company, and as president of three foreign affiliates: International Petroleum Company, Ltd., Esso Inter-America, and Esso Europe. In 1974, he was transferred to New York City to become a director and senior vice president, and was elected president and chief operating officer of Exxon Corp. the following year, a position he held until his retirement in 1985. Mr. Kauffmann served on a number of boards of directors, including The Chase Manhattan Corp., Chase Manhattan Bank, United Technologies, Pfizer, Celanese, and Ryder Systems. He was also a director of the American Petroleum Institute, The New York Chamber of Commerce, The New York Partnership, The United Way of New York City, and the Business Council of New York State. He served as director and chairman of the National Council for Minorities in Engineering, as vice president of the John F. Kennedy Center for Performing Arts, and as trustee of the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton University, among other posts. Howard and Suzanne Kauffmann made their home in Atlanta since 1996. They are members of the Mt. Vernon Baptist Church of Atlanta. Howard Kauffmann was known to all as a smart, tough, self-disciplined, fair, loyal and generous man with an admirable work ethic, playful sense of humor, and unwavering devotion to God, country and family. He will always be in the hearts and prayers of his family and friends. Howard C Kauffmann is survived by his wife of 71 years, Suzanne McMurray Kauffmann of Atlanta, GA; four children: Dr. Lane Kauffmann, Kristine (Joe) Hope, Rev. Douglas (Sally) Kauffmann, and Scott (Shifra) Kauffmann; seven grandchildren: Anna (Brent) Germain, Dr. Travis Kauffmann, Christina (Matt) Isenhower, Dr. Rachel Hope, Matthew Hope, Evan Kauffmann, and Amelia Kauffmann; one great-grandchild, Luke Germain; and one niece, Shari Graham. Howard Kauffmann was preceded in death by a son, Craig Kauffmann, a sister, Jean Dunlap, a brother, Donald Kauffmann, and a nephew, Richard Dunlap. 1/3

LORD--Barbara Stuart Hartley (Bobbie), age 92, passed away peacefully on Saturday, April 30, 2016 with her family beside her. Born on July 28, 1923, she lived an extraordinary life, growing up in Southampton, New York, with her parents, George Inness Hartley and Agnes de Montpellier Hartley, who predeceased her, as did her brother George. Her sister Marguerite (Bebs) survives in New York City. Barbara was a direct descendant of 19th century painter George Inness. Barbara went to Foxcroft School in Middleburg, Virginia, graduating in 1941, and went on to become a housemother and secretary to the founder of Foxcroft, Charlotte Haxall Noland, a dear friend and mentor. In fact, Foxcroft honored Barbara just this past month with its Distinguished Alumna Award. Barbara and James Couper Lord were married in Southampton in 1948 at St. Andrew's Dune Church, to which she and her family were devoted. They moved to Buffalo, NY, where she raised her family for over 30 years and where their four children were born: James Couper Lord, Jr. (deceased), Mary-Louise Lord Gillespie (husband David), Barbara Hartley Lord Edwards (husband Jim), and Ruth Lord (deceased). In Buffalo, Barbara served on the Boards of Buffalo General Hospital and Elmwood Franklin School, was an active member of Trinity Church and was President of the Garrett Club. Barbara and Couper retired to Southampton in 1980 where she continued her community work. She was President of the Southampton Nursing Home, a position she held for more than twenty-five years, was devoted to St. Andrew's Dune Church, where she served as head of the Altar Guild until she retired at ninety years of age and was appointed Trustee Emeritus, and was President of the Southampton Garden Club, for which she supervised numerous flower competitions and presided at a Garden Club of America zone meeting on the very day that her fifth granddaughter was born. Upon retiring from the Southampton Garden Club, she was honored to receive the Garden Club of America's Medal of Merit in recognition of her "inspirational and wise leadership". For many years Barbara served as an active member of the Village Improvement Association of Southampton, a local organization founded even before the incorporation of Southampton Village. A beloved mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother, she taught her children life's lessons of compassion for others and working within one's community. Her 'understanding heart' and empathy for the less fortunate was a gift she bequeathed to everyone about her, regardless of where she lived. Barbara is also survived by five granddaughters, whom she called her "pearls"--Hartley Gillespie Wenger, Lorrie Edwards, Eleanor Gillespie Strumolo, Caroline Cook Edwards, Courtney Matson Edwards--and six great-grandchildren--Noah, Walter, Henry, Jack, Sophie, and Lily--with all of whom she celebrated her 92nd birthday. Barbara Hartley Lord guided her family, relatives, and countless friends in their accomplishments, inspiring everyone to make the world a better place. All of them loved her deeply and will dearly miss her. God rest her blessed soul. A memorial service will be held in July at St. Andrew's Dune Church in Southampton. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to St. Andrew's Dune Church, St. John's Church in Southampton, or the J. Couper Lord, Jr., Dialysis Fund at Southampton Hospital. 1/3

HART--Norma J.,Passed away peacefully on April 23, 2016. She was born November 23, 1929 in New York City, where she lived her whole life. She was the daughter of the late David and Julia (Jarcho) Joseph and the sister of the late Arlene Ingerman. She was a strong believer in education and was proud to have obtained her college degree from Wellesley in an era when few women did so. She later earned an MA and M.Phil from NYU and a Psy.D from Yeshiva University. Dr. Hart worked for over 20 years as a school psychologist for the NYC Board of Education. Throughout her entire life she was a tenacious advocate for others, devoting herself to activities in both monolingual and bilingual general and special education, she was a delegate- member of the United Federation of Teachers and a founding member of two of their committees, Hispanic Affairs and Capably Disabled. She was a Member of the Board of the City Club of New York and directed the club's program interacting with city public high schools and colleges. She was a devoted single mother who raised her three sons Michael, Steven and Andrew on her own, and adored her two grandchildren Dylan and Molly. Norma will be remembered as a loving mother and grandmother, a loyal friend, and a person who dedicated herself to trying to make the world a better place for others. Those who knew her know how clearly she succeeded. She will be missed. Norma said that she would be honored if anyone wished to make a donation in her memory to the college or charity of their choosing. 1/3

von MEHREN--Robert B.,The last surviving lawyer in the infamous Alger Hiss trials of the late 1940s, died Thursday at his home in Manhattan from congestive heart failure, according to his wife, Susan Heller Anderson, a writer and former reporter for The New York Times. Mr. von Mehren was 93. As a young lawyer for the firm that is now Debevoise & Plimpton, Mr. von Mehren served on the defense counsel team representing Mr. Hiss, a highly regarded former government official, during his two trials for perjury in 1949 and 1950. Mr. Hiss, then president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, was told in August, 1948, that Whittaker Chambers, an editor at Time magazine, had testified before the Committee for the Investigation of Un-American Activities of the House of Representatives and had accused Hiss of being a spy for the Soviet Union while working for the U.S. government. Newspapers labeled the proceedings "the trial of the century." Richard M. Nixon subsequently became nationally famous for his pursuit of Communists, specially Mr. Hiss, and 20 years later, in 1968, was elected president. He revealed later, in the Watergate tapes, that he had mounted a systematic campaign of leaking information that would turn opinion against Hiss. Among the many positions Mr. von Mehren held outside the law firm were legal counsel to the Preparatory Commission of the International Atomic Energy Agency, which composed the guidelines for the United Nations' agency that exist today; consultant to the Rand Corporation on disarmament; consultant to the Hudson Institute on international law, and senior lecturer in law at the Wharton School. An active proselytizer of arbitration, Mr. von Mehren taught and lectured all over the world. He pioneered international arbitration among American lawyers, serving in more than four dozen arbitrations after he "retired" from Debevoise. His pro bono positions included chairman, vice chairman and/or president of the International Law Association, the Practicing Law Institute, the American branch of the International Law Association, several committees of the City Bar Association of New York and the Harvard Law School Association of New York. He was an honorary member of the Commercial Bar of London and the Singapore Bar. He was also on the board of the American Arbitration Association; a fellow of the American Bar Foundation; the vice-president emeritis of the Axe-Hougton Foundation, and a member of the Council on Foreign Relations, the Century Association and the University Club. Born in Albert Lea, Minn., he won a national scholarship to Yale University, from whence he graduated summa cum laude, then magna cum laude from the Harvard Law School, where he served as president of its Law Review. Upon graduation he became associated with Debevoise, where he spent most of his career until he became an international arbitrator. He clerked for Judge Learned Hand at the Second Circuit Court of Appeals and Supreme Court Justice Stanley F. Reed. An avid sailor, Mr. von Mehren raced his beloved Mariner Phalarope, on Martha's Vineyard, where he owned a home that he bought from James Cagney in 1957. In addition to his wife, Mr von Mehren is survived by his loving children: a son, Carl; three daughters, Katharine, Jane and Margaret, and Philip D. Anderson, his stepson. He was predeceased by his first wife, Mary Katharine; his younger son, John, and his identical twin, Arthur T. von Mehren. A celebration of his life is to be held in the fall in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made in his name to the Sherriff's Meadow Foundation, 57 David Ave., Vineyard Haven MA 02568. The family will receive friends at their Manhattan apartment 4pm-8pm on Sunday, May 8, and 6pm-8pm on Monday, May 9. 1/3

ESCOBAR--Marisol. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of this esteemed sculptor, who achieved early recognition as a "10th Street artist" in the '50s and the "queen of Pop Art" in the '60s and '70s. Her sculptures reflect gentle satire, understated humor and childlike directness. 1/3

Horrible Bear!By Ame Dyckman.Illustrated by ­Zachariah OHora. 40 pp. Little, Brown. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 6)
 
Dyckman and OHora (the team behind “Wolfie the Bunny”) specialize in full-spectrum emotion and offbeat charm, making a kid’s temper tantrum as fun as a theme park ride. Bear doesn’t mean to break the girl’s kite, but she is furious, clomping home proclaiming his horribleness. Bear’s enraged too. (The injustice!) Heading to her house for a fight, he’s met with contrition, and they patch it up. The art is a blast — even at her surliest, the girl will win smiles with her gigantic red curls.

WEINER--Walter H. The Trustees and staff of the Museum of Jewish Heritage - A Living Memorial to the Holocaust express profound sadness on the passing of Life Trustee Walter H. Weiner who was dedicated to the Museum's mission since its early years. Walter was an esteemed leader of numerous committees and a champion of Museum affiliates, JewishGen and the Auschwitz Jewish Center. We send our condolences to his wife, Nina, and to their entire family. Bruce C. Ratner, Chairman Elissa Schein, Deputy Director 1/3

Hurry Up, Alfie!Written and illustrated by Anna Walker. 32 pp. Clarion/Houghton Mifflin Harcourt. $14.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 6)
 
But for their giant snouts, scaly green skin and tails ­sticking out of their adorable clothes, the gentle, house-dwelling crocodile family we meet in this Australian import is utterly human. As little Alfie’s sweet mom tries to get him dressed, out the door and to the park, his ever-distractible ways will strike a chord with preschoolers and exhausted parents alike. (She’s an example to us all, never once baring her teeth.) Walker’s lovely illustrations mix soft watercolors and textile patterning.

COOKE--Bridget Birdsall, a noted specialist in teaching reading to children with learning disabilities, died in Sleepy Hollow, NY, on April 18. Ms. Cooke had studied and worked in the academic world in New York from her freshman year at Barnard College until four years ago, when she retired to Kendal on Hudson. She was 84 years old. Ms. Cooke was born in Boston, child of Paul Birdsall, a historian and U.S. foreign service officer, and Helen Grew Birdsall. Her older brother, Paul Birdsall, operates Horsepower Farm in Penobscot, Maine, a project where prospective farmers seek internships to live and farm there without electricity. After graduating from Milton Academy in Massachusetts and Barnard in 1953, Bridie, as she was known, worked as a secretary at the Columbia Graduate School of Journalism. She earned a master's degree and an Ed.D. at Yeshiva University in New York and began teaching at SUNY and CUNY, where she helped to prepare students for college work. Her career was principally invested in teaching and coaching struggling students in grade school and high school, first at the Ramaz Modern Orthodox School on the Upper East Side in New York and then, from 1987 to 2001, at Columbia Grammar and Preparatory on the Upper West Side. She also had an independent practice, and was widely sought by parents. She married twice and had no children. But her understanding of the young was strong. Margo Potter, the dean at Columbia Prep when Ms. Cooke was there, said, "She could reach children the way no one else could. She was the teacher they always came back to see after they had been graduated. She was much beloved." Rhoda Weyr of Boothbay, Maine, formerly a literary agent in New York, said that her daughter, Garret Freymann-Weyr, now a published author, had been led out of her youthful tangles with spoken and written language by Ms. Cooke. "Garret really loved her," Ms. Weyr said, "and when she came in the door problems began to lessen." Ms. Cooke retired from Columbia Prep in the summer of 2001. However, on September 11, she hurried back to the school to make sure that her pupils got home safely. "I just felt I had to be there for them, " she told an associate. Her marriages to Frank Pulliam and Jack Cooke, both of whom she met at Columbia, ended in divorce. Her sister, Jessie, died earlier. There is no funeral; she willed her body to medicine. A memorial service is being planned. 1/3

LESSER--Herb, in Houston, on May 5. Beloved husband of Linda (nee Farfel) for 55 years; father of Larry (Laurie Davis) and Lori (Daniel Shuchman); grandfather of Judah, Aaron and Ariela. Born in Ft. Worth, TX in 1937; Rice University, Fulbright Scholar and Princeton PhD in chemical engineering. Careers in energy (Exxon, Mitchell Energy) and finance (UBS). President of Seven Acres Jewish Senior Care Services. Loved travel, opera, museums, financial news, Houston sports teams (fair or foul weather), nature, math and science, dining with friends and entertaining his grandchildren. Amateur genealogist, photographer and astronomer; frequent search engine for Internet humor. Above all, a truly kind and decent man who enjoyed life. He will be sorely missed. Donations may be made to Seven Acres: sevenacres.org. 1/3

von MEHREN--Robert B. The Board of Trustees and staff of Practising Law Institute (PLI) mourn the passing of long time Trustee, Board Chairman, Executive Committee Chairman and Chairman Emeritus, Robert B. von Mehren. Robert was an active contributor to PLI, co-author of PLI's "American Arbitration: Principles and Practice", speaker at PLI programs and an ongoing supporter of continuing legal education. MICHEL--Ernest W. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Ernest W. (Ernie) Michel, a major historic figure whose powerful story of resilience and professional leadership left an enduring imprint on the Jewish people. A Holocaust survivor, Ernie devoted himself to Jewish communal service for over six decades. In 1947, he joined the staff of the United Jewish Appeal, where he served as its executive vice president from 1970-1989 and oversaw the merger that created UJA-Federation of New York. Ernie was the chairman of the World Gathering of Jewish Holocaust Survivors in Israel, bringing together 6,000 survivors and their families from across the world. He negotiated with the Mormon Church for the withdrawal from Church records of Jewish Holocaust victims posthumously baptized. An acclaimed author, lecturer, and visionary leader, Ernie kept his promise to bear witness and help the Jewish people worldwide. We extend our deepest condolences to Ernie's wife, Amy Goldberg Michel; his children, Lauren Shachar (Chaim), Joel Michel (Terry), Karen Daniels (Brian); his sister, Lotte Rein; his grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3

SCHLESSEL--Walter "Wally" (92). February 29, 1924 - May 6, 2016. Founder and principle of GemcoWare manufacturing, took the last exit after a full and loving life to fly to the moon and play among the stars. A prince of a man once nicknamed Duke. Quiet and quick-witted. Handsome and humble. He was a creator and a provider, a wholehearted husband and father - and a pretty snappy dresser! Principled, honest, kind and caring. A man of style and substance and of gentle strength and humor whose generosity and soul are etched into the hearts and minds of the many he touched throughout his long life. But none more so than his eternal flame and beautiful wife of 70 years, Marilyn - as well as his adoring sons, Derek and Bobby, his daughter-in-law Debbie and his cherished grandson, Ryan. His passing is an end- of-an-era loss. He will be missed till all he knew are gone. We honor him in memory of his departed son, Howard, his parents, Harry and Ceil, and his brother, Mel. Funeral services will be held at Gutterman Warheit Chappel 7240 North Federal Highway Boca Raton Monday, May 9 at noon. A graveside service will be held Wednesday at 11am at Beth Moses cemetery in New York. Donations can be made in his honor to the Howard Evan Schlessel Scholorship Foundation at National Jewish Hospital https://www.national jewish.org/help/ways-to-give/ tribute-gifts. 1/3
MICHEL--Ernest W. The Zises family mourns the loss of a great Jewish hero, leader and dear friend. Our condolences to Amy Goldberg Michel and the entire Michel Family worldwide. The Zises Family 1/3

WEINER--Walter. Banker Edmund Safra chose Walter Weiner as chairman of Republic Bank because of his careful judgement and accessibility to all. Walter was filled with optimism and a keen wit. He will never be forgotten by the many he helped. The Ekstract Family 1/3

HEISLER--Donald, 83 years old, died peacefully at home on May 6, 2016. Beloved husband of Deena. Devoted father of Rachel and Joel Sheinfeld, Abram Heisler and Riva Silverman and Eliot and Erica Heisler. Cherished and fun-loving grandfather of Gabrielle, Nathan, Shoshana, Naomi, Jacob, Adina, Amanda, James, Jason and Chloe. Respected dentist for over 50 years. President of Congregation Ohab Zedek in Belle Harbor. A kind and gentle man, beloved by all who knew him. Services 12 Noon on Sunday, May 8, 2016 at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (Opp. LIRR), Great Neck, NY. Interment to follow at Baron Hirsch Cemetery, Staten Island, NY. 1/3

MICHEL--Ernest W. Died peacefully at home in Manhattan, May 7, with his beloved wife, Amy Goldberg, by his side. Loving husband, father, grandfather, brother and uncle. Born July 1, 1923 in Mannheim, Germany. Survived six years in concentration camps including Auschwitz and Buchenwald. Organizing chairman of World Gathering of Jewish Holocaust Survivors. Author of "Promises to Keep." Devoted his life to serving the Jewish people through an extraordinary career for 60 years at UJA and as a mentor, educator, role model and inspiration to future generations. 1/3
