SLAVEN--Seymour, born August 13, 1923, died peacefully Sunday, May 8, 2016. Beloved husband of Marie Yvonne, father of Steven (Marcy), Arthur (Jane), the late Nadine Slaven, and Catherine Kohn (Adam); grandfather of Nicole Kaufmann, Stacee Silver Behar, David Slaven, Michael Slaven, Carly Silver Pearson, and Peter Slaven; great-grandfather of Sophya, Sasha, Sydney, Yoshua, Sloane, Charlotte and Anthony. Born in Brooklyn, New York, he attended Boys High School and served his country in the U.S. Army Air Corps during the Second World War. At the age of 25 he moved his family to Ponce, Puerto Rico, where he built a business, Ponce Pearl Corp., and in a few years became a pillar of the community. He was a founder of The Caribbean School and taught Spanish at the Catholic University. In 1963 he moved to Sands Point, New York. He headed Dickard Widder Industries until 1994 when he moved to Boca Raton, Florida. A renaissance man who lived life with great enthusiasm, he was a raconteur known for his sharp whit and great sense of humor. He was a respected businessman and advisor, spoke four languages, and was an avid reader. He played and enjoyed many sports and was an accomplished Bridge player. He was dearly loved by his family and friends and his memory will be forever cherished. Donations in his memory may be made to American Foundation for Suicide Prevention. Funeral services Wednesday, May 11, 2016, 2:30pm at B'nai Israel, 2200 Yamato Road, Boca Raton, FL. 1/3

BELFER--Norman. The American Society for Yad Vashem mourns the passing of Norman Belfer, an esteemed Founder of the Society, member of the Board and Guardian of Yad Vashem, Jerusalem. His commitment to Holocaust education and remembrance served as an inspiration to us all. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his wife Elinor and to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Leonard Wilf, Chairman Ron Meier, Executive Director 1/3
MICHEL--Ernest W. You were a rare human being - who left a noble legacy. We will always love you. Eugene and Emily Grant 1/3

GARFINKEL--Howard. Basketball legend, the Garf passed away peacefully on May 7, 2016 at the age of 86. Graveside service at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, Queens, NY on Tuesday, May 10 at 2pm. A celebration of his life will be held at Clyde's Frazier's (485 10th Ave.) on Friday, May 20 at 6pm (donation required), with funds going to a camp scholarship in Garf's name. Donations may be made to Five Star Foundation, 101 W. Jefferson St., Rockville, MD 20850. 1/3
MICHEL--Ernest W. The Zises family mourns the loss of a great Jewish hero, leader and dear friend. Our condolences to Amy Goldberg Michel and the entire Michel Family worldwide. The Zises Family 1/3

MILLER--Joseph R.,of Manhattan died peacefully at home May 8th at age 93 in the company of his family. A kind and gentle soul, Joe brightened the lives of all he knew. He was a loving and devoted husband to his wife Shelley and daughter Lesley and had loving relationships with his sister Perry and countless other family members and friends. Joe graduated from the University of Michigan and had a long, successful career in advertising sales. He was an avid traveler, an advocate of the arts and gave generously to causes he was passionate about. Joe created a lifetime of wonderful memories that will live eternally in our hearts. A memorial service will be held Riverside Memorial Chapel at 180 W. 76th St. in Manhattan on Thursday, May 12th at 5pm. 1/3
BRONFMAN--Judith, medieval scholar and political activist, died at 81. Memorial service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel Sunday, May 15 at 3pm. 1/3

KARETSKY--Dr. Alfred J. Died May 9th surrounded by his loving family at the age of 79. Beloved husband of Bernice for 57 years. Dear brother of Samuel and the late David. Devoted father of Marc (Melissa), Marcia Goldstein (Brian) and Gary (Holly). Grandfather of Jordan, Oliver and Paige Goldstein, Ethan and Ross Karetsky, Ryan, Zachary and Daniel Karetsky. A respected dentist for over 50 years. Basketball star at Stuyvesant High School and Lafayette College. He was loved by all who had the privilege to know him. Services 11:30am, Wednesday, May 11th at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, New York. 1/3

MICHEL--Ernest W. Died peacefully at home in Manhattan, May 7, with his beloved wife, Amy Goldberg, by his side. Loving husband, father, grandfather, brother and uncle. Born July 1, 1923 in Mannheim, Germany. Survived six years in concentration camps including Auschwitz and Buchenwald. Organizing chairman of World Gathering of Jewish Holocaust Survivors. Author of "Promises to Keep." Devoted his life to serving the Jewish people through an extraordinary career for 60 years at UJA and as a mentor, educator, role model and inspiration to future generations. 1/3

PHILLIPS--Joshua "Josh," of Brooklyn, New York and Highland Park, Illinois passed away on May 8, after a long illness at the age of 79. Josh was born December 15, 1936, in Brooklyn, New York to Eli and Hilda Phillips. Josh graduated from Williams College in 1957 and received his MBA from the University of Pennsylvania Warton School of Finance and Commerce in 1959. Josh is survived by Rheva Phillips nee Betensky, his wife of 54 years; their son Jason, his wife Janet and their daughter Elianna. Josh's greatest passion was his family. Josh was an avid traveler, a "foodie" before there ever was such a term, and a great dance partner. He will be profoundly missed. A Memorial Service will be held on Wednesday, May 11, at 2pm at Chicago Jewish Funerals, 8851 Skokie Blvd. (at Niles Center Road), Skokie, IL 60077. In lieu of flowers, memorials in his memory to a charity of your choice would be appreciated. Services being handled by Chicago Jewish Funerals-Skokie Chapel 847-229-8822, cjfinfo.com. 1/3

MICHEL--Ernest W. Selfhelp Community Services deeply mourns the passing of Ernest Michel, an extraordinary leader, visionary and tireless advocate for the needs of Holocaust survivors. Having lived through the terrors of the Holocaust, Ernie emerged to dedicate his life to serving the Jewish community. His work at the helm of UJA-Federation of New York was legendary and he was a steadfast friend and supporter of Selfhelp. As the largest provider of comprehensive services to Holocaust survivors in North America, Selfhelp's founders pledged to serve as the last surviving relative to victims of Nazi persecution. Ernie Michel exemplified this promise. He will be profoundly missed. We extend sincerest heartfelt condolences to Ernie's wife, Amy Goldberg Michel, his children, grandchildren, and the entire family. Raymond V.J. Schrag, President Stuart C. Kaplan, CEO 1/3

SKEIE--Andrew Francis, 72, a lifelong resident of Rutherford, NJ, passed away on May 7, 2016. Andrew served in the U.S. Navy during the Vietnam War. For over 25 years, he worked for The New York Times Delivery in Edison and retired as the Floorman in the delivery department with the Drivers Union. Prior, he was a bartender at the Cornerstone Inn in Carlstadt and the Wayne Manor. Beloved husband of the late Elizabeth B. (nee Pittari) Skeie. Loving father of Meredith M. Robinson and her husband Daniel. Cherished grandfather of Brigid, Katherine, Patrick, Eliza and Harley. Funeral departing from the Kimak Funeral Home, 425 Broad St., Carlstadt, NJ on Thursday, May 12, 9am for a Funeral Mass in Assumption Church, Wood-Ridge, NJ at 9:30am. Cremation will be private. Visitation Wednesday 2-4pm, 7-9pm. 1/3

HEISLER--Dr. Donald. American Friends of Soroka Medical Center extends their heartfelt condolences to our Executive Director, Rachel Heisler Sheinfeld and her family on the passing of her beloved father, Dr. Donald Heisler. Ken Abramowitz, Pres Caroline Freidfertig, Sec Ruth Steinberg, Tr 1/3

SCHATTEN--Ira. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Ira Schatten, who leaves behind a loving family to carry on a tradition of exceptional Jewish philanthropy. We extend our condolences to Ira's beloved wife, Alma; his siblings, Philip (Cheryl Fishbein) and Marlene Rosen (Jay); his children, Debbie Kadosh (Siman), Sandy Schatten, Rebecca Schneider (Scott) and Solomon (Bonnie); his grandchildren; his great- grandchild; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3
BAUM--Ann R.,82, of Sarasota, FL, formerly of White Plains, NY, died May 7, 2016. Services May 10 in Sarasota. Complete obit at hebrewmemorialfl.com 1/3

WEINER--Walter H. Consummate lawyer, banker and philanthropist. Founding member of Kronish Lieb Weiner & Hellman and former Chairman and CEO of Republic National Bank. Our partner, our client and our dear friend. We mourn his passing and extend our condolences to his dear wife Nina, his sons Tom and Jon, and his family. Cooley LLP 1/3

MICHEL--Ernest W. The Trustees and staff of the Museum of Jewish Heritage - A Living Memorial to the Holocaust express profound sadness on the passing of Trustee Emeritus and Holocaust survivor Ernest Michel. Ernie was a remarkable man who devoted his life to the Jewish community as a whole and the survivor community in particular. He was a great supporter of our Museum and a devoted Trustee. His vision and counsel will be deeply missed. Bruce C. Ratner, Chairman Elissa Schein, Deputy Dir. 1/3

ELLSWEIG--Barbara Mendler, November 24, 1932 to May 7, 2016. Survived by Robert Ellsweig, loving husband of 65 years, children Daniel, Debra and Lisa, grandchildren Andrew, Jessica, Julee, and Katherine, great-grandchildren River and Alice. You will be forever in our hearts. All services were held privately under the care of Martin Funeral Home, Clinton NJ . www.martinfh.com 1/3

FASHENA--Margaret "Peg" Wagner. (December 11, 1925-May 9, 2016). Patient wife, devoted, loving mother, formidable PTA leader, dedicated professional, staunch ally, savior of strays, wise counselor, and generous friend. Died peacefully after a sudden, short illness. A magnificent survivor with a kind heart, sharp eye, and a keen, independent mind. A graduate of New Jersey College for Women (Rutgers), she made her own way in publishing by intellect, dedication, and professionalism. A random meeting on July 14, 1949, introduced her to the love of her life, Sidney Fashena. They married in 1958 and she left her career in 1960 to devote herself to raising four children. She returned to work at Woman's Day magazine in 1975 and ultimately rose to Chief Production Editor before retiring in 1995. She served repeatedly as President of the Friends of the Mount Pleasant Public Library, staffing a book sale just eight days before her death. She survived the loss of her beloved Sidney in 2003 and of her younger sisters Henryetta and MaryFrances. She is survived by children David, Daniel, Sarah, and Jonathan; grandsons Zed and Aidan Fashena, Benjamin Coleman, and honorary granddaughter Victoria Joire, MaryFrances' granddaughter. Visitation will be held at the Beecher Flooks Funeral Home in Pleasantville, NY, (914) 769-0001, 7-9pm, Wednesday, May 11, and 9-10am Thursday, followed by a Celebration of Life, before she rejoins her husband in Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla. In lieu of flowers, please donate to your local ASPCA shelter. 1/3

SULLIVAN--Robert J.,age 86, of Cold Spring Harbor, NY, passed away peacefully May 8, 2016. Married to his beloved late wife Joan for 60 years, he is survived by daughter Kathleen and her partner Helen; son Robert and his wife Kandy, and son James and his wife Sara and their children Kira, Daniel and Sean. Born to Joseph and Kathleen (O'Connor) Sullivan in New York on May 7, 1930, he attended Bishop Loughlin High School and Queens College, graduating in 1957 after serving his country in the United States Air Force, where he rose to First Lieutenant. Magnetically handsome, intellectually gifted, and possessed of a sparkling wit, he also was exceptionally kind and generous, with a fierce love for and pride in his family. After obtaining a CPA, he worked at Price Waterhouse before going on to hold executive positions at American Express, Bush Universal, Warner Amex Cable and Cablevision. He joined the Board of LaborReady shortly after its founding in 1989, and served a long and successful tenure as Chairman of the Board, taking the company (now called TrueBlue) onto the NYSE and retiring only at age 81. An exceptional athlete, he won numerous golf trophies in his 37 years at the Huntington Country Club. His family is deeply grateful for the gift of his full and wonderful life. Visitation Thursday, May 12 2-4pm and 7-9pm at M.A. Connell Funeral Home, Huntington Station, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations in his honor may be made to Queens College, CUNY at: http://bit.ly/rsullivan 1/3

SLAVEN--Seymour, born August 13, 1923, died peacefully Sunday, May 8, 2016. Beloved husband of Marie Yvonne, father of Steven (Marcy), Arthur (Jane), the late Nadine Slaven, and Catherine Kohn (Adam); grandfather of Nicole Kaufmann, Stacee Silver Behar, David Slaven, Michael Slaven, Carly Silver Pearson, and Peter Slaven; great-grandfather of Sophya, Sasha, Sydney, Yoshua, Sloane, Charlotte and Anthony. Born in Brooklyn, New York, he attended Boys High School and served his country in the U.S. Army Air Corps during the Second World War. At the age of 25 he moved his family to Ponce, Puerto Rico, where he built a business, Ponce Pearl Corp., and in a few years became a pillar of the community. He was a founder of The Caribbean School and taught Spanish at the Catholic University. In 1963 he moved to Sands Point, New York. He headed Dickard Widder Industries until 1994 when he moved to Boca Raton, Florida. A renaissance man who lived life with great enthusiasm, he was a raconteur known for his sharp whit and great sense of humor. He was a respected businessman and advisor, spoke four languages, and was an avid reader. He played and enjoyed many sports and was an accomplished Bridge player. He was dearly loved by his family and friends and his memory will be forever cherished. Donations in his memory may be made to American Foundation for Suicide Prevention. Funeral services Wednesday, May 11, 2016, 2:30pm at B'nai Israel, 2200 Yamato Road, Boca Raton, FL. 1/3

MICHEL--Ernest W. The Yeshiva University family is deeply saddened by the loss of Ernie Michel, a beloved and cherished Jewish communal leader who committed his entire life to strengthen the Jewish community having lived and survived through the horrors of the Holocaust. Yeshiva University was extremely proud to bestow an Honorary Doctoral Degree upon Ernie to recognize his leadership to the Jewish community and to serve as a role model for our students. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus 1/3

RABKIN--Maxwell "Max" Jason, 27, passed on May 7, 2016 in Hollywood, FL. Max was born June 19, 1988 to Ronald and Melissa Rabkin. Max was raised in Montville, NJ. While still in high school, he worked as a Page in the U.S. House of Representatives and later interned at The White House and for the Office of Congressman Rodney P. Frelinghuysen. He graduated in 2010 from George Washington University. While living in Chicago and New York, Max spent the last few years pursuing a career in Capital Introduction at Societe Generale as well as other financial institutions. Max had a larger-than-life, passionate personality that was contagious to all who had the fortune of knowing him. His smile, humor and passion for life brought so much joy to his family and friends. Max is survived by his loving parents, Ronald and Melissa; devoted sister, Liza; beloved grandparents, Jerome, Joyce, and Pat. A memorial service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th Street in Manhattan on Thursday, May 12th at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, donations in Max's memory may be made to the Jewish United Fund of Metropolitan Chicago (JUF). 1/3

KARETSKY--Dr. Alfred J. Died May 9th surrounded by his loving family at the age of 79. Beloved husband of Bernice for 57 years. Dear brother of Samuel and the late David. Devoted father of Marc (Melissa), Marcia Goldstein (Brian) and Gary (Holly). Grandfather of Jordan, Oliver and Paige Goldstein, Ethan and Ross Karetsky, Ryan, Zachary and Daniel Karetsky. A respected dentist for over 50 years. Basketball star at Stuyvesant High School and Lafayette College. He was loved by all who had the privilege to know him. Services 11:30am, Wednesday, May 11th at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, New York. 1/3

McCAFFREY--Margaret A.,of East Setauket, NY on May 10, 2016 at the age of 74. Daughter of the late John and Anne (nee Bane) McCaffrey, born April 19, 1942 and raised in the Bronx, NY. MILLER--Joseph R.,of Manhattan died peacefully at home May 8th at age 93 in the company of his family. A kind and gentle soul, Joe brightened the lives of all he knew. He was a loving and devoted husband to his wife Shelley and daughter Lesley and had loving relationships with his sister Perry and countless other family members and friends. Joe graduated from the University of Michigan and had a long, successful career in advertising sales. He was an avid traveler, an advocate of the arts and gave generously to causes he was passionate about. Joe created a lifetime of wonderful memories that will live eternally in our hearts. A memorial service will be held Riverside Memorial Chapel at 180 W. 76th St. in Manhattan on Thursday, May 12th at 5pm. 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Martin. Martin was a valued friend to Isamu Noguchi, and by extension, to The Noguchi Museum. An inimitable spirit, he defined an era. TIEDEMANN--Carl Hans II, age 89, died peacefully on Saturday April 30, 2016 at his home in New York City. Born June 3, 1926 in Cleveland, Ohio to May Glenn and Carl Hans Tiedemann. At the age of three Carl lost his father in the midst of the Great Depression. His mother moved Carl and his sister Frances to Plainfield, New Jersey where she had family and a support system. Carl served in the Navy in World War II and he was forever a devout supporter and champion of America's greatness. Carl attended Phillips Exeter Academy followed by Trinity College in Hartford, Connecticut. He was the founder of the school's lacrosse program and later had the honor of being inducted into Trinity's Lacrosse Hall of Fame. After college, Carl began his professional career in sales at American Cyanamid, one of the nation's largest conglomerates at the time. While he honed his sales skills, he always had his eye on Wall Street and jumped at the chance to begin his career at Stone & Webster, a small brokerage firm. A few years later in 1962, when offered the opportunity to join a new firm, Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette (DLJ), he quickly accepted. After working his way up the ranks, in 1975 he took over as President until his departure in 1980 to start the Tiedemann Investment Group (TIG). Carl served on the boards of Alltel Corporation, Curtice Burns, Claremont Capital Corp, Dillon Read & Co., Nikko Securities International, Kleinwort Benson International, National Medical Care, Piedmont Management Company, Winrock International (a Winthrop Rockefeller Foundation), was a Trustee of the Allen-Stevenson school, and also served as a Governor of the American Stock exchange from 1969 to 1972. At TIG, Carl utilized his global network of contacts to source investment talent and provide financial backing and infrastructure to help build their hedge fund business. He loved finding talented individuals while giving them the opportunity to harness their entrepreneurial energy. Those efforts led to a variety of successful funds through the years, and a business that is still thriving 36 years later as one of the longest standing firms in the hedge fund industry. The company that was Carl's longtime dream to found was Tiedemann Trust Company, now known as Tiedemann Wealth Management (TWM). It was Carl's belief that families had been poorly served by large institutions "wrought with conflicts and inflexibility" for decades. This view was forged from his own family experience in dealing with a traditional trust bank. He wanted to build a trust company that could invest with the best and the brightest, but without any conflict or financial arrangement with the money managers. It was a simple concept, but one that was not being offered. This open architecture model is now the standard within the industry, as even the large institutions have had to pivot their business models to adapt to new competition from firms like TWM. As a leader, Carl was remarkably positive. In the face of the greatest challenges he would find a silver lining. He was the eternal optimist. His legacy is a unique one, and will live on through his two businesses, now larger and more institutional than at any point in his life, but with the same great culture he created. Carl is survived by his wife, Kari Jonassen Tiedemann. He is also survived by his four children, Hans Tiedemann of Santa Monica, CA; Mark Tiedemann of Los Angeles, CA; Leigh Tiedemann of Lexington, MA; Michael Tiedemann of New York, NY, and their respective spouses. Carl is also survived by 11 grandchildren. Carl was a member of the University Club, Maidstone Club, Link Club, River Club of New York, Doubles, Angler's Club, Tabusintac Club, Club at Windermere, Economic Club of New York, and Long Island Wyandanch Club. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, May 24, 2016 at 10:45am at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, 325 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10022. Instead of flowers, the family suggests a gift to The Tiedemann Family Scholarship Fund at the Middlesex School, 1400 Lowell Road, Concord, MA 01742. 1/3

ZAREMBSKI--Rose. Rose Goldberg was born in Warsaw, Poland in 1922. She was 17 years old when the Nazis invaded. Strong in spirit and in mind, she survived the Warsaw Ghetto and multiple concentration camps-the sole member of her family. After the war, she married a fellow survivor, Sam Zarembski in a Displaced Persons camp in Europe and the two moved to New York to start a new life. Rose used her many creative talents to find work as a seamstress, and became a member of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union. She had two children, Allan and Frieda. Rose went on to be a grandmother and later a great-grandmother. Rose's home was always filled with the smell and warmth of Jewish tradition, and today her legacy lives on through her recipes and her devoted family. 1/3

WEEKS--Robert Doughty Jr.,of Pelham, NY passed away on Tuesday, May 10th after a long battle with prostate cancer. He was 82 years old. Born in Manhattan to the late Robert Doughty and Marjorie Klehr Weeks, he was raised in Babylon, Long Island. He graduated from the Taft School and Duke University and served in the US Navy Pacific and Atlantic fleets retiring as Captain in the active reserves. Robert was a Senior Vice President at the Chase Manhattan Bank and later helped direct the opening of the New York offices for Credit Agricole, Sumitomo Bank, and Banque Arab et International d'Investissement, Paris. Mr. Weeks assisted the World Bank and US AID in the economic reconstruction of numerous former communist countries including Romania and Bosnia where he and his wife resided for many years. He was an avid traveler, sailor, skier, and choral singer. Robert leaves behind his beloved wife, Sarabeth, his cherished children Cynthia M. Lawlor and Robert D. Weeks III, Cynthia's husband William, Robert's wife, Susan, and his four dear grandchildren. Services will be held at Christ Church, 1415 Pelhamdale Ave., Pelham Manor, NY on Saturday, May 14th at 10:30am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Christ Church or Calvary Hospice, Bronx, NY. 1/3

AMIRAIAN--Adrienne, died peacefully at age 90, surrounded by her beloved family, on May 7, 2016. She was born in Bridgeport, Connecticut to Harold and Angele (Melkonian) Gevrekian and raised in Brooklyn, NY. She attended Brooklyn College prior to marrying the late Dr. Kenneth Amiraian. Together they enjoyed 63 wonderful years together as best friends and constant companions, sharing, celebrating and supporting each other through life's many journeys. Though always active in leadership roles in church and civic organizations, Adrienne's most cherished role was that of mother to her two sons, Dr. Richard Amiraian and Ronald Amiraian, who pre-deceased her. Her generosity of heart knew no boundaries. She was an outspoken advocate for the underprivileged, suffering and oppressed and always championed that which was right and fair. She will be deeply missed by all those she touched. In addition to her son, she is survived by his partner, Robert Pontarelli, and many loving nieces, nephews and great-nieces and nephews. Donations in celebration of Adrienne's life may be made to: The Ron- ald Amiraian Scholarship Fund, Union College, 807 Union Street, Schenectady, NY 12308. 1/3
BREGMAN--Dorothy. 3/20/1940 - 5/12/2013. Loved, remembered and very much missed. Abe 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Sidney, international entrepreneur, inventor, avid boater and sports fisherman, passed away on May 4, 2016 at the age of 83. Sidney was the son of the late Yetta and David Friedman, father of the late Dean and Andrew Friedman, and grandfather of Zane Friedman. Beloved companion to Harriet Harkavy. Brother to Harold, Leon, Barbara, and the late Paul, Florence and Edna; uncle to many loving nieces and nephews. Sidney, the founder and owner of Opsales, an innovator in the sunglass and optical field, was devoted to his longtime employees. He was a founding member of the Sunglass Association of America and a past President. Sidney lived between Oceanside, NY and Jupiter, FL, often aboard his boat the "Best Revenge". Donations in Sidney's memory may be made to Hadassah in Westfield, NY or Chabad of Oceanside, NY. 1/3

HANSEN--Joanne Cammett. December 11, 1934 - May 9, 2016. Predeceased by husband, Robert: June 23, 1934 - March 24, 2016. Survived by son Marc, sisters-in-law Janet Hansen and Sandi Cooper, and many nieces and friends. 1/3

LEHMAN--Wendy Vanderbilt, a New York artist whose work resides in the collection of the National Gallery of Art, died of heart failure Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 72. Known for her love of modernism, Wendy was greatly inspired by her mentors Georgia O'Keefe and O'Keefe's sister, Anita Young. Wendy's artistic expression spanned several mediums. Her work included extraordinary sculptures in wood and aluminum as well evocative paintings in acrylic and watercolor. In 2008, she was selected to be a part of The Dorothy and Herbert Vogel Collection: Fifty Works for Fifty States, which resulted in the placement of her work in museums across the country. Wendy was also blessed with a wry sense of humor. She was beloved for her vast and high-powered email list to which she posted everything from political commentary to dirty jokes. Always savoring a good laugh, she embraced her role as a social connector and loyal friend. There were few things Wendy appreciated more than spending time with her numerous and multifarious friends. Wendy was born in California to Manuela Hudson and Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt II, a pioneer in thoroughbred racing, whose father had gone down on the Lusitania. She grew up between Palm Beach and Manhattan. Wendy was featured in one of Lilly Pulitzer's first advertising campaigns and attended the Truman Capote Black and White Ball in 1966. Although she enjoyed the social circuit, Wendy chose to devote her time to her children and her art. In addition to her work as an artist, Wendy was a founding member of STOP: Stop Traffic Offenses Program, having witnessed a red light runner nearly kill a friend's child. A natural born tinkerer, in the 70s Wendy made her friends light dimmers out of margarine containers for Christmas. She spent countless hours working on benefits for institutions like the New York Studio School. Wendy was also a spirited member of both The Century Association and the Junior Fortnightly. After attending Sarah Lawrence College, Wendy was married the late Orin Lehman, New York State's longest-serving commissioner of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation. The couple had two daughters. They divorced in 1995. Wendy is survived by her three daughters, Brooke Lehman of Millerton, NY, Sage Lehman of Brooklyn, and Susan Lehman of Greenwich, CT; six grandchildren; and her companion, Bill Beermann. Mrs. Lehman's artistic creativity and passion for her family and friends was unparalleled. Her loyalty and brazen sense of humor will be dearly missed. 1/3
LEVINE--Noel. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and longtime friend, Noel Levine, and send condolences to his family. 1/3

CORSELL--Peter P.,passed away peacefully on Thursday, May 5, 2016, at Cornerstone Hospice Center in The Villages, Florida. He was 94. A native New Yorker resident in Florida since his retirement, Peter loved dancing, golf, pinochle, pasta aioli and his 1986 Mercedes. His sense of humor seldom failed and his deep appreciation and love for his many friends and his family never did. The son of Vincenzo and Luca Corsello, Peter grew up above the family's Italian bakery in Brooklyn, New York, where his father baked sweet Italian bread in a wood fired oven 365 nights a year. After WW II service as a gunnery instructor and in Army intelligence, Peter returned to New York to complete a construction/design program and work with Sonneborn & Sons, soon becoming the company's go to technical expert in waterproofing product applications. Peter pioneered the development of fluid applied membranes and other waterproofing solutions for masonry and curtain wall structures, first as president of Toch Brothers, a waterproofing company founded in the 1800's and later as president of his own consulting firm, Peter Corsell Associates. Projects to which Peter contributed included Chicago's Sears Tower and, together with the PCA team of architects and building engineers, the remediation of curtain wall failures at Boston's John Hancock Building and development of specifications designed to preserve landmark masonry buildings throughout the northeast, including New York's iconic Chrysler Building. Peter is survived by four children, three grandchildren and one great-grandson. The family is planning memorial services in New York City and The Villages later this year. 1/3

NEWMAN--Sydell (Schneiderman), died peacefully at age 100. Predeceased by beloved husband David and cherished sisters Doris Berkowitz and Jeanne Singer. Loved and admired by daughters Barbara (Bernard), Nancy (Henry); grandchildren Matthew (Gillian), Susan (Andrew), Benjamin, Adam (Shana), Justin (Alexa); great-grandchildren Sasha, Jane, Charlotte, David, Keira, Marie. Contributions in her memory can be made to her not-for-profit residence: Carnegie East House, c/o Joseph Girven, Director, 1844 Second Ave., NYC, NY 10128. 1/3
MICHEL--Ernest W. You were a rare human being - who left a noble legacy. We will always love you. Eugene and Emily Grant 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Martin. The Board of Trustees and staff of Madison Square Park Conservancy mourn the passing of our public art program's visionary and long-time member of Mad. Sq. Art's Art Committee. Martin played a pivotal role in the creation and shaping of Mad. Sq. Art and his guidance and leadership were critical to defining and executing our mission. He was an innovative museum director, friend and champion of artists, fierce advocate for public art, and a man who lived an extraordinary life. He challenged us to push the boundaries of public art, to commission and show thought-provoking and groundbreaking original sculpture by world class contemporary artists in historic Madison Square Park. His impact on artists was legendary and his clarity of purpose stretched to this art program with remarkable foresight for how public sculpture can impact people and serve as a catalyst for an artist's breakthrough. It was our great honor to have been the beneficiary of his great gift as a teacher and a friend. We extend our sympathies to his family. David Berliner, Chair; Keats Myer, Executive Director; Brooke Kamin Rapaport, Director and Martin Friedman Senior Curator 1/3

LEVINE--Noel. The Board of Directors and Staff of the American Friends of the Israel Museum, Jerusalem mourn the death of our dear friend and generous donor, Noel Levine. Noel's commitment to the Museum, was exceptional. He and his wife, Harriette, gifted one of the most comprehensive private collections of 19th century through classic modern photography, accompanied by an endowment for the Museum's Noel and Harriette Levine Department of Photography. We extend deepest condolences to the entire family. Stephen Lash and Judy Steinhardt, Board co-chairs, AFIM; Stacey Bronfman, President, AFIM; James Snyder, Anne and Jerome Fisher, Dir., IMJ; Leah Siegel, Exec Dir., AFIM 1/3

LEVINE--Noel. Noel Levine, Philanthropist, Photography Collector, Investor died Monday, May 9, 2016 at his home in New York City. He was 95. Mr. Levine, an avid collector of vintage 19th century and early modernist photographs and patron of the arts, was President of Troon Management Inc., a Real Estate and Equity Management firm in New York. Mr. Levine was the former Chairman and CEO of Associated Products. He was currently a Director of The Bank of Greenwich. Mr. Levine was Chairman Emeritus of the National Trustees of the National Symphony Orchestra, Washington D.C. Mr. Levine and his wife, Harriette gifted their Photography Collection as well as an endowment to the Israel Museum in Jerusalem. The endowment will support acquisitions, research, and exhibitions. The Israel Museum has renamed its photography department, The Noel and Harriette Levine Department of Photography. In addition to the Israel Museum, Mr. Levine had gifted photographic works to the Museum of Modern Art and the Metropolitan Museum, both of which have named galleries in his honor. Mr. Levine had participated in many charitable endeavors and had served as a board member and trustee to a number of cultural and arts institutions. He is survived by his wife, Harriette and their two daughters, Denise Saul and Caryn Harris, his sisters, Norma Shapiro and the late Myra Davis, three grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Funeral Services are private. 1/3

FISHMAN--Barry, age 57, died May 9 in Beaverton, OR. Survived by Bryan Kellogg, Charles, Nancy, Alexa and Kimberly Fishman. He was a retail business analyst at Columbia Sportswear. Beloved by all who knew him, he has left us far too soon. Funeral May 15, at 10am at the Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, Dobbs Ferry. 1/3

PERLMUTTER--Leila Herman, 79. Adored wife of Alfred and mother of Wayne, Chaya, Raina, Dann, and Donna. Adoring grandmother of Cassandra, Ethan, Alisa and Shmuel. Thomas Jefferson High School and Adelphi University (BS and MSW). Longtime psychotherapist at New York City-based social agencies and in private practice on Long Island. Moved with her husband to Israel in 2010. Burial Sunday, May 15, 11:30am, Eretz Hachaim Cemetery, Bet Shemesh. Shiva in Jerusalem, where Leila often joyfully exclaimed, "Another beautiful day in Jerusalem." 1/3

RATNER--Michael. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Michael Ratner, who leaves behind a loving family who carry on a tradition of exceptional Jewish philanthropy. We extend our condolences to Michael's beloved wife, Karen Ranucci; his siblings, Bruce and Ellen; his children, Jake and Ana; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3

LEVINE--Noel. The Officers, Board of Directors, shareholders and staff of 660 Park Avenue mourn the passing of their former President, friend and neighbor. Noel served as President of the building from 1982 until recently. His unstinting service to his neighbors, his kindness and unfailing courtesy earned him the respect and affectionate regard of all who worked with him. Heartfelt condolences to his wife, Harriette, and their family. 1/3

FRANKEL--Leonard, age 90, formerly of Port Washington, NY passed away on Wednesday, May 11, 2016. Leonard is survived by his beloved wife of 60 years Eve, as well as his loving sons Robert (Mary Ann) and Richard (Geri), and his cherished grandchildren Jason, Rebecca, Justin (Amanda), Joshua and Gregory. Leonard was a proud graduate of the Bronx High School of Science, and obtained his Bachelor's Degree from New York University. May his memory be eternal. Funeral services will be held graveside on Sunday, May 15, 2016, commencing at 1:30pm at the Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, NY. (www.IJMorrisDixHills.com). 1/3

PARISH--Lawrence J.,86, of Millbrook, NY and Block Island, RI, died on May 11th surrounded by his loved ones. Larry will be remembered for his kindness, sharp wit, and his insatiable desire to learn. He was an avid woodworker, collector of antiques, and a true Renaissance man. Larry graduated from Horace Mann School, Syracuse University and Downstate Medical Center. Some of his best memories were his years in the Air Force as a flight surgeon stationed in Anchorage, AK. Following this, he moved to New York and practiced dermatology for 40 years. Larry grew up in New York, the son of Molly and Mitchell Parish. Mitchell Parish was a lyricist whose songs include "Stardust," "Deep Purple," "Sophisticated Lady," and "Sleigh Ride." Larry is survived by his sister, Ruth, his beloved wife, June, and their children Karen (Ted), Susan, Wendy, Jamie, David and two grandchildren, Max and Jack. 1/3

SHEFFIELD--Margaret, 77, died in her NYC apartment on April 30th, ending her courageous battle with Alpha 1 Antitrypsin Deficiency, a genetic disorder that led to her crippling lung disease. After attending the Brearley School and graduating from Milton Academy and Smith College, she received her MA in English literature at New York University. Throughout her impressive career, Margaret taught literature and writing at varied institutions of higher learning, especially enjoying her unique courses at Bard College. Her many accomplishments demonstrated her creativity and her love for the arts and literature. A teacher, writer, editor, and arts critic, Margaret's diverse art and cultural essays were published in numerous art journals. Her major book, The Expressive Edge, is an analysis of form in sculpture that came out in 2010, and The Blue Tibetan Poppy, a collection of her poems and watercolors, was published in 2015. She spent most of her life in NYC, but loved to travel and spent six years living in Italy. Margaret was actively involved in her club, the Century Association. In 1981 she married Piero Mannoni; they separated in 1993. She is survived by her siblings, Jim and Ann, and her step-daughters Francesca and Alessandra. Margaret, and her charming whimsy, will be greatly missed by her family, her wide circle of friends, and her beloved dog Giorgio. A private Memorial Service will be held on June 14. For details: jimsheff@gmail.com. Margaret asked that contributions be made to Alpha 1.org, the non-profit organization dedicated to finding a cure for her disease. 1/3

LEVINE--Noel. We note with sorrow the passing of our longtime member Noel Levine and extend sincerest condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Angela W. Buchdahl, President Abigail Pogrebin, Central Synagogue of New York City 1/3

SAFRAN--Shirley D. Shirley D. Safran, died suddenly May 3, 2016 of a heart attack at 85 years old. She was the beloved wife of Rick Safran, mother of Jessica and Elizabeth, grandmother of Emma and Raphael, and mother-in-law of Andreas. Shirley was a lifelong New Yorker and a graduate of Music and Art High School, Brooklyn College, with a B.A. in Speech and Theater, and Hunter College, with an M.A. in English. An award-winning student actress, she continued acting after graduation as a member of Actors' Equity, SAG, and AFTRA. Her work ranged from nightclub singing at the famous Bricktop's in Rome, to musical theater and movie voiceovers. She moved on from acting to become a high school English teacher at Art & Design High School and adjunct lecturer in Communication Arts and Skills at New York City Community College in Brooklyn. Shirley directed Art & Design's school plays and coached the debate team, who under her guidance became New York City high school champions. She received the MIT Inspirational Teacher Award, awarded by MIT Alumni Association to exceptional high school educators, after being nominated by a former student who attended MIT. Shirley was an active member and strike veteran of the New York City United Federation of Teachers and was also a passionately engaged member of the Jane Austen Society of North America and local New York Chapter. For several years Shirley was also a theater critic for CurtainUp.com, an Internet theater magazine where she covered New York City and the Berkshires. Shirley was a positive, sustaining, and vibrant presence in many lives. We will miss her radiant, welcoming smile, her discerning intellect, her general elegance, and her fierce devotion to her friends and family. We love you, Shirley. "You pierce my soul." 1/3

MALLARD--Henry Clay, M.D.,age 70 of New York City passed away peacefully at home on Monday, May 9, 2016. Dr. Mallard is survived by his beloved wife, Laura Osinoff Mallard, his brother and sister-in-law George and Susie Mallard, his niece Stephanie and his son Jeremy. Dr. Mallard was southern-born and educated in Alabama and Arkansas. He came to New York City in the early 70's and trained at Harlem Hospital and St. Luke's Roosevelt. Dr. Mallard served as a training and supervising analyst at New York Psychoanalytic Society and Institute, and as a psychiatric consultant to the Episcopal Diocese of New York and as Medical Director at SPOP. He also had a private practice in Manhattan. He inspired others as a teacher, supervisor, analyst, and colleague. His intellect, clinical acumen, sly humor, dedication, and strength of character will be deeply missed. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, May 15, 12 noon at "The Riverside," 76th Street at Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made in Henry Mallard's honor to New York Psychoanalytic Society & Institute, www.nypsi.org, or to Calvary Hospice, www.calvaryhospital.org, and National Institute for the Psychotherapies, www.nipinst.org. 1/3
IDONE--Christopher. Celebrated chef and culinary author, died April 15, 2016. Contributions: God's Love We Deliver Cookbook -- GLWD.org. 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Martin. The Board of Trustees and staff of Madison Square Park Conservancy mourn the passing of our public art program's visionary and long-time member of Mad. Sq. Art's Art Committee. Martin played a pivotal role in the creation and shaping of Mad. Sq. Art and his guidance and leadership were critical to defining and executing our mission. He was an innovative museum director, friend and champion of artists, fierce advocate for public art, and a man who lived an extraordinary life. He challenged us to push the boundaries of public art, to commission and show thought-provoking and groundbreaking original sculpture by world class contemporary artists in historic Madison Square Park. His impact on artists was legendary and his clarity of purpose stretched to this art program with remarkable foresight for how public sculpture can impact people and serve as a catalyst for an artist's breakthrough. It was our great honor to have been the beneficiary of his great gift as a teacher and a friend. We extend our sympathies to his family. David Berliner, Chair; Keats Myer, Executive Director; Brooke Kamin Rapaport, Director and Martin Friedman Senior Curator 1/3

DORFMAN--Adeline, age 88, passed away on Wednesday, May 11, 2016. Adeline was a great mother, sister, aunt, mother-in-law, grandmother, great-grandmother and friend. She gave special love to all of us. Grave service will take place on Sunday, May 15, 2016 at 10am at Mount Lebanon Beth Israel Cemetery, 78-00 Myrtle Ave, Glendale, NY 11385. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Temple Emanuel, 150 Hicks Lane, Great Neck, NY 11024 to Rabbi's Discretionary Fund. 1/3

RATNER--Michael. It is with great sorrow that we join the Ratner family in mourning the loss of our dear friend Michael Ratner. Michael had a lifelong commitment to social justice and was a champion for those who did not have one. He defended the rights of suspects held without judicial review and worked to end wholesale stop and frisk policies in New York City, among many other causes. He was a brilliant civil liberties attorney and a beloved brother, husband, father and friend to many. He will be greatly missed. MaryAnne Gilmartin Forest City Ratner 1/3

SLOANE--Robert Benedict DDS, of Manhattan died peacefully at his home on May 10, 2016 at the age of 98. Bob was born in Brooklyn, NY on January 4, 1918 to David Lewis Sloane, DDS, and Sarah Kanterman Sloane and was preceded in death by his brother Theodore S. Sloane of Palm Beach, Florida. A graduate of James Madison High School, Class of 1938, Bob enrolled in a two-year accelerated college program at Alfred University prior to graduating NYU College of Dentistry in 1942. He started his dental practice in his father's office after coming home from World War II in 1946 after four years of service. He conducted a very successful practice in reconstructive dentistry on 69th Street across from his beloved Central Park. Bob brought a meticulous and artistic eye to his work, which was much admired by his patients and professional colleagues. An innovative thinker and problem solver, he embraced new technologies well into his 90s, staying engaged with life and the people around him, including grandchildren who helped keep him young. A wonderful storyteller with a keen sense of humor, he was easily able to engage those around him. Always an artist at heart, Bob reveled in many hours painting in his studio after finally retiring from dentistry in 1995 at age 79. He had an infectious charm and children were mesmerized by his magic tricks. His sense of fun was highly attuned as was his intellectual curiosity. He is survived by his wife of 46 years, Ann, and their children, Margaret of Washington DC, and Douglas and his wife, Esther, of New York, NY and two daughters by his first marriage to the former late Joan Lahm, Carol and her partner, Jim Bowers, of Maine, Adrienne of Massachusetts as well as grandsons, Asa Oines, Alex and Oliver Sloane of New York, NY; and Nicholas G.B. Sloane of Washington, DC. A memorial reception for friends and family will be held at Frank E. Campbell's Funeral Home on Saturday, May 14th from 2:30-4:30pm. Donations in Bob's memory may be made to the Central Park Conservancy in lieu of flowers. 1/3

RATNER--Michael. The trustees and staff of BAM mourn the passing of Michael Ratner, beloved brother of Bruce C. Ratner, BAM Board Chairman Emeritus. We extend our sincerest condolences to Bruce and his family. Chairman Alan H. Fishman, President Emerita Karen Brooks Hopkins. 1/3

de MICHIELL--Robert Lawrence, Jr. A Celebration of Life will be held on Sunday, May 15 at New World Stages, 340 W. 50th Street, New York, with a cocktail reception from 5pm to 7pm, and a tribute presentation at 7pm. Robert passed away October 12, 2015 in Manhattan after a three year battle with cancer. He was one of the most prolific commercial illustrators of his time, with a distinctive style that was synonymous with sophisticated New York City-based entertainment and culture. His work appeared frequently in the New York Times, The New Yorker (including the cover in March, 1993), Entertainment Weekly, and Premiere Magazine's "If You Ask Me" column for 12 years. Additionally, he created signature art for many Broadway and Off-Broadway shows, including "Oliver" (1984), "The Wind and the Willows" (1985), "Arsenic and Old Lace" (1986), "The Most Fabulous Story Ever Told" (1998) and "La Cage aux Folles" (2004), as well as numerous posters for Broadway Cares/Equity Fights Aids, including the organization's annual Easter Bonnet, Gypsy of the Year, Nothing Like a Dame, Broadway Flea Market and Broadway Barks events. His illustrations have appeared in The Wall Street Journal, Readers Digest, TV Guide, Hartford Courant and hundreds of newspapers and magazines around the country. His corporate work includes images for American Express, Absolut Vodka, and many others. He married Jeffrey M. Wilson on March 25, 2012, and their wedding was profiled in the New York Times. He is also survived by his mother Nan DeMichiell; sisters Gail DeMichiell and Lynn Lynch and her husband Brian, of Waterford, CT; nephews Matthew Lynch of Waterford and David Lynch of New York City; niece Jessica Harran of Waterford; uncles Ronald DeMichiell of Waterford and Dr. Bernard F. McEvoy and his wife Barbara of Schenectady, NY and his cousins. His father, Robert DeMichiell, Sr., passed away in 2014. Donations can be made in Robert's name to The Actors Fund, 729 Seventh Ave., New York, NY, 10019 or to Calvary Fund (Calvary Hospital Hospice), 1740 Eastchester Rd., Bronx, NY 10461. 1/3

HERZ--William, Jr.,gentleman of the theatre, last surviving participant of the War of the Worlds broadcast and world class curmudgeon passed away Tuesday, May 10 a few months shy of his 100th birthday. His last years were made easier by the loving care he received from Beverly and Maria. He will be missed by his friends for his wry judgements and contrary opinions. His stories about living in Orson Welles' spare bedroom, dating Babes in Arms' soubrette Mitzi Green, dining with Pierre Monteux or Jed Harris or frequently leaving his ticket office next to Sardi's to hear Mary Martin "raise the temperature of the theater" while singing about her wonderful guy, made 20th century theatrical history palpable. 1/3

EXSTEIN--Louis "Buddy" H.,born December 14, 1924, died May 12, 2016. Beloved husband of Barbara Marks, and predeceased by his first wife Babs, passed away peacefully at Sharon Hospital in Connecticut, on May 12. He was the fond father of Michael and Ted and their respective spouses Lida and Patti. He doted on his five grandchildren: Jeremy, Adam, Isabel, Max, and Benjamin in addition to his second wife Barbara's daughters Shelia (Roy), Nancy (Jimmy), and nephew Gerry (Patti). He is survived by his sister Theza and many loving nieces and nephews. He was dearly loved and will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Buddy proudly served in the United States Army Air Corps during World War II and in the Air Force during the Korean War. He was an accomplished Certified Public Accountant, beginning his career at Touche, Ross and served as the Vice President at Schober Organ, and CEO of Youth and Men's Fashion Guild in New York City. Buddy was also a long time member of the International Chinese Snuff Bottle Society, serving on its board. A memorial service will be held at Schwartz Brothers Jeff Memorial Chapel, Forest Hills, on May 15 at 2pm. Buddy's remains will be interred at Arlington National Cemetery. 1/3

MALLARD--Henry. The NY Psychoanalytic Society & Institute mourns the loss of our esteemed member Henry Clay Mallard, M.D. His intellect, clinical acumen, clear-sightedness, quiet humor, devotion, and extraordinary character will be sorely missed. He gave selflessly to others as a teacher, supervisor, analyst, colleague, as a TA at NYPSI, a psychiatric consultant to the Episcopal Diocese of New York and Medical Director at SPOP. He is survived by his loving wife, Laura Osinoff Mallard. Donations in his honor can be made to New York Psychoanalytic Society & Institute, nypsi.org, or to Calvary Hospice, calvaryhospital.org. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, May 15, 11:30am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W 76th St. 1/3

LITSKY--Harold, on May 12, 2016. Captain, NYPD (Retired), graduate US Merchant Marine Academy, decorated merchant mariner for his bravery during the Murmansk Run, Chevalier of the Legion d'honneur for his participation in the liberation of France during WWII. Predeceased by Betty, his loving wife of 60 years. Survived by his children, Andy, Eric (Norma), Amy Brachfeld (Alan) and Tom (Rosemary). His beloved Sylvia. Devoted grandfather to Jason (Michelle), Jonathan (Marlee), Robert Litsky, Justin and Melissa Brachfeld, Alexandra (Stephen) Billick and Drew (Maria) Taylor. Proud great grandfather of Emerson and Grant Litsky and Zoe Taylor. Funeral services at noon, Sunday, May 15, Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made in his honor to the Southern Poverty Law Center or the social action organization of your choice. 1/3

RATNER--Michael Columbia Law School is deeply saddened by the loss of our distinguished alumnus Michael Ratner, a pioneering civil liberties attorney and passionate advocate for human rights around the world. Michael was an influential mentor and colleague to many members of our community for decades. He will be missed, but his legacy will live on for generations. We extend our condolences to his wife, Karen Ranucci; his children, Jake and Ana; his brother, Bruce Ratner; and his sister, Ellen Ratner. 1

SLOANE--Robert Benedict DDS, of Manhattan died peacefully at his home on May 10, 2016 at the age of 98. Bob was born in Brooklyn, NY on January 4, 1918 to David Lewis Sloane, DDS, and Sarah Kanterman Sloane and was preceded in death by his brother Theodore S. Sloane of Palm Beach, Florida. A graduate of James Madison High School, Class of 1938, Bob enrolled in a two-year accelerated college program at Alfred University prior to graduating NYU College of Dentistry in 1942. He started his dental practice in his father's office after coming home from World War II in 1946 after four years of service. He conducted a very successful practice in reconstructive dentistry on 69th Street across from his beloved Central Park. Bob brought a meticulous and artistic eye to his work, which was much admired by his patients and professional colleagues. An innovative thinker and problem solver, he embraced new technologies well into his 90s, staying engaged with life and the people around him, including grandchildren who helped keep him young. A wonderful storyteller with a keen sense of humor, he was easily able to engage those around him. Always an artist at heart, Bob reveled in many hours painting in his studio after finally retiring from dentistry in 1995 at age 79. He had an infectious charm and children were mesmerized by his magic tricks. His sense of fun was highly attuned as was his intellectual curiosity. He is survived by his wife of 46 years, Ann, and their children, Margaret of Washington DC, and Douglas and his wife, Esther, of New York, NY and two daughters by his first marriage to the former late Joan Lahm, Carol and her partner, Jim Bowers, of Maine, Adrienne of Massachusetts as well as grandsons, Asa Oines, Alex and Oliver Sloane of New York, NY; and Nicholas G.B. Sloane of Washington, DC. A memorial reception for friends and family will be held at Frank E. Campbell's Funeral Home on Saturday, May 14th from 2:30-4:30pm. Donations in Bob's memory may be made to the Central Park Conservancy in lieu of flowers. 1/3

MALLARD--Henry Clay, M.D.,age 70 of New York City passed away peacefully at home on Monday, May 9, 2016. Dr. Mallard is survived by his beloved wife, Laura Osinoff Mallard, his brother and sister-in-law George and Susie Mallard, his niece Stephanie and his son Jeremy. Dr. Mallard was southern-born and educated in Alabama and Arkansas. He came to New York City in the early 70's and trained at Harlem Hospital and St. Luke's Roosevelt. Dr. Mallard served as a training and supervising analyst at New York Psychoanalytic Society and Institute, and as a psychiatric consultant to the Episcopal Diocese of New York and as Medical Director at SPOP. He also had a private practice in Manhattan. He inspired others as a teacher, supervisor, analyst, and colleague. His intellect, clinical acumen, sly humor, dedication, and strength of character will be deeply missed. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, May 15, 12 noon at "The Riverside," 76th Street at Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made in Henry Mallard's honor to New York Psychoanalytic Society & Institute, www.nypsi.org, or to Calvary Hospice, www.calvaryhospital.org, and National Institute for the Psychotherapies, www.nipinst.org. 1/3

LeFRAK--Ethel. February 1, 1920 -May 14, 2013 Grace was in all her steps, Heaven in her eye, in every gesture, dignity and love. She loved people. And all loved her. Her daily prayer was simply doing good. You are so loved and so missed, Denise and Family 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Sidney, international entrepreneur, inventor, avid boater and sports fisherman, passed away on May 4, 2016 at the age of 83. Sidney was the son of the late Yetta and David Friedman, father of the late Dean and Andrew Friedman, and grandfather of Zane Friedman. Beloved companion to Harriet Harkavy. Brother to Harold, Leon, Barbara, and the late Paul, Florence and Edna; uncle to many loving nieces and nephews. Sidney, the founder and owner of Opsales, an innovator in the sunglass and optical field, was devoted to his longtime employees. He was a founding member of the Sunglass Association of America and a past President. Sidney lived between Oceanside, NY and Jupiter, FL, often aboard his boat the "Best Revenge". Donations in Sidney's memory may be made to Hadassah in Westfield, NY or Chabad of Oceanside, NY. 1/3

EXSTEIN--Louis "Buddy" H.,born December 14, 1924, died May 12, 2016. Beloved husband of Barbara Marks, and predeceased by his first wife Babs, passed away peacefully at Sharon Hospital in Connecticut, on May 12. He was the fond father of Michael and Ted and their respective spouses Lida and Patti. He doted on his five grandchildren: Jeremy, Adam, Isabel, Max, and Benjamin in addition to his second wife Barbara's daughters Shelia (Roy), Nancy (Jimmy), and nephew Gerry (Patti). He is survived by his sister Theza and many loving nieces and nephews. He was dearly loved and will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Buddy proudly served in the United States Army Air Corps during World War II and in the Air Force during the Korean War. He was an accomplished Certified Public Accountant, beginning his career at Touche, Ross and served as the Vice President at Schober Organ, and CEO of Youth and Men's Fashion Guild in New York City. Buddy was also a long time member of the International Chinese Snuff Bottle Society, serving on its board. A memorial service will be held at Schwartz Brothers Jeff Memorial Chapel, Forest Hills, on May 15 at 2pm. Buddy's remains will be interred at Arlington National Cemetery. 1/3

HILL--Edward A.,45, of Washington, DC, beloved husband of Jessica Zufolo, passed away on Sunday, May 1, 2016 at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington, DC of stage IV Metastatic Esophageal cancer. Ed started his career in health care policy working as an aide for Senator Chris Murphy's first congressional campaign. Following Murphy's campaign, Ed dedicated his life and career to public service. He helped elect President Barack Obama working tirelessly as a field organizer in several states during the 2008 campaign. Ed also had a distinguished nine-year career as a senior legislative aide in the U.S. House of Representatives, where he served on the staffs of both Congressman Peter DeFazio (D-OR) and Congressman Ruben Hinojosa (D-TX). While in Congress, Ed worked on the development and passage of the Affordable Care Act. Ed also played a pivotal role in advocating for America's microbreweries through his management of the bipartisan Congressional Small Brewers Caucus, which today boasts 207 members of Congress. Most recently, Ed was a lobbyist for Association of Marriage and Family Therapists. Ed was deeply loved and cherished by his wife and two dogs, Hopper and Stewie. His lovable personality and hilarious sense of humor brought tremendous joy to everyone who knew him. Thank you Ed for being my partner and best friend. I will miss you. 1/3

HARPER--Thomas Patrick, died peacefully at home on May 12, 2016. Employed by New York City's Human Resources Administration, Thomas was the beloved son of the late Eugene and Muriel. He was the loving brother and brother-in-law of Eugene (Joanne), James (Mary) Robert (Sascha), Gerard, Daniel (Kate) and Mary (Dennis Hagan). He was predeceased by his brothers, Lawrence and William. Adored by nieces and nephews, Elizabeth, Jessica, Ginger (Tom), Katie, Joe, Timothy (Catie), Sarah (Kieran), Amanda, Julia, Caitlin, Tess, Kerry, Mike, Pete, and Chris, and by beloved grand-nephew, Timmy and grand- niece, Siena. Visitation on Monday, 2-8pm at Redden's Funeral Home, 325 West 14th St., NYC. Mass of Christian burial Tuesday, 10:30am, St. Mary's Chapel, 26 Leonardville Rd., Middletown, NJ. Donations to Holy Apostle Church, Soup Kitchen, 296 Ninth Avenue, New York 10001 in lieu of flowers. 1/3

MOSER--Judith S.,86, of Pawlet, VT, died May 13, 2016 at the Rutland Regional Medical Center. She was born July 8, 1929 in West Orange, NJ, the daughter of Charles Lewis and Anna (Toomey) Schweinler. The widow of Harry V. Moser, Jr., she graduated from Convent of the Sacred Heart in Greenwich, CT and Trinity College in Washington, DC. She is survived by her children, M. Chris Moser of Little Falls, NJ and M. Beth Moser-Duquette and husband, Raymond, Sr. of West Pawlet, VT; two grandchildren, McKayla M. Kashner and Nicholas V. Kashner. Instead of a gathering funeral, her family and friends are asked to go to their own worship places and express their gratitude to God for all the amazing people that God put in her wonderful life to give her all the support and care through the years; and the truth, goodness and beauty God has shown her. She also asks for prayers for her children and grandchildren that God would meet their needs. Mrs. Moser was predeceased by a son, Henry V. Moser III. Private burial will be held in Restland Memorial Park in East Hanover, NJ. Memorial contributions may be made to Rutland Area Visiting Nurse Association & Hospice, 7 Albert Cree Drive, Rutland, VT 05701, or Carmelite Monastery, 189 Madison Avenue, Morristown, NJ 07960. Services are under the direction of Tossing Funeral Home. 1/3

OBERMAYER--Herman. Herman "Obe" Obermayer, loving husband, father, grandfather, great-grand- father, and friend, died peacefully in his sleep on May 11 at his home in Arlington, VA. He was 91. He was married for 58 years to the love of his life, Betty Nan L. Obermayer, who passed away in 2013. Mr. Obermayer's rich life spanned the worlds of journalism, publishing, and politics in both the United States and abroad. He was owner and publisher of the Long Branch (New Jersey) Daily Record from 1957 to 1971 and of the Northern Virginia Sun from 1963 to 1989, and he lived in the Washington area since 1971. He counseled newspapers in emerging democracies for the U.S. State Department from 1990 to 2002 in Hungary, Poland, Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia, Ukraine, Moldova, Slovenia, Macedonia, Russia, Croatia, and Serbia. He also wrote several significant books: "Soldiering for Freedom: A GI's Account of World War II" about his experiences as a U.S. Army soldier in the European Theatre, published in 2005; "Rehnquist: A Personal Portrait of the Distinguished Chief Justice of the U.S." about his friendship with the renowned justice, a 2009 work that was translated into Chinese and became a best seller in China; and Jews in the News: British and American Newspaper Articles about Jews 1665 through 1800. Additionally, he donated his collection of 3,100 original newspaper articles to the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington. While publisher of the Northern Virginia Sun, he wrote a weekly column about his life, politics, and philosophy. In 1983 and 1984, he served as a judge for the prestigious Pulitzer Prize. Obe Obermayer was born in Philadelphia on September 19, 1924 where he graduated from Central High School. He graduated cum laude from Dartmouth College in 1946 and was an English major, studying under the poet Robert Frost. His college years were interrupted by World War II, during which he served as a Staff Sergeant in the European Theatre from 1943-1946 and was awarded the Rhineland Campaign Star. He attended the Nuremberg Trials. As a teen, he became an Eagle Scout and as an adult, he was a member of the Executive Council of the Monmouth County (New Jersey) Boy Scout Council from 1958 - 1971 and on the Executive Committee of the National Capital Council of the Boy Scouts of America from 1971 - 1979. He also worked with the Jewish Policy Center and served on the National Board of the Jewish Institute for National Security Affairs (JINSA) since 1996 and the National Council of the American Jewish Committee (AJC). From 1989 to 2006, he was on the board of Commentary, a monthly magazine focused on religion, Judaism, politics, social and cultural issues. Mr. Obermayer was an active member of many other clubs and organizations, including Temple Rodef Shalom (Falls Church, VA), the Washington Golf & Country Club (Arlington, VA), Cosmos Club (Washington, D.C.), Mont Pelerin Society, National Press Club (Washington, D.C.), Dartmouth Club (New York City), Rotary Club, and Sigma Chi. He is survived by his four daughters, Helen Levy-Myers of Reston, VA, Veronica Atnipp of Houston, Adele Malpass of New York City, and Elizabeth Weintraub of Rockville, MD.; 11 grandchildren; and one great- granddaughter. A Memorial Service will take place at Temple Rodef Shalom, 2100 Westmoreland St., Falls Church, Va., on Tuesday, May 17 at 10:30am. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Temple Rodef Shalom or the Folger Shakespeare Library. 1/3
SEIDEMAN--Abby Rachel. Nov. 18, 1974 - May 15, 2012 Years of love lost. Mom, Dad and Wendy 1/3
MICHEL--Ernest. A noble man who dedicated his life to the Jewish people and Israel. He will be missed. Norman Jacobson & Family 1/3

HOROWITZ--Estelle Meislik. July 31, 1919 - May 13, 2016. Treasured mother of Janice Horowitz Bookstaber and Bert Horowitz, grandmother to Michael and Daniel Horowitz and Anna Bookstaber. Beloved and admired for her strength, compassion and devotion to educators' rights. Estelle was Professor of Economics at Pratt Institute, founding President of its teacher's union and head of the United Federation of College Teachers. Our bright light of inspiration and fortitude, Estelle led with her intellectual acumen, ethics and heart. She survived her husband Sidney, and siblings Jules, Morris, Sidney, Harry, and Anne. Estelle passed away peacefully in her home. 1/3

Henry was a long time staff member and a well respected colleague, teacher, advisor, and friend. Our deepest condolences to his wife Laura Osinoff Mallard and his family. 1/3
SCHWARTZ--Ellen. Gone three years, but with us every day. Michael, Liza, Alyson & Joseph 1/3

SIDEL--Ruth (Grossman), of New York, NY on Thursday, May 12, 2016. For 60 years, the loving wife of Dr. Victor W. Sidel. Cherished mother of Mark Sidel and his wife Margaret Raymond and Kevin Sidel and his wife Inge. Loving grandmother of Andrew, Rosemary and Theodora. Beloved sister of the late Jerome and Edgar Grossman. Ruth Sidel was Professor of Sociology at Hunter College from 1978-2012. She is the author of numerous books and articles about the impact of poverty on women and children and the need for a comprehensive U.S. family policy and lectured worldwide on these issues. Graveside services at Temple Ohabei Shalom Cemetery, 147 Wordsworth Street, East Boston, MA on Friday, May 20, 2016 at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to The Research Foundation of CUNY for WRI (Welfare Rights Initiative), Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10065. 1/3
RATNER--Michael. Michael Ratner's unique combination of moral outrage and creative lawyering will be sorely missed. Cora and Peter Weiss 1/3

ROTHCHILD--Herbert. Herbert Rothchild, lifelong New Yorker, passed away on October 27, 2015 in the company of his children. His beloved wife Florence, to whom he had been married for 67 years, predeceased him by two days. He is survived by his daughters Betsy Lessans (Jay), Barbara Waxman (Richard), Jane Rothchild (Adell Donaghue), grandsons Steven Lessans (Stacey), David Oshry, and Philip Lessans, and great-granddaughter Sophia Lessans. He is also survived by his brother Joseph, his sisters-in law Shirley, Ellen and Gloria, and many nephews, nieces and friends. Herb was born in Borough Park on December 27, 1921 to Philip and Yetta (Fisch). He attended yeshiva in Brooklyn, and was a graduate of Bernard Baruch College of the City of New York. He considered his greatest achievements in life to have been his family, his Army service during World War II in the Signal Corps as a cryptographer, his successful business career with his brother, Joe, in the family business, Rothchild Printing Company, and his passionate support for the State of Israel through his work with the United Jewish Appeal. He was loyal and devoted to the people he loved, and he inspired loyalty and devotion in others. Herb maintained friendships with his employees and professional colleagues well after he retired. Herb loved to travel and he loved fly-fishing, particularly on the Snake River in Wyoming. He and Florence enjoyed opera, classical music, and theater, and supported New York institutions devoted to them all. He was an avid reader of anything related to Civil War history and Abraham Lincoln. He can best be described as an authentic man of integrity who was modest and had a great sense of humor. He was fond of a good dirty limerick, especially those he penned himself. We miss him. Donations in his memory may be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinsons Research or to the New York Public Library. 1/3

LEVITHAN--Robert "Bobby". On May 13, 2016, peacefully at home. Beloved brother, uncle, great-uncle, cousin, nephew, friend, partner, adviser, and counselor. Born in Manhattan, he was raised in Englewood, New Jersey, graduated with a BA in History at the University of Pennsylvania and earned an MA in Transformational Counseling from Southwestern College. While a committed New Yorker, he also spent considerable time in Italy, Venezuela, Brazil and Santa Fe and travelled extensively. His varied experiences included dancing in the movie "Hair" for Twyla Tharp, and performing with Robert Wilson. He also co-produced the first productions of Eve Ensler's The Vagina Monologues, One Man Band and Word of Mouth. His true calling was as an AIDS and LGBT activist and as a psychotherapist. For many years he facilitated groups and lead workshops, nationally and locally, including at Friends In Deed, where he was Co-Chair of the Board for seven years. He was a regular contributor to The Huffington Post and other popular sites, and his writings were collected into his well- received book, the "New 60: Outliving Yourself and Reinventing a Future." To his family and friends, Bobby's greatest gift was his capacity to be forever caring, giving, vibrant and loving, and to live and face challenges courageously and with grace. His special circle of friends provided him with extraordinary caring and love during his last battle with pancreatic cancer. He will be sorely missed by his two brothers and wives, Allen and Beth and Jack and Roberta, his loving nieces, nephews, grand-nieces and grand-nephews, dear cousins, aunts, brothers and sisters- in-law, and many friends. A memorial service will be held on May 22 at 2pm at Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY 10023. 1/3
