Leaves behind her loving husband, Zen, who gave her hope and made her smile until the end, and her many caring family members and friends. Services are private. For those who would like to make a donation in her honor, (in lieu of flowers), Babs family has chosen Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Dr. Raajit Rampal, Leukemia Group. http://giving.mskcc.org/ ways-give 1/3

LEHMAN--Wendy Vanderbilt. A New York artist whose work resides in the collection of the National Gallery of Art, died of heart failure Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 72. Known for her love of modernism, Wendy was greatly inspired by her mentors Georgia O'Keefe and O'Keefe's sister, Anita Young. Wendy's artistic expression spanned several mediums. Her work included extraordinary sculptures in wood and aluminum as well evocative paintings in acrylic and watercolor. In 2008, she was selected to be a part of The Dorothy and Herbert Vogel Collection: Fifty Works for Fifty States, which resulted in the placement of her work in museums across the country. Wendy was also blessed with a wry sense of humor. She was beloved for her vast and high-powered email list to which she posted everything from political commentary to dirty jokes. Always savoring a good laugh, she embraced her role as a social connector and loyal friend. There were few things Wendy appreciated more than spending time with her numerous and multifarious friends. Wendy was born in California to Manuela Hudson and Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt II, a pioneer in thoroughbred racing, whose father had gone down on the Lusitania. She grew up between Palm Beach and Manhattan. Wendy was featured in one of Lilly Pulitzer's first advertising campaigns and attended the Truman Capote Black and White Ball in 1966. Although she enjoyed the social circuit, Wendy chose to devote her time to her children and her art. In addition to her work as an artist, Wendy was a founding member of STOP: Stop Traffic Offenses Program, having witnessed a red light runner nearly kill a friend's child. A natural born tinkerer, in the 70s Wendy made her friends light dimmers out of margarine containers for Christmas. She spent countless hours working on benefits for institutions like the New York Studio School. Wendy was also a spirited member of both The Century Association and the Junior Fortnightly. After attending Sarah Lawrence College, Wendy was married the late Orin Lehman, New York State's longest-serving commissioner of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation. The couple had two daughters. They divorced in 1995. Wendy is survived by her three daughters, Brooke Lehman of Millerton, NY, Sage Lehman of Brooklyn, and Susan Lehman of Greenwich, CT; six grandchildren; and her companion, Bill Beermann. Mrs. Lehman's artistic creativity and passion for her family and friends was unparalleled. Her loyalty and brazen sense of humor will be dearly missed. 1/3

SAFRAN--Shirley D. Shirley D. Safran, died suddenly May 3, 2016 of a heart attack at 85 years old. She was the beloved wife of Rick Safran, mother of Jessica and Elizabeth, grandmother of Emma and Raphael, and mother-in-law of Andreas. Shirley was a lifelong New Yorker and a graduate of Music and Art High School, Brooklyn College, with a B.A. in Speech and Theater, and Hunter College, with an M.A. in English. An award-winning student actress, she continued acting after graduation as a member of Actors' Equity, SAG, and AFTRA. Her work ranged from nightclub singing at the famous Bricktop's in Rome, to musical theater and movie voiceovers. She moved on from acting to become a high school English teacher at Art & Design High School and adjunct lecturer in Communication Arts and Skills at New York City Community College in Brooklyn. Shirley directed Art & Design's school plays and coached the debate team, who under her guidance became New York City high school champions. She received the MIT Inspirational Teacher Award, awarded by MIT Alumni Association to exceptional high school educators, after being nominated by a former student who attended MIT. Shirley was an active member and strike veteran of the New York City United Federation of Teachers and was also a passionately engaged member of the Jane Austen Society of North America and local New York Chapter. For several years Shirley was also a theater critic for CurtainUp.com, an Internet theater magazine where she covered New York City and the Berkshires. Shirley was a positive, sustaining, and vibrant presence in many lives. We will miss her radiant, welcoming smile, her discerning intellect, her general elegance, and her fierce devotion to her friends and family. We love you, Shirley. "You pierce my soul." 1/3
GINIGER--Bernard B. October 1922 - May 2015 In loving memory of Gig- raconteur par excellence. You are always in our thoughts and our hearts. Your Loving Family 1/3

SANDVED--Kjell Bloch, naturalist, lecturer, filmmaker, and photographer for the Smithsonian Institution Museum of Natural History, and discoverer of the Butterfly Alphabet, died at his home in Washington, on December 20, 2015. The cause of death was dementia. He never married. He is survived by a brother and many nieces and nephews in Norway. Mr. Sandved was born October 20, 1922, in Strandebarm, in the Hardangerfjord, where his father, Alf Michael Bloch Sandved, had become the district physician. Kjell's mother loved to play the piano, instilling in him an appreciation for classical music. After taking courses in Arts and Natural History at UiO, Mr. Sandved saw a great need for a music encyclopedia. He was the publisher and author of two encyclopedias -- one on Classical Music and one on Classical Art, subsequently revised and edited for 10 different countries. The books, Musikkens Verden and Kunstens Verden, were richly illustrated, with African mahogany covers -- a worldwide success. In the spring of 1960, as a visiting researcher gathering materials for his encyclopedia of natural history at the SI, he discovered a silvery letter "F" in the delicate design of a butterfly wing. It was the beginning of his search for all letters of the alphabet on the wings of butterflies. He put aside plans for the encyclopedia, stayed in Washington, taught himself photography and customized a portable microscope and electronic camera gear. He visited more than 30 countries to discover all the letters of the alphabet on the wings of butterflies. His quest for the alphabet took him through the United States, and tropical rain forests and islands around the world. Mr. Sandved became the Smithsonian Museum of Natural History's first full-time nature photographer. He traveled the world with leading researchers for nearly three decades, capturing the beauty and diversity of nature. He started his business, Butterfly Alphabet, Inc., in 1993, after he retired from his 32- year career at the Museum of Natural History. In his posters, prints and his classic children's book, Butterfly Alphabet, Kjell Sandved has shared with the world -- particularly with children -- his unique ability to see meaning in the tiniest details. The different Butterfly Alphabets have now become the most distributed educational nature posters in the U.S. Over a million of his colorful Butterfly Alphabet posters now grace homes and schools everywhere. He co-authored nine books of nature photography -- four on butterflies, and other books on insects, shells, rain forests, leaves and bark. Kjell Sandved's Butterfly Alphabet and nature images have been displayed at the Kennedy Center and in museums around the world and have appeared in many publications including Smithsonian Magazine and National Geographic. Mr. Sandved always brightened every space he entered with his joy and enthusiasm for life, discovery and love. 1/3

PATTERSON--Patricia S. Venetian Heritage mourns the loss of its founding board member Patricia S. Patterson. Her loyalty to us and love of Venice were exemplary. We will all miss her greatly. Pierre Durand, Chairman and President Mrs. Donald K. Miller, Vice Chairman 1/3

ZAREMBSKI--Rose. Rose Goldberg was born in Warsaw, Poland in 1922. She was 17 years old when the Nazis invaded. Strong in spirit and in mind, she survived the Warsaw Ghetto and multiple concentration camps-the sole member of her family. After the war, she married a fellow survivor, Sam Zarembski in a Displaced Persons camp in Europe and the two moved to New York to start a new life. Rose used her many creative talents to find work as a seamstress, and became a member of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union. She had two children, Allan and Frieda. Rose went on to be a grandmother and later a great-grandmother. Rose's home was always filled with the smell and warmth of Jewish tradition, and today her legacy lives on through her recipes and her devoted family. 1/3
IDONE--Christopher. Celebrated chef and culinary author, died April 15, 2016. Contributions: God's Love We Deliver Cookbook -- GLWD.org. 1/3

WAXMAN--Alan N.,60, of Manhattan, died after a brief illness. He was born in Akron, Ohio, and graduated from the University of Akron in 1977. He moved to New York that year to study at Columbia Law School, where he became a Harlan Fiske Stone Scholar and received a letter of commendation from Ruth Bader Ginsburg, his Constitutional Law professor. He joined the firm Squire, Sanders & Dempsey in Cleveland in 1980 and practiced public finance law before moving to New York in 1984 to begin a career in corporate and securities law. He became a partner of the firm in 1989 and spent the next 27 years representing his clients with distinction at the now Squire Patton Boggs. Alan especially relished his role as legal counsel to the Federal Home Loan Banks and the Musicians Emergency Fund, both of which he served for more than 30 years. He is survived by his wife of 32 years, Val Castronovo; daughter Olivia B. Waxman; sisters Barbara Miller, Arlene Bass (Ron), and Harriet Waxman; five nieces and nephews; and seven grand-nieces and grand-nephews. Alan was an Ohio boy who loved New York City. Contributions in his memory can be made to the New York Public Library. 1/3
KEYBL--Jaroslav. Born November 11, 1927, passed away on May 11, at his home in Flushing, NY. Czech journalist, manager at Lufthansa and lifelong learner. Survived by his wife Marie and two sons. 1/3

MUELLER--John Cochran, 80, of New York City, died on January 21, 2016. A memorial service celebrating his life will be held at Church of the Incarnation, 209 Madison Avenue (at 35th St.) Wednesday, May 18, 2016, at 4pm. 1/3

HERZ--William, Jr.,gentleman of the theatre, last surviving participant of the War of the Worlds broadcast and world class curmudgeon passed away Tuesday, May 10 a few months shy of his 100th birthday. His last years were made easier by the loving care he received from Beverly and Maria. He will be missed by his friends for his wry judgements and contrary opinions. His stories about living in Orson Welles' spare bedroom, dating Babes in Arms' soubrette Mitzi Green, dining with Pierre Monteux or Jed Harris or frequently leaving his ticket office next to Sardi's to hear Mary Martin "raise the temperature of the theater" while singing about her wonderful guy, made 20th century theatrical history palpable. 1/3

RATNER--Michael. It is with great sorrow that we join the Ratner family in mourning the loss of our dear friend Michael Ratner. Michael had a lifelong commitment to social justice and was a champion for those who did not have one. He defended the rights of suspects held without judicial review and worked to end wholesale stop and frisk policies in New York City, among many other causes. He was a brilliant civil liberties attorney and a beloved brother, husband, father and friend to many. He will be greatly missed. MaryAnne Gilmartin Forest City Ratner 1/3

RASHBAUM--Lynn P.,died at her home in Riverdale, NY on April 27, surrounded by her family. She was 91 years old. Lynn worked as a psychotherapist and social worker in Manhattan for roughly two decades. She grew up in Birmingham, AL, and moved to New York City after studying opera and classical music at Bennington College. In 1956, she married Dr. William K. Rashbaum, with whom she had two children. They divorced in 1972; he died in 2005. A courteous graceful woman with an easy smile, her keen intelligence, curiosity and desire to help others led her to three masters degrees, in teaching, psychology and social work. She is survived by her daughter, Sara Lyn Phillips, her granddaughter, Isabel K. Phillips, her son, William K. Rashbaum Jr., and his wife, Christian L. Wright. A Memorial Service will be May 22 at 3:45pm at the Fourth Universalist Society at 160 Central Park West in Manhattan. 1/3
COOPER--Henry S.F.,Jr. The family of Henry S.F. Cooper, Jr., invites you to a celebration of his life on Thursday, May 26 at 5pm at The Century Association at 7 West 43rd Street, New York. 1/3

KOZLIK--Judith. May 11, 2016. Judy was a funny, tough and generous lady who loved her family and her hometown of New York City. She will be missed by all who had the good fortune to know her, but most dearly by her daughter Arlene and son-in-law Charlie whom she loved with all of her heart. Rest in peace Mom. 1/3

LITSKY--Harold, on May 12, 2016. Captain, NYPD (Retired), graduate US Merchant Marine Academy, decorated merchant mariner for his bravery during the Murmansk Run, Chevalier of the Legion d'honneur for his participation in the liberation of France during WWII. Predeceased by Betty, his loving wife of 60 years. Survived by his children, Andy, Eric (Norma), Amy Brachfeld (Alan) and Tom (Rosemary). His beloved Sylvia. Devoted grandfather to Jason (Michelle), Jonathan (Marlee), Robert Litsky, Justin and Melissa Brachfeld, Alexandra (Stephen) Billick and Drew (Maria) Taylor. Proud great grandfather of Emerson and Grant Litsky and Zoe Taylor. Funeral services at noon, Sunday, May 15, Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made in his honor to the Southern Poverty Law Center or the social action organization of your choice. 1/3

GREEN--Alice, beloved wife of Stanley, mother of David, Douglas and Ronald, grandmother to Andrew, Joshua, Ashley, Matthew and Kevin. A Rehabilitation Counselor, she lived across the country from Brooklyn, Philadelphia and Pittsburgh to Palo Alto. A lover of laughs, Indian art, the Southwest, travel and all things chocolate. 1/3

SHEFFIELD--Margaret, 77, died in her NYC apartment on April 30th, ending her courageous battle with Alpha 1 Antitrypsin Deficiency, a genetic disorder that led to her crippling lung disease. After attending the Brearley School and graduating from Milton Academy and Smith College, she received her MA in English literature at New York University. Throughout her impressive career, Margaret taught literature and writing at varied institutions of higher learning, especially enjoying her unique courses at Bard College. Her many accomplishments demonstrated her creativity and her love for the arts and literature. A teacher, writer, editor, and arts critic, Margaret's diverse art and cultural essays were published in numerous art journals. Her major book, The Expressive Edge, is an analysis of form in sculpture that came out in 2010, and The Blue Tibetan Poppy, a collection of her poems and watercolors, was published in 2015. She spent most of her life in NYC, but loved to travel and spent six years living in Italy. Margaret was actively involved in her club, the Century Association. In 1981 she married Piero Mannoni; they separated in 1993. She is survived by her siblings, Jim and Ann, and her step-daughters Francesca and Alessandra. Margaret, and her charming whimsy, will be greatly missed by her family, her wide circle of friends, and her beloved dog Giorgio. A private Memorial Service will be held on June 14. For details: jimsheff@gmail.com. Margaret asked that contributions be made to Alpha 1.org, the non-profit organization dedicated to finding a cure for her disease. 1/3

FREEDMAN--Ralph. died in Decatur, Georgia, on May 5th, after a brief illness. Freedman was born on February 24, 1920 in Hamburg, Germany. A Jewish refugee, he emigrated to England in early 1939, and the United States in 1940. In 1941, he entered the army where he served as an intelligence officer and saw combat in Tunisia and at the invasion of Sicily and, finally, in the forward unit of 5th Army Headquarters in Italy. Upon his return, Ralph wrote a novel based on recollections of his brief post-war service in counter-intelligence in Austria, Divided (1948) which earned him the Lewis & Clark Northwest Award offered by E.P. Dutton in 1947 (unlike his first novel which he had flung into the Thames River in London). After graduating from the University of Washington, Ralph received an M.A. in philosophy from Brown and Ph.D. in Comparative Literature from Yale in 1953. A revision of his dissertation The Lyrical Novel was published by the Princeton University Press in 1963. He later went on to publish biographies of Hermann Hesse (Pilgrim of Crisis, 1978) and Ranier Maria Rilke (Life of a Poet, 1996). His work has been translated into German, Italian, French, Korean, Spanish and Chinese. Freedman taught at the University of Iowa, was for many years a mainstay of the Comparative Literature Department at Princeton, and ended his career at Emory University. He was was unfailingly loyal to his friends and generous to his students, who loved him as much as he loved them. He survived the Nazis, the World War, McCarthyite America, the 60s, Reagan and Bush, all of whom he spent much time bemoaning; he wrote on Rilke, Hesse, Woolf and novel theory with old world knowingness and New World wonder. He sired three children, Jonathan of Ann Arbor, Michigan and Mark of New York, New York, and Ruth Ellen who died in 1966. His surviving children and his six grandchildren all miss him a ton. 1/3

PATTERSON--Patricia. Patricia Shephard Patterson, passed away peacefully in Palm Beach, Florida surrounded by her loving family on Mother's Day, May 8th following a long illness. She was born in San Francisco on June 29th, 1925. Shortly after graduating from Stanford University in 1947, Patricia and her sister, Geraldine, moved to New York City. In 1958 she married Bruce A. Norris, owner of the Detroit Red Wings. Together they had a daughter, Wendy Norris, who they cherished. They divorced in 1967. In April, 1970 she married Herbert Patterson, then President of Chase Manhattan Bank. In the late 1970's Patricia began a long and esteemed career in Real Estate. As Vice President of Sotheby's International Realty in Manhattan she was a top producer. Clients became friends, her friends became clients and her career turned into her passion. Pat actively and continuously dedicated herself to making the world a better place for others. She worked tirelessly with boards, commissions and volunteer organizations. She was noted for her work as a Board Member of The Boys Club of New York, The School of American Ballet, International Committee of the Museum of Modern Art, The Venetian Heritage, The Central Park Conservancy, The Junior League and The Parish Art Museum. Traveling the world was one of Patricia's many passions. She loved exploring museums, galleries, cathedrals and diverse cultures. She was a passionate collector and supporter of the arts. Her most precious memories were the times she was able to share her life's journeys with friends and family. She was an avid sportswoman, proficient in many sports. Pat spent many happy days competing at her favorite Clubs, including The Meadow Club, Lyford Cay Club and the Everglades Club. Weekends were always spent either enjoying lunch on the porch at The Bathing Corporation or Sunday night dinners at Piping Rock. Holidays were spent at The Colony Club and The River Club. Patricia Patterson is survived by her daughter Wendy Norris Grant and her grandson Bruce Norris Grant. She was predeceased by her sister Geraldine Shephard. Patricia Patterson's funeral will be private. A Memorial will be held in New York City in September and Palm Beach in the winter. An announcement will follow. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in her memory to The Boys Club of New York, The School of American Ballet, The Central Park Conservancy, and The Venetian Heritage. 1/3

SIMPSON--Anne Vickery, on March 10, 2016. The Yorkville Community Association deeply mourns the passing of Anne who administered masterfully their charity event for over 40 years. Heartfelt condolences to daughters Marcia Brose and Diane Tompkins. Mrs. Frederick A. Parker, President 1/3

TIEDEMANN--Carl Hans II, age 89, died peacefully on Saturday April 30, 2016 at his home in New York City. Born June 3, 1926 in Cleveland, Ohio to May Glenn and Carl Hans Tiedemann. At the age of three Carl lost his father in the midst of the Great Depression. His mother moved Carl and his sister Frances to Plainfield, New Jersey where she had family and a support system. Carl served in the Navy in World War II and he was forever a devout supporter and champion of America's greatness. Carl attended Phillips Exeter Academy followed by Trinity College in Hartford, Connecticut. He was the founder of the school's lacrosse program and later had the honor of being inducted into Trinity's Lacrosse Hall of Fame. After college, Carl began his professional career in sales at American Cyanamid, one of the nation's largest conglomerates at the time. While he honed his sales skills, he always had his eye on Wall Street and jumped at the chance to begin his career at Stone & Webster, a small brokerage firm. A few years later in 1962, when offered the opportunity to join a new firm, Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette (DLJ), he quickly accepted. After working his way up the ranks, in 1975 he took over as President until his departure in 1980 to start the Tiedemann Investment Group (TIG). Carl served on the boards of Alltel Corporation, Curtice Burns, Claremont Capital Corp, Dillon Read & Co., Nikko Securities International, Kleinwort Benson International, National Medical Care, Piedmont Management Company, Winrock International (a Winthrop Rockefeller Foundation), was a Trustee of the Allen-Stevenson school, and also served as a Governor of the American Stock exchange from 1969 to 1972. At TIG, Carl utilized his global network of contacts to source investment talent and provide financial backing and infrastructure to help build their hedge fund business. He loved finding talented individuals while giving them the opportunity to harness their entrepreneurial energy. Those efforts led to a variety of successful funds through the years, and a business that is still thriving 36 years later as one of the longest standing firms in the hedge fund industry. The company that was Carl's longtime dream to found was Tiedemann Trust Company, now known as Tiedemann Wealth Management (TWM). It was Carl's belief that families had been poorly served by large institutions "wrought with conflicts and inflexibility" for decades. This view was forged from his own family experience in dealing with a traditional trust bank. He wanted to build a trust company that could invest with the best and the brightest, but without any conflict or financial arrangement with the money managers. It was a simple concept, but one that was not being offered. This open architecture model is now the standard within the industry, as even the large institutions have had to pivot their business models to adapt to new competition from firms like TWM. As a leader, Carl was remarkably positive. In the face of the greatest challenges he would find a silver lining. He was the eternal optimist. His legacy is a unique one, and will live on through his two businesses, now larger and more institutional than at any point in his life, but with the same great culture he created. Carl is survived by his wife, Kari Jonassen Tiedemann. He is also survived by his four children, Hans Tiedemann of Santa Monica, CA; Mark Tiedemann of Los Angeles, CA; Leigh Tiedemann of Lexington, MA; Michael Tiedemann of New York, NY, and their respective spouses. Carl is also survived by 11 grandchildren. Carl was a member of the University Club, Maidstone Club, Link Club, River Club of New York, Doubles, Angler's Club, Tabusintac Club, Club at Windermere, Economic Club of New York, and Long Island Wyandanch Club. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, May 24, 2016 at 10:45am at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, 325 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10022. Instead of flowers, the family suggests a gift to The Tiedemann Family Scholarship Fund at the Middlesex School, 1400 Lowell Road, Concord, MA 01742. 1/3

FISHMAN--Barry, age 57, died May 9 in Beaverton, OR. Survived by Bryan Kellogg, Charles, Nancy, Alexa and Kimberly Fishman. He was a retail business analyst at Columbia Sportswear. Beloved by all who knew him, he has left us far too soon. Funeral May 15, at 10am at the Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, Dobbs Ferry. 1/3

LANCHNER--Carolyn, died peacefully at home on May 14th, surrounded by family members. They and her many devoted friends will miss her terribly. A distinguished curator of painting and sculpture at The Museum of Modern Art for over 20 years, she was a fiercely independent woman of sharp intellect, large mind, and a profoundly generous spirit. She died after a short, intense struggle with cancer. Memorial service details will follow. 1/3

FREEDMAN--Ralph. died in Decatur, Georgia, on May 5th, after a brief illness. Freedman was born on February 24, 1920 in Hamburg, Germany. A Jewish refugee, he emigrated to England in early 1939, and the United States in 1940. In 1941, he entered the army where he served as an intelligence officer and saw combat in Tunisia and at the invasion of Sicily and, finally, in the forward unit of 5th Army Headquarters in Italy. Upon his return, Ralph wrote a novel based on recollections of his brief post-war service in counter-intelligence in Austria, Divided (1948) which earned him the Lewis & Clark Northwest Award offered by E.P. Dutton in 1947 (unlike his first novel which he had flung into the Thames River in London). After graduating from the University of Washington, Ralph received an M.A. in philosophy from Brown and Ph.D. in Comparative Literature from Yale in 1953. A revision of his dissertation The Lyrical Novel was published by the Princeton University Press in 1963. He later went on to publish biographies of Hermann Hesse (Pilgrim of Crisis, 1978) and Ranier Maria Rilke (Life of a Poet, 1996). His work has been translated into German, Italian, French, Korean, Spanish and Chinese. Freedman taught at the University of Iowa, was for many years a mainstay of the Comparative Literature Department at Princeton, and ended his career at Emory University. He was was unfailingly loyal to his friends and generous to his students, who loved him as much as he loved them. He survived the Nazis, the World War, McCarthyite America, the 60s, Reagan and Bush, all of whom he spent much time bemoaning; he wrote on Rilke, Hesse, Woolf and novel theory with old world knowingness and New World wonder. He sired three children, Jonathan of Ann Arbor, Michigan and Mark of New York, New York, and Ruth Ellen who died in 1966. His surviving children and his six grandchildren all miss him a ton. 1/3

PATTERSON--Patricia. Patricia Shephard Patterson, passed away peacefully in Palm Beach, Florida surrounded by her loving family on Mother's Day, May 8th following a long illness. She was born in San Francisco on June 29th, 1925. Shortly after graduating from Stanford University in 1947, Patricia and her sister, Geraldine, moved to New York City. In 1958 she married Bruce A. Norris, owner of the Detroit Red Wings. Together they had a daughter, Wendy Norris, who they cherished. They divorced in 1967. In April, 1970 she married Herbert Patterson, then President of Chase Manhattan Bank. In the late 1970's Patricia began a long and esteemed career in Real Estate. As Vice President of Sotheby's International Realty in Manhattan she was a top producer. Clients became friends, her friends became clients and her career turned into her passion. Pat actively and continuously dedicated herself to making the world a better place for others. She worked tirelessly with boards, commissions and volunteer organizations. She was noted for her work as a Board Member of The Boys Club of New York, The School of American Ballet, International Committee of the Museum of Modern Art, The Venetian Heritage, The Central Park Conservancy, The Junior League and The Parish Art Museum. Traveling the world was one of Patricia's many passions. She loved exploring museums, galleries, cathedrals and diverse cultures. She was a passionate collector and supporter of the arts. Her most precious memories were the times she was able to share her life's journeys with friends and family. She was an avid sportswoman, proficient in many sports. Pat spent many happy days competing at her favorite Clubs, including The Meadow Club, Lyford Cay Club and the Everglades Club. Weekends were always spent either enjoying lunch on the porch at The Bathing Corporation or Sunday night dinners at Piping Rock. Holidays were spent at The Colony Club and The River Club. Patricia Patterson is survived by her daughter Wendy Norris Grant and her grandson Bruce Norris Grant. She was predeceased by her sister Geraldine Shephard. Patricia Patterson's funeral will be private. A Memorial will be held in New York City in September and Palm Beach in the winter. An announcement will follow. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in her memory to The Boys Club of New York, The School of American Ballet, The Central Park Conservancy, and The Venetian Heritage. 1/3

FRIED--Judith, passed peacefully at her residence on May 15, 2016, Loving wife of Wilbur. Devoted mother of Elizabeth and David. Adorned grandmother of Matthew, William, Emily, Sam, Sophie, Jack and Leo. Interment to take place at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Services private. Any additional information, contact "The Riverside Memorial Chapel" 212-362-6600. 1/3

NEWMAN--Betty R.,89, died peacefully in North Caldwell on May 16, 2016. Born in New York City, she resided for 36 years in West Orange before moving to Short Hills in 1992. She is survived by her sons, John (Ann) and Scott (Wendy), and her grandchildren, Daniel (Rebecca), Rachel (Corey), Cody and Becky. Her husband of 50 years, Richard, died in 1999. Funeral services will be held 1:00pm Tuesday at Bernheim-Apter- Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Short Hills Road, Livingston, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Newark Academy for the Betty Newman Scholarship Fund. 1/3

WAXMAN--Alan N.,60, of Manhattan, died after a brief illness. He was born in Akron, Ohio, and graduated from the University of Akron in 1977. He moved to New York that year to study at Columbia Law School, where he became a Harlan Fiske Stone Scholar and received a letter of commendation from Ruth Bader Ginsburg, his Constitutional Law professor. He joined the firm Squire, Sanders & Dempsey in Cleveland in 1980 and practiced public finance law before moving to New York in 1984 to begin a career in corporate and securities law. He became a partner of the firm in 1989 and spent the next 27 years representing his clients with distinction at the now Squire Patton Boggs. Alan especially relished his role as legal counsel to the Federal Home Loan Banks and the Musicians Emergency Fund, both of which he served for more than 30 years. He is survived by his wife of 32 years, Val Castronovo; daughter Olivia B. Waxman; sisters Barbara Miller, Arlene Bass (Ron), and Harriet Waxman; five nieces and nephews; and seven grand-nieces and grand-nephews. Alan was an Ohio boy who loved New York City. Contributions in his memory can be made to the New York Public Library. 1/3

CHARNAY GORMAN-- Patricia. My lovely and deeply loved wife, Pat, passed away on March 11, 2016, at Calvary Hospital. Pat was a cosmetics copywriter, an avid birdwatcher and dog lover. Her greatest talent, though, lay in making and maintaining lasting friendships with family, co-workers, fellow birdwatchers, and most everyone else she met during her life. She was my Shining Star! She will be profoundly missed. Michael Gorman 1/3

HENICK--William. We note with sorrow the passing of our longtime member, William Henick and extend sincerest condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Angela W. Buchdahl, President Abby Pogrebin, Central Synagogue of New York City 1/3

SHUART--Dr. James M. The Hofstra community is deeply saddened by the passing of President Emeritus Dr. James M. Shuart on May 13, 2016. Dr. Shuart was Hofstra's seventh president, serving from 1976 to 2001. There are few people who shared a more profound bond with Hofstra University, or had a more profound impact on the Hofstra community, than Dr. Shuart - as a student, an alumnus, a faculty member, an administrator and finally, as the University's longest-serving president. Under his leadership, Hofstra grew and expanded in many ways: enrollment increased; academic offerings and library holdings more than doubled; athletics grew to Division I status; our internationally respected presidential conferences began; new facilities, buildings and wings were constructed that more than doubled the University's physical space; the School of Communication was founded; and Hofstra became the first private university campus in the nation to be fully accessible to the physically challenged. In 2002 Hofstra Stadium was named in Dr. Shuart's honor. Dr. Shuart was also a dedicated public servant, serving as Nassau County commissioner of social services and deputy Nassau County executive from 1971 to 1975. He was recognized with Hofstra's Alumni Achievement and Alumnus of the Year awards, as well as the Long Island Association Medal of Honor. To honor the memory of Dr. Shuart, all University flags were lowered to half-staff. Alan J. Bernon, Chair, Hofstra University Board of Trustees; Stuart Rabinowitz, President, Hofstra University 1/3

PATTERSON--Patricia. The School of American Ballet celebrates the life of Pat Patterson, a generous friend and Board Member for over 30 years. Elected to the Board in 1975, Pat was steadfastly dedicated to furthering SAB's mission and worked enthusiastically to widen the School's circle of supporters. We send our gratitude, sympathy and condolences to Pat's daughter Wendy Norris Grant and her family. Max R. Shulman, Chairman of the Board Peter Martins, Chairman of Faculty Marjorie Van Dercook, Executive Director 1/3
GINIGER--Bernard B. October 1922 - May 2015 In loving memory of Gig- raconteur par excellence. You are always in our thoughts and our hearts. Your Loving Family 1/3

LANCHNER--Carolyn. It is with profound sorrow that I mourn the loss of my dear friend, Carolyn Lanchner. She was a hard-working, astute historian of the key figures of modern art; her many Museum of Modern Art exhibitions and publications reflect her deep, unaffected erudition no less than her sensitivity to the past's pertinence and connection to contemporary art. An over 30-year and particularly beloved member of the MoMA staff, she also had an enviable personal life. Self-effacing and possessed of an endearingly wry sense of humor, piercingly honest yet always empathetic, her personal qualities are as indelible as her professional achievements. My condolences to the family and many friends of a marvelous and wise woman, whom I will greatly miss. Agnes Gund 1/3

OREMLAND--Martha H.,passed away on May 12 in her 101st year. A woman of high fashion and intellect. Held lovingly by sons, Randall Weingarten (Elizabeth) and Jon Weingarten (Susan), grandchildren Hilary, Kai, Jason and Leigh-Ann, and great- grandchildren, Erin, Amy, and Xuan. She touched the lives of all who knew her. 1/3

RATNER--Michael. The Board of Governors and staff of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade Archives (ALBA) mourns the loss of Michael Ratner, a longtime defender of civil liberties and social justice. His visionary leadership leaves a lasting and inspiring legacy. We extend deepest condolences to his family. Fraser Ottanelli, Chair of the Board; Ellyn Polshek, Vice-Chair; Marina Garde, Exec Director 1/3

HOROWYTZ--Harold, passed away peacefully on May 15, 2016 after a wonderful life filled with the joy of family. His acumen in the food business was always evident at Zabar's where he worked for over 40 years. Beloved husband of Vera for 65 inseparable years. Treasured and devoted father of Mark (Rae Gladstein), Roni (Jim Ackerman) and Sheri (Craig Tendler). Cherished and adored grandfather of Josh (Maria), Adam, Matt (Carol), Alicia, Daniel, Josh, Helena (Sam) and Amanda and great- grandfather of Jonathan, Marissa, and London. He will be missed by those whose lives he enriched with his genuine kindness and larger than life spirit. Funeral services at 1pm, May 17th, Robert Schoem Memorial Chapel, Paramus, NJ. Shiva will be observed Tuesday - Monday at 867 Columbus Drive, Teaneck, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family would be grateful for any donation made in Harold's memory to: Temple B'nai Sholem, New Bern, NC. 1/3
FINNEGAN--Lawrence J.,Jr. Dear Larry, Happy thoughts when thinking of you! You remain in our hearts. 1/3
LEVINSON--Ari Lee, Heart of a Lion. Forever our love; Mom, Dad, Jed, Jane, Keith and Neil 1/3

LANCHNER--Carolyn. The Trustees and Staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the loss of Carolyn Lanchner, a longtime curator in the Museum's Department of Painting and Sculpture. Carolyn joined The Museum of Modern Art in 1967 and retired in 1998. During her illustrious career she organized and co-organized outstanding exhibitions that include Sophie Taeuber-Arp (1981), Henri Rousseau (1985), Paul Klee (1987), Joan Miro (1993), Fernand Leger (1998), and Alberto Giacometti (2001). Carolyn was widely admired for her impeccable eye, scholarly rigor, and diplomatic aplomb. She was a beloved friend of many artists both in New York and Paris. Always generous with her time, ideas, and encouragement, she was a cherished and inspiring mentor to a host of younger curators. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Carolyn's daughter Renate, her son David, her son-in-law Collins, her daughter-in-law Kirsten, and her grandson John. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, June 8th, at 9:30 a.m. in the Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1 at The Museum of Modern Art. 1/3

TULLY--Daniel P. The Board of Trustees and the entire Hospital for Special Surgery community extend our heartfelt sympathy at the passing of Daniel P. Tully, father of Daniel G. Tully, a former vice-chair of the Board of Trustees. The Tully family have been longtime friends and generous supporters of the Hospital. We are grateful for Mr. Tully's commitment to HSS and extend our deepest condolences to his family. Kendrick R. Wilson, III, Chair, Board of Trustees; Louis A. Shapiro, President and CEO; Todd J. Albert, M.D., Surgeon- in-Chief and Medical Director, Hospital for Special Surgery 1/3

LEHMAN--Wendy. The New York Studio School mourns the loss of a dear friend and former trustee of many years, Wendy Vanderbilt Lehman. She was cherished--clever, funny, and spirited. A fine artist who brought humanity to her many projects. Everyone knew Wendy and she knew everyone. She was a true presence in the New York art world. We offer condolences to her family, especially Brooke, Sage, and Susan. Wendy will be sorely missed. 1/3

GARELIK--Allen, 74, of Bedford, NY, passed peacefully on May 17th. Devoted husband of 47 years to Sheila, son to Lea and the late Milton, father to Michael (Jennifer), grandfather to Charles and Eli. Brother to the late Susan. A devoted uncle and friend. He was always ready for a new adventure. Services Wednesday, 11:15am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

GRAYSON--Marilyn, on May 16, 2016. Beloved wife of Gene. Loving mother of Mathew, Julie and Jay Goldbaum. Cherished grandmother of Robin and Will. Services today at 11am, at The Reconstructionist Synagogue of the North Shore, 1001 Plandome Road, Plandome, New York. (516) 627-6274. 1/3

LEVINE--Noel. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our beloved Noel Levine. The only thing bigger than his frame was his heart. Dear Harriette, our thoughts are with you during this difficult time. Marion, Elie, and Elisha Wiesel 1/3

GIURGOLA--Romaldo. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of this teacher-thinker-builder who was responsible for the education of many architects practicing around the world. 1/3

BROWN--Bruce Stephen. Loving husband of Anita Kalusin, devoted father of Laura and David Vexler, Eric and Gabrielle Brown, doting grandfather of Caroline, Jonathan and Zachary Vexler, and Luca and Jasper Brown, steadfast brother of James and Barbara Brown. Bruce graduated from the McBurney School, Harvard College and Fordham Law School. He had a long and successful career as a tax attorney and CPA, and was highly respected in his field of Corporate and International Taxation. He was a member of the Board of Philip Morris Capital Corporation. Bruce successfully structured the tax department of Altria, creating a new design to efficiently operate throughout years of acquisitions and divestitures, which served as a model for other corporations. He was always loyal to the company and his staff, as they were to him. Although proud of his professional career, Bruce always felt his greatest achievement was his wonderful family. As a dear friend wrote, "We have lost a quiet anchor for the family, and a person to emulate. He was a mensch, who thought carefully before he spoke. Somebody who tried his best to be a decent human being." Contributions in his memory may be made to: The Bruce S. Brown Memorial Fund c/o The Jewish Federation of Cleveland, 25701 Science Park Drive, Beachwood, OH 44122 www.jewishcleveland.org 1/3

DURST--David. The Board of Directors and staff of the Hebrew Free Loan Society mourn the passing of David Durst, whose unparalleled generosity changed the course of countless lives. David expressed his deep devotion to the Jewish community through his work with HFLS, where he provided leadership in many ways, including serving as board President for a decade. We extend our heartfelt condolences to David's beloved children, Jody, Joshua, Kristoffer, Laurel, and Robin; his wife Carola; his grandchildren; and the entire family. 1/3

MUSCHE--Dorothy E.,age 75, passed away on May 14th at Mary Manning Walsh hospice in New York City following a long battle with leukemia. Preceded in death by her parents, Ruth and Chester Musche, and sister, Geraldine, she will be buried next to her parents in Portland, Maine. 1/3

HAUCK--Louis Herbert. 1918-2016. Louis H. Hauck, 97, of Flushing, NY and Whiting NJ, passed away peacefully on May 13. He was a US Army Air Forces WWII veteran and proud to be part of the 427th Night Fighter Squadron. A distinguished New York attorney, he was a member of the Queens County Bar Association for more than 50 years. Louis was an officer for the Flushing Community Volunteer Ambulance Corps and President of the Flushing Lawyers Association. He was the devoted husband of Rita V. Hauck for 55 years. He loved his family, the law, a great meal, corny jokes and beating the stock market. He is survived by his daughters Barbara Hauck-Mah and Christine Hauck as well as his grandchildren Rebecca, Emma and Greg. A Memorial Service will be held at 10:45am on May 21 at St. Elizabeth Ann Seton Church, 30 Schoolhouse Road, Manchester Township, NJ, preceded by visitation at the Carmona- Bolen Funeral Home, 66 Lacey Road, Whiting, NJ. In lieu of flowers, a donation is requested for the Flushing Community Volunteer Ambulance Corps. 1/3

LANCHNER--Carolyn. It is with profound sorrow that I mourn the loss of my dear friend, Carolyn Lanchner. She was a hard-working, astute historian of the key figures of modern art; her many Museum of Modern Art exhibitions and publications reflect her deep, unaffected erudition no less than her sensitivity to the past's pertinence and connection to contemporary art. An over 30-year and particularly beloved member of the MoMA staff, she also had an enviable personal life. Self-effacing and possessed of an endearingly wry sense of humor, piercingly honest yet always empathetic, her personal qualities are as indelible as her professional achievements. My condolences to the family and many friends of a marvelous and wise woman, whom I will greatly miss. Agnes Gund 1/3

WISE --Arthur and Alice. The ashes of Arthur and Alice Wise were joined on May 15, in a pretty knoll where they enjoyed hiking with young grandsons years ago. May their names be inscribed in the Book of the Just and their memory cherished always. 1/3

ROSENBERG--Elaine F.,95, died peacefully surrounded by family members on May 16, 2016. Devoted wife of late husband Jack. Beloved mother of Ellen and Jerry Saffer, Nina and Eric Hertz. Adored grandmother of Allan and Brett Saffer, Lisa and Seth Borsuk, Michelle and Adam Levine. Loving great-grandmother of Joseph Borsuk and Sydney Levine. Funeral services will be held at 1:00pm Thursday at Wellwood Cemetery, 1400 Wellwood Ave., Pinelawn, NY. Donations may be made to American Heart Association. 1/3

DURST--David. I first met David Durst in 1987 when I had the opportunity to collaborate with the Durst family on a new office building. I will never forget the wisdom and amazing generosity of this man. David lived a full life, supporting admirable causes, sharing his enthusiasms and impacting the lives of all who knew him. He was a true friend and a kind mentor. I feel truly blessed for having known him. My wife Gloria and I wish to express our heartfelt condolences to David's family and all those whose lives he touched. Bob Fox, New York, NY 1/3

O'CONNELL--Patricia, 85, Broadway Actress, passed away Saturday, May 14th after a long chronic lung infection. Lifelong New Yorker, part of the New York theater community since she was 18. Viewing at Frank E. Campbell, Thursday 2-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral Friday 10:30am at St. Jean Baptiste Church. Burial to follow. Donations to the Actors Fund or St. Judes Hospital. 1/3
VELA--Telmo. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Telmo Vela, associated with The New York Times from December 1, 1969 until retiring on April 16, 2006. 1/3

GREEN--Hadassa Miriam, nee Lewit, age 77, of Great Neck, NY, passed on Monday, May 16, 2016 at home. Beloved mother of Adina and Liora, grandmother to Rachel. Service Friday, May 20, 10am at Riverside-Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. 1/3

WOOD--Timmy, a comedian, writer, one-time Ralph Lauren Model, and New York City's resident "Man of Mirth," passed away on Saturday, May 14th in his home in Brooklyn, New York at the age of 32. Timmy started his comedy career in Houston before moving to New York City. He was a beloved performer at the Upright Citizens Brigade Theatre and traveled the country with the UCB TourCo. Timmy appeared on "Jimmy Kimmel Live!," Funny or Die, Improv Everywhere, Fusion, and in countless UCB Comedy videos. Timmy loved Halloween and telling spooky stories around the campfire, so his family and friends are absolutely positive that Timmy Wood is now a ghost. Timmy Wood The Ghost's chief unfinished business will be to watch over his wife, Julie, who once swore that she and Timmy would never, ever date. They recently celebrated five years of marriage and the only blemish on their relationship was a rather lackluster performance on television's "The Newlywed Game." Timmy Wood The Ghost will also be joining his father, Jim, in looking after his mother, Terianne, his sister, Rebekah, and his brother, John. Even in the afterlife, Timmy Wood The Ghost will lovingly tend to his pet candles Howie Candel and LeBron Flames. ("Candles are the new pets.") Timmy Wood The Ghost's spooky spirit will always be felt at the UCB Theatre. It is said that if you listen closely after late Thursday night shows, you can still hear him uttering his annual comedy catchphrases, including "Suck it down, Charlie Brown," "Uhhhhhhhhhh... check please!" "HOLD THE SLAW," and "DAH FOOK?!?" Even in death, Timmy Wood The Ghost still stands by his controversial, nearly career- ending 2015 catchphrase "I'll have one more picky for my ticky." Now that he has shuffled off this mortal coil (Shakespeare, baby!), Timmy Wood The Ghost will have more time to tinker with his comprehensive ranking of Bond movie theme songs, create insane games with made-up rules that only he can understand, finally watch a regular season Houston Rockets game, research Illuminati conspiracy theories on the internet, defend "Yeezus" as his favorite Kanye West album, and drink Shinerbock in one of his many New York City "secret spots." Timmy will be missed dearly. And even though it was far too short, his time in this realm gets a perfect five out of five big, beautiful, man-beards. In lieu of flowers, Timmy's family asks that anyone wishing to celebrate his life of seemingly boundless love and positivity contribute to The Timmy Wood Comedy Memorial Fund at gofundme.com/timmywood. As always, everyone who donates gets one high-five. 1/3

KENNEDY--Richard, on May 15, 2016. Senior Director at Cushman & Wakefield. His funeral services will be held on May 19, 2016 at Crestwood Funeral Home, 445 West 43rd Street, 2-4pm and 5-8pm. Mass will be held at Saint Patrick's Cathedral, Fifth Ave., on May 20, 2016 at 10am. 1/3
MELLON--Sean Francis. Happy Birthday in Heaven. Love always, Mom, Dad & Liam 1/3

GARELIK--Allen Y. Devoted and loving nephew/ cousin. Allen's kind, caring, gentle and generous manner set an example for all. His love for family was limitless and a blessing to five Garelik generations. May his wonderful memory provide comfort and serve as an inspiration. Our heart extends to Lea, Shelia, Michael and Jenny for the loss of their great son, husband, father and grandfather. Neal Garelik 1/3
DARVIN--Renee. Never forgotten... Love always, Jerry 1/3

KRAININ--Harold L.,age 88, formerly of Glen Head, NY. Loving husband of Carol. Father of Fred, Rick, David and Dan and ten cherished grandchildren. Proud attorney, entrepreneur and writer. Contributions to Memorial Sloan-Kettering. 1/3

MULLEN--Doran A.,72, of New York City, Southampton, and Palm Beach, passed away peacefully on Friday, May 13, at The Dawn Greene Hospice in New York City. He is survived by his partner of 42 years, Charles O. Donnaud IV; brothers, Joseph and his wife Nancy of Franklin, MA, and Michael of Sinking Spring, PA; and sisterin-law Nancy of New York City. He was predeceased by his brother Thomas, who passed away earlier this year. In addition to a successful career with Metropolitan Life Insurance, he was Past President of St. George's Society of New York, The New England Society in the City of New York and The Knickerbocker Republican Club. He was also an active member of The Amateur Comedy Club. A Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated on Tuesday, May 24 at 3pm, at Church of Our Saviour, 59 Park Ave., New York, NY 10016. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made in memory of Doran A. Mullen to: Calvary Hospice, 1740 Eastchester Road Bronx, NY 10461; or Church of Our Saviour, 59 Park Ave., New York, NY 10016. 1/3

MUSCHE--Dorothy E.,age 75, passed away on May 14th at Mary Manning Walsh hospice in New York City following a long battle with leukemia. Preceded in death by her parents, Ruth and Chester Musche, and sister, Geraldine, she will be buried next to her parents in Portland, Maine. 1/3

HOFFSTEIN--Robert. May 18, 2016, at the age of 89. Loving husband, father and grandfather. Although his passions were mysticism and philosophy, Bob enjoyed a long and productive career at Pace University. Services will be held at Menorah Chapel in Staten Island on May 20th at 12pm. 1/3

GARELIK--Allen Y. Devoted and loving nephew/ cousin. Allen's kind, caring, gentle and generous manner set an example for all. His love for family was limitless and a blessing to five Garelik generations. May his wonderful memory provide comfort and serve as an inspiration. Our heart extends to Lea, Shelia, Michael and Jenny for the loss of their great son, husband, father and grandfather. Neal Garelik 1/3

TULLY--Dan. The Board of Directors, administration, physicians and staff of Stamford Health mourn the loss of our dear friend and benefactor, Daniel Patrick Tully, who, along with his wife Grace, established the Daniel and Grace Tully & Family Health Center in 2002. The Tully family's commitment to helping others has improved the health of hundreds of thousands of people in lower Fairfield County, CT and beyond. We will always be grateful for the countless ways Dan inspired us, and his kind and generous spirit will help us care for families for generations to come. Andrew M. Merrill, Chair, Board of Directors; Brian G. Grissler, President and CEO, Stamford Health; H. Darrell Harvey and George Sarner, Co-Chairs, Stamford Hospital Foundation 1/3
KEIDAN--Sheldon, on May 18, 2016. Beloved husband of Sandie. Devoted father of Dina and Leslie. Services today, 11:15am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

DUNN--Winifred T. (Saitta), 59, of Jersey City, NJ died of ALS, commonly known as Lou Gehrig's disease, on May 19, 2016. Winnie was born on November 12, 1956 at Lennox Hill Hospital, New York, NY, to Mary Saitta and the late Paul Saitta. Winnie grew up in East Williston, Long Island, attended Our Lady of Mercy High School and Marist College, where she met her husband of 36 years, William Gerard Dunn. She spent 30 years working at ABC in television production for shows like "One Life to Live," "The City," "Good Morning America" and "20/20." Most recently she worked at her passion of fitness as a Barre Instructor at Vitality Fitness in Ridgewood, NJ, and in other studios over northern New Jersey. She is survived by her two daughters, Casey and Taylor, one son, Billy Jr., and her loving and supportive husband, Billy Sr. Winnie, aka Big Mama. She will be remembered for always having a smile on her face and projecting positive energy to those around her. Funeral Monday 9am at Feeney Funeral Home, 232 Franklin Ave., Ridgewood, and 10am at Our Lady of Mt. Carmel RC Church, Ridgewood. Interment, Maryrest Cemetery, Mahwah. Visiting Saturday 7-9pm and Sunday 2-4pm and 7-9pm at the funeral home. In lieu of flowers, donations made to the ALS Greater New York Chapter - Patient Services - 42 Broadway, Suite 1724, NY, NY 10004, alsgreaternewyorkchapter. org in Winnie's memory would be greatly appreciated. 1/3

HOROWYTZ--Harold. It is with profound sadness and deep affection that Zabar's announces the passing of Harold Horowytz, Zabar's Deli Director, on May 15, 2016. Born in 1928, Harold was one of the last of the old-school deli men. A deep affection and special bond was shared between Harold and anyone who had a chance to work with him. Harold's reach went beyond the deli counter at Zabar's. His advice was sought after and he was respected as a confidant and a beloved figure throughout the store. Although Harold retired in 1992, each holiday season he would return to supervise the department. Harold was truly larger than life and will be missed by all. 1/3

SAFER--Morley. He gave selflessly of his time and was a great friend to NYSCI. His loss will be felt by all of us. 1/3

BOTTEX--Seymour E. 93, "Haitian painter," died. He is known for his colorful scenes and unique style "Modigliani" like female figures. His paintings are on exhibition in US, Italy, France and England. 1/3

SAFER--Morley. We note with sorrow the passing of our longtime member Morley Safer and extend sincerest condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Angela W. Buchdahl, President Abigail Pogrebin, Central Synagogue of New York City 1/3

FARNWORTH--Maria. On May 8th the singing world lost Maria Farnworth, nee Caruso, the inspiration to generations of voice students. Known internationally for her nuanced approach to teaching her career spanned six decades; her passion compelled her students to higher standards. Born in Brooklyn to Joseph and Teresa Caruso, she studied music and at 19, won a scholarship to the Julliard School. Trained in the Lamperti method, Maria's own discoveries led her to develop her own theory which taught her students to understand the voice as a powerful yet delicate instrument that engaged mind, body and spirit. Beloved for her sharp wit and biting humor, Maria was a source of strength to all. She is survived by her brother Robert Caruso and was mother to three sons: Steven (predeceased), Thomas and Bruce. 1/3
BAUER--Irvin, Screenwriter, playwright, died of lymphoma, July 24, 2015, his devoted wife Vimi at his side. 1/3

WOOD--Timmy, a comedian, writer, one-time Ralph Lauren Model, and New York City's resident "Man of Mirth," passed away on Saturday, May 14th in his home in Brooklyn, New York at the age of 32. Timmy started his comedy career in Houston before moving to New York City. He was a beloved performer at the Upright Citizens Brigade Theatre and traveled the country with the UCB TourCo. Timmy appeared on "Jimmy Kimmel Live!," Funny or Die, Improv Everywhere, Fusion, and in countless UCB Comedy videos. Timmy loved Halloween and telling spooky stories around the campfire, so his family and friends are absolutely positive that Timmy Wood is now a ghost. Timmy Wood The Ghost's chief unfinished business will be to watch over his wife, Julie, who once swore that she and Timmy would never, ever date. They recently celebrated five years of marriage and the only blemish on their relationship was a rather lackluster performance on television's "The Newlywed Game." Timmy Wood The Ghost will also be joining his father, Jim, in looking after his mother, Terianne, his sister, Rebekah, and his brother, John. Even in the afterlife, Timmy Wood The Ghost will lovingly tend to his pet candles Howie Candel and LeBron Flames. ("Candles are the new pets.") Timmy Wood The Ghost's spooky spirit will always be felt at the UCB Theatre. It is said that if you listen closely after late Thursday night shows, you can still hear him uttering his annual comedy catchphrases, including "Suck it down, Charlie Brown," "Uhhhhhhhhhh... check please!" "HOLD THE SLAW," and "DAH FOOK?!?" Even in death, Timmy Wood The Ghost still stands by his controversial, nearly career- ending 2015 catchphrase "I'll have one more picky for my ticky." Now that he has shuffled off this mortal coil (Shakespeare, baby!), Timmy Wood The Ghost will have more time to tinker with his comprehensive ranking of Bond movie theme songs, create insane games with made-up rules that only he can understand, finally watch a regular season Houston Rockets game, research Illuminati conspiracy theories on the internet, defend "Yeezus" as his favorite Kanye West album, and drink Shinerbock in one of his many New York City "secret spots." Timmy will be missed dearly. And even though it was far too short, his time in this realm gets a perfect five out of five big, beautiful, man-beards. In lieu of flowers, Timmy's family asks that anyone wishing to celebrate his life of seemingly boundless love and positivity contribute to The Timmy Wood Comedy Memorial Fund at gofundme.com/timmywood. As always, everyone who donates gets one high-five. 1/3
KRACH--Bill. 1922-2006 Ten years without you on Earth but always in my heart and soul. I love you, Ellie 1/3

CODEY--John W. The Rockefeller University mourns the passing of our cherished friend John Codey, who served for nearly two decades as an advisor and executive vice president of Helmsley Enterprises, Inc. and, more recently, as a trustee of the Helmsley Charitable Trust. A guiding light in New York's philanthropic community, John will be remembered for his wise leadership and his dedication to many causes, including medical research and conservation. At Rockefeller, he was instrumental in advancing basic and clinical research through generous grants from The Leona M. and Harry B. Helmsley Charitable Trust to establish and help support the Center for Basic and Translational Research on Disorders of the Digestive System. Under the direction of Barry Coller, M.D., the center brings together physicians and scientists for intensive interdisciplinary collaboration intended to result in new treatments for a broad range of health conditions. John believed strongly in investing in the scientific leaders of the future. He was deeply interested in the young investigators whose research the Trust has supported at Rockefeller, and he showed great curiosity about their work. They, in turn, felt privileged to know and interact with a foundation executive of such tremendous personal warmth. With deepest gratitude to John, we extend our heartfelt sympathy to his beloved wife, Anne; his three children; his grandchildren; and his colleagues at the Helmsley Charitable Trust. David Rockefeller, Honorary Chair and Life Trustee Russell Carson, Chair Marc Tessier-Lavigne, President Barry Coller, V.P. for Medical Affairs Marnie Imhoff, Senior Vice President 1/3

KAMEN--Renee, on May 18, 2016. Age 93. Elegant, vivacious and wise, she is survived by her adoring husband Milton, loving daughter Peggy, devoted son Michael and dear nieces and nephews. A good life, well spent. Services were private. 1/3

COMINSKY--George, passed away on Sunday, May 8, 2016 in his New York City home after a brief fight with cancer. George was born on April 2, 1932, in Tamaqua, Pennsylvania. He lost his father in a Pennsylvania coal mining accident at a young age, and he was raised by his mother and her siblings. He served in the Army in Korea and attended Villanova University graduating in 1954. He married Margaret McNamara, and they raised three children - Agnes, Karen and George. His careers in publishing and advertising took him to Pennsylvania, Chicago, Connecticut, New York and New Jersey. The passions he had for his Lithuanian heritage, fishing, Villanova basketball and a beer at his "local" were only surpassed by the love for his family. George was always there with a well told story, wise words of advice and a joke to those who encountered his company. He is survived by his wife, two daughters and four grandchildren. George will be dearly remembered and missed. A Memorial Mass will be held on June 11, 2016 at 9:30am at the Catholic Center at NYU. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Nursing School at Villanova University c/o Villanova University Development Office, 800 Lancaster Avenue, Villanova, PA 19085. 1/3
GORE--Gerie. 11/11/19 - 5/21/12 Your clever wit and loving warmth are with us every day. Eternally incomparable. Eloise and Allen 1/3

SAFER--Morley. When Morley recently visited us and walked into our new building for design, he maintained his robust gait and warm smile full of humor while mocking his need for a cane. His face lit up when he gazed upwards at the lighting fixture Josef Albers created for the Weimar Bauhaus. He declared it, and Anni Albers's colorful maquette for a synagogue arc curtain, two of the most surprising and splendid art works of the last century. "Simply wonderful," he said, with his resonant voice and contagious enthusiasm. He held to his strong opinions about recent art, and revered what he admired with abiding passion. We send our deepest love to brilliant, beautiful Jane and the family he adored. Nicholas Fox Weber, The Josef and Anni Albers Foundation 1/3

ALLEN--Ruth Singer, 97, beloved wife of the late Howard Allen. Loyal sister, devoted aunt, and collector of all things giraffe, died peacefully at home on May 19, 2016 after a brief illness. She embodied a zest for living and aged with vigor and grace. She is survived by her sister, Julie, her niece and nephew, Susan and Warren, their spouses, Don and Sel, three great nieces and their husbands, Tanya and Ryan, Lauren and Brett, and Rachel and Eli, and a great nephew and his wife, Brian and Jen. She is also survived by five great-great nieces and nephews and a cousin Peter. There will be a private service for the family. Contributions in her memory can be made to the Himan Brown Senior Program at the 92nd Street Y. 1/3

TEMPERLEY--Joe, long regarded as one of jazz's leading baritone saxophonists, died on May 11 in New York City. He was 88. Temperley's 60-year career in jazz was highlighted by long stints in both the Duke Ellington Orchestra and the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra. In addition to his own varied discography as a bandleader, and sharing a bandstand with Billie Holiday, Frank Sinatra, Ella Fitzgerald, Barbra Streisand, and many more, Temperley was a beloved educator who helped aspiring musicians grow both in the United States and his native Scotland. Temperley was born in the town of Lochgelly, in Fife, Scotland on September 20, 1927. His father was a bus driver - a rarity in a town where most men worked in the coalmines - and his mother took care of the household. For his fourteenth birthday he was given an alto saxophone by his older, trumpet- playing brother Bob. He took to the horn immediately, practicing whenever he wasn't working in a local butcher shop. By age 17, he had switched to tenor saxophone, and his success with an ensemble that won a big band competition in Glasgow landed him a spot in a Glaswegian jazz quintet. Temperley's talent quickly took him to London, where he played with some of Great Britain's leading jazz ensembles. In 1958, he switched to baritone saxophone to perform with trumpeter Humphrey Lyttelton's band - widely regarded as one of the best jazz ensembles outside of the United States - and the instrument soon came to be his instrument of choice. Temperley traveled with Lyttelton to America for the first time in 1959. That trip left an indelible impression on him. He decided to get back to the thriving New York City jazz scene as soon as possible. The move finally happened on December 16, 1965 when Temperley boarded the Queen Mary and set sail for the U.S. When he first arrived in New York, he stayed at the Bryant Hotel and sold transistor radios as he looked for gigs. His first regular job, obtained with help from friends pianist Nat Pierce and drummer Jake Hanna, was with famed bandleader Woody Herman's New Thundering Herd. That soon led to a spot in the Thad Jones/Mel Lewis Orchestra as well as gigs with luminaries like Clark Terry, Duke Pearson, and Joe Henderson who appreciated Temperley's lush, soulful sound. "My approach to playing is purely vocal," Temperley once said. "If you can get all the air out singing a note, there's no reason you can't do it on a saxophone." Moving to the U.S. allowed Temperley to befriend one of his heroes, Harry Carney, the long-tenured baritone saxophone chair for Duke Ellington's orchestra. When Carney died in 1974 - just months after Ellington himself passed Temperley was asked to perform at the funeral, where he played the jazz legend's signature "Sophisticated Lady." Soon after, Mercer Ellington Duke's son, who'd stepped into his father's position as bandleaderasked Temperley to take Carney's place in the orchestra. That led to a fourteen-year stint with the world's most storied big band. "My main influence was - and still is - the Duke Ellington Orchestra," Temperley told Smithsonian Magazine in 2011. "That has always been my prime motivation for playing music, for playing jazz." In 1988, a few years after he'd left the Ellington Orchestra to pursue other opportunities, Temperley received another life- shaping call. This time, it was to join Wynton Marsalis and the newly created Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra. Temperley occupied the JLCO's baritone saxophone chair for the next 28 years, touring the world many times over, serving both as the ensemble's elder statesman and the definitive model for the baritone saxophone's sound. Temperley taught on the faculty of the Juilliard School for Jazz Studies for many years. He was a mentor and co-founder of the FIFE Youth Jazz Orchestra program in Scotland, which now enrolls 70 young musicians, ages 7-17, playing in three full-size bands. He released many albums as a leader including Nightingale (1991), Sunbeam and Thundercloud with pianist Dave McKenna (1996), With Every Breath (1998), and Double Duke (1999). More recently, he released Cocktails for Two (2007) on Sackville and The Sinatra Songbook (2008) on Hep Jazz. His film soundtrack credits include Cotton Club, Biloxi Blues, Brighton Beach Memoirs, When Harry Met Sally, and Tune In Tomorrow. He is survived by his wife of 32 years, Laurie, his son Dr. Matthew Lurin, his sister Helen, and many nieces and nephews. 1/3

FRANKFURT--Ruth, 90, loving and adored wife of the late Daniel for 62 years, mother of Judith (James R. Oestreich) and Jaclyn (Mark Cahn), proud grandmother of Jordan and Joey Frankfurt Cahn, sister of the late Gittel Silverberg (Mervin) and Esther Beckman (Irving), cousin and best friend of Fayge Cohen (the late Solly), on May 19, 2016. GROSSER--Alan (Al), died on September 4, 2015 at 92. Al was born, lived and, for most of his career, worked in the Bronx. Aware of the atrocities occurring in Europe during WWII, he enlisted in the Air Force and served as a fighter pilot. His commitment to avenging and protecting the Jewish people remained a passion of his for the rest of his life. After the war, Al earned a BS in economics from Long Island University and an MA from Columbia Teachers College. In September 1953, he began his thirty-four year career in the NYC Public Schools teaching Social Studies in Junior High School 52. It was a perfect fit. History was his favorite subject. His extensive knowledge, keen memory and ability to speak extemporaneously made him a captivating teacher. After teaching for ten years, Al became assistant principal of Community Schools 54 and later 77. He was also the principal of several summer school programs. Al was a wise, supportive and diligent administrator. He was cherished by the staff in every school he worked. He never took a sick day! Al was an erudite man. He had many interests and hobbies that fulfilled his long life, including studying and investing in the stock market, collecting coins, playing chess and cards, gardening, painting, photography, classical music, opera, traveling. Al was a natural athlete. As a youngster, his baseball skills were good enough to earn him a tryout for a professional baseball team! He played tennis until he was 88! Al was a good natured, honest and gracious gentleman. He had a wonderful sense of humor and sharp memory that enabled him to recall and tell countless jokes at every occasion and at just the right time! Al is survived and sorely missed by his beloved wife, Blanche (of 65 years), devoted daughters Barbara, Laura (Stuart), Nancy (Joseph), loving sister Rosalind, six grandchildren, one great-grandson, a niece and nephew. 1/3

THOMPSON--Robert Torrey, a private equity investor and resident of New Canaan, CT, passed away peacefully on Sunday, May 15 in his home. He was 61. A devoted husband and father, Bob is survived by his wife, Frances (Bush-Brown) Thompson, and his children, Sarah M. Thompson and Augustus T. Thompson, both of New York City. He is also survived by his sister, F. Dana Thompson, of Denver, CO. Bob spent 40 years in the financial services industry, most recently as a Senior Advisor to Intermediate Capital Group, for whom he served as the Non-Executive Chairman of ICG Strategic Secondaries. Additionally, he served as a Senior Advisor/Board of Directors Member to multiple private equity general partners and a High Net Worth family office. Until 2012, Bob served as the Global Head of Alternative Investments for AIG Investments, which rebranded to PineBridge Investments upon its spinout from AIG in 2010. In this capacity, Bob was responsible for all private equity and hedge fund activities globally. Prior to AIG, Bob was a founder and Managing Partner of Ferrer Freeman Thompson & Co., LLC, a Greenwich, CT-based private equity platform. Previously, Bob was a Managing Director and Equity Group Leader at GE Capital Corporation where he was the founder of the GE Capital private equity business and developed GE Capital's private equity activities throughout the United States, Europe and Asia. Before joining GE Capital, Bob was a consultant at Bain & Co. in Boston, MA and a commercial lending officer at Chemical Bank in New York City, where his career began in 1976. Born in Boston, MA in 1954, Bob was raised in Andover, MA. He received an A.B. in Economics from Harvard College and an M.B.A. from the Stanford Graduate School of Business. Bob's childhood home was proximate to the playing fields of Phillips Academy, which fostered an early and lasting fanaticism with sports. Bob was a heralded student-athlete at Berkshire School and subsequently played varsity soccer, varsity golf, and junior varsity hockey at Harvard. He excelled in golf and numerous racquet sports well into his adult years. Friends and family will remember Bob most especially for his infectious personality, dry wit, and kind-hearted nature. His balance of obvious intellect and distinct approachability facilitated enduring friendships and profound impressions on those within his personal and professional lives. He was loved by many and will be deeply missed by all. A memorial service to celebrate Bob's life will be held at 11am on Saturday, June 18 at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan, CT. In lieu of flowers, the family has kindly asked that donations be made in memory of Robert Torrey Thompson to support cancer research at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, Attn: Kirstin Burdett, 885 Second Ave, 7th Fl., New York, NY 10017. 1/3

MACCIA--Dr. George Salvatore. Professor Maccia no longer has an operative body through which his beautiful mind can express itself to us who are in a body. Born in 1920, he is the last of the children of Carmela Tosti and Salvatore Maccia who came from Italy and settled in New Jersey of America. He spent a large portion of his life as professor at Ohio State University and Indiana University at Bloomington teaching philosophy and research, so the legacy he leaves are his students and the extension of the thought of the great American Pragmatist Charles Sanders Peirce. Also, he was gifted artistically, musically and mechanically and so further enriched the lives of those he touched, particularly me, for I was his friend and lover since 1947. We were professors together at Ohio State University and Indiana University (even doing research and professional writing together). We traveled together (around the world twice) plus all our travels by land in our motor home (S.S. Grata), by air in our Cessna 182, and sea in our trawler, Chinita. We played together on the beaches of Florida (especially on the beach of Captiva Island where we lived the first ten years of our retirement); and we tangoed at The Italian American Club of Cape Coral. My love will continue. Dr. Liz Steiner 1/3
