HINERFELD--Susan. Susan Hope Slocum Hinerfeld, died April 30 in Santa Monica, CA, at age 79. She is survived by her husband of nearly 59 years, Robert Elliot Hinerfeld; two sons, Daniel Slocum (Laura Kleinhenz) and Matthew Ben (Nora Jaskowiak, MD); and five grandchildren, Sophie Rose, Eli Milton, Theo Jonathan, Willa Belle and Maude Hall. Susan was born in New York City, August 6, 1936, to Milton Jonathan Slocum, MD and Belle Esther Slocum (nee, Gibralter). Milton often walked Susan to the Calhoun School in the morning, quizzing her on Latin along the way. Susan graduated from Calhoun in 1953 and from Wellesley College in 1957. In 1959, Susan and Robert moved from Cambridge, MA to Los Angeles, where Susan worked for the public relations counselor Elaine K. Sewell Jones, wife of architect A. Quincy Jones. To get the job, Susan took a one-question exam: name the middle initial of the first director of the Museum of Modern Art. Susan instantly replied "H," for Alfred H. Barr, Jr., and began a job and a lifelong friendship with the Joneses. Through them she became acquainted with Ray and Charles Eames and developed a love of design and modernist architecture. Decades later, Susan's son Matthew worked for Ray on her final book project. Susan was a great reader, an elegant writer and an exacting editor. She was co-author, with her father, of Manhattan Country Doctor, a best-selling memoir of Dr. Slocum's 34-year medical practice in Hell's Kitchen (Scribner's, 1986). Susan edited Wellesley After-Images (1974) and was a regular book reviewer for the Los Angeles Times. She often edited Robert's appellate briefs. Susan used her love of language, literature, design, art and architecture to teach her sons and their friends to be better writers, better observers, and more creative people. Many of them credit Susan's encouragement, instruction and editorial rigor with getting them into college and graduate school and helping them launch successful careers. Susan invested time and energy in the progressive schools her children attended, Westland and Crossroads. She had a wide circle of friends, young and old, and her home was a special gathering place where lives intersected, ideas and laughter flourished, and those in need found refuge. Susan was charming, stylish, nurturing, funny, brilliant, playful, selfless and kind. She was adored by all who knew her and loved dearly by her family. As a toddler, when Susan's parents asked her to do something against her wishes, she replied: "Has I has to?" That, Susan said in recent months, was her question about dying. A memorial is planned for the fall. For information, contact Daniel Slocum Hinerfeld at: dhinerfeld@gmail.com. 1/3

HOPKINS--Albert L.,Jr. Albert L. Hopkins, Jr., of Danbury, NH, and Palm Coast, FL, died on May 17th, 2016, at the Stuart F. Meyer Hospice House here. He was the son of the late Albert L. Hopkins, Sr., Esq, of Chicago, IL, and Florence (Odil) Hopkins, originally of Nashville, TN. The senior Hopkins was founding partner of the firm Hopkins Sutter. Raised in the city, the younger Hopkins completed his primary education at the Laboratory School of the University of Chicago. His secondary education was at Phillips Exeter Academy, in New Hampshire. He did his undergraduate work at Harvard University, earning a Bachelor's Degree in Engineering. A gifted mathematician, Albert Hopkins, Jr., continued at Harvard earning both his Masters and PhD at the Harvard Computational Laboratory. There he studied under the legendary Howard Aiken, considered by many as the Father of Digital Computing in America. In 1960 Albert Hopkins joined the MIT Instrumentation Laboratory, later known as the Draper Lab, where he was a colleague of Dr. Charles Stark Draper. At the lab Albert worked in the Digital Development Group, under Eldon C. Hall. His team members there included Ramon Alonso, Alan Green, and Hugh Blair-Smith, among many other pioneers of digital computing. Dr. Hopkins was a key member of the team that completed the contract with NASA to design the Apollo navigation program. Hopkins was in charge of guiding the Apollo spacecraft from the Earth to the Moon, and back. With Ramon, he designed and hand built the prototype Guidance and Navigation Computer (G&NC) used to perform that critical task. It should be remembered that digital electronics in the early 1960's bore little relation to the advanced IT science of today. Not only was Albert Hopkins' team at Draper Lab confined to the use of core memory, but they were also limited by the amount of space, the shape of that space, and the weight they would be allowed to put aboard the Command Module. Having designed the hardware it also fell to Hopkins to devise and write both the Operating System and Input/Output Language it would use to make the roughly 240,000 mile voyage with a course deviation of under one tenth of one percent. Following the success of the Apollo Program, Albert Hopkins remained at Draper for long enough to perform some of the earliest work on Fault Tolerant computer systems and computer controlled machining centers for clients such as Fiat. After his tenure at MIT, Hopkins joined with two other colleagues to form a private consulting practice known as ITP Computing. With his first wife, the late Bess (House) Hopkins, he is the father of four grown children and now six grandchildren. He was also married to Ellen (Berger) Hopkins. In 1980 Albert married Lynne Zaccaria. The Hopkins' moved to Danbury, NH, and set about learning the craft of pottery making. Together they opened The Danbury Pottery in 1989. Ever restless to take on new challenges, Albert decided to build the couple a home on the property they shared with Lynne's family. In typical fashion he taught himself the basics of Post and Beam construction and with the help of family members cut timber on the property and hewed it into beams using a combination of chain saws and Yankee Ingenuity. The result was a new barn and a custom designed year-round abode for the aspiring potters. In 2003 Dr. Hopkins presented with symptoms of Multiple Myeloma. He ultimately sought treatment at the Myeloma Institute of the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences. Under the care of then Director Dr. Bart Barlogie, MD, PhD, Albert Hopkins faced the challenge to his health as he had always faced all other challenges. He was successful in holding off the ravages of the disease for far longer than the statistical average. His death, thirteen years later, was finally the result of complications associated with Myeloma. He could not have persevered for that time without the consultation and medical skills, in chronological order, of Dr. Becki Melton, MD, of Palm Coast; Bonnie Jenkins, RN; Nadine Baxter, APN; Dr. Giampaolo Talamo, MD; Mary Hickman, RN; and all the nurses and APN's of the Myeloma Institute. He also owes a debt of gratitude to Dr. Paul Dodd, MD, and his associates Dr. Kathleen B. Doughney, MD; Dr. Christopher Alexander, DO; and the entire professional staff of the Florida Cancer Specialists. Dr. Hopkins was a member of the Institute for Electrical and Electronic Engineers. He was also a Fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science. He was the author of numerous technical articles on subjects ranging from Math Theory to Practical Computing. He and his wife are major contributors to the Myeloma Institute, the South Danbury Christian Church, and fittingly the Stuart F. Meyer Hospice House. He is survived by his wife, Lynne Zaccaria Hopkins. He also leaves his children Terry Hopkins and his wife Mandy, of Winchester UK, Tom Hopkins, of New York City, Jay Hopkins, of Hyannis, MA, and Sarah Hopkins Samore, of Salt Lake City. He was the beloved brother of his late sister Catharine and her late husband, David Ruml. He was also the beloved brother of Nancy Hopkins Gerson, 92, and her husband Isak Gerson, of Chicago. He leaves nieces and nephews David J. Ruml and Elizabeth Hopkins Ruml, both of South Strafford, VT, and Susan Haskins and her husband Steven Dolloff of New York City, and the late Amy Gerson, of Chicago. He was the beloved grandfather of Benjamin Hopkins, of Los Angeles; Rebecca and Marina Hopkins of London; Theodore Samore, of Los Angeles; Samuel Samore, of Salt Lake City, and Eliza Samore, also of Salt Lake City. He will be remembered for his integrity, honesty, wit, humor, sincerity, charm, his love of playing piano, classical and folk guitar, and for his love of gardening. Services are being managed by Chadwick Funeral Home, New London, NH. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made in Albert's Name to the Danbury Community Center, Danbury, NH 03230. 1/3

BLAU--Lawrence McDara. Larry Blau of New York City and Boca Grande, Florida died peacefully on May 16, 2016. His wife Elizabeth Blau and his two sons Andrew and Christopher were by his side. A faithful and loving husband, father, grandfather and friend, he was happiest when his family, dogs, and friends were nearby. Born in Huntington Park, California on June 30, 1941, Larry spent his early years growing up in Columbia, South America. He was a graduate of Admiral Farragut Academy (1959) in St. Petersburg, Florida and Emory University (1963) in Atlanta, Georgia. A member of the Sigma Chi fraternity at Emory, he was a record holding Captain of the swim team. Having moved to New York in 1963 he worked first at Goodbody and Company, then for many years at Oppenheimer and Company. In 1988, he launched BEM Management, a hedge fund, with his business partner, which they managed together successfully until 2001. He then retired to Boca Grande. Larry was an avid and competitive golfer. He was a member of the University Club in New York City, Westchester Country Club in Rye, New York, and the Gasparilla Golf Club in Boca Grande, Florida. He was a member of the board of The York Theater Company, and volunteered on his coop board in New York City for several years, also serving as president. In his retirement in Florida he was an active volunteer and philanthropist in his community, serving on the board of the Gasparilla Island Conservancy and Improvement Association. He was a member of the Investment Committee for the Island School Foundation. Larry served on the board of the Boca Grande Health Clinic Foundation from it's inception in 2003. Passionate about the mission to ensure the financial viability of the Clinic, he served as a Trustee, Executive Committee member and Investment Committee member. He is survived by his loving wife of 54 years, Elizabeth Blau of Boca Grande, his son Andrew Blau of San Francisco, grand-daughters Emily and Anne, son Christopher Blau of Santa Barbara, daughter-in-law Wendy, grand-daughters Pippa, Lulu, and Ingrid, and his faithful dog Edwina. A memorial celebration will be held in his honor in the fall. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Boca Grande Health Clinic Foundation, Inc., PO Box 2340, Boca Grande, FL 33921. 1/3

CODEY--John W. The Rockefeller University mourns the passing of our cherished friend John Codey, who served for nearly two decades as an advisor and executive vice president of Helmsley Enterprises, Inc. and, more recently, as a trustee of the Helmsley Charitable Trust. A guiding light in New York's philanthropic community, John will be remembered for his wise leadership and his dedication to many causes, including medical research and conservation. At Rockefeller, he was instrumental in advancing basic and clinical research through generous grants from The Leona M. and Harry B. Helmsley Charitable Trust to establish and help support the Center for Basic and Translational Research on Disorders of the Digestive System. Under the direction of Barry Coller, M.D., the center brings together physicians and scientists for intensive interdisciplinary collaboration intended to result in new treatments for a broad range of health conditions. John believed strongly in investing in the scientific leaders of the future. He was deeply interested in the young investigators whose research the Trust has supported at Rockefeller, and he showed great curiosity about their work. They, in turn, felt privileged to know and interact with a foundation executive of such tremendous personal warmth. With deepest gratitude to John, we extend our heartfelt sympathy to his beloved wife, Anne; his three children; his grandchildren; and his colleagues at the Helmsley Charitable Trust. David Rockefeller, Honorary Chair and Life Trustee Russell Carson, Chair Marc Tessier-Lavigne, President Barry Coller, V.P. for Medical Affairs Marnie Imhoff, Senior Vice President 1/3

SIMONDS--Cassandra Goss, of Freeport, ME died on May 6, 2016 at Scarborough Terrace Assisted Living facility in Scarborough, ME. She is survived by her adored four children, Christopher, Melissa (Michael Vachow), Sprague and Reade and her beloved grandchildren, Anna Simonds Glennon (Michael), Natalie Simonds, William Simonds, Sean Simonds, Carlyn Vachow and Christopher Vachow. She is also survived by her sisters, Diana Ward of Beverly, MA and Tania Evans (Thomas) of Grafton, VT and Wilson, WY, and numerous much loved nieces, nephews and God- children. She was born in New Haven, CT on June 16, 1933 to the late Chauncey Porter Goss III and the late Natalie Holbrook Goss of Middlebury, CT. She graduated from Garrison Forest School in 1951 and Connecticut College in 1955 with a degree in sociology after which she attended the Columbia School of Nursing until her marriage to Charles Sprague Simonds in 1956. She later received her MA from Fairfield University prior to starting her business as an independent educational consultant, which she ran for many years in Darien, CT. Dedicated to the field of education throughout her life, she founded the first English speaking school for the children of servicemen in Okinawa, Japan during her husband's deployment there in the late 1950's and was also instrumental in starting the First Presbyterian Nursery School in New Canaan, CT in the late 1960's. She was the President of the Connecticut College Alumni Association Board from 1974-1977; the College recognized her commitment by honoring her with the Agnes B. Leahy Award in 1980. After moving to Maine in the 1980's, her volunteer efforts included serving as a docent at the Tate House in Portland, a property of the Colonial Dames of America of which she was a member, and the South Freeport Congregational Church where she used her considerable cooking skills to bring meals and comfort to many who were ill or shut in. Hers was a generous, loving heart and she will be greatly missed. A memorial service is being planned for later this summer. To share memories and condolences with the family, please go to: www.coastalcremation services.com. Should you wish to make a donation in her name, please consider the Connecticut College Fund (https://www.conncoll.edu/ giving/) or The Wohelo Endowment or Campership Funds www.wohelo.com/donations/. 1/3

HERING--Barbara Gordon, age 92, died in Washington DC on May 19, 2016. Barbara is survived by her loving husband of 59 years Louis Hering, children Janet G. Hering, James G. Hering and Louis G. Hering, daughter-in-law Lisa Gannon and granddaughters Phoebe and Eliza. Her strength of character, kindness and intelligence will be missed by all who knew her. 1/3

BALACHAMDRAN--C.G. On May 18, 2016, Dr. C.G. (Balu) Balachandran, passed away in New York City, surrounded by his family. He was born in Kumbakonam, India, the youngest of five children. After obtaining his Ph.D. in physics from the IISc, his career as a physicist (acoustics) took him and his family to London, Wellington, Calgary and New York. Dr. Balachandran was a true renaissance man with diverse interests, but a passion for Carnatic music. He was an accomplished mridangist, accompanying many famous artists over the years, and with his wife of 55 years Usha, shared their love of music and dance wherever they lived. The passion he had for science and music were only surpassed by the love for his family. He is survived by his wife Usha, daughter Rama (Jayant), son Murali (Vijayagouri), two grandchildren Uma and Yuva, brother Pattabhiraman, and his beloved Max. Balu will be fondly remembered and missed. Funeral home viewings will be from 2-5pm and from 7-9pm on Sunday, May 22 at Frederick Funeral Home, 192-15 Northern Blvd., Flushing, NY 11358. 1/3

BUHL--Edward T. 81, died Monday, May 16, 2016. Loving husband of Lynn Minton. Predeceased by his wife of 43 years, Theresa Marie Guttieri. Brother of Mary Maiorana; father of Paul, Peter, Maria and Miriam Buhl. Stepfather of Tim, Charlie and Katherine Minton. Devoted grandfather to Cecilia, Elizabeth, Ethan Buhl; Nicholas Preller, Maxmilian and Julia Kracker; Maximilian and Heidi Grascher. Loving step- grandfather to Rachel, Jack, Alex, Gabrielle and Phillip Minton and James Bessoir. Ed graduated first in his class from Cathedral College in Brooklyn. He earned his law degree from St. John's University Law School, during which time he worked nights in the mailroom at IBM World Trade in New York City. Hired by IBM as an attorney in 1960, Ed rose through the ranks, eventually serving as General Counsel for IBM Europe (1979-1983) and finally Assistant General Counsel. Ed worked under IBM General Counsels Burke Marshall and Nicholas deB. Katzenbach, and his career covered several notable legal initiatives, including helping to draft the first United States affirmative action policy for businesses (1969) and negotiating IBM's position with respect to apartheid-era South Africa. He retired in 1992. Ed was a Renaissance man who loved opera, ballet, medieval art and architecture; spoke several languages, including French, Spanish and Latin; adored hiking, canoeing, bird watching, and nature photography. He was a wildflower expert and led tours for Teatown Lake Reservation in Ossining. He became an educator at the Cloisters, where he led tours and taught school children about medieval art and history. He had a wonderful sense of humor and was known for his kindness and sense of social justice. A private burial is planned. A memorial celebration of his life will be held at a later date. Contributions in his memory may be made to Teatown Lake Reservation, the Metropolitan Museum of Art (Cloisters) or Goddard Riverside Community Center, NYC. Ed's wife Lynn welcomes friends to their home at 350 Central Park West, NYC on Monday, May 23rd from 4-6pm and Tuesday, May 24th from 6-8pm. 1/3

IGOE--Margaret, of Bronxville, NY, native County Roscommon, Ireland, on May 18, 2016. Beloved cousin of Edward Igoe Cunningham, Susan Hassert, Carol Moran and her children; Tod Moran, Patricia Moran, and the late Cathleen Moran Elisha and her daughter Kate Elisha. Margaret arrived in New York from Ireland at the age of 16 and earned her BS and MSN degrees from NYU. She worked for over 40 years in the New York City Hospital System, retiring in 1973, as Director of Nursing at Jacobi Medical Center. She was a devout and active parishioner of St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 9am to 10:30am Monday. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Monday, May 23 at 10:45am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to Melanoma Awareness & Research at Katesfoundation.com. 1/3

TEMPERLEY--Joe, long regarded as one of jazz's leading baritone saxophonists, died on May 11 in New York City. He was 88. Temperley's 60-year career in jazz was highlighted by long stints in both the Duke Ellington Orchestra and the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra. In addition to his own varied discography as a bandleader, and sharing a bandstand with Billie Holiday, Frank Sinatra, Ella Fitzgerald, Barbra Streisand, and many more, Temperley was a beloved educator who helped aspiring musicians grow both in the United States and his native Scotland. Temperley was born in the town of Lochgelly, in Fife, Scotland on September 20, 1927. His father was a bus driver - a rarity in a town where most men worked in the coalmines - and his mother took care of the household. For his fourteenth birthday he was given an alto saxophone by his older, trumpet- playing brother Bob. He took to the horn immediately, practicing whenever he wasn't working in a local butcher shop. By age 17, he had switched to tenor saxophone, and his success with an ensemble that won a big band competition in Glasgow landed him a spot in a Glaswegian jazz quintet. Temperley's talent quickly took him to London, where he played with some of Great Britain's leading jazz ensembles. In 1958, he switched to baritone saxophone to perform with trumpeter Humphrey Lyttelton's band - widely regarded as one of the best jazz ensembles outside of the United States - and the instrument soon came to be his instrument of choice. Temperley traveled with Lyttelton to America for the first time in 1959. That trip left an indelible impression on him. He decided to get back to the thriving New York City jazz scene as soon as possible. The move finally happened on December 16, 1965 when Temperley boarded the Queen Mary and set sail for the U.S. When he first arrived in New York, he stayed at the Bryant Hotel and sold transistor radios as he looked for gigs. His first regular job, obtained with help from friends pianist Nat Pierce and drummer Jake Hanna, was with famed bandleader Woody Herman's New Thundering Herd. That soon led to a spot in the Thad Jones/Mel Lewis Orchestra as well as gigs with luminaries like Clark Terry, Duke Pearson, and Joe Henderson who appreciated Temperley's lush, soulful sound. "My approach to playing is purely vocal," Temperley once said. "If you can get all the air out singing a note, there's no reason you can't do it on a saxophone." Moving to the U.S. allowed Temperley to befriend one of his heroes, Harry Carney, the long-tenured baritone saxophone chair for Duke Ellington's orchestra. When Carney died in 1974 - just months after Ellington himself passed Temperley was asked to perform at the funeral, where he played the jazz legend's signature "Sophisticated Lady." Soon after, Mercer Ellington Duke's son, who'd stepped into his father's position as bandleaderasked Temperley to take Carney's place in the orchestra. That led to a fourteen-year stint with the world's most storied big band. "My main influence was - and still is - the Duke Ellington Orchestra," Temperley told Smithsonian Magazine in 2011. "That has always been my prime motivation for playing music, for playing jazz." In 1988, a few years after he'd left the Ellington Orchestra to pursue other opportunities, Temperley received another life- shaping call. This time, it was to join Wynton Marsalis and the newly created Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra. Temperley occupied the JLCO's baritone saxophone chair for the next 28 years, touring the world many times over, serving both as the ensemble's elder statesman and the definitive model for the baritone saxophone's sound. Temperley taught on the faculty of the Juilliard School for Jazz Studies for many years. He was a mentor and co-founder of the FIFE Youth Jazz Orchestra program in Scotland, which now enrolls 70 young musicians, ages 7-17, playing in three full-size bands. He released many albums as a leader including Nightingale (1991), Sunbeam and Thundercloud with pianist Dave McKenna (1996), With Every Breath (1998), and Double Duke (1999). More recently, he released Cocktails for Two (2007) on Sackville and The Sinatra Songbook (2008) on Hep Jazz. His film soundtrack credits include Cotton Club, Biloxi Blues, Brighton Beach Memoirs, When Harry Met Sally, and Tune In Tomorrow. He is survived by his wife of 32 years, Laurie, his son Dr. Matthew Lurin, his sister Helen, and many nieces and nephews. 1/3

POLLACK--Mark S. We mourn the untimely death of our beloved Mark, our cherished and devoted cousin. Our hearts are forever broken. STROM--Victor T.,age 90, of Ridgewood, NJ and Lake George, NY, on April 19, 2016. Beloved husband of Neva M. (nee Nichols). Loving father of Neva D. Strom (Thomas L. Dula), Dina Grant, and the late Rolf T. Strom. Adoring grandfather of Nikolas and Hannah Dula, and John, George, and Katherine Grant. LEONARD--Polly. "Polly" Leonard, the devoted wife of Rev. Dick Leonard of New York City for 46 years. Born September 9, 1924, in Lancaster, PA, Anna Barr Leonard died peacefully on May 14, 2016, in Lawrenceville, GA, after battling Alzheimer's for seven years. Her first marriage, which ended in divorce, was to Stanley C. Mason during WWII. Their three children, Helen Thilo Bigelow, Kenneth Grant Mason, and Martha Jean Mason, joined Dick's two daughters, Suzanne Sykora and Elizabeth Leonard, in an eventual extended family of almost 200 persons, which included their parents, their siblings with their families, seven grandchildren, six great-grandchildren, plus innumerable relatives and in-laws. Polly was the matriarch, delighting in the yearly family reunions. At the same time, she assisted Dick in his church and excelled in the banking world, doing investigations for Citibank CEO's Walter Wriston and John Reed. She was a marvelous cook. Her winsome spirit is missed by her family, her friends, and her congregation at the All Souls Unitarian Church, where a memorial will be held in the Fall. Donations in her name can be made to the Alzheimer's Association or to All Souls Church, 1157 Lexington Ave., NY, NY 10075. 1/3

RACHLIN--Helen Raebeck, died May 13th, 2016 at the age of 99. Born in Brooklyn, she attended Erasmus Hall High School, Barnard College, and Columbia University Graduate School. She spent her entire career working to improve women's lives. For twenty years, she was the Director of Public Affairs and Training at the National Council of Jewish Women. In 1968, Dorothy Height offered her a position at the National Council of Negro Women, where, in 1970, she established The Women's Center for Education and Career Advancement, an organization which has assisted over 40,000 New York City women. Helen Rachlin was strong, independent and intelligent. She cared deeply for her family and cherished her lifelong friends. She loved nothing more than walking or sitting at the beach, having a martini, and doing the crossword puzzle. She was married to Carl Rachlin, a Labor and Civil Liberties Attorney, for 52 years. She is survived by her daughters, Margaret Pine and Ruth Rachlin Menard, her sons-in-law, Larry Pine and Andrew Menard, three grand-children Jacob Pine, Kate Menard and William Menard, and three great- grand children, Ruby Pine, Sadie Pine, and Kellen Menard. 1/3

GILMARTIN--Michael J.,Born: December 30, 1950, Died: May 17, 2016 of heart failure. Founder of Gilmartin Studio, he was a highly respected woodworker and furniture designer in Atlanta, GA. for nearly 40 years. Known for the award winning 'Gilmartin Chair,' his works are in the permanent collection of numerous museums including the Brooklyn Museum of Art and the High Museum of Art; he was exhibited nationally and is in prized private collections. A native New Yorker, Michael was a graduate of Chaminade, Binghamton University, SUNY Buffalo, where he received his MBA, and Penland School of Crafts. A member of a large, gregarious New York family, Michael was predeceased by his father James. He leaves his mother Adelaide; sisters Christine Cavanaugh (Tom), Eileen Gilmartin (David Lavallee), and Dorothy Acquino (Dominick); his brothers Bob and Jim (Ann); and many nephews, nieces and grand nephews and nieces; a myriad of cousins; and host of deeply close friends, colleagues and clients. Family services will be held at St. Barnabas, Bellmore, NY on May 24. 1/3

DURST--David. The Board of Directors and staff of the Hebrew Free Loan Society mourn the passing of David Durst, whose unparalleled generosity changed the course of countless lives. David expressed his deep devotion to the Jewish community through his work with HFLS, where he provided leadership in many ways, including serving as board President for a decade. We extend our heartfelt condolences to David's beloved children, Jody, Joshua, Kristoffer, Laurel, and Robin; his wife Carola; his grandchildren; and the entire family. 1/3

SAFER--Morley. When Morley recently visited us and walked into our new building for design, he maintained his robust gait and warm smile full of humor while mocking his need for a cane. His face lit up when he gazed upwards at the lighting fixture Josef Albers created for the Weimar Bauhaus. He declared it, and Anni Albers's colorful maquette for a synagogue arc curtain, two of the most surprising and splendid art works of the last century. "Simply wonderful," he said, with his resonant voice and contagious enthusiasm. He held to his strong opinions about recent art, and revered what he admired with abiding passion. We send our deepest love to brilliant, beautiful Jane and the family he adored. Nicholas Fox Weber, The Josef and Anni Albers Foundation 1/3

SULTZER--Barnet Martin, 87, passed away on May 20, 2016 in New Paltz, NY. PHD of Microbiology and Immunology. Among his many scientific accomplishments they would include patents for chemical detoxification of endotoxins and the discovery of the genetic basis for mammalian responses to endotoxins including immunological and pathophysiological effects and the development of the first commercial immunological pregnancy test. Beloved husband to Judith M. Sultzer, proud father to Steven B. Sultzer and father-in-law to Robin E. Sultzer, loving grandfather to Rachel L. Sultzer and Samantha N. Sultzer and devoted brother to the late Rhoda L. Boughton. Science and Family, The Love of His Life. Graveside Service will be held at 1pm, Monday, May 23, 2016 at the Beth-El Cemetery, 735 Forest Ave., Paramus, NJ 07652. 1/3

KRAMER--Sarah Greenberg, passed away at home peacefully after a long and meaningful life at the age of 96 surrounded by her family. She leaves her three loving children, Noelle Parket, Marilyn Kramer Weitzman (Kahn) and Glenn Kramer and their respective spouses, Robert Parket, Thomas Graham Kahn and Lynn Wechsler Kramer. She leaves seven devoted grandchildren and their spouses, ten loving great-grandchildren and many caring relatives and friends. Her beloved husband, Philip Kramer, former President and CEO of Hess Corporation predeceased her. Sarah was a beautiful, independent woman who moved from humble beginnings to a luxury New York City building and still maintained her modest demeanor. She frequented the ballet, theater and museums, but was always available for family and her most beloved spouse. Within the last few months, she continued to lead an active life. A funeral service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street at Amsterdam Avenue, on Monday, May 23 at 11:15am. The family will be sitting Shiva on Monday, May 23 and Tuesday, May 24 from 4:30pm-8:00pm at the home of Marilyn Weitzman Kahn, 25 Central Park West and on Wednesday, May 25 and Thursday, May 26 from 3:00pm-5:00pm and 7:00pm-9:00pm at the home of Noelle Parket. Anyone wishing to celebrate Sarah's life may contribute to CaringKind - The Heart of Alzheimer's Caregiving, Attention: Lou-Ellen Barkan, 360 Lexington Ave., 4th floor, NY, NY 10017. 1/3

BEGUN--Martin S.,whose long and distinguished career in the fields of medicine, public service and community relations set the highest standard, died suddenly on Saturday of complications from pneumonia. He was 85 years old, but remained actively engaged to the end of his life. He is survived by his loving wife of nearly 20 years, the real estate entrepreneur Louise Sunshine, step-children Suzanne, Samuel and Paul Sunshine, and three step-grandchildren Alexa and Marc Mendel and Arielle Sunshine. Born to Judith and Michael Begun, Martin grew up in New York City, which remained the center of his life and activities. He received a BA from the University of Wisconsin, and an MA from the Department of Public Law and Government from Columbia University, where he also did post-Graduate work. He was a Senior Fellow at Taub Urban Research Center of NYU's Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Administration. Martin performed Military service as a Sergeant in the Army National Guard from 1955-1960. He served as Chairman of the New York State's Liberal Party. Martin was a partner in Reiter/Begun, a private sector consulting marketing and management firm for governmental and community relations. He was also President and Founder of MSB Strategies, a public policy planning consulting firm. Prior to that, Martin, also known as Dean Begun, served for more than 35 years at New York University School of Medicine and Medical Center as Senior Associate Dean and Vice President for External Affairs with Dr. Saul Farber. Martin was a member of numerous boards, and was Board Chair for the Baruch School of Public Affairs, as well as a board member for the Parks Council of New York City, the New York City Economic Development Corporation, and the American Red Cross of Greater New York. He was Chairman of the Community Services Board of the New York City Department of Mental Health and Mental Retardation, and Chairman of the Board of the New Milford Foundation. He served on the New York State Hospital Review and Planning Council, on the Task Force on Police Community Relations, and on Governor Pataki's Task Force on Health Care Facilities in the 21st Century. He was appointed by Mayor Giuliani to the New York City Korean War 50th Anniversary Commemorative Commission, was a Member of the Battery Park City Authority, the New York City Campaign Finance Board, and the Jonas Center. He was President of the Jewish Community Relations Council of New York, board member of Lechters, Inc., and a member of the Advisory Board at Tri Cap Health Group. Martin has received many honors including those from Housing and Human Services, the Metropolitan Council on Jewish Poverty, and the Coalition of Voluntary Mental Health Agencies. He loved classical music, theater, politics, and spending time in Florida with Louise and Beni. The funeral service and interment will be held on Wednesday at 10am. A memorial service will take place in June. The family requests in lieu of flowers, contributions to the American Red Cross or the American Jewish Distribution Committee (JDC) would be appreciated. 1/3

CODEY--John. The Salk Institute for Biological Studies honors the memory of our friend John Codey, whose vision as a tireless supporter of science was transformative for many fields of biomedical research. As a Trustee of the Helmsley Charitable Trust, Mr. Codey was central to the founding of the Helmsley Center for Genomic Medicine at the Salk Institute. Since its founding, the Center has produced groundbreaking discoveries in cancer, diabetes and mental disorders, offering new hope for conquering these diseases. Mr. Codey's support of the Salk Institute was just one of many examples of how he worked for the betterment of humanity. He will be greatly missed, but his legacy will carry long into the future. On behalf of Irwin M. Jacobs, Chairman of the Salk Board of Trustees, the entire Salk Board of Trustees, Dr. Elizabeth Blackburn, President of the Salk Institute, the senior leadership and the faculty and staff of the Salk community, we expresses our deepest sympathy for Mr. Cody's family. 1/3

HOFFMAN--Edna Sonia Ranow, was born in New York, and died in Bridgeport, CT, on May 22, 2016, at the age of 96. The cherished daughter of Paula Firestone Ranow, Edna was the treasured wife of Maurice Jerome Hoffman of Bridgeport, whom she married on September 15, 1940, after her graduation from Vassar College. Edna and Maury, who lived their magnificent lives in Bridgeport and Fairfield, were perfect co-partners and co-paragons for 54 loving years, until Maury's death in 1995. We, Edna's children -- Elisabeth (Alan) Doft, Constance (Yves) de Balmann, Laurence Hoffman, and Bruce Hoffman, plus eight grandchildren -- Michael Doft, Jonathan Doft (Dr. Melissa), Rachel Doft (John Wareck), Raphael de Balmann (Courtney), Gabriel de Balmann, Paul Hoffman, Andrew Hoffman, Daniel Hoffman, plus five great-grandchildren -- Andrew and Alexander Doft, Eliza Wareck, Alexander and Natalie de Balmann -- have lost our mother's glowing presence, but we will never lose our memories of her unending kindness, selfless generosity, incisive intellect, and enthusiastic joie de vivre. Immersed in life-long learning and culture, she was equally committed to "repairing the world." Always contributing, effective, high-minded, and principled, she had a seriousness of purpose combined with an innate grace and lightness of touch which made her totally irresistible. She was the star that lit up our firmament, and she has left a stellar legacy for us all. Her life was -- and her memory will always remain -- an undying blessing. The funeral will be at 11am on Wednesday, May 25th, at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 2385 Park Ave., Bridgeport, CT 06604. Elisabeth and Alan Doft welcome friends for shiva at the Plaza Athenee Hotel (37 E. 64th St.), on Thursday, May 26th, from 4-7, and Friday, May 27th, from 2-5. 1/3

PAPERT--Fred. Paul Travis and Washington Square Partners mourn the passing of Fred Papert. Fred left an indelible mark on the city he loved. From fighting to save Grand Central to being the pioneer in the revitalization of Times Square, he changed the course of New York City. He believed that a great city was marked by the intersection of history, culture and growth, most notable in the development of Theatre Row on West 42nd Street which stands as his legacy. He will be missed. Paul Travis, Washington Square Partners 1/3

CODEY--John. The Salk Institute for Biological Studies honors the memory of our friend John Codey, whose vision as a tireless supporter of science was transformative for many fields of biomedical research. As a Trustee of the Helmsley Charitable Trust, Mr. Codey was central to the founding of the Helmsley Center for Genomic Medicine at the Salk Institute. Since its founding, the Center has produced groundbreaking discoveries in cancer, diabetes and mental disorders, offering new hope for conquering these diseases. Mr. Codey's support of the Salk Institute was just one of many examples of how he worked for the betterment of humanity. He will be greatly missed, but his legacy will carry long into the future. On behalf of Irwin M. Jacobs, Chairman of the Salk Board of Trustees, the entire Salk Board of Trustees, Dr. Elizabeth Blackburn, President of the Salk Institute, the senior leadership and the faculty and staff of the Salk community, we expresses our deepest sympathy for Mr. Cody's family. 1/3

DUBE--Alexander J. (1948 - 2016) The dance world lost a dedicated advocate last week. Alexander J. Dube, who led Career Transition For Dancers since 2001 and was instrumental in integrating their programs and services into The Actors Fund last year, passed away at the age of 67. He had a great passion for dancers and worked tirelessly for the dance community. The Actors Fund sends condolences to his family and his many friends. 1/3

BEGUN--Martin S. Donald J. Trump and The Trump Organization are deeply saddened by the passing of Martin Begun, husband of the wonderful Louise Sunshine. Martin was a dear friend and great humanitarian. He had a long and extremely distinguished career, and was admired and respected by all who knew him. Our sincere condolences to Louise and family on this very somber occasion. 1/3

RATNER--Michael. North Star Fund deeply mourns the loss of Michael Ratner, a lion of the global social justice movement. A founding donor and longtime advisory board member, Michael was ever there for us. Our heartfelt condolences go out to Karen, Ana, Jake and everyone at the Center for Constitutional Rights and those in New York City's broader progressive community who knew, loved and respected our dearest and most fierce donor leader. 1/3

KRAMER--Sarah Greenberg, passed away at home peacefully after a long and meaningful life at the age of 96 surrounded by her family. She leaves her three loving children, Noelle Parket, Marilyn Kramer Weitzman (Kahn) and Glenn Kramer and their respective spouses, Robert Parket, Thomas Graham Kahn and Lynn Wechsler Kramer. She leaves seven devoted grandchildren and their spouses, ten loving great-grandchildren and many caring relatives and friends. Her beloved husband, Philip Kramer, former President and CEO of Hess Corporation predeceased her. Sarah was a beautiful, independent woman who moved from humble beginnings to a luxury New York City building and still maintained her modest demeanor. She frequented the ballet, theater and museums, but was always available for family and her most beloved spouse. Within the last few months, she continued to lead an active life. A funeral service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street at Amsterdam Avenue, on Monday, May 23 at 11:15am. The family will be sitting Shiva on Monday, May 23 and Tuesday, May 24 from 4:30pm-8:00pm at the home of Marilyn Weitzman Kahn, 25 Central Park West and on Wednesday, May 25 and Thursday, May 26 from 3:00pm-5:00pm and 7:00pm-9:00pm at the home of Noelle Parket. Anyone wishing to celebrate Sarah's life may contribute to CaringKind - The Heart of Alzheimer's Caregiving, Attention: Lou-Ellen Barkan, 360 Lexington Ave., 4th floor, NY, NY 10017. 1/3

REICH--Samuel. With profound sadness, we mourn the passing of our dear friend, Samuel Reich. To his wife, Betty, children, Rachelle (Stephen) Winters, Nathan (Lauren) Reich and Helene Reich (Aric Gitomer), his sister, Barbara Chodosz and his grandchildren, we offer our condolences and sympathies. May the entire Reich family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Cecile and Edward Mosberg, Beatrice Mosberg, Louise and Stuart Levine, Caroline and Darren Karger and Families 1/3

BEGUN--Martin S. I have a had a long and rewarding career as a physician, author, teacher and researcher, which would not have been possible without the extraordinary help of Marty Begun when he was Dean at NYU School of Medicine. I, and a multitude of others, are eternally grateful to him. He will be missed but never forgotten. Steven R. Goldstein, M.D. Professor of Obstetrics and Gynecology NYU Langone Medical Center 1/3

BEGUN--Martin. The Board of Trustees of the Sackler School of Medicine NY State American Program of Tel Aviv University mourn the loss of our friend, fellow Trustee, and Founding Member since 1976. We send our very sincerest condolences to Louise and the family. We have worked with Martin for half a century and will miss his guidance and sense of humor and special personality more than can be stated. 1/3

KLEINBERG--Belle, nee Koenigsberg, of San Diego died peacefully in her sleep on Sunday, May 22, 2016 at age 97. Beloved wife of the late Cantor Jacob Kleinberg. Loving and devoted mother of Ann Robin "Bobbin" and Nahman David "Nik". Cherished aunt and faithful friend to many. Her life of charitable deeds created a path for all to follow as we mourn the loss of this beautiful woman of valor. Graveside services will take place at Cedar Park Cemetery, 735 Forest Ave., Paramus, NJ on Wednesday, May 25, 2016 at 12:30pm. 1/3

BEGUN--Martin S.,who had a long and distinguished career in the fields of medicine, public service and community relations, died suddenly on Saturday of complications from pneumonia. He was 83 years old, but remained actively engaged to the end of his life. He is survived by his loving wife of nearly 20 years, the real estate entrepreneur Louise Sunshine, step-children Suzanne, Samuel and Paul Sunshine, and three step-grandchildren Alexa and Marc Mendel and Arielle Sunshine. Born to Judith and Michael Begun, Martin grew up in New York City, which remained the center of his life and activities. He received a BA from the University of Wisconsin, and an MA from the Department of Public Law and Government from Columbia University, where he also did post-Graduate work. He was a Senior Fellow at Taub Urban Research Center of NYU's Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Administration. Martin, performed Military service as a Sergeant in the Army National Guard from 1955-1960. He served as Chairman of New York State's Liberal Party. Martin was a partner in Reiter/Begun, a private sector consulting marketing and management firm for governmental and community relations. He was also President and Founder of MSB Strategies, a public policy planning consulting firm. Prior to that, Martin, also known as Dean Begun, served for more than 35 years at New York University School of Medicine and Medical Center as Senior Associate Dean and Vice President for External Affairs with Dr. Saul Farber. Martin was a member of numerous boards, and was Board Chair for the Baruch School of Public Affairs, as well as a board member for the Parks Council of New York City, the New York City Economic Development Corporation, and the American Red Cross of Greater New York. He was Chairman of the Community Services Board of the New York City Department of Mental Health and Mental Retardation and Alcoholism, and Chairman of the Board of the New Milford Foundation. He served on the New York State Hospital Review and Planning Council, on the Task Force on Police Community Relations, and on Governor Pataki's Task Force on Health Care Facilities in the 21st Century. He was appointed by Mayor Giuliani to the New York City Korean War 50th Anniversary Commemorative Commission, was a Member of the Battery Park City Authority, the New York City Campaign Finance Board, and the Jonas Center. He was President of the Jewish Community Relations Council of New York, board member of Lechters, Inc., and a member of the Advisory Board at Tri Cap Health Group. Martin has received many honors including those from Housing and Human Services, the Metropolitan Council on Jewish Poverty, and the Coalition of Voluntary Mental Health Agencies. He loved classical music, theater, politics, and spending time in Florida with Louise and Beni. The funeral service and internment will be held on Wednesday at 10:30am at Congregation Rodeph Sholom at 7 W. 83rd St, New York City. A memorial service will take place in June. The family requests in lieu of flowers, contributions to the American Red Cross or the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) would be appreciated. 1/3

SHAPIRO--Ronald, of Great Barrington, MA and Daytona Beach, FL, died peacefully at his home in Florida on May 21, 2016 at the age of 83. He is survived by his loving wife Evelyn, devoted children Alan (Nancy), Marci Silbert (Graeme) and Amy Guenzl (Simon), eight grandchildren and his brother, Lewis Shapiro. He was philanthropic, charitable and lived life to the fullest. Graveside service will be at 10am at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery in Glendale, NY followed by a Memorial Service at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel" at 12:30pm on Madison Avenue and 81st Street. 1/3

BEGUN--Martin S. JBI International, Inc. (established in 1931 as The Jewish Braille Institute) mourns the passing of its Trustee and good friend Martin S. Begun. Our condolences to his wife, family and many friends. He will be missed. May his memory serve as a blessing. Judy E. Tenney, Co-Chairman of the Board Steven P. Polivy, Co-Chairman of the Board Dr. Ellen Isler, President & CEO Israel A. Taub, Vice President & CFO 1/3

CARP--Rhoda (nee Reich), passed away peacefully on Sunday at an assisted living facility in a Philadelphia suburb. Loving wife of the late Dr. Leon Carp, beloved mother and grandmother of Marc, Michael, Jeffrey and Ned and their children, and devoted sister of Seymour Reich of Manhattan and the late Lorraine Firstman, Rhoda was full of fun and life and will be missed very much. The funeral will be today in Philadelphia. Seymour D. Reich 1/3

BEGUN--Martin S. The Jewish Community Relations Council of New York mourns the passing of our beloved esteemed Past President, Martin S. Begun. Martin was an exceptionally compassionate leader, counselor and friend. His wise guidance and vivacious personality will be sorely missed. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Ronald G. Weiner, President Charles S. Temel, President-Elect Michael S. Miller, Exec. VP and CEO 1/3

BEGUN--Martin, Elegant, funny, smart and wise, caring. He was the essence of humanity. We will miss him deeply. Martin I. Hassner Executive Director Liberal Party of New York 1/3

HOFFMAN--Miriam. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Miriam Hoffman, who leaves behind a loving family who carry on a tradition of exceptional Jewish philanthropy. We extend our condolences to Miriam's beloved children, Alan (Nancy) and Stacy; and to the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3

CODEY--John. The Salk Institute for Biological Studies honors the memory of our friend John Codey, whose vision as a tireless supporter of science was transformative for many fields of biomedical research. As a Trustee of the Helmsley Charitable Trust, Mr. Codey was central to the founding of the Helmsley Center for Genomic Medicine at the Salk Institute. Since its founding, the Center has produced groundbreaking discoveries in cancer, diabetes and mental disorders, offering new hope for conquering these diseases. Mr. Codey's support of the Salk Institute was just one of many examples of how he worked for the betterment of humanity. He will be greatly missed, but his legacy will carry long into the future. On behalf of Irwin M. Jacobs, Chairman of the Salk Board of Trustees, the entire Salk Board of Trustees, Dr. Elizabeth Blackburn, President of the Salk Institute, the senior leadership and the faculty and staff of the Salk community, we express our deepest sympathy for Mr. Cody's family. 1/3

PAPERT--Fred. The Board of Directors and staff of Henry Street Settlement mourn the death of Fred Papert, a longtime member of our Board of Directors. We are grateful for his generous support, leadership, and friendship, and extend our deepest condolences to his family. 1/3

REICH--Samuel. With profound sadness, we mourn the passing of our dear friend, Samuel Reich. To his wife, Betty, children, Rachelle (Stephen) Winters, Nathan (Lauren) Reich and Helene Reich (Aric Gitomer), his sister, Barbara Chodosz and his grandchildren, we offer our condolences and sympathies. May the entire Reich family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Cecile and Edward Mosberg, Beatrice Mosberg, Louise and Stuart Levine, Caroline and Darren Karger and Families 1/3

HOFFMAN--Edna Sonia Ranow, was born in New York, and died in Bridgeport, CT, on May 22, 2016, at the age of 96. The cherished daughter of Paula Firestone Ranow, Edna was the treasured wife of Maurice Jerome Hoffman of Bridgeport, whom she married on September 15, 1940, after her graduation from Vassar College. Edna and Maury, who lived their magnificent lives in Bridgeport and Fairfield, were perfect co-partners and co-paragons for 54 loving years, until Maury's death in 1995. We, Edna's children -- Elisabeth (Alan) Doft, Constance (Yves) de Balmann, Laurence Hoffman, and Bruce Hoffman, plus eight grandchildren -- Michael Doft, Jonathan Doft (Dr. Melissa), Rachel Doft (John Wareck), Raphael de Balmann (Courtney), Gabriel de Balmann, Paul Hoffman, Andrew Hoffman, Daniel Hoffman, plus five great-grandchildren -- Andrew and Alexander Doft, Eliza Wareck, Alexander and Natalie de Balmann -- have lost our mother's glowing presence, but we will never lose our memories of her unending kindness, selfless generosity, incisive intellect, and enthusiastic joie de vivre. Immersed in life-long learning and culture, she was equally committed to "repairing the world." Always contributing, effective, high-minded, and principled, she had a seriousness of purpose combined with an innate grace and lightness of touch which made her totally irresistible. She was the star that lit up our firmament, and she has left a stellar legacy for us all. Her life was -- and her memory will always remain -- an undying blessing. The funeral will be at 11am on Wednesday, May 25th, at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 2385 Park Ave., Bridgeport, CT 06604. Elisabeth and Alan Doft welcome friends for shiva at the Plaza Athenee Hotel (37 E. 64th St.), on Thursday, May 26th, from 4-7, and Friday, May 27th, from 2-5. 1/3

PAPERT--Frederic S. The Board and Staff of 42nd Street Development Corp. mourn the loss of our founder, Frederic S. Papert, a tenacious and courageous leader who, as President, led 42nd Street Development Corp. for 39 years. Throughout those years, Fred played a prominent role in transforming the landscape of New York City, particularly the West End of 42nd Street. A resourceful and inspired visionary, Fred launched a mission to transform derelict and abandoned buildings along 42nd Street into a mecca of theatrical art and restaurants, now known as "Theatre Row." An avid lover of the arts, Fred supported fledging theatre groups with grants funded by our organization. As a preservationist, Fred teamed up with Jackie Kennedy Onassis to win the fight to save Grand Central Station from the wrecking ball. Fred's efforts to make NYC a more beautiful place were recognized through numerous honors and awards. We send our deepest condolences to Fred's daughters and their families. A. Jones Yorke, Board Chairman Wendy Rowden, President 1/3

BEGUN--Martin S. We mourn the passing of New York's true champion, whose extraordinary contributions will be long remembered. Deepest condolences to Louise Sunshine and the entire family. Lisa Linden, President and CEO, LAK Public Relations, Inc. 1/3

BEGUN--Martin. The Board of Trustees of the Sackler School of Medicine NY State American Program of Tel Aviv University mourn the loss of our friend, fellow Trustee, and Founding Member since 1976. We send our very sincerest condolences to Louise and the family. We have worked with Martin for half a century and will miss his guidance and sense of humor and special personality more than can be stated. Dr. Raymond and Beverly Sackler Drs. Marlene and Stephen Lazar, Board of Trustees 1/3

PAPERT--Fred. Midtown Manhattan has lost a brilliant champion who changed it for the better in many ways. Our condolences to his family and many friends on the passing of one of our founding directors. Dan Biederman Bryant Park Corporation 1/3

BEGUN--Martin S. We are stunned and saddened by the untimely passing of our friend of over 50 years. Your wit, charm and sense of humor will be sorely missed. The shock of your passing is unbearable. Something we will never get over. We loved you so. Sincere condolences to his wife Louise. The world has lost a gem. Jane and Larry David 1/3

PAPERT--Fred. I am deeply saddened at the passing of "Mr. Papert". He was my fearless leader for the last 17 years of his illustrious tenure as Founder and President of 42nd Street Development Corporation. I learned invaluable lessons from him -- lessons that I didn't learn in college or graduate school. Papert taught me how to fight for what I believe in and to never, never give up. He liked it when I stood up to him appropriately. Working for Mr. Papert was like listening to an autobiography and the history of the city he loved. Although he was known as a demanding champion of preservation and renewal, Mr. Papert was an avid supporter of the arts and culture. He was a writer with quick wit and intellect. Mr. Papert loved his horses and the races. I knew the charming, gentle and compassionate Mr. Papert. He enjoyed gazing at the beauty of the earth as he drove his red BMW out to his beach home in Quogue. Mr. Papert loved his family and friends and his famous "lunch dates". I had a special relationship with Mr. Papert and I won't forget him. I will always remember his humor, his intellect and his books. Thank you Mr. Papert for being a great teacher. You had a long run here. You touched the lives of many. You were gifted with a charmed and highly productive life. Well done, Fred Papert. Well Done. Jacqui L. McMurray 1/3

PAPERT--Fred. Visionaries can find a way to turn a privilege into a right...learning to play the piano has long been only a privilege. Fred Papert felt it should be a right for public school students, particularly in NYC. Not many people can say that they read an article about brain research and turned that experience into a program that has served more than 400,000 elementary school students in close to 300 public schools across NYC and beyond for nearly 20 years. Fred Papert did just that after a lifetime of courageous and successful projects. After reading an article in Newsweek in 1996 that mentioned the impact studying music could have on children's brain development, Fred gathered important thinkers on the subject and used his non-profit 42nd St. Development Corp. to lay the foundation for Music and the Brain. MATB is a program that continues to empower hundreds of music teachers and public schools by making learning the language of music and playing the piano/keyboard a core part of a public school child's educational week. Fred's daughter, Lisha Lercari, who has served as the Program Director for Music and the Brain along with her team members Lisala Beatty and Emina Nusbaum will forever be grateful for the positive changes he made to both the community and individual lives. Farewell FSP -- until we meet again. 1/3

BELKIN--Arlette C.,passed away on May 11, 2016 after a long and courageous battle with heart disease. She is survived by her loving family, husband Gene, daughter, Andrea, son-in-law David, sister Jacqueline, and grandchildren Michael, Marisa and Jonathan. Her daughter Suzanne predeceased her. In addition to being a beloved wife, mother, sister and grandmother, she was also a teacher, educator, artist and community volunteer. Loved by all who knew her, she is greatly missed by her adoring family and friends. 1/3

FAIRCHILD-ISIDORE-- Rosemary, nee Bangham, former resident of New York City, Quogue, LI, and recently of Lakewood NJ, died May 23 following a surgical procedure. Rosemary, 81, raised three children on her own while managing a prominent career in advertising, political consulting, and later, as an advisor/guru/metaphysician to far too many to mention here. You know who you are. Along the way she met the wholehearted love of her life and was the bond that turned two very different families into one big, wonderful -- occasionally chaotic, but always interesting, famiglia. She is survived by her husband Tony, brother Richard, five children -- Chris and Ethan Eichrodt, Ashley O'Keeffe, and Chris and Adam Isidore -- and ten stunning grandchildren -- Alec, Eleanor, Holly, Allison, Griffin, Nico, Sophia, Charlotte, Olivia and Katrina. As a final wish, Rosemary would request you vote for Hillary. She will be greatly missed, long remembered and forever in our hearts. 1/3

CARP--Rhoda (nee Reich), passed away peacefully on Sunday at an assisted living facility in a Philadelphia suburb. Loving wife of the late Dr. Leon Carp, beloved mother and grandmother of Marc, Michael, Jeffrey and Ned and their children, and devoted sister of Seymour Reich of Manhattan and the late Lorraine Firstman, Rhoda was full of fun and life and will be missed very much. The funeral will be today in Philadelphia. Seymour D. Reich 1/3

PAPERT--Frederic. The Board and staff of The Municipal Art Society mourn the passing of Director Emeritus, Fred Papert, one of our City's greatest champions. Frederick Iseman, Chair Gina Pollara, President 1/3
FRIED--Arthur K. A life well lived by a man well loved. Remembered today and every day. Goldy and Your Family 1/3

TOULOUSE--Eileen Weinberg, 64, born on August 31, 1951 in New York City, passed away peacefully in her Montana home on May 21, 2016. She was the adored daughter of Robert F. Weinberg and the late Marilyn Spinoza Weinberg; the loving mother of Stacy Reilly (Sam); Scott Hesse (Whitney); doting and beloved Gammy of Jake and Cameron Reilly. Under the direction of Frank E Campbell "The Funeral Chapel," Madison Ave. and 81st Street. 1/3
BEGUN--Martin S. We have lost a very special friend and the world has lost a unique person. We will miss him always. Love to Louise and the family. The Postel Family 1/3

ROSE--Dr. Murray F.,95. Kind, adored and revered. For many, he was everything. His love of life and contributions will never be forgotten. Survived by his beloved wife Karel, five sons, eight grandchildren. Memorial service at Temple Beth-El, Great Neck, NY, May 26th, 12 noon. 1/3

PAPERT--Frederic S. The Board of Directors of Carnegie Hill Neighbors mourns the passing of Frederic S. Papert, one of the founders (in 1970) and the first president of CHN. His mission to preserve the architectural heritage of Carnegie Hill continues to this day. 1/3

JANIS--George Gary, 74, passed away May 22. Graduate Tulane Law. NYS Administrative Judge (retired). Survived by brother David and sister Lenore. Funeral service Thursday, May 26 at 1pm at Sharon Gardens. 1/3
KAYE--Peter B. Dec. 9, 1955 -May 25, 2014 Another year but our love and memories of you will never diminish nor our tears that would fill an ocean. Mary, Mom, Dad, Jim, Jodi, Matthew and Allison 1/3

PAPERT--Fred. The Board and Staff of The New York Landmarks Conservancy mourn the passing of our former Board Member. Fred's vision, passion and determination were directed at improving civic life and preserving the best of the City. Lloyd P. Zuckerberg, Chair Peg Breen, President 1/3

TEICHER--Laurence. On May 24, 2016. Beloved partner of almost 40 years to Peggy Palmer. Loving, devoted father of Tracy and Michael Nathanson, Daryl and Alan Eisenberg and Allison and Lou Wallach. Adoring grandfather of Jillian and Amanda Eisenberg, Jake and Nicky Nathanson and Charlie and Annie Wallach. Loving brother to Jeffrey and Joyce Teicher and the late Ronny Teicher and adored uncle to his nieces and nephews. A true bon vivant and friend to all, he will be dearly missed. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to New York Presbyterian Hospital or to a charity of your choice. Service will be Thursday, May 26 9:30am at The Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 91st St. 1/3

WALDMAN--Hilda. Died peacefully on May 24, 2016 after suffering a massive stroke. The wife of the late Edward A. Waldman, she was 95. Loving wife, mother and grandmother, she is survived by her son Lawrence and his sons David and Jeffrey. Predeceased by her beloved son, Robert, survived by his children Rachel, Brett and Alexandra. Her brother Edward Schachter, his wife Lucy and daughter Susan Fleisher were very close to her. Hilda grew up in Cologne, Germany and immigrated to the United States in 1938. She married Edward in 1946 and dedicated her life to her family and home. When Edward developed dementia, she worked tirelessly to have him remain at home. Services Friday 11:15am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations may be made to the Cancer Center, Mount Sinai Hospital. 1/3

KAYE--Peter B. 12/9/55 - 5/25/14 It has been two heartbreaking years. The pain of your loss and absence never goes away. I think of you every hour of every day. With everlasting love, I remain lost without you. Mary 1/3

BEGUN--Martin S.,who had a long and distinguished career in the fields of medicine, public service and community relations, died suddenly on Saturday of complications from pneumonia. He was 83 years old, but remained actively engaged to the end of his life. He is survived by his loving wife of nearly 20 years, the real estate entrepreneur Louise Sunshine, step-children Suzanne, Samuel and Paul Sunshine, and three step-grandchildren Alexa and Marc Mendel and Arielle Sunshine. Born to Judith and Michael Begun, Martin grew up in New York City, which remained the center of his life and activities. He received a BA from the University of Wisconsin, and an MA from the Department of Public Law and Government from Columbia University, where he also did post-Graduate work. He was a Senior Fellow at Taub Urban Research Center of NYU's Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Administration. Martin, performed Military service as a Sergeant in the Army National Guard from 1955-1960. He served as Chairman of New York State's Liberal Party. Martin was a partner in Reiter/Begun, a private sector consulting marketing and management firm for governmental and community relations. He was also President and Founder of MSB Strategies, a public policy planning consulting firm. Prior to that, Martin, also known as Dean Begun, served for more than 35 years at New York University School of Medicine and Medical Center as Senior Associate Dean and Vice President for External Affairs with Dr. Saul Farber. Martin was a member of numerous boards, and was Board Chair for the Baruch School of Public Affairs, as well as a board member for the Parks Council of New York City, the New York City Economic Development Corporation, and the American Red Cross of Greater New York. He was Chairman of the Community Services Board of the New York City Department of Mental Health and Mental Retardation and Alcoholism, and Chairman of the Board of the New Milford Foundation. He served on the New York State Hospital Review and Planning Council, on the Task Force on Police Community Relations, and on Governor Pataki's Task Force on Health Care Facilities in the 21st Century. He was appointed by Mayor Giuliani to the New York City Korean War 50th Anniversary Commemorative Commission, was a Member of the Battery Park City Authority, the New York City Campaign Finance Board, and the Jonas Center. He was President of the Jewish Community Relations Council of New York, board member of Lechters, Inc., and a member of the Advisory Board at Tri Cap Health Group. Martin has received many honors including those from Housing and Human Services, the Metropolitan Council on Jewish Poverty, and the Coalition of Voluntary Mental Health Agencies. He loved classical music, theater, politics, and spending time in Florida with Louise and Beni. The funeral service and internment will be held on Wednesday at 10:30am at Congregation Rodeph Sholom at 7 W. 83rd St, New York City. A memorial service will take place in June. The family requests in lieu of flowers, contributions to the American Red Cross or the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) would be appreciated. 1/3

PAPERT--Frederic. Working for Fred Papert at 42nd Street Development Corporation, I was privileged to watch how his amazing vision and tenacity transformed a derelict block of West 42nd Street into Theatre Row. What an extraordinary teacher he was. He showed how seemingly impossible ideas can become reality. I will miss my dear friend always. My deepest condolences to his daughters, Lisha and Emily. Patricia Zedalis 1/3

RAINONE--Nanette, age 73, died May 23, 2016. A fierce fighter against sexism, racism, war, intolerance, and, most recently, cancer, she was a dedicated daughter, mother, wife, friend, and artist. She pioneered on-air consciousness-raising at WBAI radio, created the Brooklyn Bridge Centennial, founded the Celebrate Brooklyn concert series, the Rotunda Gallery and the nonprofit arts and media organization BRIC, and took on ceramic sculpture with energy and passion. She was predeceased by her husband Harvey Schultz and is survived by her beloved son Bruno, stepsons Jason, Matthew, and Daniel, granddaughter Maxine, step-grandchildren Jack, Daniel and Evangeline, brother Martin, nephews Rocky and Shaun, and many loving family members, colleagues and friends. Services will be at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. and W. 91st St., on Tuesday May 31 at 3pm. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to Planned Parenthood, BRIC, Greenwich House Pottery, or the Women's Studio Workshop in Rosendale, NY. 1/3

TOULOUSE--Eileen Weinberg, 64, born on August 31, 1951 in New York City, passed away peacefully in her Montana home on May 21, 2016. She was the adored daughter of Robert F. Weinberg and the late Marilyn Spinoza Weinberg; the loving mother of Stacy Reilly (Sam); Scott Hesse (Whitney); doting and beloved Gammy of Jake and Cameron Reilly. Eileen was an avid golfer, philanthropist and cherished friend to many. Graveside Service will be Saturday 11am at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY followed by a celebration of her life on Tuesday, May 31st at Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street, 5-8pm. Under the direction of Frank E Campbell "The Funeral Chapel," Madison Ave. and 81st Street. 1/3

RAINONE--Nanette. BRIC mourns the loss of its founder Nanette Rainone, a trail-blazer who brought together artists, audiences, celebrities, donors and government officials to galvanize the Brooklyn community and spearhead community revitalization through the arts. Nanette led The Fund for the Borough of Brooklyn (later renamed BRIC) from 1979-2002. She launched ground-breaking programs and initiatives including the Celebrate Brooklyn! Performing Arts Festival, The Rotunda Gallery, the Welcome Back to Brooklyn Festival, Brooklyn Community Access Television, Art in the Anchorage (of the Brooklyn Bridge), the New York Beer Fest, and many other programs. She commissioned a study for adaptive reuse of the former Strand Theater on Fulton Street, which laid the groundwork for the development of BRIC House. Nanette was a great collaborator and led partnerships with BAM, the Brooklyn Museum, Brooklyn Public Library, Prospect Park, Brooklyn Botanic Garden, Brooklyn Historical Society, Arts at St Ann's, and many others. She was a force for good, and Brooklyn has benefitted greatly from her efforts. She will be missed, and was loved dearly by those who worked under her leadership. Hilary Ackermann, Board Chair Leslie Schultz, President Jack Walsh, Vice President 1/3

WALDMAN--Hilda. Died peacefully on May 24, 2016 after suffering a massive stroke. The wife of the late Edward A. Waldman, she was 95. Loving wife, mother and grandmother, she is survived by her son Lawrence and his sons David and Jeffrey. Predeceased by her beloved son, Robert, survived by his children Rachel, Brett and Alexandra. Her brother Edward Schachter, his wife Lucy and daughter Susan Fleisher were very close to her. Hilda grew up in Cologne, Germany and immigrated to the United States in 1938. She married Edward in 1946 and dedicated her life to her family and home. When Edward developed dementia, she worked tirelessly to have him remain at home. Services Friday 11:15am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations may be made to the Cancer Center, Mount Sinai Hospital. 1/3

ROSE--Dr. Murray F. Sonia, Jessica, Barbara, Keen Babes for Social Justice, send love and condolences to Karel Rose, our wonderful sister founding member. We always considered Murray an honorary member. Our hearts go out to you. 1/3

PAPERT--Frederic S. The Board and Staff of 42nd Street Development Corp. mourn the loss of our founder, Frederic S. Papert, a tenacious and courageous leader who, as President, led 42nd Street Development Corp. for 39 years. Throughout those years, Fred played a prominent role in transforming the landscape of New York City, particularly the West End of 42nd Street. A resourceful and inspired visionary, Fred launched a mission to transform derelict and abandoned buildings along 42nd Street into a mecca of theatrical art and restaurants, now known as "Theatre Row." An avid lover of the arts, Fred supported fledging theatre groups with grants funded by our organization. As a preservationist, Fred teamed up with Jackie Kennedy Onassis to win the fight to save Grand Central Station from the wrecking ball. Fred's efforts to make NYC a more beautiful place were recognized through numerous honors and awards. We send our deepest condolences to Fred's daughters and their families. A. Jones Yorke, Board Chairman Wendy Rowden, President 1/3
LANOIL--Dr. Jerry, of White Plains, NY, died peacefully on May 24 at the age of 73. Funeral services will be held at noon on Friday, May 27 at the Riverside Funeral Chapel, in Mt Vernon, N.Y. 1/3

COWIN--Daniel. It has been 24 years since you left us. Those who were acquainted with you miss your intelligence, quiet manner, empathy and friendship. For those of us who knew you best, we miss you on a daily basis. Your kindness, intense support of our endeavors, wisdom, taste, patience and innate strength of character. Would that you could return to us! With love, Kenneth, Andrew, Dana and Joyce 1/3

KRASNER--Harvey, age 89, of Port Washington, NY passed away on May 11. Beloved husband of Gladys for 68 years, father of Margot, Howard and Cindy, loving grandfather and great-grandfather. Harvey was a pioneer in the data communications industry. He is best remembered for his wit, integrity, love of travel and snorkeling. 1/3

TEICHER--Laurence. On May 24, 2016. Beloved partner of almost 40 years to Peggy Palmer. Loving, devoted father of Tracy and Michael Nathanson, Daryl and Alan Eisenberg and Allison and Lou Wallach. Adoring grandfather of Jillian and Amanda Eisenberg, Jake and Nicky Nathanson and Charlie and Annie Wallach. Loving brother to Jeffrey and Joyce Teicher and the late Ronny Teicher and adored uncle to his nieces and nephews. A true bon vivant and friend to all, he will be dearly missed. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to New York Presbyterian Hospital or to a charity of your choice. Service will be Thursday, May 26 9:30am at The Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 91st St. 1/3

MUELLER--Suzanne Carreau (Sue or Sazie). Died on May 21, 2016 in Westwood, Massachusetts at the age of 92, after a life devoted to her family and the important communities of her life. She died in her sleep with family present after a period of decline. Born in New York City, Sue was the daughter of Helen and Louis Carreau. She attended Rye Country Day School and graduated from Wellesley College in 1946, after which she worked at Time Life in New York City. She married Carl Mueller, an engineer turned banker, in 1948. Sue and Carl raised a family of five children in Ridgewood, New Jersey, then moved to Manhattan where they lived for thirty-two years. During her busy years in Ridgewood and continuing through the first decade of this century, Sue served on a number of boards and organizations in addition to her active role as wife and mother. She was a trustee of the Ridgewood Public Library, and then the New York Public Library where she helped to launch significant fundraising and other innovative initiatives. She served for many years as a trustee of Wellesley College where she led numerous fundraising efforts. Carl and Sue have been longtime summer residents and maintained a home on Nantucket Island. Sue was a trustee of the Nantucket Land Council, a conservancy organization. For the past twelve years she and Carl have lived at Fox Hill Village in Westwood, Massachusetts. Sue enjoyed reading--surrounding herself with books. She loved travel, and was a skilled tennis player well into her 80s. She is survived by her husband Carl Mueller of Westwood; her five children, Anne Redman of Seattle, Fred Mueller (Karen) of Providence, Elizabeth Wales (Karen) of Seattle, Charles Mueller of New York, and Henry Mueller (Gerilyn) of New Rochelle; her ten grandchildren, Thomas Wales of London, Jorma Mueller (Christine) of Arlington, Alex Mueller of Arlington, Amy Wales (Erik) of Seattle, Ian Redman of Seattle, Carreau Mueller Ryder (Jon) of Boston, Toby Mueller of Providence, Ross Mueller (Laura) of New York, Graham Redman of Seattle, and Carl Mueller of Santa Barbara; and her four great- grandchildren, Joren and Sonia Pearson, Lincoln Mueller, and Gideon Mueller. Her family will miss Sue and remember her special mix of spirit, strength and style. Currently, a small private service is being planned. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Nantucket Land Council or to the Alzheimer's Association. George F. Doherty & Sons Funeral Home, Needham, MA 781-444-0687. 1/3

BERNSTEIN--William. The Downtown Alliance mourns the passing of our Chief Operating and Chief Financial Officer, Bill Bernstein, a former city official who played a significant role in shaping our vision and work for nearly two decades. Starting at the Alliance in 1997, he served as acting president three times and helped guide the Alliance during several tumultuous periods in Lower Manhattan's history, including the attacks of September 11, 2001 and Hurricane Sandy. Before joining the Downtown Alliance, Bill was the First Deputy Executive Director of the New York City Department of City Planning for more than ten years. Prior to this, he worked for the New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development's Rent Control Division and for the New York City Loft Board. Esteemed by the staff at the Alliance and a beloved mentor to many, he was an avuncular presence and was often sought after for advice of both a professional and personal nature. A devoted husband, Bill lost his wife Donna in 2013. A longtime resident of Flatbush, Brooklyn, Bill attended New York City public schools, including Stuyvesant High School, and graduated from City College of New York and New York University School of Business. He was 64 at the time of his death. In addition to his son Adam Bernstein, he is survived by his sister, Dava Jo Zavodnick. 1/3

WALLER--Allen C, 96, of Rye, NY and The Ocean Reef Club, Key Largo, FL passed away on May 24th. Loving and devoted husband of Gladys for almost 64 years. Beloved father of Richard "Cass", daughter-in-law Jill, and the late Robert. Cherished grandfather of Jamie, Dana, Tracy and Gregory. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to The American Cancer Society 132 W. 32nd Street, NY, NY 10001 Attn: Jackie Walsh. 1/3

PAPERT--Frederic S. The Graduate Center, CUNY, deeply mourns the loss of Frederic S. Papert, who served on the Board of Visitors and was a long-tenured trustee of the Graduate Center Foundation. Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chairman; Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Emeritus; Neil G. Bluhm and Laurie M. Tisch, Co-Chairmen; Rich DeMartini, President; Adam D. Weinberg, Alice Pratt Brown Director 1/3
