BERNSTEIN--William. The Downtown Alliance mourns the passing of our Chief Operating and Chief Financial Officer, Bill Bernstein, a former city official who played a significant role in shaping our vision and work for nearly two decades. Starting at the Alliance in 1997, he served as acting president three times and helped guide the Alliance during several tumultuous periods in Lower Manhattan's history, including the attacks of September 11, 2001 and Hurricane Sandy. Before joining the Downtown Alliance, Bill was the First Deputy Executive Director of the New York City Department of City Planning for more than ten years. Prior to this, he worked for the New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development's Rent Control Division and for the New York City Loft Board. Esteemed by the staff at the Alliance and a beloved mentor to many, he was an avuncular presence and was often sought after for advice of both a professional and personal nature. A devoted husband, Bill lost his wife Donna in 2013. A longtime resident of Flatbush, Brooklyn, Bill attended New York City public schools, including Stuyvesant High School, and graduated from City College of New York and New York University School of Business. He was 64 at the time of his death. In addition to his son Adam Bernstein, he is survived by his sister, Dava Jo Zavodnick. 1/3

WALLER--Allen C. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished longtime member, Allen Waller. To his family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. The beautiful qualities of his life shall endure forever. 1/3

RAINONE--Nanette. BRIC mourns the loss of its founder Nanette Rainone, a trail-blazer who brought together artists, audiences, celebrities, donors and government officials to galvanize the Brooklyn community and spearhead community revitalization through the arts. Nanette led The Fund for the Borough of Brooklyn (later renamed BRIC) from 1979-2002. She launched ground-breaking programs and initiatives including the Celebrate Brooklyn! Performing Arts Festival, The Rotunda Gallery, the Welcome Back to Brooklyn Festival, Brooklyn Community Access Television, Art in the Anchorage (of the Brooklyn Bridge), the New York Beer Fest, and many other programs. She commissioned a study for adaptive reuse of the former Strand Theater on Fulton Street, which laid the groundwork for the development of BRIC House. Nanette was a great collaborator and led partnerships with BAM, the Brooklyn Museum, Brooklyn Public Library, Prospect Park, Brooklyn Botanic Garden, Brooklyn Historical Society, Arts at St Ann's, and many others. She was a force for good, and Brooklyn has benefitted greatly from her efforts. She will be missed, and was loved dearly by those who worked under her leadership. Hilary Ackermann, Board Chair Leslie Schultz, President Jack Walsh, Vice President 1/3

FINSIE--Geraldine Bohrod, 86. Beloved daughter, wife, mother and grandmother. Predeceased by her husband Sherwin. Beloved mother of Marita Altman (Michael) and Brian Finsie (Cynthia), and adored grandmother of Samantha Gardner (Evan), Theodore Altman, Leah Finsie and James Finsie. Donations may be made to the Hebrew Home at Riverdale and the Metropolitan Opera. 1/3

BATLLE--Luis. Three generations of musicians, audiences and the family members of the Marlboro Music School and Festival mourn the loss of their beloved musician, pianist and friend who shared his wisdom, artistry, his humor and humanity with rare generosity. Our hearts reach out to his wonderfully compassionate and loving wife Geraldine Pittman de Batlle, his children Eliza, Luis, Leopoldo and Jorge and his grandchildren. His spirit lives on through all those he touched. The Marlboro Music Family Mitsuko Uchida, Artistic Director 1/3

WALLER--Allen C, 96, of Rye, NY and The Ocean Reef Club, Key Largo, FL passed away on May 24th. Loving and devoted husband of Gladys for almost 64 years. Beloved father of Richard "Cass", daughter-in-law Jill, and the late Robert. Cherished grandfather of Jamie, Dana, Tracy and Gregory. Funeral services will be held at 11:00am on Friday, May 27th - Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Rd, Scarsdale, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to The American Cancer Society 132 W. 32nd Street, NY, NY 10001 Attn: Jackie Walsh. 1/3
LANOIL--Dr. Jerry, of White Plains, NY, died peacefully on May 24 at the age of 73. Funeral services will be held at noon on Friday, May 27 at the Riverside Funeral Chapel, in Mt Vernon, N.Y. 1/3

WALDMAN--Hilda. Died peacefully on May 24, 2016 after suffering a massive stroke. The wife of the late Edward A. Waldman, she was 95. Loving wife, mother and grandmother, she is survived by her son Lawrence and his sons David and Jeffrey. Predeceased by her beloved son, Robert, survived by his children Rachel, Brett and Alexandra. Her brother Edward Schachter, his wife Lucy and daughter Susan Fleisher were very close to her. Hilda grew up in Cologne, Germany and immigrated to the United States in 1938. She married Edward in 1946 and dedicated her life to her family and home. When Edward developed dementia, she worked tirelessly to have him remain at home. Services Friday 11:15am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations may be made to the Cancer Center, Mount Sinai Hospital. 1/3

GUEOVJIAN--John, of The Landings on Skidaway Island, Savannah, GA, formerly of Pelham Manor, NY, died on Saturday, May 21, 2016. John is survived by his wife, Lynette Love; two daughters, Marion (Erich) Altvater, of Woodbridge, Connecticut; Denise (Steve) Miller and their daughters, Anna and Bethie Miller of Skillman, New Jersey. Remembrances may be made in John's Memory to Hospice Savannah, Inc., P.O. Box 13190, Savannah, GA 31406. Please sign our on-line guestbook at: foxandweeks.com Fox & Weeks Funeral Directors, Hodgson Chapel is in charge of services. 1/3

HOFFMAN--Edna. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Edna Hoffman, who leaves behind a loving family who carry on a tradition of exceptional Jewish philanthropy. We extend our condolences to Edna's beloved children, Elisabeth Doft (Alan), Constance de Balmann (Yves), Laurence, and Bruce; her grandchildren; her great- grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3

DUBE--Alexander J. (1948-2016). The Board of Directors, Staff and Friends of the National Museum of Dance were deeply saddened to hear of the passing of Alexander Dube on May 19, 2016. Alex was a kind, generous, creative and larger-than life character, giving his life to the dance world, through his tireless work and fundraising for Career Transition for Dancers. His constant support of the National Museum of Dance and Hall of Fame was not only sincerely appreciated, but instrumental in many of the institution's successes and achievements. His passion for dance, dancers and the arts was clear, and was at the heart of everything he did. The National Museum of Dance and Hall of Fame sends its sincere condolences to all those touched by the life of Alexander Dube. May he live on in the wonderful memories so many shared with him. 1/3

GRANT--Alfred D.,M.D., passed away on May 26, 2016 at the age of 82. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, uncle, friend, and not least of all, doctor. He is survived by Ellen Michels Grant, Michele Grant, Laura Grant Dagan, the late Susan Grant Kaplansky, Edan, Shir, Tamir, Gil and Eliyah Kaplansky; Danielle and Sean Dagan; Jeffrey Michels and Gustavo Carillo. He is Loved by many and will be Missed by all. Service 11:30am today at "The Riverside" 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

TROSS--Lee. We are very saddened by the news that the mother of our esteemed and dear partner, Scott Tross, passed away yesterday. We express our heartfelt sympathy and condolences to Scott and his wife, Evangeline, to their children, Brian and Emily, and to all of the other members of Scott's family. Herrick, Feinstein LLP 1/3

GRANT--Alfred D.,M.D. The NYU Hospital for Joint Diseases Department of Orthopaedic Surgery mourns the passing of our esteemed colleague and friend Dr. Alfred D. Grant, Clinical Professor of Orthopedic Surgery at the NYU School of Medicine. Dr. Grant was an important part of the Hospital for Joint Diseases for over 55 years. During many of these years, he held important clinical leadership positions that enhanced the name and reputation of the Division of Pediatric Orthopaedics, the Department and the Institution. He was a national and international leader in the care of children with orthopaedic and neuromuscular problems. A respected clinician and educator, Dr. Grant contributed to the education of over 300 orthopaedic residents and fellows creating a legacy of patient care that will continue for decades. We send our heartfelt condolences to his wife Ellen, daughters Laura and Michele and his seven grandchildren. Funeral services will take place at Riverside Chapel on Friday, May 27 at 11:30am. His family has requested that donations in Dr. Grant's memory be directed to the Alfred and Ellen Grant Visiting Professorship at NYU Langone Medical Center. Joseph D. Zuckerman, M.D. and Dr. Alfred Grant's colleagues and friends in the NYUHJD Department of Orthopaedic Surgery 1/3
CHAIKIN--Stacey 59/2015/m. Best wife, mother, daughter, sister and nana. To her memory we sing, now and forever. Eric, Lee, Shana & family 1/3

LEE--Wol Sue (Chun) Wol Sue Lee (Chun) has passed peacefully at her home in Scarsdale, New York. Born in Cheonan, South Korea on January 11, 1938, Wol Sue studied English Literature at Ewha Womans University in Seoul, graduating with honors in 1960. In 1963 she followed love seven thousand miles across the Pacific Ocean to Boston, where she married John Jongjin Lee and earned her Masters in Education at Boston University. John and Wol Sue moved to Nashville, Tennessee in 1968, where she earned a Masters in Library Science at Peabody College. In 1970 Wol Sue took a job at the New York Public Library where she ultimately served as Head Reference Librarian at the Mid-Manhattan branch. For 38 years she answered questions for New Yorkers on every conceivable topic, finally retiring from NYPL in 2008. Warm hearted and quick to laugh, Wol Sue took care of everyone around her. She is survived by her husband John, children Carol and Christopher, her grandchildren Jack, Moose, and Ellie who will miss their Halmony deeply, her sisters Yang Soo Kim, Yun Soo Lim and Nam Sue Chun, and her brothers Myung Soo Chun, Chong Soo Chun and Moon Soo Chun. She was preceded in death by her sister Ae Sue Jin. Memorial services will be held at Scarsdale Community Baptist Church on Saturday, May 28, 2016 at 2 o'clock. Donations can be made to the Wol Sue (Chun) Lee Scholarship at Ewha Womans University through the International Foundation of Ewha Womans University (IFEWU) at 475 Riverside Drive, Rm 1505, NY, NY 10115. Raise a glass (small) of Harvey's Bristol Cream and remember her well. 1

ROSE--Dr. Murray F. Sonia, Jessica, Barbara, Keen Babes for Social Justice, send love and condolences to Karel Rose, our wonderful sister founding member. We always considered Murray an honorary member. Our hearts go out to you. 1/3

SESSIONS--L. William (Bill), died peacefully on May 13 at age 96 with his family gathered at home in New Canaan, CT. He lived a vibrant life with love for his family, friends and community. He is survived by his wife of 72 years Nancy, sons Stuart (Elizabeth Morrison) of Chevy Chase, MD and David (Kathleen Donohoe) of Ypsilanti, MI, daughters Andy (Martin Zenni) of Andersonville, TN and Brooke (Hank Berkowitz) of Rowayton, CT and nine grandchildren: Tina (Spencer Pahlke), Carrie, Sarah, Steve, Rob, Billy, Jake, Colton and Mike. A memorial service will be held May 28 at 11am at St. Mark's Episcopal Church, 111 Oenoke Ridge Road, New Canaan, CT, with a reception to follow nearby. 1/3

GARBER--Cherri Brooks-Altman. The Child Mind Institute mourns the loss of Cherri Brooks-Altman Garber, mother of our Co-Founder and Board Chair Brooke Garber Neidich. Cherri was a beautiful and elegant lady who had endless dreams that her daughter made real. We send our sympathy to Brooke and Dan, Mallory, Stephen, Aliza, Jon, Alessandra, and their extended family and many friends. Debra G. Perelman, Vice Chair Harold S. Koplewicz, M.D., President Child Mind Institute 1/3

MUELLER--Suzanne C. The Trustees and staff of The New York Public Library deeply mourn the passing of Suzanne C. Mueller, a devoted and beloved member of the Library family. A dedicated Library Trustee for more than three decades, she was a founding co-chairman and longstanding honorary chairman of the Library's Conservators Program, home to a generous group of Library donors established in 1979. A strong advocate and active fundraiser for the Library, she and her husband Carl were also generous Library supporters themselves. We offer our deep sympathies to Carl and all of her family and friends. Evan R. Chesler, Chairman; Samuel C. Butler, Catherine Marron, Elizabeth Rohatyn, Marshall Rose, Neil L. Rudenstine, Chairmen Emeriti; Anthony W. Marx, President 1/3

FEINBERG--Arthur. Born March 22, 1935 in the Bronx, NY, Married in the Bronx, NY. Died complications from Diabetes. Brother of Ernest (deceased) and Lita (deceased). Surviving are Judith, his devoted wife of 59 years, his loving children, Robert, Meredith and Kenneth and his four adored granddaughters. Graduate of Stuyvesant High School and Hunter College. He was a high school English teacher at Evander Childs and retired from The Bronx High School of Science. He was also a high school football coach at Evander Childs. In retirement, in addition to extensive traveling, Arthur taught adult education classes in New Rochelle at LYRIC. Arthur had a broad range of interests which included the theater and opera. His favorite sports teams included the New York Yankees, Giants and Tottenham Hotspur. 1/3

His passion for dance, dancers and the arts was clear, and was at the heart of everything he did. DOUGLAS--Paulette Joy. The fiery force that was Paulette Joy Douglas came into this world on March 18, 1950. Born to Helen and Hal in Philadelphia, PA, and raised in Bridgeton, NJ, with her brother Bobby, she graduated from Bridgeton High School in 1968. She had an endless passion for human rights and equality, and was involved in the major social movements of her time: she marched on Washington D.C., she burned her bras. After graduating from Temple University, Paulette embarked on an illustrious television career. She started as a makeup artist on the Mike Douglas Show, but quickly shifted into producing and directing. Paulette was a pioneer in this male- dominated field, and became one of the first female directors in news and sports. She was selected by the AFI's Directing Workshop for Women, for which she made her narrative directorial debut in the feature short The Couch, staring then-up-and-comer Julia Louis Dreyfus. Some of her greatest work was on the numerous featured specials which she produced and directed, including SITV's Vietnam: Long Time Coming, as well as countless productions during her tenure at Sports Illustrated Television. Her dynamic and compassionate work earned her five Emmys, and she left an everlasting impression on all the coworkers who bore witness to her intense passion and artistic vision. In 1987, Paulette married the love of her life, fellow television producer/director, Woody Freiman. Their union produced two daughters, Hannah and Halle Freiman, and one yellow lab, Yogurt. The couple raised their family on the Upper West Side of New York City. Her children were her pride, joy, and favorite source of anxiety. She adored her girls with a ferocious intensity, and she and Woody could not have been happier with the results of their two finest collaborations. In recent years Paulette focused on independent artistic endeavors, producing and directing two brilliant documentary features, The Peglegs of Stuyvesant High and The TEAM Makes a Play. She also continued her lifelong devotion to social justice and care for others: cooking dinners for a local homeless shelter, organizing a CSA, and journeying to Greece with Woody this past December to aid refugees fleeing Syria. In addition to her beloved brother, husband, and daughters, Paulette is survived by countless friends and family, including her half-brother Arthur, and cousins Pam Kaplow and Donald Douglass, who will miss her honesty, her fearlessness, her wisdom, her humor, her penchant for four-letter-words, her beauty, and her spirit. Losing her so soon and so suddenly was no one's plan, but Paulette never stuck to anyone's plan but her own. 1/3

PHILIP--Tania Kaiulani, age 52, died of complications from Amyloidosis on April 27, 2016 in her home in Bronxville, New York, where she lived with her husband Michael Siberry and daughter Chloe Siberry. Born March 18, 1964 in Honolulu, Hawaii to Dr. Alistair G.S. Philip, MD and the late Elin M. Roberts. Tania trained at the National Ballet School in Toronto and danced with the Hamburg Ballet (Germany), Joffrey Ballet, N.Y.C. Opera Ballet and Broadway's Phantom of the Opera. She graduated Magna cum Laude from Columbia University with a B.A. in English Literature and became Senior Vice President of the PR firm WEILL, where she headed media campaigns in South America, Europe, Africa, Middle and Far East. She is survived by her husband and daughter, her father Dr. Alistair G.S. Philip, stepmother Louise Holcumb, sister Katrina, brother-in-law and niece. 1/3

GRANT--Alfred D.,M.D. The NYU Hospital for Joint Diseases Department of Orthopaedic Surgery mourns the passing of our esteemed colleague and friend Dr. Alfred D. Grant, Clinical Professor of Orthopedic Surgery at the NYU School of Medicine. Dr. Grant was an important part of the Hospital for Joint Diseases for over 55 years. During many of these years, he held important clinical leadership positions that enhanced the name and reputation of the Division of Pediatric Orthopaedics, the Department and the Institution. He was a national and international leader in the care of children with orthopaedic and neuromuscular problems. A respected clinician and educator, Dr. Grant contributed to the education of over 300 orthopaedic residents and fellows creating a legacy of patient care that will continue for decades. We send our heartfelt condolences to his wife Ellen, daughters Laura and Michele and his seven grandchildren. Funeral services will take place at Riverside Chapel on Friday, May 27 at 11:30am. His family has requested that donations in Dr. Grant's memory be directed to the Alfred and Ellen Grant Visiting Professorship at NYU Langone Medical Center. Joseph D. Zuckerman, M.D. and Dr. Alfred Grant's colleagues and friends in the NYUHJD Department of Orthopaedic Surgery 1/3

Memorial services are planned in Fort Lauderdale and New York City later this year. 1/3

EDELMAN--Richard Matz, beloved husband of Anne Coyne Holbach, died peacefully at his home in Manhattan on May 25, 2016, at the age of 85. A lawyer and teacher, he had a keen intellect that led him to public service and a career that made him a staunch defender of civil liberties. He was passionate about the arts, in particular poetry, and was a devotee of Shakespeare, Winston Churchill, and Mozart. Born in Brooklyn, he graduated from Poly Prep Country Day School, and earned degrees from Harvard College and Harvard Law School. His first job as a lawyer was working as an assistant district attorney in New York County under Frank Hogan. He went on to work as a prosecutor in Washoe County, Nevada, and later served as counsel at the United States Department of Energy in Washington, D.C. He also worked as a lawyer in private practice in Washington and New York and taught social studies at the Fieldston School in the Bronx. His grandfather was Israel Matz, who founded the Ex-Lax Corporation. In addition to his wife, he is survived by his two sons, David Armstrong Edelman, and his wife Yahne Miorini, and Jonathan Sams Edelman, as well as his sister, Louise Sagalyn, and two grandchildren, Antoine and Annabel Edelman. Visitation will be on Sunday, June 5, from 5pm to 7pm at Frank E. Campbell; a funeral service will be held there on Monday, June 6 at 11:30am, followed by a reception at the Harvard Club between 5pm and 8pm. 1/3

KINGSLAND--Eve Grantham, 94, died May 19. Born and raised Evanston, IL. Radcliffe College,1943. An intellectual beacon in New York literary circles, she enjoyed a prolific 50 year career (mostly under first married name, Eve Auchincloss) as highly esteemed editor, literary and art critic. Associate Editor of Mademoiselle, then of New York Review of Books from NYRB inception; New York Editor of Book World, then Senior Editor of Connoisseur Magazine. Beloved wife of James Kingsland, she and her late husband enjoyed to the fullest European travels, sailing in Maine, and country life in beautiful second homes and gardens in France and Pennsylvania. Her remarkable breadth of talent and intellect, her unerring insight, together with her brightly rewarding smile, leave an indelible impression on all who knew her and will greatly miss her. Her only child Jill Auchincloss predeceased her in 1988. She is survived by nephews and nieces, Kit Grantham of Tucson, AZ; James Grantham of Gainesville, FL; Judith Paton of Helena, MT; Lucy Greszes of Atlanta, GA; Jeremy Grantham of Abingdon, VA; Sarah Williams of Raleigh, NC, and stepchildren Lucia Gesinus-Visser and Nicholas Kingsland. Memorial Gathering to be announced. 1/3

CUSHNY--Cora Cavanagh, passed peacefully at her home in Lexington, KY on May 26, 2016. She was born November 14, 1932, to James F. and Elise Burns Cavanaugh of Glen Head, NY. Funeral Service will be held at St. Paul's Catholic Church in Lexington, KY on Tuesday, May 31, 2016 at 10:00 am with a Memorial Service at 37 Frost Mill Road, Mill Neck, NY at 12:30 pm on June 18, 2016. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to Hospice of the Bluegrass or the United States Equestrian Team. 1/3

DUBE--Alex J.,Dancer Advocate, Pioneer in Unionizing Dance Companies across America, and Executive Director of Career Transition For Dancers (CTFD) at the Caroline and Theodore Newhouse Center for Dancers, died May 19th. Age 67. With the Sono and Victor Elmaleh Foundation Gifts, CTFD's programs and services were expanded, and its yearly galas Netting $1-million-plus revenues, offered Dancers, career counseling, educational and entrepreneurial grants. During CTFD's 30th Anniversary, Alex assisted in integrating CTFD into the Actors Fund. CTFD's dedicated Past Gala Chairs, Anka Palitz, Michele Herbert, Michele Riggi, Ann Van Ness, Patricia Kennedy; Vice Chairs, Janice Becker, Christina Rose, Marisa and Robin van Bokhorst, Irene and Fred Shen; Admiring Friends, Gerald Applestein, Richard Kielar, Christian Zimmermann, Roberta Silbert, Gianni Russo, Sandy, Greg and Ryan Kriser, as well as Thousands of grateful Dancers, mourn his death. Donation in his honor may be sent to: CTFD, Dancer Programs, The Actors Fund, 729 7th. Avenue, NYC, NY 10019. His memory will stay with us. 1/3

SCHWARZ--Patricia, died peacefully at home on May 26, 2016. She was born in Michigan and came to New York to study at The Juilliard School, from which she graduated with an Artists Diploma and B.S. Degree. For 25 years, she was Arts Coordinator of the America-Israel Cultural Foundation. In 1986 the US-China Arts Exchange at Columbia University sent her for a month in China to observe western and traditional Chinese music in the major conservatories. For many years, Mrs. Schwarz was a member of the Music Critics Association of North America and the American Society for Jewish Music. She leaves her beloved son Jack; grandchildren Daniel, Emily and Brian; and her great-grandchildren Jacob, Annie and Sebastian. In 1999 she lost her beloved younger son, K. Robert Schwarz. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Queens College Foundation, Queens College- CUNY, 65-30 Kissena Blvd, Flushing, NY 11367-1597 for the Boris Schwarz Scholarship Fund and the K. Robert Schwarz Archive of Music. 1/3

SULLIVAN--John Francis. Died peacefully at home in Southampton, New York on May 23 with his loving family at his side. Born in Orange, NJ, November 26, 1927 to Margaret Dwyer and John Sullivan. He received his BA from Notre Dame in 1950 and his MBA from NYU in 1959. He was a Founding partner at Faulkner Dawkins & Sullivan a small boutique brokerage firm that later merged with Shearson Hayden Stone and then American Express. In 1978, he Founded Sullivan Morrissey and Mickle where he served as Chairman until his death. His first marriage to Joy Karn produced his daughter Lisa whom he cherished every day. A devoted lifelong golfer, he was a member of Shinnecock Hills Golf Club, Deepdale and Lost Tree. He was also a member of the Southampton Bathing Corporation, and The Meadow Club a reflection of his true love of Southampton. John was devoted to his family. Survived by his wife Gladys of 26 years, daughter Lisa Sullivan Crawford (Philip), grandchildren John and Kingsley Crawford, a stepson Edward Neuburg (Lilliana), Lisa's sister Julia McCormack and Dianne Kelly his assistant of 33 years. Burial will be private. A celebration of his life will take place this summer in Southampton. An announcement will follow. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Hypertension Research Fund at New York Presbyterian Weill Cornell, 424 East 70th Street, New York, NY 10021. 1/3
TEMPERLEY--Joe. Remembering Joe Temperley and all he did for us with gratitude and love. Thanks, Joe. The Board and Staff of Jazz at Lincoln Center 1/3

HOWE--Margaret (Peggy) Burke, died May 15, 2016, at her home in Essex, CT in the company of her children. Margaret was born May 25, 1922, to Elizabeth and John Woolfolk Burke M.D., of Washington, D.C., and was the last surviving child of four. She was married to Arthur Howe Jr. for over 70 years until his death in December 2014. She leaves her four surviving children, Margaret Howe Emmons, of Yarmouth, ME, Samuel A. Howe, of Andover, MA, Arthur Howe, III, of South Portland, ME, and Thomas A. Howe, of Gilmanton, NH. A memorial service will be held at 3:00pm on Saturday, June 11, 2016, at the First Congregational Church of Old Lyme, 2 Ferry Rd., Old Lyme, CT, 06371. Donations in her memory may be made to the Community Music School, PO Box 387, Centerbrook,, CT 06409, or to AFS Intercultural Programs (AFS Archives for Arthur Howe Jr.) 71 W. 23rd St., New York, NY. 10010 1/3

SPILLMAN--Harry J.,of New York City and Ocean Beach, Fire Island. Adored and Cherished Partner of Helen Cunneen, Loving father to Allison Spillman, Blair Burke (Robert) and Lee Spillman, Dear grandfather to Liam and Dylan Burke. A quintessential New York City working actor. He was a lover of Shakespeare and the classics, music, especially jazz, cooking and fine cuisine, gardening, fishing and photography. A modern day renaissance man. Visitation will be Tuesday from 11am to 1pm. Interment to follow Woodlawn Cemetery. Services are being handle by Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel". 1/3

BERENDSEN--Mildred J. The Board of Trustees of The New York Center for Living mourns the death of its Trustee Mildred Jeanmaire Berendsen. Her breadth of knowledge, passion, vision and commitment were invaluable to The Center's success. She was an exceptional Trustee and her kindness and warmth will be greatly missed. We send our heartfelt condolences to her husband Charlie and her sister Liliane. Elizabeth R. Kabler, President Cera B. Robbins, Treasurer 1/3

DUBE--Alexander J.,dancer advocate and artist manager, died from pancreatic cancer on Thursday, May 19, 2016, at the age of 67. Alex was raised in Massachusetts and embraced the athleticism of tap dancing at a young age, studying classical ballet at the famed Robert Joffrey School of Ballet. In 1976, Alex and Isabelle D. Zakin established the first- ever dance management agency concentrating on the needs of dance superstars for opera houses and dance companies around the world. In 1985, Alex joined the American Guild of Musical Artists and also served on the board of directors of Career Transition For Dancers, the first American organization addressing the needs of dancers facing the early aging-out of their careers. In 2001, Alex was appointed Executive Director of CTFD and soon after the organization's President. In 2015, Alex assisted with integrating CTFD into The Actors Fund and continued to serve as an advisor. "To my great surprise and delight, over the course of my career, I've never needed a resume, having always had the good fortune of being the recipient of wonderful opportunities, always serving dancers and dance." 1/3
NEWMAN--William Lloyd. 30 years and you are always in our hearts and thoughts. Your loving family 1/3

FAIRCHILD-ISIDORE-- Rosemary, nee Bangham, former resident of New York City, Quogue, LI, and recently of Lakewood NJ, died May 23 following a surgical procedure. Rosemary, 81, raised three children on her own while managing a prominent career in advertising, political consulting, and later, as an advisor/guru/metaphysician to far too many to mention here. You know who you are. Along the way she met the wholehearted love of her life and was the bond that turned two very different families into one big, wonderful -- occasionally chaotic, but always interesting, famiglia. She is survived by her husband Tony, brother Richard, five children -- Chris and Ethan Eichrodt, Ashley O'Keeffe, and Chris and Adam Isidore -- and ten stunning grandchildren -- Alec, Eleanor, Holly, Allison, Griffin, Nico, Sophia, Charlotte, Olivia and Katrina. As a final wish, Rosemary would request you vote for Hillary. She will be greatly missed, long remembered and forever in our hearts. 1/3

BERENDSEN--Mildred J.,88, passed away May 25. Beloved wife of Charles for 65 years and loving sister to Liliane, she profoundly influenced the lives of countless women who attended The Chapin School in New York where Millie was a history teacher and then headmistress from 1959 until her retirement in 1993. A graduate of Smith College '49, where she received an honorary Doctor of Humane Letters in 1991. Trustee for many years at Trinity Pawling School and the Browning School. Her family and friends mourn her passing and will remember her brilliant mind and her caring and loving spirit. Donations in her memory may be made to The Chapin School or Smith College. 1/3

KERSHNER--Bernard A.,76, of Avon, CT passed away on May 25, 2016. Beloved husband of Bonnie Kershner and father of three sons, Jason, Aron and Mark, he also leaves behind daughter-in-law, Laura, grandson Wyatt and sister Betty. Born in Brooklyn, he held degrees from Bethany College and Cornell University. A pioneer in the field of ambulatory care, he dedicated his professional life to Healthcare Administration. He loved spending time with his family at their ranch in Colorado. 1/3

CODEY--John. The Wildlife Conservation Society expresses sincere condolences to the family and colleagues of John Codey. John was a champion for the environment and his passion and support from the Leona M. and Harry B. Helmsley Charitable Trust has had a significant impact in countries like Myanmar and Madagascar. WCS was fortunate to work with him in these two countries and in efforts to build capacity for environmental stewardship by future generations. We will miss his enthusiasm across our field sites, but will celebrate his vision in our continued work. 1/3

NELSON--Merlin E.,born in Fargo, North Dakota on January 30, 1922, died peacefully at home in New York City on May 26, 2016. He was the youngest son of Theodore G. Nelson and Eva Hultgren Nelson. With Merlin aged two the family moved first to California, camping for the six week journey, then in 1933 they moved to Salem, Oregon (in a Model A Ford and a four-wheeled trailer) where Merlin grew up. He graduated from Salem High School where he became student body president and from the University of Oregon where was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. He was called to active duty in the U.S. Army Enlisted Reserve Corps in 1943, and following training as a demolition specialist, he proceeded in November 1944 to Cherbourg, Normandy, and then with his unit to Holland and Germany. He was wounded on December 11, 1944, and subsequently awarded the Purple Heart. Under the G.I. Bill of Rights he attended Yale Law School and upon graduation joined the Marshall Plan in Washington, DC. In 1952 he joined Davis, Polk, Wardwell in New York City, but by 1958 he was being offered jobs outside the law and in 1962 chose the International Division of AMF, Inc. and lived in London for ten years. He returned to New York in 1971, retiring from AMF in 1984 as Vice-Chairman. In retirement he was actively involved with conservation organizations, principally the Trust for Public Land and the Tuckernuck Land Trust. Devoted to his family, Merlin was always unfailingly generous and loving. He is survived by his wife, Janet; three children, Craig, Claudia and Rolf; and five grandchildren. His son Brian predeceased him. 1/3

ROOME--Dorothy Anne, (nee Haigney), passed away peacefully on the evening of May 16, 2016, after a long and courageous battle with cancer. A longtime resident of Manhattan, Anne distinguished herself as an attorney, a painter, a wife, a sister to six siblings, and as a devoted friend to many. Born in Manhattan on June 3, 1944, she was the eldest child of the late attorney John E. Haigney and his late wife, also named Dorothy Anne. She grew up in Larchmont, New York, and graduated with a bachelor's degree in Fine Arts at Manhattanville College in Purchase in 1966. After graduation, she moved to Manhattan where she resided for the rest of her life. In 1971, she was betrothed to the late Phillip L. Roome who died in 1993. After years of running her household and producing numerous fine oil paintings in her spare time, Anne determined to pursue a legal career by enrolling in Fordham Law School whence she graduated in 1983. From then until her father's retirement in 1997, she was associated with the law firm he had founded and managed, Ide, Haigney & Rado. After she retired from the practice of law, Anne remained active in church and social affairs until her illness prevented her participation. She is mourned by her loving brothers, Stacy, Mark, and Paul, sisters Kate, Jennifer and Courtney, companion Fanny Coll, and innumerable close friends and relatives. A memorial service will be held at the Church of St. Augustine (corner of Larchmont and Cherry Avenues) in Larchmont on Saturday, June 18, at 11am. 1/3

WONG--Pershing. The partners of Pei Cobb Freed & Partners Architects note with sorrow the recent passing of our former Associate Partner Pershing Wong, a gifted designer and accomplished architect who made major contributions to the work of our firm across its first three decades 1955-85. 1/3

CONNORS--Gerald Martin. Born November 10, 1927 in Manhattan, died May 25, 2016 in Sleepy Hollow, NY. Longtime Wall Street Reporter for the New York Daily News. Navy Combat Veteran WWII, Destroyer Escort USS Naifeh; Korea, fireman, battleship USS New Jersey. Survived by his wife, Elizabeth K. Flynn; their children, Andrew Tait (Erica), Kathryn E., Elizabeth M. (Mark Fogle), and grandson Everett Gerald He also had three children from his first marriage: Jonathan M. (Maria), Jennifer Dillon (John), and Anthony B., and five more grandsons. Wake, 4pm-8pm Monday, Coffey Funeral Home, Tarrytown; Mass, 11am, Tuesday, St. Teresa of Avila Church, Sleepy Hollow; Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Valhalla NY. 1/3

BERENDSEN--Mildred J. Members of The Chapin School community mourn the loss of Mildred Jeanmaire Berendsen, who brilliantly led our school for 34 years as Headmistress from 1959 to 1993. Millie will be remembered as a passionate and dedicated leader, a tireless ambassador for women's education, a devoted friend, and a proud supporter of every young woman--the names of whom she always knew--who passed through these doors. We send our deepest condolences to her family and hope they find comfort in the fact that her memory lives on at The Chapin School. 1/3
JARETZKI--Alfred III, MD. Always 1/3

SHAPIRO--Norman, 101, formerly of Flushing, NY, passed away on Sunday, May 22, 2016. He was married to his wife, Trudy for 69 years. He enjoyed sports and held several leadership positions at the Bayside Jewish Center. He served in the Army and Air Force during World War II. He is also survived by his son, Larry, and his wife Barbara of Wayne, NJ; his daughter, Ellen and her husband, Lenny, of New York, NY; grandchildren, Jason and Sara, and their spouses, Jen and Ben, and great-grandsons, Samuel and Henry. He will be sorely missed. Memorial contributions may be made to the American Macular Degeneration Foundation. 1/3

SHAINSWIT--Lisa. Beloved mother and grandmother died peacefully on May 25 at age 93. Vibrant until her last days. Lisa leaves behind her children Carol and Joseph and her grandchildren Ashley and Gregory and son-in-law Stuart. A recognized artist and wife of the late George Shainswit. A renowned chess master. Lisa will be remembered for her beauty, wisdom and indomitable spirit. 1/3
MARCUS--Jane. Dear Jane, We think of you every day. All our love, Michael and Your Family 1/3

NEWMAN--Elle, died peacefully on May 28th. Loving mother of Hilary and Robin and their husbands Stuart and Michael, grandmother to Zoe and Noah, sister to John and his wife Nancy, cousin of Howard and Barbara, aunt of Stephanie and her husband Chris and daughter Samantha, aunt to Matthieu and his wife Jen. A service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St., on Tuesday, May 31st, at 2pm. Donations in Elle's name can be made to Dorot, 171 West 85th St., NY. 1/3

KUWAYAMA--Fumiko Akabane, 84, on May 1, after a lifetime of gracious kindnesses. Beloved sister of Masako Dougherty, Asako and Seiichiro Akabane; treasured aunt; and devoted friend. Predeceased by her husband Kelly. Services in Washington, DC on June 16, 2016 by Joseph Gawler's Sons. In lieu of flowers, gifts to PetSmart Charities (petsmartcharities.org) welcomed. 1/3

BANKS--Seymour. Born 3 Oct. 1917, died 29 May 1996 Hard to believe it's been 20 years! We miss you every day. And no, it's "not better than a poke in the eye with a sharp stick". With love, Miriam, Hannah, Joel, David and the ganze mispocha. 1/3

WOLFF--Raymond A. "Dutch." April 21, 1925 - May 23, 2016. WWII Veteran, musician, Oberlin Conservatory graduate, teacher, dance band leader, husband to Joan. Survived by daughters Margaret and Melora, extended family, and loving friends. 1/3

BATLLE--Luis. Three generations of musicians, audiences and the family members of the Marlboro Music School and Festival mourn the loss of their beloved musician, pianist and friend who shared his wisdom, artistry, his humor and humanity with rare generosity. Our hearts reach out to his wonderfully compassionate and loving wife Geraldine Pittman de Batlle, his children Eliza, Luis, Leopoldo and Jorge and his grandchildren. His spirit lives on through all those he touched. The Marlboro Music Family Mitsuko Uchida, Artistic Director 1/3

KLINGENSTEIN--Diane S. (Dee), died at her home in Maine on May 22, 2016 comforted by her children. Born to Charles W. and Emily W. Stinchfield of Grosse Pointe, MI, her education included receiving diplomas from the Ethel Walker School and Sarah Lawrence College. Then it was on to New York to attend Columbia's School of Social Work while also employed doing social work. In New York she met her husband Bernard Klingenstein (Bud). Married in 1950, they began life together in Purchase, NY. Here they had their three children. Dee's interests, besides her devotion to family were athletics, literature and philanthropy. Dee was predeceased by her husband Bud (2012) and her brothers Charles (1933) and Robert (1994). She is survived by her children Chuck, Geoff and Ginger; their spouses (respectively) Sarah, Alixandra and Michael; two grandchildren; two great-grandchildren as well as her brother-in-law Lee. In lieu of flowers, donations in memory of Dee may be made to either Berea College, C.P.O. 2216, Berea, KY 40404 or the Animal Refuge League of Greater Portland, P.O. Box 336, Westbrook, ME 04098. 1/3

BERENDSEN--Mildred J. The Board of Trustees of The New York Center for Living mourns the death of its Trustee Mildred Jeanmaire Berendsen. Her breadth of knowledge, passion, vision and commitment were invaluable to The Center's success. She was an exceptional Trustee and her kindness and warmth will be greatly missed. We send our heartfelt condolences to her husband Charlie and her sister Liliane. Elizabeth R. Kabler, President Cera B. Robbins, Treasurer 1/3

NELSON--Merlin E.,born in Fargo, North Dakota on January 30, 1922, died peacefully at home in New York City on May 26, 2016. He was the youngest son of Theodore G. Nelson and Eva Hultgren Nelson. With Merlin aged two the family moved first to California, camping for the six week journey, then in 1933 they moved to Salem, Oregon (in a Model A Ford and a four-wheeled trailer) where Merlin grew up. He graduated from Salem High School where he became student body president and from the University of Oregon where was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. He was called to active duty in the U.S. Army Enlisted Reserve Corps in 1943, and following training as a demolition specialist, he proceeded in November 1944 to Cherbourg, Normandy, and then with his unit to Holland and Germany. He was wounded on December 11, 1944, and subsequently awarded the Purple Heart. Under the G.I. Bill of Rights he attended Yale Law School and upon graduation joined the Marshall Plan in Washington, DC. In 1952 he joined Davis, Polk, Wardwell in New York City, but by 1958 he was being offered jobs outside the law and in 1962 chose the International Division of AMF, Inc. and lived in London for ten years. He returned to New York in 1971, retiring from AMF in 1984 as Vice-Chairman. In retirement he was actively involved with conservation organizations, principally the Trust for Public Land and the Tuckernuck Land Trust. Devoted to his family, Merlin was always unfailingly generous and loving. He is survived by his wife, Janet; three children, Craig, Claudia and Rolf; and five grandchildren. His son Brian predeceased him. 1/3

NEWMAN--Elle, died peacefully on May 28th. Loving mother of Hilary and Robin and their husbands Stuart and Michael, grandmother to Zoe and Noah, sister to John and his wife Nancy, cousin of Howard and Barbara, aunt of Stephanie and her husband Chris and daughter Samantha, aunt to Mathieu and his wife Jen. DUBE--Alex J.,Dancer Advocate, Pioneer in Unionizing Dance Companies across America, and Executive Director of Career Transition For Dancers (CTFD) at the Caroline and Theodore Newhouse Center for Dancers, died May 19th. Age 67. With the Sono and Victor Elmaleh Foundation Gifts, CTFD's programs and services were expanded, and its yearly galas Netting $1-million-plus revenues, offered Dancers, career counseling, educational and entrepreneurial grants. During CTFD's 30th Anniversary, Alex assisted in integrating CTFD into the Actors Fund. CTFD's dedicated Past Gala Chairs, Anka Palitz, Michele Herbert, Michele Riggi, Ann Van Ness, Patricia Kennedy; Vice Chairs, Janice Becker, Christina Rose, Marisa and Robin van Bokhorst, Irene and Fred Shen; Admiring Friends, Gerald Applestein, Richard Kielar, Christian Zimmermann, Roberta Silbert, Gianni Russo, Sandy, Greg and Ryan Kriser, as well as Thousands of grateful Dancers, mourn his death. Donation in his honor may be sent to: CTFD, Dancer Programs, The Actors Fund, 729 7th. Avenue, NYC, NY 10019. His memory will stay with us. 1/3

ROOME--Dorothy Anne, (nee Haigney), passed away peacefully on the evening of May 16, 2016, after a long and courageous battle with cancer. A longtime resident of Manhattan, Anne distinguished herself as an attorney, a painter, a wife, a sister to six siblings, and as a devoted friend to many. Born in Manhattan on June 3, 1944, she was the eldest child of the late attorney John E. Haigney and his late wife, also named Dorothy Anne. She grew up in Larchmont, New York, and graduated with a bachelor's degree in Fine Arts at Manhattanville College in Purchase in 1966. After graduation, she moved to Manhattan where she resided for the rest of her life. In 1971, she was betrothed to the late Phillip L. Roome who died in 1993. After years of running her household and producing numerous fine oil paintings in her spare time, Anne determined to pursue a legal career by enrolling in Fordham Law School whence she graduated in 1983. From then until her father's retirement in 1997, she was associated with the law firm he had founded and managed, Ide, Haigney & Rado. After she retired from the practice of law, Anne remained active in church and social affairs until her illness prevented her participation. She is mourned by her loving brothers, Stacy, Mark, and Paul, sisters Kate, Jennifer and Courtney, companion Fanny Coll, and innumerable close friends and relatives. A memorial service will be held at the Church of St. Augustine (corner of Larchmont and Cherry Avenues) in Larchmont on Saturday, June 18, at 11am. 1/3

BERENDSEN--Mildred J. Members of The Chapin School community mourn the loss of Mildred Jeanmaire Berendsen, who brilliantly led our school for 34 years as Headmistress from 1959 to 1993. Millie will be remembered as a passionate and dedicated leader, a tireless ambassador for women's education, a devoted friend, and a proud supporter of every young woman--the names of whom she always knew--who passed through these doors. We send our deepest condolences to her family and hope they find comfort in the fact that her memory lives on at The Chapin School. 1/3

WONG--Pershing. The partners of Pei Cobb Freed & Partners Architects note with sorrow the recent passing of our former Associate Partner Pershing Wong, a gifted designer and accomplished architect who made major contributions to the work of our firm across its first three decades 1955-85. 1/3

FEINBERG--Arthur. Born March 22, 1935 in the Bronx, NY, Married in the Bronx, NY. Died complications from Diabetes. Brother of Ernest (deceased) and Lita (deceased). Surviving are Judith, his devoted wife of 59 years, his loving children, Robert, Meredith and Kenneth and his four adored granddaughters. Graduate of Stuyvesant High School and Hunter College. He was a high school English teacher at Evander Childs and retired from The Bronx High School of Science. He was also a high school football coach at Evander Childs. In retirement, in addition to extensive traveling, Arthur taught adult education classes in New Rochelle at LYRIC. Arthur had a broad range of interests which included the theater and opera. His favorite sports teams included the New York Yankees, Giants and Tottenham Hotspur. 1/3

BUCHWALD--Daniel, of Fort Lee, NJ, formerly of Palm Beach Gardens, FL and Tenafly, NJ died May 29, at age 93. He is survived by his wife, Hazel, children Pamela (Micah Abrams), Gayle (Burt Garson), and grandchildren Natalie Garson, Miriam Garson, and Summer Abrams. He was a loving husband, father and grandfather who will be truly missed. Dan graduated City College Cum Laude and Beta Gamma Sigma, served in WWII as an Army Air Corps weather observer, and was a CPA after the war. He was a partner in Warshaw Clark and Edward Isaacs & Co. from which he retired as a Senior Partner. While living in Tenafly, NJ Dan served on the boards of the Tenafly Schools and Temple Sinai. He also served on the finance committee of Englewood Hospital. There will be private graveside funeral Wednesday, June 1 in Farmingdale, New York. Shiva will be held Wednesday evening-Friday until Shabbat at Hazel and Dan's home 1530 Palisade Ave., Apt 20H, Fort Lee, NJ. For condolences, directions, or information: www.edenmemorial.com or Call 201-947-EDEN. 1/3

SOCOL--Sheldon E.,J.D. The Yeshiva University family is deeply grieved by the passing of our esteemed alumnus and colleague, Dr. Sheldon E. Socol, of blessed memory who served as Vice President for Business Affairs for half a century in the years following his graduation from our then affiliated Brooklyn High School for Boys, and Yeshiva College, and his earning a law degree from the New York University Law School. His wife and all their children are alumni of Yeshiva University Schools. He devoted his efforts to strengthen our institution through his management of the of the University's finances and was committed to the mission of Torah U'Madda as well as to the advancement of each school's goals. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife, Genia "Ginger" Socol and their children, Jeffrey (and Robin) Steven (and Leslie) and Sharon (Sura) and (Steven) Tuchman and their grandchildren. May they be comforted among all whom mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus 1/3

GROFFMAN--Sidney, the patriarch of our large wonderful family died on Saturday, May 28. ASHEN--Frank Z.,of New York City and Monterey, MA. He is survived by his wife Nancy, whom he adored, his children Scott (Christine), Jenifer (Russell), and Benjamin and his grandchildren Rachel, Zachary, Taylor and Savannah, his brother Jeffrey (Michelle) and many nephews, nieces, cousins and friends. Frank had a 30 year career of progressively responsible positions at the NYSE, retiring as Executive Vice President and a member of the Management Committee, with responsibility for Human Resources, Ethics, Security and Administration. He loved going to work each day and also gave back to the community as Chairman of the Board of Better Business Bureau, Vice Chairman of Junior Achievement, President of Stephen Wise Free Synagogue and as a Board Member of many other non-profits. He was also elected to the Lake Buel Tax District Prudential Committee in Western Massachusetts. In retirement, Frank was a committed member, student and leader at the Institute for Retired Professionals at New School University. Curious about everything, he and Nancy loved to travel the world, The Yankees, the theater and a good mystery. Frank had a deep love for his family and tried hard to make the world a better place. He was generous, caring and funny and he will be missed. Remembrances to IRP at New School University or MJHS Foundation. Services will be held at "The Riverside" on Amsterdam and W. 76th St., on June 1 at 2:00pm. 1/3

NOTTIDGE--Mariette B. (Metta), of 176 East 71st Street, New York, NY on May 25, 2016 at Lennox Hill Hospital, New York, age 76. Beloved wife of O. Richard Nottidge and mother of the late Simon F. R. Nottidge; sister of Anne Marie Dwyer, of the late Joseph R. Dwyer and of Jim Dwyer and his wife Anne; sister-in-law to Faith Miller and H. Andrew Nottidge and his wife Pamela; aunt to many nephews and nieces. Metta was born February 1, 1940 in Sydney, New South Wales, to Frank A. Dwyer, barrister and later Justice of the Supreme Court of New South Wales, and the former Anne J. Glennon, of Dublin. After working for barristers for years in Sydney, Metta joined the UN Secretariat in New York where she worked in the office of the Legal Counsel and met Richard working two floors up in the Office of Personnel. They married in her Parish Church in Mosman, New South Wales, on February 11, 1969. Their son, Simon, born November 24, 1969, died November 22, 1989 after a boating accident in Maine. Viewing Thursday, June 2, from 7-9pm at John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Avenue (between 69 and 70), New York; Mass of the Resurrection will be held Friday, June 3 at 11am, St. Vincent Ferrer, Lexington Avenue, New York (at 66th Street). Burial at Nassau Knolls Memorial Park, Port Washington Blvd, Port Washington, NY. 1/3

GROFFMAN--Sidney, the patriarch of our large wonderful family died on Saturday, May 28. STEINHART--Arthur N.,DPM, died May 24, 2016 after a long illness. He was a well-respected professor in the medicine department of the New York College of Podiatric Medicine for more than 30 years, loved and respected by students, staff and patients. A man of many interests and talents, he began making his own craft beers, wines, and specialty breads and cakes under the name "Doc and Family Basement Brewers." He leaves behind a family devastated by his loss, his wife Susan, his sons Joshua and Shawn, Shawn's partner Luke, daughter-in-law Jessie, and grandson Lyle. His sister Joyce predeceased him. His life was devoted to helping others. He will be sorely missed by family, friends and all who knew him. 1/3

ASHEN--Frank Z.,of New York City and Monterey, MA. He is survived by his wife Nancy, whom he adored, his children Scott (Christine), Jenifer (Russell), and Benjamin and his grandchildren Rachel, Zachary, Taylor and Savannah, his brother Jeffrey (Michelle) and many nephews, nieces, cousins and friends. Frank had a 30 year career of progressively responsible positions at the NYSE, retiring as Executive Vice President and a member of the Management Committee, with responsibility for Human Resources, Ethics, Security and Administration. He loved going to work each day and also gave back to the community as Chairman of the Board of Better Business Bureau, Vice Chairman of Junior Achievement, President of Stephen Wise Free Synagogue and as a Board Member of many other non-profits. He was also elected to the Lake Buel Tax District Prudential Committee in Western Massachusetts. In retirement, Frank was a committed member, student and leader at the Institute for Retired Professionals at New School University. Curious about everything, he and Nancy loved to travel the world, The Yankees, the theater and a good mystery. Frank had a deep love for his family and tried hard to make the world a better place. He was generous, caring and funny and he will be missed. Remembrances to IRP at New School University or MJHS Foundation. Services will be held at "The Riverside" on Amsterdam and W. 76th St., on June 1 at 2:00pm. 1/3
HALLINGBY--Paul Jr. In loving memory on the Eleventh Anniversary of your death. You are in my heart eternally. Jo 1/3

BILIK--Al. Age 93, passed away peacefully on May 28, 2016 in Washington, DC after a full, long and love-filled life. Al was born on September 27, 1922 in Brooklyn, NY to immigrants Jacob and Lena Bilik, worked in the family drug store on Coney Island, and graduated from James Madison High School. Al enlisted in the Navy at the age of 19 and served as a medical corpsman on the USS Hyde in the Pacific theatre of World War II, earning the Bronze Star. Al earned his Bachelor's Degree from Brooklyn College, where he met his first wife, Dorothy Seidman, who predeceased him. He later received a Master's Degree in Political Science from Columbia University. He began a long and distinguished career in the American labor movement in the 1950s as an organizer for the United Auto Workers in Connecticut and Kentucky. Settling in Cincinnati, Al raised his first family, served as Council Director for the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees and later as President of the AFL-CIO Labor Council, ran for city council with Dr. Albert Sabin as honorary campaign chairman, and tirelessly built bridges between the labor, anti-poverty and civil rights movements, including leading a contingent of activists to join Rev. Martin Luther King's march on Selma. In the early 1970s, Al moved to Washington, DC to serve as Director of Organizing for AFSCME and oversaw a period of significant nationwide membership growth for the union. He returned to New York City in the early 1980s, where he served as Victor Gotbaum's deputy at AFSCME's District Council 37, and met and was married to Mary Jane Wilson. Al and Mary Jane moved to Washington, DC in 1985, where they put down roots and raised their two sons. Al continued working to strengthen the labor movement, serving as President of the AFL-CIO's Public Employee Department and later as consultant for AFSCME District Council 20. He retired in 2011 at age 89, when kidney disease began to slow him down, but Al remained a force to be reckoned with, always ready to express an opinion or engage on the issues of the day, and never leaving any doubt of his unconditional love for his wife, children and grandchildren. Al's seemingly limitless energy for living life to the fullest, and his advocacy of basic human rights on the job and elsewhere, are an inspiration to all who have known and loved him. He is survived by his loving wife Mary Jane Wilson-Bilik of Washington, DC; daughter Lisa Bilik Forberg of Nashville, TN; sons James D. Bilik of Albany, NY, Michael Bilik of Brooklyn, and Benjamin Bilik of Washington, DC; grandchildren Daniel Forberg, Julia Forberg, Lena Gillern Bilik, and Henry Bilik; son-in-law Richard Forberg, daughter-in-law Mary Bilik, in-laws Pat and Bill Carr, and their daughters Jennifer and Madeleine. Visitation hours are Thursday, June 2nd and Friday, June 3rd, from 5-9pm at Joseph Gawler & Sons Funeral Home in Washington. Donations should be sent to Bread for the City and Martha's Table in lieu of flowers. 1/3

HUNT--Walter. Condolences to Judy and to Walter Hunt's family. Among Walter's many legacies was his instrumental role in the founding and funding of the Center for Architecture. His vision and tireless energy brought the CFA to its seminal role today as a center of information about the built environment. Walter's leadership in the profession was inspiring to everyone he knew. He will be greatly missed. Rolf Ohlhausen 1/3

ORTIZ--Wanda. October 18, 1958 - June 1, 2015. Beloved mother, wife, daughter, sister, and friend to all. 1 year ago today the world became a little less beautiful. Forever in our hearts! Jessica and Richard 1/3

SCHWARZ--Patricia, died peacefully at home on May 26, 2016. She was born in Michigan and came to New York to study at The Juilliard School, from which she graduated with an Artists Diploma and B.S. Degree. For 25 years, she was Arts Coordinator of the America-Israel Cultural Foundation. In 1986 the US-China Arts Exchange at Columbia University sent her for a month in China to observe western and traditional Chinese music in the major conservatories. For many years, Mrs. Schwarz was a member of the Music Critics Association of North America and the American Society for Jewish Music. She leaves her beloved son Jack; grandchildren Daniel, Emily and Brian; and her great-grandchildren Jacob, Annie and Sebastian. In 1999 she lost her beloved younger son, K. Robert Schwarz. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Queens College Foundation, Queens College- CUNY, 65-30 Kissena Blvd, Flushing, NY 11367-1597 for the Boris Schwarz Scholarship Fund and the K. Robert Schwarz Archive of Music. 1/3

BYRNE--James "Jim" III, 79, of Tenafly, New Jersey passed away on Sunday, May 29, 2016. After a short battle with cancer, he passed peacefully at home surrounded by his family and close friends. He is survived by his wife of over 50 years, Carol, his two children and their spouses, Jamie Byrne and Talisa Reeve, Carrie and Alex Putelo and his cherished grandchildren Luke and Lila. Jim was born and raised in Utica, NY, the son of James Henry Byrne II and Ruth Jones Byrne. He had a mischievous spirit as a child, which carried through his life. A graduate of Syracuse Newhouse School of Communications in 1959 and a veteran of the Armed Services, Jim was a devoted fan of the Orangemen and Army Football. Jim, an author and marketing communications professional, had a rewarding career in media and communications including 19 years as a director of marketing for CBS, the director of communications for the United States Football League (USFL), senior vice president at NW Ayer, Assistant Postmaster General of the United States and director of information at CBS News, where he worked closely with Walter Cronkite. He penned several books over his life, including works on the NFL, the Apollo space missions and "The $1 League: The Rise And Fall Of The USFL". His passions included travel, reading, politics, sports and vodka martinis, but most of all his family and close friends. Beginning in 2000, he traveled extensively with his wife, Carol and then beginning in 2011 with Carol and his grandson Luke to incredible destinations including South Africa, Greece, Istanbul, Spain, Portugal, Morocco, China, Tibet and Peru. Family will receive visitors on Thursday, June 2nd between 7pm - 9pm and Friday, June 3rd between 2pm - 4pm and 7pm - 9pm at Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the John Theurer Cancer Center at Hackensack University Medical Center. 1/3

McGOLDRICK--William J.,of Gaylordsville, CT, died at home on Sunday, May 29, 2016. He was born in New Milford, CT, on August 24, 1931, the oldest of three sons born to William F. McGoldrick and Margaret Lillis McGoldrick. He was raised on the McGoldrick Farm, which straddles the Naromiyocknowhusunkatankshunk Brook and Sherman/New Milford town line, owned by the family since 1884. Bill attended the one-room Gaylordsville School and New Milford High School, and graduated from Harvard University with honors in 1952 and Harvard Law School in 1955. Throughout those college years, he returned home every summer to be with his family and help on the farm. In 1955, Bill enlisted in the U.S. Navy. Lieutenant McGoldrick served with distinction for three years as an on-board air controller flying off aircraft carriers traveling to the Arctic and every port on the northern side of the Mediterranean including Gibraltar and Istanbul, plus a stop in Lebanon during the Lebanese Crisis in 1956 and 1957. In 1958, Bill embarked on a 30-year career at J.P. Morgan in New York City, rising through the ranks to Senior Vice President in the Trust & Investment Division. He married Phyllis Gruler in 1959 and settled in Brooklyn Heights, where they raised their son, Sean. But weekends and vacations were spent largely at the farm helping his parents and brother. In 1993, Bill and Phyllis retired to Sherman full-time, where he partnered with his brother, Dick, to take care of the family farm and keep it operating. He was also involved with the Sherman Historical Society, Sherman Chamber Ensemble, Naromi Land Trust, New Milford Visiting Nurse Association and Hospice, and Sacred Heart Catholic Church in Kent. Donations of land and conservation easements to Weantinoge Heritage guarantee that the land Bill loved will be forever preserved for future generations to enjoy. Bill's roots were well established and nourished in those formative years on the farm, where he learned the values of hard work, honesty, loyalty and dedication to family, farm and faith. He inherited his father's soft spoken manner, modesty and work ethic, and his mother's quest for the opportunities that education provided and curiosity to see the world beyond the horizon. Thriving in the competitive arenas of Harvard, the U.S. Navy and J.P. Morgan, Bill never forgot who he was or where he came from. Bill is survived by his wife, Phyllis; his son, Sean; and his brothers, Dave and Dick. A Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated on Friday, June 3, 2016 at 11am at Sacred Heart Church in Kent. Interment will be private. Calling hours will be held on Thursday, June 2nd from 5:00pm to 8:00pm at the Lillis Funeral Home, 58 Bridge Street, New Milford, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the New Milford VNA and Hospice, 68 Park Lane Rd., New Milford, CT 06776 or the Sherman Historical Society, 10 Route 37 Center, Sherman, CT 06784. 1/3

PINDUS--Sarah, age 92, of Hockessin, DE, passed away Saturday, May 28, 2016. Sarah worked side-by-side with her husband of 61 years, the late Oscar Pindus at his store, Tri-Town Pharmacy in Lynbrook, NY. They moved to Hockessin, DE from Merrick, NY in 1984 upon Oscar's retirement. Sarah is survived by daughters, Ellen Jane Kurtz (Robert Kurtz, M.D.) and Nancy Pindus (Henry Hertzfeld); grandchildren, Pamela Kurtz Pardes (James Pardes), Mark Kurtz (Norkie Cosgrove Kurtz), Laura Hertzfeld, and Stephen Hertzfeld, and greatgrandchildren Jake Pardes, Dylan Pardes, Hudson Kurtz, Connor Kurtz, and Ainsley Kurtz. She is also survived by many loving nieces, nephews, grand nieces and nephews, and great-grandnieces and nephews Private graveside services will be in New York. The family suggests contributions to Seasons Hospice, Easterseals, or the AI DuPont Hospital for Children Family Assistance Program. Services handled by Schoenberg Memorial Chapel. 1/3

OLNICK--Sylvia Nadel, passed away peacefully on May 31, 2016 in her 97th year. Beloved and cherished wife of the late Robert S. Olnick, treasured mother of Barbara Lane and Nancy Olnick, adored mother-in-law of Richard Lane and Giorgio Spanu, grandmother of Allison Lane Rubler, Meredith Lane Verona, Eve Margot Lateiner, Robert Olnick Lateiner and Stella Olnick Spanu. Proud great-grandmother of six: Madeleine and Olivia Rubler, Avery, Morgan, Quinn and Dean Verona. Loving aunt of Tobette Feinberg. A graduate of New York University, she was an active supporter of many Jewish charities in New York, Palm Beach and Israel. A dear soul, blessed with beauty, grace and elegance. She was a wonderful woman, wife, mother, grandparent and great-grand- parent. Her loving and comforting nature was a blessing to all who knew her. Her commitment to Jewish life and family was an inspiration and her love made each of us better. We miss her terribly... Funeral service will be held at Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 E. 87th St. at Madison Ave., on June 2nd at 10am. 1/3

GILPIN--Kenneth N.,III, Who had a long and distinguished career as a journalist, died on Thursday, May 5 at 66 from complications of lung cancer. He is survived by his loving wife of 30 years, Katharine Brengle, and two adoring daughters, Eliza and Lucy Gilpin. Born to Kenneth N. Gilpin, Jr. and Lucy Mitchell Gilpin on June 2, 1949, Kenneth grew up in Clarke County, VA. His grandfather was the legendary air power visionary, General William Lendrum "Billy" Mitchell, who is regarded as the father of the United States Air Force. Kenneth received a BA from Union College in 1972 and an MA from the School of Advanced International Studies at Johns Hopkins University in 1976. He then moved to New York City where he began writing for the weekly newsletter, Business International with a focus on European affairs. He next was hired by The Journal of Commerce to write editorials on a range of foreign economic and political topics. From 1980-2004, Kenneth was a business and financial reporter for The New York Times. His stories covered a wide range of international and domestic issues with commentary about the fixed income, foreign exchange, futures and equity markets. The biographical sketches that he wrote with others on the news staff about the lives of people lost during the attacks on the World Trade Center, titled "Portraits of Grief," were among his proudest contributions to the paper. Later, he worked as a contract writer for SAP America, US Trust Company, Merrill Lynch & Co., and UBS. For the past seven years, Kenneth served as a Senior Counselor for the strategic communications firm, The Dilenschneider Group, Inc. He was a member of the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club and the Meadow Club of Southampton. Kenneth loved Mozart, literature, politics, the East End of Long Island, always a good argument, and especially, his "T"s. A memorial service will be held at Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 East 90th St., New York City on Saturday, June 11 at 3:30pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Kenneth's memory may be made to the Lung Cancer Research Foundation or Citymeals on Wheels. 1/3

HERTZ--Judith. We note with sorrow the passing of our longtime member Judith Hertz and extend sincerest condolences to her bereaved family. Rabbi Angela W. Buchdahl, President Abigail Pogrebin, Central Synagogue of New York City 1/3

OLNICK--Sylvia. The Board of Directors and Staff of the American Friends and of the Israel Museum, Jerusalem deeply mourn the passing of Sylvia Olnick, our beloved friend and Board member. Sylvia's dedication to the Museum manifested in gifts to the collections and endowment campaigns and leadership of our Palm Beach benefits. Sylvia and her love for the Museum will be long remembered. We extend heartfelt condolences to Barbara and Rick; and to Allison, Meredith, and the entire family. Stacey Bronfman, President, AFIM; Stephen Lash and Judy Steinhardt, Board Co-Chairs, AFIM; James S. Snyder, Anne & Jerome Fisher Dir., IM; Leah Siegel, Exec Dir., AFIM 1/3

GREENBERG--Henry "Hank". We sadly announce the death of Hank Greenberg, one of the true legends in retailing. He set a standard in leadership that is strived for to this day. He is survived by his beloved wife and best friend, Roz, they were married 64 years, his adored children, Bonnie, Randy, and Amy, and his devoted grandchildren. Funeral services will be at Monmouth Reform Temple on June 2nd at 11am. Shiva will be at the home of Bonnie Klein. Donations in his memory may be made to Monmouth Medical Center Foundation or the Visiting Nurse Association of Central New Jersey. 1/3

SHEN--Fred, of Greenwich, CT passed away peacefully on May 31, 2016 at the age of 74 surrounded by his family. Born in Shanghai, he moved to the US to attend the University of Michigan. In 1986, he founded Shen Milsom & Wilke, one of the largest multidisciplinary consulting firms in the world. He is survived by his wife of 50 years Irene; children Stephanie and Tom; grandchildren Jack, Sukie, Jeremy, Cameron and Harrison. Funeral services will be held on Friday, June 3, 2016 at 11:30am, St. Michaels Church, Greenwich. 1/3
BAILEY-- Lynn Gordon, Sr. Carlsbad, CA, died May 30, 2016, age 80. Memorial Service: June 16, 2016. La Costa Glen. Mooh-Hooh! 1/3
LEVINE--Steven A.,PhD. Today marks the 50th anniversary of your birth; beloved Steven. We miss you terribly every day, but today we celebrate your life. 1/3

READ--Donald Bartow, 86, of Old Lyme, died Tuesday, May 31, 2016 at home. Mr. Read was born on December 11, 1929 in Boston, MA, the seventh son of William Augustus and Edith Fabyan Read. He attended St. Paul's School and received his BA in Art History from Trinity College in Hartford, CT, where he was a member of the St. Anthony Hall. He married Jean (Beasley) in 1954. After a career in the financial industry in Hartford and New York City, he pursued his love of the sea in a position of rigger at a sailmaker in Stamford, CT. His passion for art and fabrication expressed itself in a collection of metal and wood sculptures which can be seen in private collections. After 17 years, he retired and moved to Old Lyme to sail frequently on the Maine coast. Mr. Read is survived by his wife Jean, his two sons R. Bartow Read of Appleton, ME and Mark E. Read of Carmel, CA, four grandchildren and one great-grandchild. He was predeceased by his son J. Miles Read. No services are planned by his request. 1/3

OLNICK--Sylvia Nadel. My sincerest condolences to Sylvia Olnick's children, grandchildren and great- grandchildren on my friend's passing. Sylvia's kind and generous nature, her elegance and sense of humor will always be remembered. Bruce S. Simon 1/3
SAROT--Hortense, age 93. Mother of James Kramon, Elizabeth Harlan, and Patricia Pincus. Stepmother of Ellin Sarot. 1/3

PUNDYK--Bernard. Born in 1925 in New York City to Max and Helen Pundyk. Devoted husband to Marcia Pundyk for 60 years. Loving father of four, grandfather of 10 and great-grandfather of one. A veteran of the Navy, he joined Glamorise Foundations in an entry-level position and rose to become the company's CEO. He worked there for 67 years, until his death, where he created a culture that valued innovation, loyalty and, beyond all else, compassion toward colleagues and their extended families. In addition to his wife, he is survived by his children, Jamie Davis, Jeffrey Pundyk, Jon Pundyk and Joanne Goldberg, their families and the countless friends, colleagues, and associates to whom he has quietly offered support, good counsel and generosity over his many years. 1/3

RESEK--Dr. Carl Peter, died peacefully in his home in Petaluma, California on May 27, 2016 at age 86. Born in the Czech Republic in 1929, Dr. Resek immigrated to the U.S. in 1939. A distinguished scholar and academic of American Intellectual History, Dr. Resek leaves his beloved wife, Dr. Shirley Blum, his two children, Dr. John Resek and Susan Resek, his stepson Jason Blum, and his two grandchildren, Anna Resek and Ethan Miller. 1/3

OLNICK--Sylvia Nadel. The Olnick Organization employees extend our deepest condolences to the Olnick family on the passing of Sylvia Olnick, wife of the late Robert S. Olnick who was a prominent New York real estate developer and the founder of the Olnick Organization. Mrs. Olnick lived a wonderful and long life and was surrounded by people who loved and respected her. Seth Schochet, President of the Olnick Organization 1/3

OLNICK--Sylvia. The partners and staff of Berdon LLP mourn the passing of our client and good friend Sylvia Olnick, under whose guidance the Olnick Organization continued its tradition as one of the most respected and successful development, management and leasing companies in New York. Our fondest thoughts go out to her children, Barbara and Nancy, her grandchildren, and great-grandchildren. We will all miss her dearly. 1/3

OLNICK--Sylvia. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of The Hebrew Home at Riverdale deeply mourn the loss of Sylvia Olnick, beloved wife of our late Trustee Robert Olnick, loving mother of our dear friend Barbara Lane and mother-in-law of our esteemed Trustee Richard S. Lane. Sylvia was a warm, gracious and generous woman who will be missed by all. With deep affection and in profound sadness we extend our heartfelt condolences on the passing of a devoted mother and grandmother. May the entire Olnick and Lane families be comforted among the mourners of Zion. The Hebrew Home at Riverdale Jeffrey S. Maurer, Chairman Daniel Reingold, President & CEO 1/3

KIMBALL--Arthur Ogden. (1931-2016), formerly associated with Columbia University School of Law for thirty-two years, succumbed to a decade of major illnesses shortly after his 85th birthday. Early in the 1960s at the invitation of the late William C. Warren, then Dean, he served as Director of Development. Later, simultaneously as Associate Dean; in addition to steering the Board of Visitors, as well being active on several non-profit boards; last being the Archives of American Art, a bureau of the Smithsonian. He was a longtime member of Phi Beta Kappa (400) and the University Club. Colby College in Waterville, ME (his birthplace) awarded him one of three scholarships. He graduated Cum Laude to follow with an M.B.A. from Columbia's Business School prior to joining the Law School. Retirement was spent in Williamsburg, VA with his wife of 58 years, Bernice. Memorials may be made to the Arthur Kimball Scholarship Endowment Fund, Columbia University School of Law, 435 West 116th Street, New York, NY 10027, established in his honor some thirty years ago by a group of the school's law alumni. 1/3

OLNICK--Sylvia. AJC and the AJC Women's Leadership Board mourn the passing of our beloved friend. With a passion for Israel, the Jewish people, and the rights and dignity of all, Sylvia for decades dedicated herself to a range of philanthropic causes. A longtime member of the AJC Women's Leadership Board, she was honored in 2003 by AJC Palm Beach for her exceptional leadership. We send our heartfelt condolences to her beloved daughters, Barbara Lane and Nancy Olnick Spanu, and their families. AJC CEO David Harris Chair, AJC Women's Leadership Board Cori Berger 1/3

RODILOSSO--Thomas Vincent, died peacefully at home in Palm Harbor, FL on May 28, 2016 following a life full of service, courage and, above all, kindness. Born November 13, 1931, beloved husband to his Bryant High School, Astoria sweetheart, Patricia (Goss), for 62 years, and family man to the core. Enlisted in Air Force at age 19, became one of New York's Bravest, member of Engine 54 and Ladder 4 for two decades. Moved to Tarpon Springs, FL in 1978, joined Emergency Service unit at St. Petersburg Clearwater Airport. With jet black hair, dark eyes and an ever-present, warm smile, Tom was still most recognized by his bright and cheerful personality. Young in spirit and body, he was suddenly challenged by a stroke in 2013. His quiet strength, love of life and incredible courage led to an epic battle that inspired all who witnessed it. His courage was only matched by his kindness, and he leaves a mark that extends far beyond his large family. Predeceased by his sister Josephine Roy. In addition to his wife, Pat, survived by his sister Anne Chatterton of Pinehurst, NC; his five children: T.R. (Patricia) of Naples, FL, Laura Glading (Randy) of Waccabuc, NY, Jennifer Steffes (Mark) of Morrison, CO, Patty Wolfe of Orlando, FL, and Francis (Alison) of Rye, NY; and, most proudly, 12 grandchildren and one great-granddaughter. Donations in Tom's memory may be made to Fisher House (www.fisherhouse.org). 1/3

OLNICK--Sylvia. The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its profound sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member Sylvia Olnick, and extends sincere sympathy to her daughters Barbara Lane and Nancy Latainer and other members of her family. Jeffrey B. Lane, President Warren Spector, Club Secretary 1/3

OLNICK--Sylvia Nadel, passed away peacefully on May 31, 2016 in her 97th year. Beloved and cherished wife of the late Robert S. Olnick, treasured mother of Barbara Lane and Nancy Olnick, adored mother-in-law of Richard Lane and Giorgio Spanu, grandmother of Allison Lane Rubler, Meredith Lane Verona, Eve Margot Lateiner, Robert Olnick Lateiner and Stella Olnick Spanu. Proud great-grandmother of six: Madeleine and Olivia Rubler, Avery, Morgan, Quinn and Dean Verona. Loving aunt of Tobette Feinberg. A graduate of New York University, she was an active supporter of many Jewish charities in New York, Palm Beach and Israel. A dear soul, blessed with beauty, grace and elegance. She was a wonderful woman, wife, mother, grandparent and great-grand- parent. Her loving and comforting nature was a blessing to all who knew her. Her commitment to Jewish life and family was an inspiration and her love made each of us better. We miss her terribly... 1/3

CALAME--Joan M.,died at home in Vero Beach, FL surrounded by family on May 30, 2016. Born in Brooklyn on July 30, 1927 to George and Isabelle Healy and raised in Garden City, she graduated from Trinity College, Washington, DC and earned a Masters from Teachers College, Columbia. Joan retired from teaching high school English to raise her children. A gifted artist who loved golf, singing, travel, and hosting parties and family dinners, she will be remembered for her sense of style, quick wit, unforgettable turns of phrase, knowledge of art and literature, and deep affection for her family. She is survived by her husband of 58 years, Richard J. Calame MD, and her children David, Sally and Richard, her daughter-in-law Mara, five grandchildren and one great-grandson. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated on June 11, 2016 at St. Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset. 1/3
