NELSON--Merlin E. With happy memories of our Honorary Chairman and the thousands of fun miles enjoyed together. The 72nd St. Marathoning and Pasta Club 1/3

TILZER-RHODES--Louise. died June 1, 2016 after a long and brave struggle with brain cancer. She passed away peacefully with her loving husband, William R. Rhodes and her loving daughter Jessica Chestman, at her side. A great portion of Louise's life was devoted to the visual arts which she studied, worked with artists, museums and art collectors, and eventually established and headed Louise Tilzer Rhodes Art Advisory (LTRAA). Louise, who had trained at Mass Mutual and held a life insurance brokerage license, was also involved in financial management and served as the President of Iraglo LLC. Louise and Bill Rhodes had known each other for some years and were married in March 2013. Theirs was an incredibly close and warm relationship, and she was constantly by his side. She and Bill lived in Manhattan and she was a New Yorker through and through. One of her early professional projects was working on an award winning documentary, Richard Hambleton's Nightlife, about the artist who gained great initial attention for his artworks on the streets and the sides of buildings in New York. She attended the Curtis High School on Staten Island, New York City, and went on to Syracuse University where she received a BFA degree summa cum laude in art design and painting and then studied for the masters in art history program at Hunter College. She was to work both with many artists and with art collectors over the years: from working early in her career with photographer Bert Stern as curator of his museum exhibitions, and in the production of his archival platinum prints, especially of "The Last Sitting," a collection of photographs of Marilyn Monroe; to an interview in 2011 at the World Economic Forum in Davos with sculptor and public installation artist Olafur Eliasson. Louise is survived by her husband Bill, her daughter Jessica, her son-in-law Scott Chestman, her three grandchildren, Sam, Jack and Charlie, sister Leslie Krasny and Aunt Joy Herman. The family requests memorial donations be sent to the William Rhodes and Louise Tilzer Glioblastoma Fund at New York-Presbyterian Hospital, Office of Development, 525 East 68th Street, Box 123, New York, NY 10065. If you wish further information regarding the mission of this fund please contact: Barbara Rothenberg, Principal Gift Officer, New York-Presby-terian, 646-317-7324. Funeral Services will be held at 11am on Friday, June 3, 2016 at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel," 81st Street and Madison Ave. 1/3

RANDAZZO--Philip Albert, who was often known as Al, died peacefully at home overlooking Sag Harbor, on June 1, 2016, while surrounded by his loving family. On June 1, the world lost a great artisan and storyteller whose beautiful stonework remains as widespread monuments to his skill and artistry. His family and friends joyfully recall a life of laughter, fishing, dancing, serenades, pancakes, and the quiet strength of a man whose word and handshake were characteristic of his honorable life. Preceded in death by his beloved wife Evelyn, he is survived by his devoted companion, Barbara Rollins, his children, Steven, Sharon, Sheryl and Ralph (Fred), and his loving grandchildren, Kala, Farinn, and Ruby Evelyn. His family, siblings, nieces, nephews, friends, colleagues and neighbors will miss his sparkling eyes and his steadfast reminder that anything is possible with perseverance. He loved the unbelievable. In lieu of flowers, and in celebration of a life well lived, donations may be made to The Retreat www.theretreatinc.org or the East End Hospice www.eeh. org. Reposing at The Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons West Islip Funeral Home, 1225 Montauk Hwy. (1/4 mile west of the Robert Moses Cswy.). Celebration of the Liturgy of Christian Burial Monday, 9:30am at Our Lady of Lourdes R.C. Church, West Islip, LI. Cremation is private. Visiting Saturday 7:00pm until 9:30pm and Sunday 2:00pm until 4:30pm and 7:00pm until 9:30pm. 1/3

GILPIN--Kenneth N.,III, Who had a long and distinguished career as a journalist, died on Thursday, May 5 at 66 from complications of lung cancer. He is survived by his loving wife of 30 years, Katharine Brengle, and two adoring daughters, Eliza and Lucy Gilpin. Born to Kenneth N. Gilpin, Jr. and Lucy Mitchell Gilpin on June 2, 1949, Kenneth grew up in Clarke County, VA. His grandfather was the legendary air power visionary, General William Lendrum "Billy" Mitchell, who is regarded as the father of the United States Air Force. Kenneth received a BA from Union College in 1972 and an MA from the School of Advanced International Studies at Johns Hopkins University in 1976. He then moved to New York City where he began writing for the weekly newsletter, Business International with a focus on European affairs. He next was hired by The Journal of Commerce to write editorials on a range of foreign economic and political topics. From 1980-2004, Kenneth was a business and financial reporter for The New York Times. His stories covered a wide range of international and domestic issues with commentary about the fixed income, foreign exchange, futures and equity markets. The biographical sketches that he wrote with others on the news staff about the lives of people lost during the attacks on the World Trade Center, titled "Portraits of Grief," were among his proudest contributions to the paper. Later, he worked as a contract writer for SAP America, US Trust Company, Merrill Lynch & Co., and UBS. For the past seven years, Kenneth served as a Senior Counselor for the strategic communications firm, The Dilenschneider Group, Inc. He was a member of the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club and the Meadow Club of Southampton. Kenneth loved Mozart, literature, politics, the East End of Long Island, always a good argument, and especially, his "T"s. A memorial service will be held at Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 East 90th St., New York City on Saturday, June 11 at 3:30pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Kenneth's memory may be made to the Lung Cancer Research Foundation or Citymeals on Wheels. 1/3

ZUBRIN--Charles, passed away on Thursday, June 2nd, 2016. He was 100. Charlie was born in New York City and moved to Great Neck, NY in 1960. Upon retiring, he moved to Palm Beach, FL. Charlie worked for the Topps Company in New York for many years before retiring as Vice President. He was predeceased by his wife, Rosalyn who passed away in 1998, and survived by his son Robert Zubrin, daughter, Linda Zubrin Ratner, grandchildren Jessica, David and Rachel, and great granddaughters, Salem and Mirah. Charles lived life with song and joy. He was loved by so many. The funeral service is at 9:30am on Sunday, June 5th 2016 at Temple B'Nai Or. 60 Overlook Road, Morristown, NJ. Interment: Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, NY. Services are under the direction the Par-Troy Funeral Home. (973)887-3235 or visit www. partroyfuneralhome.com. 1/3

CAHILL--Catherine. The Board and Staff of The New York Landmarks Conservancy mourn the passing of Catherine Cahill, wife of our longtime trustee William Bernhard. Our condolences to family and friends. Lloyd P. Zuckerberg, Chair Peg Breen, President 1/3

ADESMAN--Jerome, on June 2, 2016. Beloved husband of the late Alice. Loving father of Drs. Peter, Andrew and Michael and their spouses Drs. Robin Miller, Angela Romano and Susan Weil. Cherished grandfather of seven. Proud and respected physician for over 50 years. Services Sunday, 11:30am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3
KLEIN--Nancy. In loving memory of dear Nancy, always in my thoughts and heart. Harold 1/3

SEYKORA--Barbara, 85, died April 23, 2016 in Florida. Born in Corona, NY she moved to Miami in 1960 with husband Lawrence and daughters Karen and Dana. Survived by Dana O'Keefe, grandchildren and great-grandchildren, this loving woman will be missed. 1/3

CAHILL--Catherine Grace. May 26, 1939 - May 31, 2016. Died at home in New York City of cancer. Attended The Brearley School, Chatham Hall and Vassar College. Survived by her beloved husband, William L. Bernhard and many wonderful and loyal friends. The funeral service will take place at The Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at 90th Street, on Monday, June 6 at 11:00am. Catherine was a great lover of animals. If you would like to remember her, these are some of her favorite organizations: Amaryllis Farm Equine Rescue, 44 Little Fresh Pond Road, Southampton, NY 11968. Greyhound Friends, 167 Saddle Hill Road, Hopkinton, MA 01748. Save The Chimps, Box 12220, Fort Pierce, FL 34979. Wild Bird Fund, 565 Columbus Avenue, New York, NY 10024. Wildlife Rescue Center of the Hamptons, Inc., 228 West Montauk Highway, Hampton Bays, NY 11946. 1/3

SIMON--Phyllis L.,age 94, passed away peacefully June 1. She was beloved by all who knew her. Born Valentine's Day February 14, 1922 to Sam and Flora Lieber, she grew up in Mt. Vernon, NY. In 1943, Phyllis married Hyman G. "Hy" Simon. They were happily married for 54 years, had three sons and resided in Great Neck, NY. Phyllis is survived by her loving brother Stephen Lieber. his family, as well as her three devoted son and wives: Kenneth and Andi, Geoffrey and Andrea, and Robert and Teresa; six grandchildren, and four great- grandchildren. Funeral services: 10:00am, Sunday, June 5 at Riverside-Nassau North Chapel, Great Neck, NY. Donations to: Brain & Behavior Research Foundation (website: bbrfoundation.org) 1/3

GREENBERG--Henry "Hank". We sadly announce the death of Hank Greenberg, one of the true legends in retailing. He set a standard in leadership that is strived for to this day. He is survived by his beloved wife and best friend, Roz, they were married 64 years, his adored children, Bonnie, Randy, and Amy, and his devoted grandchildren. Funeral services will be at Monmouth Reform Temple on June 2nd at 11am. Shiva will be at the home of Bonnie Klein. Donations in his memory may be made to Monmouth Medical Center Foundation or the Visiting Nurse Association of Central New Jersey. 1/3

PERLMAN--Dr. Anthony. On June 1, 2016, Dr. Anthony Perlman, pediatrician and cardiologist from Baltimore, MD; loving husband of Patsy Perlman (nee Miller); cherished father of Daniel, Dr. Eric, and Ellen Perlman; adored grandfather of six. For service details, please go to www.sollevinson.com. Contributions in Tony's memory may be sent to The Associated: Jewish Community Federation of Baltimore. 1/3

O'CONNOR--Mary Susan. 49, of Cary, North Carolina, died suddenly of a heart attack on December 5th, 2015. Known by her middle name, Susan was born on December 30, 1965, in Washington, DC, to Leon Richard and Shirley JoAnne Martin Kearing. Susan grew up in the District of Columbia, where she attended Georgetown Visitation Preparatory School. She graduated from St. Lawrence University in Canton, NY, with a degree in English and earned a graduate degree in organizational psychology from Teachers College at Columbia University in New York City. She worked for several years as a paralegal at the law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell and then as an administrator at Columbia University before committing herself full time to her family. A devoted wife and mother, she was fiercely protective of her family. Their greatest ally and advocate, she brought out the best in her husband and their children. Although her family was always her first priority, she found time to volunteer in the community, including fundraising for the GetAbout program in New Canaan, working in the shop at Person-to-Person in Darien, and earning Sustainer status in the Junior League. She also achieved great success in the dog show world, finishing five champions (two of whom she bred), winning the 2010 Canadian national Cavalier King Charles Spaniel specialty show, and competing in the Westminster Kennel Club show at Madison Square Garden. She loved spending time on Martha's Vineyard and travelling with her family. Although a resident of North Carolina at the time of her death, she spent 14 years raising her family in New Canaan, CT, which she always considered her home. Susan was preceded in death by her parents and her brother. Susan is survived by her husband, Anthony M. O'Connor Jr., her daughter, Perry, and her son, Anthony III. A memorial service will be held at 11am on Saturday, June 11, 2016, at the Congregational Church in New Canaan, CT. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the American Heart Association or to Person-to-Person in Darien, CT. 1/3

KAGAN--Grace M.,94, passed peacefully at home in Palm Beach Gardens, FL on May 27, 2016 with daughter Barbra by her side. GANELES--Robert I.,M.D., of Westport, Connecticut passed away May 24, 2016. His encyclopedic knowledge, wisdom, insight, humor and charm will be missed and remembered with joy and love. He was a pioneer in the field of psychopharmacology. A graduate of Brooklyn College and Baylor School of Medicine and completed his internship, residency and fellowship in Psychiatry and was board certified in Psychiatry and Neurology. He was on staff at North Shore University Hospital for over 50 years and served as the President of the Medical Board. He also served as a Captain in the U.S. Air Force. He never fully forgave his beloved Brooklyn Dodgers for leaving, but retained a lifelong love of baseball. He was an avid Mets fan and baseball statistics aficionado. He was a lifelong reader and expert crossword puzzler. He is survived by his wife of 60 years, Ceily, daughters Mara and Tami, son-in-law Bruce, and grandchildren, Samuel, Rayna and Lila. 1/3

ABELY--Joseph F.,Jr., 87 of Sea Island, GA and Osterville, MA passed away Tuesday, May 31, 2016. Joe was born on January 22, 1929 in Arlington, MA and grew up in Belmont. He was the son of Joseph F. and Nora (Coffey) Abely. A graduate of Boston College Class of 1950, Joe earned a Masters in Business Administration from Harvard Business School and a JD from Harvard Law School. He served in the United States Air Force and went on to have a long career in senior executive positions in companies such as W.R. Grace, General Foods, RJR Industries and SeaLand Corporation, where he served as Chairman and Chief Executive Officer until his retirement. He also served on the Boards of Directors of entities including Burlington Industries, Bard Pharmaceuticals, Nations' Bank, Applera and Perkin-Elmer. He was also a member of the American Red Cross' Blood Services Committee. Joe and his wife Brenda were loyal and generous benefactors of Boston College. Joe served as a BC trustee from 1976-1983 and 1985-1993, including serving on its Executive Committee. Joe often said that he learned his trade at Harvard but was educated at Boston College. An avid and enthusiastic golfer, Joe had been a member of Oyster Harbors Club, Wianno Club, Winchester Country Club, Ocean Forest, Sea Island Club, Baltusrol Golf Club, Woodway Country Club and The Beach Club. He was also a proud member of the Knights of Malta. Joe is survived by his loving wife of almost 59 years, Brenda Conlon Abely, and their children, James Christopher Abely of Sea Island, GA and Washington, DC and Karen Latham of St. Simons, GA and his granddaughters Kimberly and Caroline Latham. Joe was also the beloved brother of the late William F. Abely and the late John K. Abely. He is also survived by many nieces and nephews to whom he served as a loyal and valued mentor. A private service will be held in Sea Island Georgia. A memorial service will be held in Boston-area later this summer. Donations may be made in Joe Abely's memory to Hospice of the Golden Isles, 1692 Glynco Pkwy., Brunswick, GA 31525. Online guestbook at gfdoherty.com. Services handled by George F. Doherty & Sons Funeral Home, Wellesley, MA. 1/3

NOLOP--Keith Bradley, died on May 31, 2016 in Los Angeles, CA from head injuries sustained in a tragic bicycle accident. He was 63. Dr. Nolop had a distinguished career of over 25 years in drug development from conception to approval with a focus on allergy, asthma, and cancer products. His work included the blockbuster drug Nasonex, a groundbreaking melanoma treatment, and highly-engineered cancer therapies. He also was the author of over 50 peer-reviewed articles and the recipient of several patents. Born in Minneapolis, MN in 1953, he moved with his family to Mobridge, SD in 1960, where he enjoyed a typical small town boyhood full of activities and games. However, he was not particularly athletic and from an early age, evinced an extraordinary interest in science and math. Rather than play with new toys, he was more likely to take them apart, just to see how they worked. Always a model student, he earned perfect grades from elementary school through college - a rare feat in the days before grade inflation. In high school he was an Eagle Scout, first chair baritone in All-State Band, a representative to Boy's State (where he captured first place in the comprehensive written examination), and the state's highest scorer in the National Merit Scholar competition. He graduated as top student in the Mobridge High School Class of 1971. He studied biology at the University of South Dakota, where he was Editor of the school newspaper (the Volante) and a member of Delta Tau Delta fraternity. He was elected to Phi Beta Kappa as a junior and graduated summa cum laude with a Bachelor of Science degree in 1975. His next stop was Vanderbilt University School of Medicine where, true to form, he was honored as first in his class. After receiving his Doctor of Medicine, he began a career in medical research and drug development, starting with a stint at the University of Louisville. Dr. Nolop spent over 11 years with Schering-Plough and then 13 years as Chief Medical Officer for three successful biotechnology companies: CoTherix, Plexxikon, and Kite Pharma. In recent years he was an independent consultant. Keith loved skiing, hiking (especially Yosemite), wine tasting, Latin music, international travel, movies, and playing the bass guitar. He also was active in animal rights organizations. Never married, he was engaged to Sonia Jimenez in 2011; but in another unspeakable tragedy, his betrothed drowned while they were vacationing in Costa Rica. After Sonia's death, Keith provided financial support and life advice to her adopted children, Roberto Jose Tercero and Martha Karina Tercero of San Francisco, CA. He is survived by his mother, Barbara Nolop, of Peoria, AZ; brothers Bruce (Susan) Nolop of New York, NY and Neil (Hege) Nolop of Houston, TX; and nephews Christopher, Michael, Andre, and Nathan Nolop. He was preceded in death by his father, Francis Nolop, in 2008. 1/3

BUXBAUM--Devorah (Dev), passed away on May 5th surrounded by family and loved ones. Her family, friends, their children, and her business, were the passions of her life. As a founder of First Editions Wallcoverings and Fabrics, Inc., in 1971, one of the first women owned businesses in the interior design industry, she was an inspiration to many. Dev's keen eye and unique sense of design brought originality and beauty to the interior design world, always nurturing artists and clients. Indomitable and inexhaustible, in January 2016 she began working on a sequel collection "imagine the possibilities" featuring new designs and technologies - her love of design a guiding force - that kept her moving forward. She is survived by her spouse Shelly Nudell, her partner in life and business for 45 years, her brother Jack Buxbaum and his wife Julie, a niece Joan Levine, nephew Joshua Tambor, sister's in law Bonita Buxbaum and Renee Tambor and her North Carolina family. She was predeceased by her loving sister Sarah Goldstein, brother Sidney Buxbaum and nephew David Buxbaum. Services were private. Contributions in Dev's name may be made to the charity of your choice. Dev will be remembered for her kindness and warmth, generosity, good humor, strength and her distinguishing "red glasses". We all have our memories of our witty, wise and wonderful Dev, and we will miss her greatly. 1/3

HUNT--Walter. Walter Alexander Hunt, Jr. FAIA, a design industry veteran who helped shape a global reputation for Gensler and served as president of the American Institute of Architects' (AIA) New York chapter, passed away peacefully on Friday, May 27, 2016. He was 74 years old. Walter is survived by his beloved wife, Judith Tansey Hunt; sons David Alexander Hunt and Christopher William Hunt of Denver, CO, and Stephen Austin Hunt of Basking Ridge, NJ; daughters-in-law Erin Crowley Hunt, Sarah Anschutz Hunt, and Mary Matthews Hunt; grandchildren William, Madeleine, Eleanor, Taylor, Caroline, Ryan, Hannah, and Alexander; sister Bonnie M. Hunt of Holderness, NH. Originally from Summit, NJ, Walter attended The Pingry School Class of 1959. He earned a Bachelor of Arts from Yale University in 1963, followed by a Masters of Architecture from Yale in 1967. Upon completion of his studies at Yale, Walter moved his family to San Francisco and commenced a 38-year career at Gensler. In 1978 he relocated to Denver to lead that office, followed by a move in 1985 to co-lead the New York office. His career included projects worldwide. He served on the Board of Directors and became the Northeast Managing Director and Vice-Chair of the firm, retiring from the firm as Vice-Chairman Emeritus in 2012. Hunt spent more than four decades in the design industry, serving on the Board of Directors of the AIA's New York Chapter from 1997-1998 and as the President in 1999. He went on to serve on AIA's New York State Board from 2000-2001. In 2001, Hunt joined the Board of Directors of the New York Foundation for Architecture and was elected President of the Board of Directors in 2004. He was an active fundraiser for Yale's School of Architecture since 1978, serving on the Board of Directors of the Yale Alumni Fund since 1992 and receiving the President's Award from Yale Alumni Fund in 2004 for his service to the School of Architecture. Hunt served on the Board of Downtown Denver, Inc. from 1980 - 1984 and was the President of the Metropolitan Denver Arts Alliance from 1982 -1984. Hunt was elevated to Fellow in the American Institute of Architects in 2005 and received both the President's Award and Harry B. Rutkins Award from the Center for Architecture/AIA New York Chapter in 2006. He received the James Kubeny Distinguished Service award by AIA New York State in 2012. Also in 2012, the Center for Architecture Foundation established the Walter A. Hunt Jr. Scholarship Fund in honor of his efforts. The fund promotes and encourages the study of architecture for New York City public high school seniors accepted to a New York State NAAB accredited School of Architecture. After retirement, Hunt founded ONE@@TIME Project Consulting, which provides pro bono consulting services exclusively for not-for-profit organizations. Walter had a real love for travel, food and wine. A Memorial Celebration will be held at the New York Athletic Club, 180 Central Park South, on June 28th, 4:30pm - 7:00pm. In lieu of flowers, donations are suggested to the Center for Architecture Walter A. Hunt Scholarship Fund, 536 LaGuardia Place, New York, NY 10012; or to the Judith and Walter Hunt Fund in Architecture, Yale University, to support faculty and student travel related to courses at the Yale School of Architecture. 1/3

LANGE--Patricia Fogelman, Ph.D.,died peacefully at the age of 76 on May 26, 2016. Born in Brooklyn, NY to Betty and Jack Mass, she is survived by her children Melissa (Scott) Siegel, Jonathan (Jill) Fogelman and brother Mitchell (Alice) Mass; her grandchildren Samantha and Jake, her nieces and nephews, Erik, Laura, Noah, Myra, Maya, Griffin; stepchildren Fred (Claudia) Lange and family, Richard (Chris) Lange, David (Carrie) Lange and dog Remy. Pat received her Ph.D. in Art Education from New York University with focus on Pueblo Pottery Figurines. In pursuit of her lifelong passion, she relocated to Santa Fe more than 25 years ago to continue her research in Native American art. There she married Charles H. Lange (deceased). Her art work was exhibited on numerous occasions. She was the author of two books, and is a quoted authority by other authors and scholars. A Wenner-Gren Foundation Grant winner and member of the Phi Theta Kappa Honor Society, Pat was also a co-curator for a show at the Wheelwright Museum of the American Indians in Santa Fe, an Adjunct Instructor at the Santa Fe Community College, Scholar in Residence at the Institute of American Indians and a Research Associate at the Museum of New Mexico, Laboratory of Anthropology/ Museum of Indian Arts and Culture. Donations in her memory may be made to the Patricia Fogelman Lange Memorial Endowed Scholarship at Santa Fe Community College Foundation, 6401 Richards Avenue, Santa Fe, NM 87508. Forever bringing beauty and color to all around, she will be greatly missed and always in our hearts. 1/3

CALAME--Joan M.,died at home in Vero Beach, FL surrounded by family on May 30, 2016. Born in Brooklyn on July 30, 1927 to George and Isabelle Healy and raised in Garden City, she graduated from Trinity College, Washington, DC and earned a Masters from Teachers College, Columbia. Joan retired from teaching high school English to raise her children. A gifted artist who loved golf, singing, travel, and hosting parties and family dinners, she will be remembered for her sense of style, quick wit, unforgettable turns of phrase, knowledge of art and literature, and deep affection for her family. She is survived by her husband of 58 years, Richard J. Calame MD, and her children David, Sally and Richard, her daughter-in-law Mara, five grandchildren and one great-grandson. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 10am on June 11, 2016 at St. Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset. In lieu of flowers, donations in Joan's memory may be made to VNA Hospice of Indian River County, at www.vnatc.com. 1/3

ZIEGLER--Jean-Claude, 68. A graduate of Linsly Military Institute '64 and Georgetown University '68, he had a long career as an executive at Y&R. He is survived by his mother, Simone Ziegler, his sister Anne-Marie Ziegler and his niece Anne-Nicole Hanus. He was a man of great character beloved by friends for his caring nature, intellect and unique charm. A consummate New Yorker, he also maintained strong family ties to France. His casual cosmopolitan spirit brightened his every conversation, with a Gallic temper held in reserve for the deserving few. A passionate collector of beautiful historical objects his presence in those circles will be deeply missed. He served as secretary to the Art Glass Forum/New York and was a member and frequent visitor to the Metropolitan Museum, Carnegie Hall and the Metropolitan Opera. As a generous advocate for the less fortunate and animal rights we suggest donations to the Humane Society of the United States or Friends of the High Line, in lieu of flowers. Memorial service at "The Riverside" on Amsterdam Ave. and 76th St., on June 10th at 3pm with a reception following (RSVP) and burial in Westport on the 11th. 1/3

PEREIRA--Dr. Milton Alan, May 15, 2016. Devoted father to David, Emily and Katherine. Loving grandfather to Lanie and Talia. Dedicated psychiatrist who loved his work and helped many. He will be greatly missed. Go Blue! 1/3

GILPIN--Kenneth N.,III, Who had a long and distinguished career as a journalist, died on Thursday, May 5 at 66 from complications of lung cancer. He is survived by his loving wife of 30 years, Katharine Brengle, and two adoring daughters, Eliza and Lucy Gilpin. Born to Kenneth N. Gilpin, Jr. and Lucy Mitchell Gilpin on June 2, 1949, Kenneth grew up in Clarke County, VA. His grandfather was the legendary air power visionary, General William Lendrum "Billy" Mitchell, who is regarded as the father of the United States Air Force. Kenneth received a BA from Union College in 1972 and an MA from the School of Advanced International Studies at Johns Hopkins University in 1976. He then moved to New York City where he began writing for the weekly newsletter, Business International with a focus on European affairs. He next was hired by The Journal of Commerce to write editorials on a range of foreign economic and political topics. From 1980-2004, Kenneth was a business and financial reporter for The New York Times. His stories covered a wide range of international and domestic issues with commentary about the fixed income, foreign exchange, futures and equity markets. The biographical sketches that he wrote with others on the news staff about the lives of people lost during the attacks on the World Trade Center, titled "Portraits of Grief," were among his proudest contributions to the paper. Later, he worked as a contract writer for SAP America, US Trust Company, Merrill Lynch & Co., and UBS. For the past seven years, Kenneth served as a Senior Counselor for the strategic communications firm, The Dilenschneider Group, Inc. He was a member of the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club and the Meadow Club of Southampton. Kenneth loved Mozart, literature, politics, the East End of Long Island, always a good argument, and especially, his "T"s. A memorial service will be held at Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 East 90th St., New York City on Saturday, June 11 at 3:30pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Kenneth's memory may be made to the Lung Cancer Research Foundation or Citymeals on Wheels. 1/3

GREENBERG--Henry "Hank". We sadly announce the death of Hank Greenberg, one of the true legends in retailing. He set a standard in leadership that is strived for to this day. He is survived by his beloved wife and best friend, Roz, they were married 64 years, his adored children, Bonnie, Randy, and Amy, and his devoted grandchildren. Funeral services will be at Monmouth Reform Temple on June 2nd at 11am. Shiva will be at the home of Bonnie Klein. Donations in his memory may be made to Monmouth Medical Center Foundation or the Visiting Nurse Association of Central New Jersey. 1/3

LOWE--James Dyer, was born on June 27th, 1929 in Pittsburgh, PA. He was predeceased by his parents Laura Dyer and William Lowe and his brother, Bill Lowe. Jim passed away peacefully on June 1st at 5:52pm at home in Manhattan with his loving partner of 26 years, Sheldon A Smith, at his side. He attended Washington and Jefferson College and served in the US Army and was stationed in Honolulu, Hawaii and Baltimore, MD. His career included being Director of Public Events at the Campbell-Ewald Advertising Agency, the National Council on Alcoholism, the National Heart Association and Director of Development at New York Presbyterian Hospital. Jim loved his home in Southampton, watching old movies with Sheldon, reading, sitting on the beach and telling wonderful stories about the celebrities he met during his work career. Jim was an elegant, most charming man who will be missed by all who knew him. Services Tuesday, June 7th, 9:30am, Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church-73/74 Streets. 1/3

SILTON--Alice, passed away peacefully on May 29, 2016 at age 94. She was the beloved wife of 67 years of the late Robert Silton and is survived by her daughter Mary, her son Robert Silton Jr., and grandchildren John and Sarah. Born in Manhattan, Alice grew up at the Beresford with summers in Purchase, NY. She attended Mount Holyoke College and graduated from Barnard. Alice spent most of her adult life in Rye, NY as a homemaker, devoted wife and mother and as an avid volunteer that included many years working at White Plains Hospital. Alice was known for her down-to-earth, genuine manner, her loyalty to all that were close to her and especially for her knack at building a social network including friends from childhood, bridge club, country club, volunteering, and from her retirement community at The Osborn in Rye. Alice will be greatly missed by her children and grandchildren and by all that knew her. Memorial service to be held on Monday, June 13th at 11:00 am at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester (2125 Westchester Ave. East, Rye, NY - corner of Kenilworth Road and Westchester Ave.). In her memory, donations may be made to White Plains Hospital at: Development Office, White Plains Hospital, 41 East Post Road, White Plains, NY 10601. 1/3
NELSON--Merlin E. With happy memories of our Honorary Chairman and the thousands of fun miles enjoyed together. The 72nd St. Marathoning and Pasta Club 1/3

STAMLER--Lillian Spitzer, 96, of Stony Creek, CT, wife of the late Judge Joseph H. Stamler, passed away peacefully at home on May 27, 2016 surrounded by family. She was born June 13, 1919 in Brooklyn to Benjamin and Beatrice Salzman Spitzer. Lillian is survived by two sons: Joseph H. Stamler, Jr., 74 and his wife Ann of Fairfield, CT and S. Paul Stamler, 69 of Stony Creek, along with Paul's children, Abbi, Reed and Teddy Stamler, and a sister, Jean Krosner. A private graveside service was planned at the family plot in Stony Creek Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to CT Hospice Home Care, 100 Double Beach Road, Branford, CT 06405, or The Seeing Eye, PO Box 375, Morristown, NJ 07963-0375. 1/3

CURLEY--Honorable Walter Joseph Patrick. The Frick Collection mourns the passing of Trustee Emeritus Walter J. P. Curley. Elected a Trustee in 1994, Ambassador Curley served the Frick with the same dedication, clear perspective, wit, and charm that characterized every aspect of his long and distinguished career, and he continued to do so after becoming a Trustee Emeritus in 2004. His advice, guidance, and friendship will be greatly missed by all who knew him. On behalf of Walter's fellow Trustees, we extend our sincere condolences to his widow, Mary, and to their family. Margot Bogert, Chairman Ian Wardropper, Director 1/3

WEIL--Ernst, passed away peacefully at his home in Zurich on June 2, 2016 at the age of 86, surrounded by his family and loved ones. Born in Zurich, he moved to New York in 1940 with his parents and sister, where he grew up as an American teenager: attending high school in Manhattan; going to Summer Camp; and taking summer jobs as a delivery boy for Eclair. The family returned to Switzerland in 1944, yet the years in New York proved formative. American characteristics such as openness and drive melded with his European sensibility and warmth. Throughout his life he continued to spend long periods of time in the US - learning the textile business prior to joining his family's firm in the early 50's, attending Harvard University's AMP program in 1972, and as CEO of Phibro Energy Corporation and Executive Vice President of Salomon Brothers from 1986 to 1993, where he had joined in 1975. Preceded in death ten years ago by his beloved wife Jacqueline Weil-Bloch, he is survived by his children Corinne (Ofer), Denis, Nathalie (Shlomo) and Philippe (Orly), nine grandchildren, his sister Hermine Bader, his companion Marianne Lang and family and friends throughout the world. Donations in his memory may be made to AFIM, the American Friends of the Israel Museum. 1/3

SCHINDLER--Michael J.,55, of Fair Lawn, NJ passed away on Wednesday, June 1, 2016, after a hard-fought battle with leukemia. Born in Philadelphia, PA, he resided in Brooklyn, NY before moving to Fair Lawn ten years ago. Michael earned a Bachelor of Fine Arts Degree in Theater from Ithaca College in 1982. He loved all sports and especially enjoyed golf, tennis, yoga and tai chi. Known professionally as Michael Sage Schindler, he owned and operated Lightning Shakes New York, a special event planning and services business, for more than 20 years. He brought passion, inspiration, compassion, and boundless energy to his work, and he remained active in the business until his passing. He also shared his enthusiasm for revelry with his community in Radburn, NJ, hosting many family and community events over the years. Beloved husband of Tiffony (Kidd) Schindler. Loving and devoted father to his daughters Kaia (9) and Luca (7) Schindler. Cherished son of Sondra Gavzy and husband Paul, and of David Schindler and wife Mary Ann. Dear brother of Lisa Wagman and Janey Dean, and dear step brother of Leah Jungkind, and Matthew, Aaron, and Joshua Gavzy. He will be deeply missed. A graveside service is planned for Monday, June 6, 2016, 1:00pm at George Washington Memorial Park, 234 Paramus Road, Paramus, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations in Michael's memory for the growth, development, and continued intellectual and athletic pursuits of his children would be appreciated. Donations may be sent to Tiffony Schindler, c/o Vander Plaat-Caggiano Funeral Home, 13-31 Saddle River Road, Fair Lawn, NJ 07410. For condolences and additional information please visit www.vpfairlawn.com. 1/3

OLNICK--Sylvia. The entire Albert Einstein College of Medicine family is profoundly saddened by the loss of our dear friend and devoted benefactor. Sylvia, along with her late husband Robert, endowed a Chair in Neuroscience and a Faculty Scholar in Cancer Research. They believed in the importance of giving back and were generous and steadfast supporters of medical research at Einstein. Sylvia joined our Board of Overseers in 1987 and served until 2015. We already miss her warm and gracious presence and extend our heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. Allen M. Spiegel, M.D, The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean; Roger W. Einiger Chair, Board of Trustees 1/3

LIPMAN--Roberta. 22 years have passed and not a day goes by when we do not think and speak of you. We love and miss you. Lipman & Carreiro Families 1/3

KEENE--Kenneth, of Bridgewater, CT, died peacefully on Thursday, June 2, 2016 at Regional Hospice in Danbury, CT, at the age of 89. He was born December 17, 1926 in Fort Meade, FL, son of the late Joseph and Anna (Keck) Keene. After graduating from P.K. Younge High School in Gainesville, FL, he served in the Navy for four years during WWII. When the war was over he finished his education at the University of Florida then received his Masters from the University of Michigan. On September 7, 1968 he married Janet Corbett. Mr. Keene had lived in Brookfield for seventeen years before moving to Bridgewater two years ago. He was a Vice President for Metropolitan Life in New York City before joining Johnson and Higgins Insurance Brokerage Firm where he was a partner for seventeen years before retiring in 1987. He was a Fellow in the Society of Actuaries and his Philanthropic efforts benefited the University of Florida, the University of Michigan, P.K. Younge High School and the Regional YMCA in Brookfield, CT. He is survived by his loving wife Janet, his sons, James Keene (Farah) of Atherton, CA, John Keene (Barbara) of Newington, CT, Thomas Keene (Susan) of Avon, CT, his daughter Panet Katherine Campbell (Dean) of Clifton Park, NY, a former daughter-in-law Gayle Keene of Simsbury, CT, his grandchildren Kristyn, Laurie and Michael Keene, Heather and Thomas Olson, Aysha and Amira Keene and his great- grandchildren Jack Olson and Oliver Pastore. He was predeceased by his son Jeffrey Keene on February 13, 1989 and his four brothers. A funeral service will be held on Thursday, June 9, 2016, 11:00am at the Bridgewater Congregational Church in Bridgewater, CT. The Interment will follow in Bridgewater Center Cemetery. Calling hours will be held on Wednesday, June 8, 2016 from 5:00pm to 8:00pm at the Lillis Funeral Home, 58 Bridge Street, New Milford, CT. The family has requested no flowers but contributions in his memory may be made to the University of Florida Foundation or the Jeffrey Keene Translational Diabetes Endowment at the University of Florida or The University of Michigan Residential College. 1/3

NOLOP--Keith Bradley, died on May 31, 2016 in Los Angeles, CA from head injuries sustained in a tragic bicycle accident. He was 63. Dr. Nolop had a distinguished career of over 25 years in drug development from conception to approval with a focus on allergy, asthma, and cancer products. His work included the blockbuster drug Nasonex, a groundbreaking melanoma treatment, and highly-engineered cancer therapies. He also was the author of over 50 peer-reviewed articles and the recipient of several patents. Born in Minneapolis, MN in 1953, he moved with his family to Mobridge, SD in 1960, where he enjoyed a typical small town boyhood full of activities and games. However, he was not particularly athletic and from an early age, evinced an extraordinary interest in science and math. Rather than play with new toys, he was more likely to take them apart, just to see how they worked. Always a model student, he earned perfect grades from elementary school through college - a rare feat in the days before grade inflation. In high school he was an Eagle Scout, first chair baritone in All-State Band, a representative to Boy's State (where he captured first place in the comprehensive written examination), and the state's highest scorer in the National Merit Scholar competition. He graduated as top student in the Mobridge High School Class of 1971. He studied biology at the University of South Dakota, where he was Editor of the school newspaper (the Volante) and a member of Delta Tau Delta fraternity. He was elected to Phi Beta Kappa as a junior and graduated summa cum laude with a Bachelor of Science degree in 1975. His next stop was Vanderbilt University School of Medicine where, true to form, he was honored as first in his class. After receiving his Doctor of Medicine, he began a career in medical research and drug development, starting with a stint at the University of Louisville. Dr. Nolop spent over 11 years with Schering-Plough and then 13 years as Chief Medical Officer for three successful biotechnology companies: CoTherix, Plexxikon, and Kite Pharma. In recent years he was an independent consultant. Keith loved skiing, hiking (especially Yosemite), wine tasting, Latin music, international travel, movies, and playing the bass guitar. He also was active in animal rights organizations. Never married, he was engaged to Sonia Jimenez in 2011; but in another unspeakable tragedy, his betrothed drowned while they were vacationing in Costa Rica. After Sonia's death, Keith provided financial support and life advice to her adopted children, Roberto Jose Tercero and Martha Karina Tercero of San Francisco, CA. He is survived by his mother, Barbara Nolop, of Peoria, AZ; brothers Bruce (Susan) Nolop of New York, NY and Neil (Hege) Nolop of Houston, TX; and nephews Christopher, Michael, Andre, and Nathan Nolop. He was preceded in death by his father, Francis Nolop, in 2008. 1/3
FRIEDLANDER--Kurt A. Dear Daddy, I think about you everyday and remember your sense of humor and the many kind and wonderful things you did for me. You always went the extra mile. Love, Poohsie 1/3

Wonderful grandfather of Zachary, Alexander, Matthew, Alice, Jesse, Nicholas and Isabella. Founder of deMarco California Fabrics, his pride and joy. In War and Life He never quit He gave his all. 1/3

HUNT--Walter. Walter Alexander Hunt, Jr. FAIA, a design industry veteran who helped shape a global reputation for Gensler and served as president of the American Institute of Architects' (AIA) New York chapter, passed away peacefully on Friday, May 27, 2016. He was 74 years old. Walter is survived by his beloved wife, Judith Tansey Hunt; sons David Alexander Hunt and Christopher William Hunt of Denver, CO, and Stephen Austin Hunt of Basking Ridge, NJ; daughters-in-law Erin Crowley Hunt, Sarah Anschutz Hunt, and Mary Matthews Hunt; grandchildren William, Madeleine, Eleanor, Taylor, Caroline, Ryan, Hannah, and Alexander; sister Bonnie M. Hunt of Holderness, NH. Originally from Summit, NJ, Walter attended The Pingry School Class of 1959. He earned a Bachelor of Arts from Yale University in 1963, followed by a Masters of Architecture from Yale in 1967. Upon completion of his studies at Yale, Walter moved his family to San Francisco and commenced a 38-year career at Gensler. In 1978 he relocated to Denver to lead that office, followed by a move in 1985 to co-lead the New York office. His career included projects worldwide. He served on the Board of Directors and became the Northeast Managing Director and Vice-Chair of the firm, retiring from the firm as Vice-Chairman Emeritus in 2012. Hunt spent more than four decades in the design industry, serving on the Board of Directors of the AIA's New York Chapter from 1997-1998 and as the President in 1999. He went on to serve on AIA's New York State Board from 2000-2001. In 2001, Hunt joined the Board of Directors of the New York Foundation for Architecture and was elected President of the Board of Directors in 2004. He was an active fundraiser for Yale's School of Architecture since 1978, serving on the Board of Directors of the Yale Alumni Fund since 1992 and receiving the President's Award from Yale Alumni Fund in 2004 for his service to the School of Architecture. Hunt served on the Board of Downtown Denver, Inc. from 1980 - 1984 and was the President of the Metropolitan Denver Arts Alliance from 1982 -1984. Hunt was elevated to Fellow in the American Institute of Architects in 2005 and received both the President's Award and Harry B. Rutkins Award from the Center for Architecture/AIA New York Chapter in 2006. He received the James Kubeny Distinguished Service award by AIA New York State in 2012. Also in 2012, the Center for Architecture Foundation established the Walter A. Hunt Jr. Scholarship Fund in honor of his efforts. The fund promotes and encourages the study of architecture for New York City public high school seniors accepted to a New York State NAAB accredited School of Architecture. After retirement, Hunt founded ONE@@TIME Project Consulting, which provides pro bono consulting services exclusively for not-for-profit organizations. Walter had a real love for travel, food and wine. A Memorial Celebration will be held at the New York Athletic Club, 180 Central Park South, on June 28th, 4:30pm - 7:00pm. In lieu of flowers, donations are suggested to the Center for Architecture Walter A. Hunt Scholarship Fund, 536 LaGuardia Place, New York, NY 10012; or to the Judith and Walter Hunt Fund in Architecture, Yale University, to support faculty and student travel related to courses at the Yale School of Architecture. 1/3

WEIL--Ernst, passed away peacefully at his home in Zurich on June 2, 2016 at the age of 86, surrounded by his family and loved ones. Born in Zurich, he moved to New York in 1940 with his parents and sister, where he grew up as an American teenager: attending high school in Manhattan; going to Summer Camp; and taking summer jobs as a delivery boy for Eclair. The family returned to Switzerland in 1944, yet the years in New York proved formative. American characteristics such as openness and drive melded with his European sensibility and warmth. Throughout his life he continued to spend long periods of time in the US - learning the textile business prior to joining his family's firm in the early 50's, attending Harvard University's AMP program in 1972, and as CEO of Phibro Energy Corporation and Executive Vice President of Salomon Brothers from 1986 to 1993, where he had joined in 1975. Preceded in death ten years ago by his beloved wife Jacqueline Weil-Bloch, he is survived by his children Corinne (Ofer), Denis, Nathalie (Shlomo) and Philippe (Orly), nine grandchildren, his sister Hermine Bader, his companion Marianne Lang and family and friends throughout the world. Donations in his memory may be made to AFIM, the American Friends of the Israel Museum. 1/3

PICKETT--Anna Lou. 1934 - 2016, longtime West Side resident, died May 10th of glioblastoma cancer in the company of her sisters Ruby Curro of Bonita Springs, FL, and Joan Wills of Washington, DC. She was 81. An accomplished educator, civil rights advocate, and civic activist. In addition to her sisters she is survived by a sister-in-law, cousins, nieces and nephews across the country. Born Anna Lou Lawson, she grew up in Gaston, IN, attended Franklin College and graduated from Ball State University. There she met her husband, Hugh D. Pickett, a campus Baptist Minister. The Picketts moved to Ann Arbor and in 1963 New York City for Hugh to become an executive of the Ministers and Missionary Benefits Board. He predeceased her in 1992. Anna Lou's professional life centered on the needs of students with disabilities, as a teacher and then a principal of a special school for disabled students denied an education. In 1979, she spearheaded the founding of the first-of-its-kind National Resource Center for Paraprofessionals at the City University of New York, now housed at the University of Utah. Her leadership sparked national voluntary practice standards for paraprofessionals which have been adopted or used as a model in most states and school districts throughout the country. Active in the New York City Reform Democratic civil rights and anti- war crusades of the 1960s, she was elected a Democratic District Leader in 1969. She was the Assistant Commissioner for Community Affairs at the Environmental Protection Administration of New York during the Lindsay administration. In 1974 she was the Campaign Manager for Mary Anne Krupsak's successful run as the first female Lieutenant Governor of New York. During that campaign she mentored Gale Brewer, now the Borough President of Manhattan. Later she served on Manhattan Community Board 5. She helped establish landmark status for several theaters and always enjoyed telling, with humor, about the process to establish landmark status for the Empire State Building. Later she became an active member of Citizens Union and active supporter of the West Side Campaign Against Hunger. She was a longtime resident, board member, and friend to the staff and residents of the 470 West End Co-Op. In the late 1960s, she was the first woman elected to a leadership position as Moderator of Judson Memorial Church, where she maintained a longstanding, faithful membership. Anna Lou valued and maintained strong relationships, and served as a mentor to many within her family, profession, and community. She was the glue that held the family together, maintained active links with Gaston High classmates, a high school exchange student from Germany and now three generations of his family consider her a "second mother" as does a range of a younger generation from her summer Shelter Island House family. A memorial service and reception will be held on June 24, 5:00pm, Judson Memorial Church, 55 Washington Square S., NYC. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions in her name to either the Judson Memorial Church (www.judson.org) or the West Side Campaign Against Hunger (www.wscah.org). 1/3

CURLEY--Walter J.P. Walter J.P. Curley, (1922-2016) died peacefully on June 2 in New York, where he was a longterm resident. He was born in Pittsburgh, PA, attended Phillips Academy Andover, Yale University, Harvard Business School and the University of Oslo, and has an Honorary Doctorate in Law from Trinity College, Dublin. In World War II, Ambassador Curley, a Marine Corps infantry combat officer, served in the Iwo Jima, Okinawa, Guam and North China campaigns, and holds decorations from the Army, Navy, Marine Corps, and The Republic of China. With the Caltex Oil Company, he worked in India and Italy (1949-1959) before becoming a partner in J.H. Whitney & Co, the venture capital firm (1960-1974). He was Commissioner of Public Events and was Chief of Protocol of New York City in the Lindsay administration. He was appointed Ambassador to Ireland by President Ford in 1975. He returned to the private sector to establish his own venture capital investment Business in New York in 1977. He served as Ambassador to France (1989-93) under President George H.W. Bush. He was a Trustee of the New York Public Library, Miss Porter's School, Brooks School in Massachusetts, The Buckley School, Barnard College, and a former director of the New York Life Insurance Company, Fiduciary Trust International, Bank of Ireland, Crane Co., Guinness Peat Aviation (U.S), Independent Newspapers Ltd. (Dublin), Fairchild Camera and Instrument Co., American Exploration Co., The New Yorker Magazine, the International Board of Banque Paribas, and Sotheby's Holdings, Inc. He is the author of four books: Almost a Century - An American Life East & West of Suez, Vanishing Kingdoms, Monarchs in Waiting, and Letters from the Pacific. Ambassador Curley was Honorary Chairman of the French American-Foundation, Chairman Emeritus of Sotheby's International Advisory Board, Trustee Emeritus of the American Hospital in Paris and of The Frick Collection; he was a member of the Council of American Ambassadors, and a member of The Council on Foreign Relations. He is survived by his wife of 67 years, the former Mary Taylor Walton of Pittsburgh, his daughter Margaret Bacon (Carter), his son, WJ Patrick III (Jane), and seven grandchildren: Kelly, Christina and Taylor Wiles, Joseph, William (Willa), Nina and Ross Curley. He was predeceased by two sons, John and James. Ambassador and Mrs. Curley lived in Manhattan and in the west of Ireland. Mass of the Resurrection St. Vincent Ferrer R.C. Church, Friday, June 10th at 10am. Services are being entrusted to Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel". 1/3

FRIEDENBERG--Honorable Marilyn R. (retired) died on June 5, 2016 at the age of 89. Born in New York to Jacob and Laura Rosenfeld, Marilyn was a graduate of NYU Law School and began her legal career as a Deputy County attorney in Nassau County. She was first appointed, and later elected to the bench of the Family Court of Nassau County where she served for 11 years. She was the first female president of the Family Court Judges Association of the state of New York. She was also appointed by Governor Cuomo to serve as a Justice of the Supreme Court of Nassau County. She served as a Judicial Hearing Officer for over 20 years in both Nassau and Suffolk sitting well into her eighties. Judge Friedenberg was active in professional organizations including the American Academy of Matrimonial Lawyers and the Bar Associations of New York, Nassau and Suffolk Countries. She was President of the Nassau County Women's Bar Association and a Master Emeritus of the New York Family Law American Inn of Court. Marilyn was a trail blazer with a zest for life and learning. For 60 years she shared a special partnership with her husband Stanley (decd). They were each other's biggest supporters in a grand professional and personal life that included travel, friendships, and family. Beloved mother of Ellen Cammer (Martin) and Robert Friedenberg (JoEllen), grandmother of Jacob, Rosie, Julie, Sam and Harry and sister of Franklin Rosenfeld. A memorial service will be held at Guttermans in Woodbury on June 7, 2016 at 3:30pm. Remembrances may be made to Nassau County Bar Association's "We Care" Fund, nassaubar.org. 1/3

HUNT--Walter A.,Jr. The Center for Architecture mourns the passing of our devoted patron, leader and friend. His vision and generosity will leave a lasting legacy. Our sympathies to his wife Judy and his entire family. 1/3

WELLNER--Charles. Beloved son of Isidor and Angele Wellner and treasured uncle of Emily Angele Russo passed away peacefully in his home on June 3 at the age of 91. Charles was forced to flee with his family from his home in Belgium in 1940 and then served in his adopted country's Armed Forces during World War II . He was a generous contributor to many Jewish charitable organizations and also was a major supporter of Technion University in Haifa, Israel. He was predeceased by his sister Georgette Wlodawer and his niece Danielle Blanche Sedlis. 1/3

O'SULLIVAN--Sonya S.,98, died at her home in Mamaroneck on June 3. Born in New York City to B.P. and Adeline Jaffe Schulberg, she moved with her parents and older brother Budd to Los Angeles, where her father was head of production at Paramount Studios. Sonya came to love sun, horses, dogs and Malibu, where Ad built one of the first houses. At the insistence of their mother, who had a literary agency in NYC from 1945 until 1977, Sonya, Budd and younger brother Stuart became writers. She attended The Progressive School, co-founded by her mother. After her parents' divorce, Sonya attended schools in Paris, Geneva and London. She started Sarah Lawrence but left at 19 when Scribners published her first novel (Maxwell Perkins was her editor). Budd's first novel, What Makes Sammy Run, made a bigger splash and Budd went on to success as a screenwriter (On the Waterfront). Sonya was married to attorney Ben O'Sullivan from 1941 until his death in 1998. Sadly, their son John O'Sullivan died in 2010. Her dear friends, brothers Budd and Stuart, also predeceased her. She is survived by other close friends: her daughter Dr. Chris O'Sullivan of NYC and Mamaroneck, Budd's and Stuart's children, among them Vicky Kingsland, Benn, Sandra, K.C., Peter and Jonathan Schulberg; her nieces Elizabeth Frank and Beth O'Sullivan; and her grandchildren Sarah and Kate O'Sullivan and great-grandson Will McCullough of Washington, DC and Betsy Schulberg. Wherever she lived, she adopted dogs and cats, tended wild animals, created gardens (on Martha's Vineyard and in Mamaroneck). She published short stories and recently completed a witty sad novel with perfectly constructed sentences about growing up in Hollywood. She was buried in the West Tisbury Cemetery on Martha's Vineyard. A reception will be held at her home in Mamaroneck in mid June. Sonya would have liked contributions to one of the many animal organizations she supported, including the Doris Day Animal Foundation, 8033 Sunset Boulevard, Suite 845, Los Angeles, CA 90046 or donate in memoriam online at DDAF. 1/3

SINKMAN--Ellen. The Institute for Psychoanalytic Training and Research mourns the untimely death of Ellen Sinkman, esteemed member and colleague. Her warmth, intelligence and strong commitment to psychoanalysis will be deeply missed. 1/3

LAMPARELLO--Julia J. The members of the Department of Surgery mourn the loss of Mrs. Julia J. Lamparello beloved mother of our esteemed and long time faculty member Dr. Patrick Lamparello. We extend our deepest condolences to Dr. Lamparello and his family on their loss. H. Leon Pachter M.D., F.A.C.S The George David Stewart Professor and Chair Department of Surgery NYU Langone Medical Center 1/3

CURLEY--Walter J.P. Walter J.P. Curley, (1922-2016) died peacefully on June 2 in New York, where he was a longterm resident. He was born in Pittsburgh, PA, attended Phillips Academy Andover, Yale University, Harvard Business School and the University of Oslo, and has an Honorary Doctorate in Law from Trinity College, Dublin. In World War II, Ambassador Curley, a Marine Corps infantry combat officer, served in the Iwo Jima, Okinawa, Guam and North China campaigns, and holds decorations from the Army, Navy, Marine Corps, and The Republic of China. With the Caltex Oil Company, he worked in India and Italy (1949-1959) before becoming a partner in J.H. Whitney & Co, the venture capital firm (1960-1974). He was Commissioner of Public Events and was Chief of Protocol of New York City in the Lindsay administration. He was appointed Ambassador to Ireland by President Ford in 1975. He returned to the private sector to establish his own venture capital investment Business in New York in 1977. He served as Ambassador to France (1989-93) under President George H.W. Bush. He was a Trustee of the New York Public Library, Miss Porter's School, Brooks School in Massachusetts, The Buckley School, Barnard College, and a former director of the New York Life Insurance Company, Fiduciary Trust International, Bank of Ireland, Crane Co., Guinness Peat Aviation (U.S), Independent Newspapers Ltd. (Dublin), Fairchild Camera and Instrument Co., American Exploration Co., The New Yorker Magazine, the International Board of Banque Paribas, and Sotheby's Holdings, Inc. He is the author of four books: Almost a Century - An American Life East & West of Suez, Vanishing Kingdoms, Monarchs in Waiting, and Letters from the Pacific. Ambassador Curley was Honorary Chairman of the French American-Foundation, Chairman Emeritus of Sotheby's International Advisory Board, Trustee Emeritus of the American Hospital in Paris and of The Frick Collection; he was a member of the Council of American Ambassadors, and a member of The Council on Foreign Relations. He is survived by his wife of 67 years, the former Mary Taylor Walton of Pittsburgh, his daughter Margaret Bacon (Carter), his son, WJ Patrick III (Jane), and seven grandchildren: Kelly, Christina and Taylor Wiles, Joseph, William (Willa), Nina and Ross Curley. He was predeceased by two sons, John and James. Ambassador and Mrs. Curley lived in Manhattan and in the west of Ireland. Mass of the Resurrection St. Vincent Ferrer R.C. Church, Friday, June 10th at 10am. Services are being entrusted to Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel". 1/3

Campbell--The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., Wednesday and Thursday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Funeral mass Friday 10:30am, St. Patrick's Cathedral, East 51st Street and 5th Ave. 1/3

ALFORD--Ann Bernhard, of Saddle River, NJ passed away peacefully surrounded by family on June 6, 2016 at the age of 87. She was a dedicated philanthropist, whose leadership was marked by grace, persistence, and an unwavering commitment to the charities she supported. She joined the Valley Hospital Foundation Board in 1994 and served as a Trustee of The Valley Hospital Foundation for 12 years. Nine of those years were as an Officer of the Board, including serving as Chairman for three years. She graduated, Phi Beta Kappa from Wells College in 1949 and later served on the Wells College Board of Trustees from 1994 to 2001. Ann served as Chair of the West Bergen Mental Healthcare Foundation Board of Trustees from 2007 to 2010 and currently serves as a Trustee. She also currently serves on the Forum School Board of Trustees. Ann had a passion for music and the arts and was a patron of The Metropolitan Opera, Parlance Chamber Concerts, American Ballet Theatre, and the Roundabout Theatre Company. Married to her late, beloved husband, George Edward Alford for 29 years Ann was devoted to her family. She is survived by her brother, Berl Bernhard; her daughters, Maria Alford Suehnholz and Elizabeth Alford Hogan; stepdaughters, Patricia Alford President, Carolyn Alford Cason, and Katherine Alford: grandchildren, George Alford Suehnholz, Michael Raymond Suehnholz, Lindsey Alford Hogan, Graham Patrick Hogan, AJ Johnson and predeceased grandson Justin Alford President. In lieu of flowers, donations should be sent to the Valley Hospital Foundation, Ridgewood, NJ or the National Foundation for Animal Rescue. 1/3

WHITE--Pamela Steele, gifted therapist and beloved mother, wife, and friend, died June 6, 2016. She was 69. Pamela is survived by her husband, Edward White, her brother Chum Steele, her children Banker White, Devon White Angelini, and Luke White, her grandchildren Leif, Elin, Dylan, Edward, Oscar, and dozens of well-earned friends. Pamela was born in Boston, and had a self-described "fairy tale" childhood. She was raised in the Hotel Continental in Harvard Square which was owned and managed by her father, Chauncey Steele. She often posed for paintings for her mother, renowned artist Marian Steele. Pam shared her fairy tale charm and optimism throughout her remarkable life. Pam was a unique, vibrant spirit who was loved by all who knew her. She had many careers: a professional model, a teacher for the developmentally delayed, a social worker and health counselor at Milton Academy, and a therapist in private practice. She co-founded a Boston area a cappella group, The Second Wind, which is in its 43rd consecutive year performing. She was a trusted ally and feared opponent on the tennis court, and an exemplar sportswoman. Even her battle with Alzheimer's disease was transformed into a work of art in "The Genius of Marian," a feature length documentary directed by her son Banker White and his wife Anna Fitch. Above all else, she loved her family, was fiercely loyal, and made everyone around her feel heard, loved, and lucky to have known her. A memorial service will be held on Friday, June 10th at 12pm at the Church of the Redeemer in Chestnut Hill. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Pamela Steele White Family Foundation, c/o Lynch Brewer Hoffman & Fink, 75 Federal St., 7th Floor, Boston, MA 02110. The foundation will fund scholarships to deserving students in the Boston Area, among Pamela's other charitable interests. 1/3

GRUENGLAS--Abe. Abe Gruenglas, beloved father, husband, son, and brother, passed away in New York City on May 30, 2016 of natural causes at the age of 89. Abe, a survivor of the Holocaust, was educated as a civil engineer at Brooklyn College and served his career in the NYC Department of Finance, retiring from his post as Assistant Surveyor for the Borough of Brooklyn. Abe is survived by his wife Magda, and his sons Michael, Benjamin and Jeffrey. Abe was laid to rest in a family plot at Mt. Lebanon cemetery in Queens, NY. He will be greatly missed. BRUNER--Jerome. The NYU School of Law mourns the death of University Professor Jerome "Jerry" Bruner. One of the most influential psychologists of the 20th century, Jerry was also a trailblazing figure in a multitude of other fields. Bringing his innate and abundant sense of wonder about the human mind to the Law School, he interwove psychology, literature, philosophy, anthropology--practically every aspect of the humanities--into his teaching. For his students and fellow teachers alike, he illuminated ways in which culture and law intersect. In a tribute for his 100th birthday last October, his colleagues hailed him as the "Pied Piper of interdisciplinary wonder." The Law School will deeply miss Jerry's dazzling intellect and personal warmth, but we are grateful for the ways in which he enriched our community. We join his family and friends in mourning his loss. Trevor Morrison, Dean 1/3

BLUMBERG--Rhoda. Died at home on June 6th at age 98. Award-winning author of non-fiction for young adults; enthusiastic wife, mother, grandmother and friend. Raised in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. After graduating from Adelphi College in 1937, Rhoda became a "career girl". She produced several programs for CBS radio and later wrote feature articles for several national magazines. In 1944, she met Gerald Blumberg, a successful attorney, and they married six months later. Moving from Brooklyn in 1951 to a farm in what was then a rural part of Westchester County, Rhoda dedicated the next 20+ years to raising their four children. She enjoyed teaching her children the joys of nature and sharing her passion for classical music, travel and tennis. When her youngest child entered college in the early 1970s, her interest in history and the exhilaration of research triumphed, and Rhoda returned to her typewriter. During the next 30 years, she wrote and composed over 25 non-fiction books. She had an uncanny ability to find and incorporate fascinating anecdotes that brought history to life for millions of young adults (and their parents). Her books received numerous awards, including the Boston Globe Horn Book Award, the Newbery Honor Medal, Orbis Pictus Award for Outstanding Non-Fiction for Children, and multiple Golden Kite awards. Her books included "Commodore Perry in the Land of the Shogun" (1985), "The Incredible Journey of Lewis and Clark" (1987), "The Great American Gold Rush" (1989), "Shipwrecked! The True Adventures of a Japanese Boy" (2001), and "York's Adventures with Lewis and Clark: An African-American's Part in the Great Expedition" (2004). Rhoda also partnered on several books with friend and renowned illustrator, Murray Tinkelman, including "The Truth About Dragons" (1980) and "Backyard Bestiary" (1979). Jerry Blumberg died in 2009 shortly after their 64th wedding anniversary. Rhoda's life is celebrated by a large family, including four children and their spouses: Larry Blumberg and Robin Lynn, Rena Blumberg, Alice and David Rubin, and Leda Blumberg and Steve Cole; nine grandchildren: Daniel Blumberg, Carla Steckman, Ilana Blumberg, William Gottlieb, Osheana Tashombe, Gregory Rubin, Amalia Rubin, Dana Rocco and Eliza Volk; ten great-grand- children; and her best friend and sister, Cynthia. She is the last to pass of her Adelphi College gang: Betty, Estelle, Gladys, Mickey, Mimi, and Norma. Funeral will be on Friday, June 10, 2016 at 11am at Temple Israel of Northern Westchester, Glengary Road, Croton-on-Hudson, NY. Burial will follow at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, New York. Shiva plans will be announced at the funeral. 1/3

We will forever miss his friendship, wisdom and sense of humor. Our condolences to his wife Nancy, daughters Pam and Cara and all his grandchildren. Bonnie & Robert Konigsberg Judy & Paul Konigsberg 1/3
