ORESMAN--Donald (1925-2016), attorney, businessman and civic leader, died peacefully May 24 at his Midtown apartment. A native New Yorker, he was born in the shadow of Washington Square and later moved to the Upper West Side with his parents. Classified 4-F by the Selective Service in World War II due to a defective heart valve, Donald sat out the conflict at Oberlin College, graduating in 1946. "Having a desire to write but little creative talent, I decided to try journalism," he later wrote. He started with the daily Ossining Citizen Register as its only reporter and soon moved to the Pittsburgh Press, which published five editions a day. After working there for a few years, he concluded that the paper's courthouse coverage was weak and applied to law school, figuring he would return to newspapers upon graduation. In 1957 he completed his degree at Columbia University Law, graduating with honors. Unable resist the law's gravitational pull, he accepted a job with Simpson Thacher & Bartlett and worked there from 1957 to 1984, largely representing public corporations. A senior partner with the firm, he was asked in 1984 to join senior management at Gulf + Western Industries, an early conglomerate that he had represented as outside counsel for 10 years. He served as Executive Vice President, Chief Counsel, and Chief Administrative Officer until the company, by then named Paramount Communications, Inc., was sold in 1994. He returned to Simpson Thacher & Bartlett after working for a year with Paramount's former board chairman, Martin Davis, who had started an investment boutique. Donald was a close advisor to late Movado Group founder Gedalio (Gerry) Grinberg and sat on the Movado Board for more than 25 years. Throughout his career, Donald's outside interests centered on the arts, literature, and libraries. He served for 25 years on the New York Landmarks Conservancy Board, including a term as chairman. In 2006 he was given the Conservancy's Chairman's Award. He served on numerous other boards, including the Library Company at Philadelphia, the Larchmont Library, the Morgan Library, the American Antiquarian Society, The Writers Room, the Roundabout Theatre Company, the Dictionary of American Regional English, Volunteer Lawyers for the Arts, the Heye National Museum of the American Indian - New York, the Museum of the City of New York, the Library of America, the Academy of American Poets, the Grolier Club, the National Building Museum, the American Academy in Rome, the American Ballet Theatre, the Gainsborough Studios, the New Criterion, and the Yale Edition of the Boswell Papers. In 1948 Donald married social worker Patricia Perry, beginning a 67-year union that he called the smartest decision of his life. His private interests, other than reading and his wife's opinion, included a collection of 20th Century images of people reading: prints, drawings, photographs, oils, watercolors, sculptures, etc. His late mother Gertrude Bergel Oresman was assistant to the editor of The Theater Magazine, and his late father A. Louis Oresman, was an attorney, C.P.A., and a financial advisor for a number of privately held corporations. He is survived by his wife Patricia; his brother, Stephen B. Oresman (Darien, CT); two sons, Thomas P. Oresman (Kent, WA) and Craig P. Oresman (Los Lunas, NM); daughter, Alison Oresman Wilson (Bellevue, WA); seven grandchildren, two step-grandchildren, and six great-grandchildren. He was preceded in death by his older brother, Roger B. Oresman, of Manhattan, a longtime partner at the Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy law firm; an infant daughter, Eliza Lyn; and great-grandson, Donny Wade. A memorial will be held September 10, 2016. Please email oresmanmemorial@ gmail.com for information. 1/3

ENRICO--Roger Anthony. 71, revered former Chairman and CEO of PepsiCo and former Chairman of DreamWorks Animation, died on Wednesday, June 1, 2016. Roger was born on November 11, 1944 in Chisholm, MN, the son of Anthony and Rose Marie Parucci Enrico. He earned a B.S. in Business Administration from Babson College, and served in the U.S. Navy during the Vietnam War, stationed in Vietnam. Recruited to PepsiCo in 1971, Roger spent 32 distinguished years with the company, ultimately attaining chairmanship. A visionary marketer and risk taker, he was the competitive catalyst at Pepsi-Cola behind Coca-Cola's unprecedented reformulation of its flagship soft drink. He transformed PepsiCo's Frito-Lay global snack food businesses, and oversaw PepsiCo's Worldwide Restaurants (Pizza Hut, Taco Bell and KFC.) He re-conceptualized PepsiCo, separating foods and beverages and spinning off restaurants into the successful YUM! Brands. Roger was a champion of front line workers, anonymously donating his salary to fund scholarships for their children. Following PepsiCo, Roger was courted out of retirement by DreamWorks Animation (DWA) CEO Jeffrey Katzenberg to chair the company through its IPO. He served for eight years at a pivotal moment in DWA's growth and evolution. Roger served on numerous corporate boards and the boards of the American Film Institute, the American Prairie Reserve, the Environmental Defense Fund, KERA, and the National Geographic Society. An active but quiet philanthropist, he was eager and generous to help others. Not only a great citizen and businessman, Roger was a loyal friend to many. Roger is survived by his childhood sweetheart and loving wife of 48 years, Rosemary Margo Enrico; their son Aaron and his wife Catherine, and their children, Daniel, Gisele and Joseph, all of Dallas. A public celebration of Roger's life will be held on Monday, June 13, 2016 at 10am at Christ the King Catholic Church, 8107 Preston Road, Dallas, TX. Contributions may be made to The Roger and Rosemary Enrico Foundation, supporting social services, outreach and education for the underprivileged, environmental conservancy and medical research. Contributions can be sent to The Roger and Rosemary Enrico Foundation, c/o Paragon Advisors, 20820 Chagrin Blvd., Suite 300, Shaker Heights, OH 44122. Please express condolences at www. sparkman-hillcrest.com. 1/3

HARDY--Paige Ethington. You were our shining light. Our hearts go out to Tripp and your amazing five children: Basil, Bennett, Tate, Ivy and Byron. We will always love you and will remember your hilarious wit, kind heart, megawatt smile and unbelievable friendship over the years. The Group 6 Episcopal Moms Breakfast Club 1/3

PUNNETT--R. John. Real Estate developer R. John Punnett died peacefully on Monday, June 6th at his home in Manhattan. He was 89 years old. Born in Zemun, Yugoslavia on February 8, 1927 to Tamara Gert and RAF pilot Schuyler Punnett, John and his sister Lydia were raised first in Greece, and later moving to Nantes, France where they lived during the German occupation. Being fluent in English, French, and Russian, he joined the RAF at age 17 and was stationed in Cairo and in Baghdad working in the Intelligence division. At the end of the war he was granted a full scholarship to attend the University of Cambridge, where he earned a BA in Russian literature. In 1956 he joined his sister in New York where he remained throughout his life. With a loan from his mother, in 1962 he began a career in real estate and founded Punnett Realty Company, eventually owning and managing up to 30 buildings largely centered in the Yorkville neighborhood. Always dressed in his trademark English suits, John was extremely respected in his field and known by everyone as a true gentleman. This was reflected by the fact that most of his employees had been with him for several decades. His work ethic was inspiring to many. Rarely taking a day off, he continued to go to his office until recently. There were few things John enjoyed more than spending time with his numerous friends and growing family and he described his six grandchildren as his "brood". He was most at peace in his Southampton home, where he maintained a residence for over four decades. He was predeceased by his sister Lydia Wasserman and is survived by his wife Carol, his son Anthony, daughters Dominique, Daniela, and his grandchildren Tatiana, Alexi, Kayden, Lucas, Olivia, and Alexandra. John will be missed for his generosity, his dry sense of humor, his keen intellect, and his love of the arts. He will be remembered by his family as a great father, teacher, and wonderful provider. Funeral services will be held at Brockett Funeral Home in Southampton on Saturday, June 11th, beginning at 10am. Memorial donations to the R. John Punnett Foundation, 107 Lee Ave., Southampton, NY 11968 would be appreciated. 1

STARK--Solomon, beloved husband of the late Charlotte. Devoted father of Ronni Greenberg and Jane Stark Berger. Father-in-law of Bruce Greenberg and Stuart Berger. Loving grandfather of Carly, Adam, David and Courtney. Dear brother of Shirley Serchuk and Libby Brooks. Service 11am, Friday at Gutterman and Musicant, 402 Park St., Hackensack, NJ. 1/3

MIGDAL--Lester Charles, died May 31 at his home of 60 years on 92nd Street in New York City. For the last 53 years, he also spent as much time as he could at his farm in Washington County, NY. Lester was born February 8, 1918 to David and Helen Migdal in Brooklyn, NY. He attended public schools in Brooklyn and graduated from City College of New York, where he studied philosophy, and from Harvard Law School. His marriage of 28 years to Ellen Marcus MigdaI ended on her death in August, 1970. His second marriage of 38 years to Eleanor Jackson Burt Migdal ended on her death in March, 2013. He is survived by five children: Joanna Migdal, Eliza Migdal, David Migdal, Kaethe Burt-O'Dea and Sarah Burt, twelve grandchildren, nine great- grandchildren, and his brother, Dr. Walter Migdal. Lester served during the Second World War as a captain in the Army combat engineers. After the Battle of the Bulge, he commanded a company that under heavy fire built one of the pontoon bridges across the Rhine River which the allied armies crossed to defeat Germany; Lester loved the law, which he practiced in New York City for over 50 years, at his own firm. His cases ranged from the defense of a victim of the McCarthy witch hunts to the representation of extended families, in all legal matters from marriage and children to death and taxes, to more public matters argued and won at the U.S. Supreme Court. Many of his clients became his close friends. Lester collected thousands of books. With insatiable curiosity and a lifetime of insomnia, he read them all. He was particularly interested in literature, criticism and poetry. In his later years, intensely missing both his wives he found special solace in poetry. Lester valued his close relationship with his family and friends. A few nights before he died he played poker with a group of friends in a game that had lasted forty years. Lester will be remembered for his intelligence, wit, fearlessness, and gentility. He maintained his talent for respectful kindness, and the easy and intense connections with others which flowed from that, until the day he died. A memorial will be held for Lester later this summer at the Harvard Club, 35 W. 44th St., New York City. 1/3

SPATZ--Ilse, born January 29, 1930, died June 5, 2016. Beloved wife of the late Werner Spatz. Adored mother of David and Linda and Sherrill and Rob. Cherished grandmother (and Oma) of Hana, Emma, Alex and Zoe. Honored sister of Bea Roberg. She taught us how to live life to the fullest, overcome difficulties with grace and without complaint and the importance of faith and giving back to your community without the expectation of praise. She will be in our hearts forever. 1/3

KAMIYA--Smile, died peacefully on Sunday, May 29th in Sunnyvale, California. He was 95 years old. He was born and died in California, but considered New York City his home. He lived there for over 60 years raising his family and working as a public accountant at his firm Kamiya & Sklar. We will miss his generous heart and dry humor. Smile is preceded in death by his wife, Emi. He is survived by his son, Akira, daughter, Sumi (Ken), and five grandchildren, Koyama, Yuta, Emiko, Miles and Maya. 1/3

DOERFLER--Marvin, passed away suddenly but peacefully at home in The Landings, Savannah, Georgia, on June 4, 2016. Beloved husband, adored father, entrepreneur extraordinaire, and bemused curmudgeon, Marvin was a man who made his life a constant creative enterprise. With great wit he excelled at seeing the humor in the world's absurdities, never failing to point out when the emperor's clothes were a sham. Marvin showed by example how to live a life of empathy, love, and humor in the face of life's challenges. He is survived by his loving wife Myrna and his three sons Steven, Brian and his husband Jim, and Eric and his life partner Sherry. There will be a celebration of his life at The Plantation Club at The Landings on June 18 from 2-4pm. 1/3

SOLOMON--Blanche, on June 6, 2016, after a long and hard battle with a relentless lung tumor, at 86 years old. Beloved wife of the late Arthur J. Solomon. Loving mother of Lisa G. Liebman, her son-in-law Steven H. Charles Liebman, and the late Gregg C. Solomon. Cherished grandmother of Samuel Alex Liebman. She will live on in our hearts and minds forever, and we will never forget her love and the positive impact that she had on all of our lives. Private graveside service will be held on Thursday. 1/3

WEIS--Theodore. May 13, 1956 - May 30, 2016. After a brief, four-month struggle with stomach cancer, Ted died peacefully, with his wife Lisa at his bedside. To say he loved his family was an understatement--Ted lived and breathed for his daughter Daniela, and his wife and companion of nineteen years, Lisa. The only son of Marie and Theodore Weis, Ted was raised in New York and New Jersey. After graduating from Indiana University and Fordham University School of Law, he practiced as an entertainment attorney in his own firm and also worked with his wife in her clothing business. An easygoing, kind hearted and exceptionally funny man, Ted was happiest amongst his family and many longtime friends. He loved music, old monster movies, the Yankees and most of all, playing baseball and dodgeball with his daughter. He was deeply loved by those fortunate to be close with him, and he will be greatly missed. 1/3

CURLEY--Walter J.P. The Board of Directors and employees of Fiduciary Trust Company International mourn the passing of our former board member and friend, Ambassador Curley--a diplomat, world class communicator and business leader. We send condolences to his wife, Mary, and his family. 1/3

BRENNAN--Eileen (Fitzgerald). Longtime resident of Manhasset, NY died June 7, 2016 at St. Francis Hospital after a brief illness, surrounded by her family. She was 90. Beloved wife of the late John J. "Jack" Brennan, and loving mother of the late Eileen Ann, she is survived by her children John (Joan) of Ardmore, PA, Edward (Julia) of Sea Cliff, NY, Beatrice Wall (Robert) of Lloyd Harbor, NY, Michael (Lisa) of Manhasset, Virginia (James Waechter) of Nashville, TN, Stephen (Patricia) of Irvington, NY, Peter (Bernadette) of Bronxville, NY, Thomas of Philadelphia, PA, and William (Margaret) of Yorktown Heights, NY.; 24 grandchildren; 10 great-grandchildren; her sister-in-law Beatrice Brennan, RSCJ, and brother-in-law Michael F. Armstrong, as well as many loving nieces and nephews. The only child of Edward Francis and Mary (Daly) Fitzgerald, she grew up in the Bronx, attending Ursuline Academy, Maplehurst Academy and Manhattanville College, on an academic scholarship, graduating in 1946. As a senior, she won Vogue Magazine's Prix de Paris essay contest and spent the next year working for the magazine in Manhattan. She married Jack Brennan in 1948 at St. Francis de Sales Church in Rockaway, NY, and they had 10 children. In 1957, the family moved to Manhasset, where for nearly six decades she was a deeply committed community volunteer and activist involved in, most notably, St. Mary's of Manhasset Parish. She served as a Eucharistic Minister, Lector, Blood Bank Coordinator, and member of the Parish Council. She also worked with the Manhattanville Alumni Association, the AAUW and the League of Women Voters. While raising her children, she earned a Masters of Arts in Liberal Studies at Manhattanville. After all 10 children finished college, she resumed her journalism career beginning at the Port Washington News, and later as editor of the Manhasset Press. Eventually, she was editing eight papers for Anton Community Newspapers. The Manhasset Rotary Club and Chamber of Commerce honored her. In Manhasset, Eileen and Jack made many beloved friends and the family knows they grieve with us now. A wake will be held at Fairchild and Sons in Manhasset on Friday; 2 to 5pm and 7 to 9pm. There will be a funeral Mass at St. Mary's at 9am sharp on Saturday followed by interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn or to St. Mary's Parish Social Ministry in Manhasset. 1/3

ROSEFSKY--Julie. The Edith and Carl Marks Jewish Community House of Bensonhurst mourns the loss of Julie Rosefsky, the sister of our dear friend and distinguished board member Yale Fergang. On behalf of all of Yale's friends at the "J", we send our sincerest condolences on this great loss. Our hearts are with you at this difficult time. Alex Budnitsky, CEO Jonathan Gold, Chairman 1/3

O'SULLIVAN--Sonya S.,98, died at her home in Mamaroneck on June 3. Born in New York City to B.P. and Adeline Jaffe Schulberg, she moved with her parents and older brother Budd to Los Angeles, where her father was head of production at Paramount Studios. Sonya came to love sun, horses, dogs and Malibu, where Ad built one of the first houses. At the insistence of their mother, who had a literary agency in NYC from 1945 until 1977, Sonya, Budd and younger brother Stuart became writers. She attended The Progressive School, co-founded by her mother. After her parents' divorce, Sonya attended schools in Paris, Geneva and London. She started Sarah Lawrence but left at 19 when Scribners published her first novel (Maxwell Perkins was her editor). Budd's first novel, What Makes Sammy Run, made a bigger splash and Budd went on to success as a screenwriter (On the Waterfront). Sonya was married to attorney Ben O'Sullivan from 1941 until his death in 1998. Sadly, their son John O'Sullivan died in 2010. Her dear friends, brothers Budd and Stuart, also predeceased her. She is survived by other close friends: her daughter Dr. Chris O'Sullivan of NYC and Mamaroneck, Budd's and Stuart's children, among them Vicky Kingsland, Benn, Sandra, K.C., Peter and Jonathan Schulberg; her nieces Elizabeth Frank and Beth O'Sullivan; and her grandchildren Sarah and Kate O'Sullivan and great-grandson Will McCullough of Washington, DC and Betsy Schulberg. Wherever she lived, she adopted dogs and cats, tended wild animals, created gardens (on Martha's Vineyard and in Mamaroneck). She published short stories and recently completed a witty sad novel with perfectly constructed sentences about growing up in Hollywood. She was buried in the West Tisbury Cemetery on Martha's Vineyard. A reception will be held at her home in Mamaroneck in mid June. Sonya would have liked contributions to one of the many animal organizations she supported, including the Doris Day Animal Foundation, 8033 Sunset Boulevard, Suite 845, Los Angeles, CA 90046 or donate in memoriam online at DDAF. 1/3

BLUMBERG--Rhoda. Died at home on June 6th at age 98. Award-winning author of non-fiction for young adults; enthusiastic wife, mother, grandmother and friend. Raised in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. After graduating from Adelphi College in 1937, Rhoda became a "career girl". She produced several programs for CBS radio and later wrote feature articles for several national magazines. In 1944, she met Gerald Blumberg, a successful attorney, and they married six months later. Moving from Brooklyn in 1951 to a farm in what was then a rural part of Westchester County, Rhoda dedicated the next 20+ years to raising their four children. She enjoyed teaching her children the joys of nature and sharing her passion for classical music, travel and tennis. When her youngest child entered college in the early 1970s, her interest in history and the exhilaration of research triumphed, and Rhoda returned to her typewriter. During the next 30 years, she wrote and composed over 25 non-fiction books. She had an uncanny ability to find and incorporate fascinating anecdotes that brought history to life for millions of young adults (and their parents). Her books received numerous awards, including the Boston Globe Horn Book Award, the Newbery Honor Medal, Orbis Pictus Award for Outstanding Non-Fiction for Children, and multiple Golden Kite awards. Her books included "Commodore Perry in the Land of the Shogun" (1985), "The Incredible Journey of Lewis and Clark" (1987), "The Great American Gold Rush" (1989), "Shipwrecked! The True Adventures of a Japanese Boy" (2001), and "York's Adventures with Lewis and Clark: An African-American's Part in the Great Expedition" (2004). Rhoda also partnered on several books with friend and renowned illustrator, Murray Tinkelman, including "The Truth About Dragons" (1980) and "Backyard Bestiary" (1979). Jerry Blumberg died in 2009 shortly after their 64th wedding anniversary. Rhoda's life is celebrated by a large family, including four children and their spouses: Larry Blumberg and Robin Lynn, Rena Blumberg, Alice and David Rubin, and Leda Blumberg and Steve Cole; nine grandchildren: Daniel Blumberg, Carla Steckman, Ilana Blumberg, William Gottlieb, Osheana Tashombe, Gregory Rubin, Amalia Rubin, Dana Rocco and Eliza Volk; ten great-grand- children; and her best friend and sister, Cynthia. She is the last to pass of her Adelphi College gang: Betty, Estelle, Gladys, Mickey, Mimi, and Norma. Funeral will be on Friday, June 10, 2016 at 11am at Temple Israel of Northern Westchester, Glengary Road, Croton-on-Hudson, NY. Burial will follow at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, New York. Shiva plans will be announced at the funeral. 1/3

ELLIS--William C.,known as Bill, was born in Shreveport, LA, and died at age 83 after a short illness on June 6, 2016, at Danbury Hospital, surrounded by his family. He lived in New York City for many years and then moved permanently to Litchfield in 2003. His parents were Olga Willoughby Ellis and Henry Clyde Ellis; his older sister, Patricia, predeceased him. For 48 years he was most happily married to Jane Bacon Ellis, who died in 2011. He is survived by loving daughters Clare Ellis of New York City and Kate Ellis Hobsbawm of London, England; son-in-law Andy Hobsbawm; grandchildren Milo and Eve Hobsbawm; and his wonderful partner, Karen Silk. For two years, Bill attended LSU, where he was a member of Kappa Sigma fraternity, before transferring to the University of Texas at Austin, where he earned a BA in architecture in 1957. He received an MA in city and regional planning from Rutgers University in 1969. From 1969 to 1982, he was a fellow at the Institute for Architecture and Urban Studies in New York City. He was a professor of architecture at the City University of New York, a visiting professor at The Cooper Union, and a visiting lecturer at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum and the Smithsonian Institution. Throughout his professional academic life, he remained an architect in private practice. Bill will be remembered by his family, his colleagues, and his many friends for his intelligence, wit, charm, insightfulness, generosity, and sweet nature. A celebration of his remarkable life will be held at the Litchfield Country Club on Saturday, June 11, 2016, at 2:00pm. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in his name to the Oliver Wolcott Library in Litchfield. 1/3

ALI--Muhammad. On behalf of Billie Jean King and the Board of Trustees and staff of the Women's Sports Foundation, we want to express our heartfelt condolences to Laila Ali and her family on the loss of her beloved father, Muhammad Ali. Muhammad Ali was a true champion in the boxing ring and a courageous hero, recognized world-wide for his wit and his willingness to speak up for peace and equality. Muhammad Ali is truly the greatest and he will be missed by all. 1/3
FINE WEINBERG--Ellen. Cherished friend will be missed forever. Marjorie & Arthur Samuels 1/3

SEGAL--Robert. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the death of our long time and devoted member, Robert Segal, beloved husband of Wendy Segal. Our heartfelt condolences to Wendy, their daughter Daniella, and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, D.D., Senior Rabbi Martin Flumenbaum, President 1/3
MIGDAL--Lester, who died this past Memorial Day, at 98, is lovingly remembered by eight special friends who met with him biweekly since the 1970's. 1/3

FORSTER--Hamilton F.,age 83, of New York City on June 6, 2016 from complications of emphysema. Graduate of Groton School and Harvard College, 1954. Pre-deceased by wife of 49 years, Elizabeth H. Forster in June, 2008, and daughter Elizabeth E. Forster in February, 2006. He is survived by son, Timothy H. Forster, his wife, Diane, and sons John and Christopher and by daughter, Laura Forster Bowman and her daughters Lily and Chloe. Mr. Forster was an avid golfer, longtime member of Somerset Hills Country Club, and also enjoyed playing paddle tennis and squash. He was a lifelong fan of the Harvard Crimson football team and took great pride in being in the stands for the 29-29 Harvard victory over Yale in 1968. He was a First Lieutenant in the United States Army from 1954-1956, stationed primarily in West Germany. He spent many years in the securities business, retiring from Merrill Lynch in 1994. The burial will be private. Mr. Forster requested that any donations be directed to the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, Attn: Stephanie Steel, 1250 Broadway, 4th Floor, New York, NY 10001. 1/3

FINE--Ellen Ginder. Beloved matriarch and tenacious businesswoman. Widow of her love Sidney L. Weinberg. Devoted mother, grandmother, sister and friend. Ellen is survived by her children Andrew, Elizabeth and Jean. Her grandchildren Alex, Sidney, Charlotte, Abigail, Annika and Margot. She is also survived by her siblings Mary, Richard, Don and John. Her son-in-law Kyle Czepiel and daughter- in-law Ayesha Fine. Visitation will be held at Frank E Campbell "The Funeral Chapel," 81st Street and Madison Ave., on Friday 2-5pm / 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Jean Baptiste, E. 76th Street and Lexington Ave., on Saturday at 9:30am. Interment to follow at Most Holy Trinity Cemetery, East Hampton, NY. 1/3

PAJEWSKI--Stan Page, born Stanley Pajewski, died peacefully on June 5. He was a singer and actor. Stan and his late wife, dancer Mickey Gunnersen, between them appeared in over two dozen broadway shows and many regional, summer stock, road companies and on television. 1/3

KAMIYA--Smile, died peacefully on Sunday, May 29th in Sunnyvale, California. He was 95 years old. He was born and died in California, but considered New York City his home. He lived there for over 60 years raising his family and working as a public accountant at his firm Kamiya & Sklar. We will miss his generous heart and dry humor. Smile is preceded in death by his wife, Emi. He is survived by his son, Akira, daughter, Sumi (Ken), and five grandchildren, Koyama, Yuta, Emiko, Miles and Maya. 1/3

ORESMAN--Donald. The Board and Staff of The New York Landmarks Conservancy mourn the passing, but celebrate the contributions, of our former Chair and longtime Board Member. Working with his great friend Brendan Gill, Donald was instrumental in early Conservancy preservation efforts. These include the fight to save the Biltmore Hotel, and successful efforts to save and preserve the Federal Archive Building, Peck Slip, the Fraunces Tavern Block and the Villard Houses. Donald was also close to the late Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, leading the Conservancy to embrace the Senator's goal of creating a great train station within the landmark Farley Post Office - an effort we continue to support. A consummate tactician, Donald urged the Conservancy to fight hard for preservation but to also work towards practical solutions, saying: "Never let the perfect be the enemy of the good." We will always remain grateful for his leadership. Our condolences to his family. Lloyd P. Zuckerberg, Chair; Peg Breen, President 1/3

ORESMAN--Donald. The Council of the Grolier Club is deeply saddened to learn of the death of fellow member and former Councilor Donald Oresman. A Grolier member since 1972, Oresman rendered distinguished service to the Grolier Club during his term as Councilor (1996 to 2005), serving as Vice-President (2002-2005) and Secretary (1998-2001), and chairing our Library, House, Modern Fine Printing, and Prints Committees. He gave generously of his time, energy, and his broad knowledge of books and prints, to the Club's great and lasting benefit; and his counsel will be sorely missed. We extend our sympathy to his wife Patricia, their family, and to his many friends and colleagues in the Grolier Club and the world of books at large. G. Scott Clemons, President 1/3
PAJEWSKI--Stanley, (Stan Page). Quintessential man of the theater. We will miss his friendship, his love and his beautiful, powerful voice. Carol and Bill 1/3

CURLEY--Walter J.P. The Board of Directors and employees of Fiduciary Trust Company International mourn the passing of our former board member and friend, Ambassador Curley--a diplomat, world class communicator and business leader. We send condolences to his wife, Mary, and his family. 1/3

SCHREIBER--Sol, Esq. Died peacefully on June 9, 2016. Son of Rose z'l and Harry z'l, loving husband to Ann z'l and then to Sharron z'l, brother to Dan and Mimi, uncle to Michael, Steven, Kenneth and their families, and friend to many. Born in Brooklyn in 1929, Sol worked in his parents' grocery store before serving in the Army for three years. Sol graduated from CCNY in 1952 and earned a law degree from Yale in 1955. Sol served as Trial and Resident Counsel for Liberty Mutual, was a Magistrate Judge in the US District Court for the Southern District of New York, served as President and CEO of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies Service Corporation, and was a partner at Milberg. Sol had a passion for education, spending over 40 years developing continuing education programs and books for ALI-ABA, being an adjunct professor at Fordham School of Law, and chairing a course on American law in China and India. But Sol will be remembered most for his founding of the Ann Schreiber Ovarian Cancer Research Fund (now OCRFA), in memory of Ann, in 1994, and his tireless advocacy on behalf of OCRFA, which has invested nearly $70 million in ovarian cancer research. Sol will be missed by all those people whose lives he touched. A Funeral Service will be held at 9:30am on Friday, June 10, at "The Riverside," Amsterdam Ave. at 76th St. Contributions in Sol's honor may be made to OCRFA at ocrf.org. No shiva but details about a future memorial service that OCRFA is arranging can be obtained from OCRFA. 1/3

JACOB--Eva Jacob, nee Neubauer. February 28, 1934 - May 15, 2016. Cherished wife of Fred for over 60 years. Much-loved sister of Frank (Hannah) Neubauer and the late Raymond (Anne Marie) Neubauer; dear mother of Stefanie (Scott Tisdel) and Walter; beloved Oma of Andy and Emmy Tisdel. Escaped Nazi Germany with her family; attended New York's Fieldston School; earned both B.A. summa cum laude and M.A. in English from Radcliffe. Served as curator for the DeCordova Museum, Lincoln, MA; wrote on issues in the arts for Boston publications; worked as Policy and Planning Officer for the National Endowment for the Arts in Washington, DC, 1978-1996, and created the Endowment's Chamber Music Rural Residencies program. Retired early to pursue her love of painting; spent almost five happy years at St. John's on the Lake, Milwaukee, WI. A memorial service will be held at noon on June 12 at St. John's. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be sent to the Wisconsin Conservatory of Music, 1584 N. Prospect Ave., Milwaukee, WI 53202. 1/3

RIDDER--Virginia Dunne, November 2, 1920 to June 4, 2016. All of Virginia's dear friends in New York City, Santa Barbara, London and Paris will miss her sparkle, warmth, grace and elegance. Born in NYC, the only daughter of Julia and John V. Dunne, one of the first members of the New York Stock Exchange, Virginia was formerly married to Joseph Ridder of California and Honolulu, who predeceased her. Virginia lived a busy life travelling around the world, fascinated by history, art, architecture, antiques and interesting places. She enjoyed her life in New York, a longtime member of the Colony Club, bridge, and a particular love of the Metropolitan Museum, Central Park and its Conservancy and many philanthropic institutions both in New York and Santa Barbara. She passed away peacefully and suddenly in Greenwich Hospital and her remains will be interred at the Dunne Mausoleum, Cemetery of the Gate of Heaven in Mt. Pleasant. At Virginia's request there will be no services. Interment is private. 1/3

SCHREIBER--Sol. With deep sorrow, Ovarian Cancer Research Fund Alliance mourns the passing of our beloved founder and Chairman Emeritus, Sol Schreiber. We are grateful for his foresight, leadership and steady guidance for the last 22 years. Sol's legacy continues to help women all over the world and will one day result in a cure for ovarian cancer. We will miss him greatly, and extend our heartfelt sympathies to his family and friends. The Board & Staff of Ovarian Cancer Research Fund Alliance. 1/3

KUSHNER--Lester. The Board of Directors of Career Bridges mourn the loss of our fellow board member Lester Kushner. His many years of loyal service as secretary, his positive attitude, his love of opera and passionate commitment to our mission of helping young opera singers will be sorely missed. 1/3

HARDY--Paige Ethington. On Monday, June 6, 2016 Heaven became a little more fabulous as Paige Ethington Hardy formally became an angel, ending her lifetime apprenticeship. While ovarian cancer may have taken her life, she won the battle, fighting with dignity, humor and grace. Until the very end, she remained the strong, happy, beautiful and courageous Paige that we all loved, unafraid and confident in her faith in God. Paige's personality and smile radiated happiness and compassion. She laughed loudly and often and she gave freely without expecting anything in return. Her beautiful spirit will live on in her five children that she absolutely adored and in the memories of countless people that she touched. A loving and devoted wife, mother, daughter, sister and friend, she is survived by an adoring husband of 17 years, Tripp and their five incredible children Basil (13), Bennett (12), Tate (10), Ivy (9) and Byron (5) of New York City; parents Mary Faye and Donnie Ethington and brother, Tim, of Shelbyville, Kentucky; mother-in-law, Virginia Hardy of Roswell, Georgia; sister-in-law, Heather Perry and husband Dan, niece Leah and nephew Levi of Marietta, Georgia. Paige also leaves behind numerous aunts, uncles and cousins. Raised in Shelbyville, Kentucky she is a graduate of Shelby County High School and the University of Kentucky, where she pledged Delta Delta Delta Sorority. She gave her time generously to organizations in support of her faith, family and friends, including serving on the Women's Committee Board of Directors of the Central Park Conservancy, on the Women's Committee at St. James Episcopal Church, on the Associate's Committee at Doubles, and as an active parent at the Episcopal School, the Browning School and the Convent of the Sacred Heart. A funeral service in celebration of Paige's life and legacy will be held at First Baptist Church in Shelbyville, Kentucky on Tuesday June 14, 2016 at 2:00pm. Public visitation is from 11:11am until 2:00pm. The Reverend Maurice Hollingsworth and the Reverend Bob Vasser will be officiating. Interment will occur at Grove Hill Cemetery in Shelbyville following the service. A memorial service will be held in New York on Thursday June 16, 2016 at 11:11am at St. James' Episcopal Church located at 865 Madison Avenue. As her friends know, she felt surrounded by angels at that time every day. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in her honor to either the Central Park Conservancy, 14 East 60th Street, New York, NY 10022, or the Ovarian Cancer Translational Research Fund care of Dr. Carol Aghajanian, Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave., NY, NY 10065. 1/3

DIMON--Themis and Theodore. On June 5th and 6th, after battling cancer, Theodore "Ted" and Themis Dimon died peacefully at home surrounded by their devoted family. They were happily married for 65 years and are survived by Themis' sister, Olga; their children Peter, Ted Jr. and his wife Tamara, Jamie and his wife Judy; their grandchildren Julia and her husband Joey, Laura, Kara and her fiance, Conor; and their great grandchild Caroline. The second son of Panos Dimon (Papademitrou), an emigre from Smyrna, Turkey and Theonia Mylonas, Ted was born on January 3, 1931 and grew up in New York City. For 65 years, he developed a successful career as a top stock broker and financial advisor, mentoring many others in the business and building a first-rate team of partners who have been with him for many years. He also served as a Trustee on the Board of the St Luke's Orchestra Society and the School for Strings and provided pro bono financial advice to numerous non-profits. Themis Anastasia Kalos was born on August 26, 1931, the third daughter of Jimmy Kalos and Iphegnia Smyrnis, both emigres from the Greek Peloponnese. When her children left for college, Themis completed her Bachelor's degree at New School and earned her Master's degree in Psychology at Teachers College. BABOULIS--Alexandra Rita. (March 19, 1969 - June 7, 2016) of Hawthorne lost her battle against cancer on June 7th at 7:52pm. She was a graduate of the Horace Mann School in 1987 and attended Barnard College at Columbia University. She acquired her Masters in Special Education and became a schoolteacher, where she devoted her time to teach underprivileged kids. She strived to make an impact in the world, and fought all ideas of convention. Being different is what she was good at, and she was loved and appreciated for that. She is survived by her mother Thelma, her sister Sharon, her brothers Philip and Paul, her nephews Richie and Jaxon, and her niece Stephanie. She was the godmother to Robert, Joel, and Johana, and friend to their mother Wendy, all whom loved her dearly. She was loved and taken care of by her boyfriend Richard, who was by her side till the end. On Sunday, June 26th there will be a reception at the River Palm Terrace in Fair Lawn to celebrate her life and remember her for the wonderful human being that she was. We ask that in lieu of flowers, the funds get redirected in the form of a donation to the American Cancer Society, to support those that continue fighting this arduous battle. Her spirit, her thirst for life, her unconditional love, and her genuineness will keep her memory alive in our hearts for eternity. 1/3

ALI--Muhammad. On behalf of the children, adolescents and families we support, the Board of Directors and Staff of Birch Family Services extend our condolences to Lonnie Ali on the loss of her husband. SADLER--Ruth nee Williams. June 14, 1926 - June 9, 2016. Now reunited with her beloved Harry Sadler. Mourned by her children Anne and Tom Reingold, by her grandchildren Maddie and Julia Reingold and Nick Reade, and by her many friends, all treasured her grace and strength. Ruth lived with ardor and died in peace. 1/3

PYLE--Willis Acton, Disney animator and artist, passed away on Thursday, June 2, at the age of 101 in his Broadway penthouse apartment. Born in Lebanon, KS in 1914, he attended the University of Colorado before joining the Disney Studios. Working with UPA, he helped develop the near-sighted Mr. Magoo, and shared the 1950 Academy Award for animation for Gerald McBoing- Boing. He was predeceased by his wife Virginia, his brother the actor Denver Pyle, and his sister Lorrayne. He is survived by his nephews Tony and David Pyle and David's family. Willis will be missed by all. 1/3

BELL--Gloria, on June 8, 2016. Beloved wife of the late Sidney, cherished sister of Sylvia and Mel Sorcher, adored aunt of Jane Bell, Rob, Michael and Peter Sorcher. Dear stepmother of Dr. Stuart and his family. Also survived by eight great-grandnieces and nephews. Service private. Donations in her memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital. 1/3

LOEFFLER--Herman "Sonny". The RiverSpring Health and Hebrew Home at Riverdale families mourn the loss of Sonny Loeffler, its treasured friend and member of its Board of Directors. Sonny was a deeply devoted family man who brought sunshine to his family, friends and all who were fortunate to know him. His commitment and leadership to the quality of life of older adults has impacted and improved the lives of countless New Yorkers. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Loeffler family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. RiverSpring Health Jeffrey S. Maurer, Chairman Daniel Reingold, President & CEO 1/3

DIMON--Themis and Theodore. On June 5th and 6th, after battling cancer, Theodore "Ted" and Themis Dimon died peacefully at home surrounded by their devoted family. They were happily married for 65 years and are survived by Themis' sister, Olga; their children Peter, Ted Jr. and his wife Tamara, Jamie and his wife Judy; their grandchildren Julia and her husband Joey, Laura, Kara and her fiance, Conor; and their great grandchild Caroline. The second son of Panos Dimon (Papademitrou), an emigre from Smyrna, Turkey and Theonia Mylonas, Ted was born on January 3, 1931 and grew up in New York City. For 65 years, he developed a successful career as a top stock broker and financial advisor, mentoring many others in the business and building a first-rate team of partners who have been with him for many years. He also served as a Trustee on the Board of the St Luke's Orchestra Society and the School for Strings and provided pro bono financial advice to numerous non-profits. Themis Anastasia Kalos was born on August 26, 1931, the third daughter of Jimmy Kalos and Iphegnia Smyrnis, both emigres from the Greek Peloponnese. When her children left for college, Themis completed her Bachelor's degree at New School and earned her Master's degree in Psychology at Teachers College. Themis volunteered at a preschool program and served on several boards, including SCAN and the New York Psychoanalytic Institute Foundation. On June 5, Ted died in Themis's arms. Twenty two hours later Themis passed, on her own terms and by her own wish, together with Ted to the end -- a real love story. 1/3

Chanos, Allan L. Gropper, Former Board Presidents and Honorary Trustees 1/3

BARROWS--Lila H. January 2, 1924 - May 28, 2016. Lila Hester Barrows died peacefully at home in New York City after a strenuous battle with cancer. Lila graduated from the Chapin School and Smith College Phi Beta Kappa. She was an avid bridge player, philatelist, tennis player, golfer and traveler and spent her career in the banking and legal industries. She was an active member of the Cosmopolitan Club, the National Society of Colonial Dames in the State of New York, and the Junior League of New York. She is survived by her sister Frances B. Harvan; her nieces Michele H. Montgomery and Abigail H. Greene; her nephews David B. Harvan, David S. Bonner, Henry M. Bonner, Jr., Robert P. Bonner, and Paul B. Bonner; her grandnieces Katherine F. Montgomery, Elizabeth A. Montgomery, Althea R. Greene, Valerie A. Greene, Margaret A. Bonner, Grace A. Bonner, Anne S. Bonner, and Emily E. Bonner; and her grandnephews Phillip M. Greene, Henry M. Bonner, III, Colin E. Bonner, and Curtis W. Bonner. She was preceded in death by her sisters, Anne B. Bonner and Elizabeth B. Watson. A memorial service will be held at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Ave. at 90th Street in Manhattan on June 18, 2016 at 10am. 1/3

ORESMAN--Donald. The Council of the Grolier Club is deeply saddened to learn of the death of fellow member and former Councilor Donald Oresman. A Grolier member since 1972, Oresman rendered distinguished service to the Grolier Club during his term as Councilor (1996 to 2005), serving as Vice-President (2002-2005) and Secretary (1998-2001), and chairing our Library, House, Modern Fine Printing, and Prints Committees. He gave generously of his time, energy, and his broad knowledge of books and prints, to the Club's great and lasting benefit; and his counsel will be sorely missed. We extend our sympathy to his wife Patricia, their family, and to his many friends and colleagues in the Grolier Club and the world of books at large. G. Scott Clemons, President 1/3
FINE WEINBERG--Ellen. Cherished friend will be missed forever. Marjorie & Arthur Samuels 1/3

He loved his family above all else and taught us to be generous and welcoming to people from all backgrounds and walks of life. These lessons and his quick sense of humor will remain with us. 1/3

HONIG--Eleanor Wiener, passed peacefully on May 14, 2016. Born January 4, 1932, she was married to William Honig, who predeceased her in 2015. BRONSTEIN--Murray. Forever remembered and always in my heart. Love, Anne 1/3

HOURIGAN--Sanford Peter, peacefully passed away at age 86 on Monday, June 6, 2016 in New York, NY. For decades, he lived and worked in Manhattan and could frequently be seen at The Boat House in Central Park overlooking the lake. He is survived by his son, Timothy P. Hourigan, his daughter Keana P. (Hourigan) Anna, with three grandchildren and his brother, John Hourigan and sister, Patricia Cain and eight nieces and nephews. ORESMAN--Donald (1925-2016), attorney, businessman and civic leader, died peacefully May 24 at his Midtown apartment. A native New Yorker, he was born in the shadow of Washington Square and later moved to the Upper West Side with his parents. Classified 4-F by the Selective Service in World War II due to a defective heart valve, Donald sat out the conflict at Oberlin College, graduating in 1946. "Having a desire to write but little creative talent, I decided to try journalism," he later wrote. He started with the daily Ossining Citizen Register as its only reporter and soon moved to the Pittsburgh Press, which published five editions a day. After working there for a few years, he concluded that the paper's courthouse coverage was weak and applied to law school, figuring he would return to newspapers upon graduation. In 1957 he completed his degree at Columbia University Law, graduating with honors. Unable to resist the law's gravitational pull, he accepted a job with Simpson Thacher & Bartlett and worked there from 1957 to 1984, largely representing public corporations. A senior partner with the firm, he was asked in 1984 to join senior management at Gulf + Western Industries, an early conglomerate that he had represented as outside counsel for 10 years. He served as Executive Vice President, Chief Counsel, and Chief Administrative Officer until the company, by then named Paramount Communications, Inc., was sold in 1994. He returned to Simpson Thacher & Bartlett after working for a year with Paramount's former board chairman, Martin Davis, who had started an investment boutique. Donald was a close advisor to late Movado Group founder Gedalio (Gerry) Grinberg and sat on the Movado Board for more than 25 years. Throughout his career, Donald's outside interests centered on the arts, literature, and libraries. He served for 25 years on the New York Landmarks Conservancy Board, including a term as chairman. In 2006 he was given the Conservancy's Chairman's Award. He served on numerous other boards, including the Library Company at Philadelphia, the Larchmont Library, the Morgan Library, the American Antiquarian Society, The Writers Room, the Roundabout Theatre Company, the Dictionary of American Regional English, Volunteer Lawyers for the Arts, the Heye National Museum of the American Indian - New York, the Museum of the City of New York, the Library of America, the Academy of American Poets, the Grolier Club, the National Building Museum, the American Academy in Rome, the American Ballet Theatre, the Gainsborough Studios, the New Criterion, and the Yale Edition of the Boswell Papers. In 1948 Donald married social worker Patricia Perry, beginning a 67-year union that he called the smartest decision of his life. His private interests, other than reading and his wife's opinion, included a collection of 20th Century images of people reading: prints, drawings, photographs, oils, watercolors, sculptures, etc. His late mother Gertrude Bergel Oresman was assistant to the editor of The Theater Magazine, and his late father A. Louis Oresman, was an attorney, C.P.A., and a financial advisor for a number of privately held corporations. He is survived by his wife Patricia; his brother, Stephen B. Oresman (Darien, CT); two sons, Thomas P. Oresman (Kent, WA) and Craig P. Oresman (Los Lunas, NM); daughter, Alison Oresman Wilson (Bellevue, WA); seven grandchildren, two step-grandchildren, and six great-grandchildren. He was preceded in death by his older brother, Roger B. Oresman, of Manhattan, a longtime partner at the Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy law firm; an infant daughter, Eliza Lynn; and great-grandson, Donny Wade. A memorial will be held September 10, 2016. Please email oresmanmemorial@ gmail.com for information. 1/3

HENOCH--Arthur Saul, 90 years old, died peacefully at his home in New York City on January 22, 2016. Born in Newark, NJ, he was married to wife Dee for 59 loving years. After his freshman year at Rutgers in 1941, Art enlisted in the U.S. Navy and volunteered for a special naval warfare unit known as the Beach Jumpers. Commanded by the actor Douglas Fairbanks, Jr., they were trained in the military art of deception, diversion and psychological warfare. A few dozen men in specially equipped air-sea rescue boats could fool the enemy into believing they were being attacked by a 70,000 man amphibious landing force. These units raised hell with German coastal defenses throughout the Mediterranean and kept the enemy off-balance while the Allies carried out the invasions of Italy and southern France. Arthur was one of the last surviving members. After the war, he graduated from George Washington University with a BA in Business and joined his father and brother Herb in the dry cleaning business. He spent 20 years building Bond Cleaners, which serviced a large portion of New Jersey. Arthur left the business in the 1960's to earn an MA in Human Relations from NYU. In 1971, while continuing his Ph.D studies, he became a Financial Officer at Essex County College and devoted the next 37 years to enhancing the reputation of this educational institution in downtown Newark. He served in a number of other capacities: Associate Professor-Social Sciences Division, Director of Counseling and Advisement, counselor in the Business Division, before retiring at age 83. Arthur was a role model and inspiring mentor to students, faculty and administrators. He also maintained a psychotherapy practice in NYC. Arthur was the first to offer a helping hand and had a kind word for everyone. All who knew and loved him benefited from his warm heart, humorous spirit and generous nature. He is deeply missed. Arthur is survived by his sister Sandra Bernstein, daughters Susan and Karen and son Gary, seven grandchildren and sons-in-law Jay Coggeshall and David Ryugo. 1/3

HARDY--Paige Ethington. On Monday, June 6, 2016 Heaven became a little more fabulous as Paige Ethington Hardy formally became an angel, ending her lifetime apprenticeship. While ovarian cancer may have taken her life, she won the battle, fighting with dignity, humor and grace. Until the very end, she remained the strong, happy, beautiful and courageous Paige that we all loved, unafraid and confident in her faith in God. Paige's personality and smile radiated happiness and compassion. She laughed loudly and often and she gave freely without expecting anything in return. Her beautiful spirit will live on in her five children that she absolutely adored and in the memories of countless people that she touched. A loving and devoted wife, mother, daughter, sister and friend, she is survived by an adoring husband of 17 years, Tripp and their five incredible children Basil (13), Bennett (12), Tate (10), Ivy (9) and Byron (5) of New York City; parents Mary Faye and Donnie Ethington and brother, Tim, of Shelbyville, Kentucky; mother-in-law, Virginia Hardy of Roswell, Georgia; sister-in-law, Heather Perry and husband Dan, niece Leah and nephew Levi of Marietta, Georgia. Paige also leaves behind numerous aunts, uncles and cousins. Raised in Shelbyville, Kentucky she is a graduate of Shelby County High School and the University of Kentucky, where she pledged Delta Delta Delta Sorority. She gave her time generously to organizations in support of her faith, family and friends, including serving on the Women's Committee Board of Directors of the Central Park Conservancy, on the Women's Committee at St. James Episcopal Church, on the Associate's Committee at Doubles, and as an active parent at the Episcopal School, the Browning School and the Convent of the Sacred Heart. A funeral service in celebration of Paige's life and legacy will be held at First Baptist Church in Shelbyville, Kentucky on Tuesday June 14, 2016 at 2:00pm. Public visitation is from 11:11am until 2:00pm. The Reverend Maurice Hollingsworth and the Reverend Bob Vasser will be officiating. Interment will occur at Grove Hill Cemetery in Shelbyville following the service. A memorial service will be held in New York on Thursday June 16, 2016 at 11:11am at St. James' Episcopal Church located at 865 Madison Avenue. As her friends know, she felt surrounded by angels at that time every day. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in her honor to either the Central Park Conservancy, 14 East 60th Street, New York, NY 10022, or the Ovarian Cancer Translational Research Fund care of Dr. Carol Aghajanian, Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave., NY, NY 10065. 1/3

MELSKY--Barbara, born December 4th, 1930 in Brooklyn NY. Married to Barney Melsky for 64 years. Died June 8th, 2016. Barbara was survived by her husband Barney, children Brian, Beth, Blaire and Barrie. Grandchildren Tyler, Cooper, Jake, Kacie, Kyle and Mallie. Amazing wife and mother and most importantly the most incredible grandmother. Impossible to imagine life without her. 1/3

LOUBE--Shirley Phyllis, Born February 22, 1920, died June 8, 2016. As vital, connected and engaged in her last days as she was in all of her 96 years, Shirley Phyllis Loube led a life filled with adventure, glamor and dedicated to philanthropy. Shirley was born and raised in San Francisco, the daughter of Consuelo Maria Carlos Camacho and Manuel Ricardo Lombardero. Immediately upon graduation from Mission High School, Shirley set out for Hollywood and landed a contract with MGM Studios. Working under the stage name Dana Marshall, she played small roles in several memorable films of the 1940s, including "Meet Me in St. Louis," "The Philadelphia Story," "Kismet" and "The Great Flamarion." In addition to the movies, Shirley was very proud of her work on the stage at the Pasadena Playhouse and the Mercury Players. She also appeared in roles in early television plays. While in Los Angeles, Shirley first lived with her aunt and uncle in the valley, but the commute (and chaperonage) proved daunting, so she jumped at the offer from her friend Maria Rivas to come live in Beverly Hills with her. Maria's mother was Marlene Dietrich, so the next three years were memorable. It was a glamorous time, with chauffeured rides to a factory, where the girls worked making planes for the war effort. There were long days at M.G.M, but also social events in the evenings, where many of the luminaries of the day gathered around the radio at the Dietrich home to hear news of the war in Europe. However, Hollywood proved no match for Shirley's longtime love interest, Irving Loube, and she rejoined him in the Bay Area in 1946 to embark upon a lifetime of love, hard work, success and fun. In her newlywed years, Shirley worked in the advertising department at the San Francisco Examiner, where she demonstrated a magical knack for salesmanship. She put Irving through law school, of which she remained very proud. Her husband went on to become a prominent attorney and businessman. When she concluded that her Irv was overworking, Shirley threatened to leave unless he developed a relaxing hobby. In response, Irving took up sailboat racing and became, with Shirley's unwavering support and encouragement, an accomplished yachtsman. Irv mounted and won many sailboat racing campaigns around the world. Shirley was the chief cheerleader, entertaining countless crews and rival boat owners over the years. Shirley and Irv supported many civic endeavors, including the presidential campaign of John F. Kennedy. The Loubes were instrumental in establishing the Oakland Symphony, the Foundation for Cardiac Research at U.C.S.F., the C.P.M.C. Foundation, and the Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation. They were also enthusiastic supporters of the San Francisco Symphony, among many other arts organizations. Shirley was an effective fundraiser and board member, using her gifts of charm, persuasion, persistence and effervescence to aid many worthy causes. In recent years, Shirley was a champion of the Marin Theater Company and thoroughly enjoyed producing several shows there. Shirley is deeply missed by all who came into contact with her. She was preceded in death by her beloved spouse of 55+ years, Irving Loube, and is survived by her adored children, Garrett Loube (Marcia Rodgers) and Suzanne Darley (Mark Darley), and by her grandchildren James Darley and Miranda Darley. She leaves behind countless friends and admirers of her great good humor, wisdom, indomitable spirit, elegant style and joie de vivre. 1/3

RIDDER--Virginia Dunne, November 2, 1920 to June 4, 2016. All of Virginia's dear friends in New York City, Santa Barbara, London and Paris will miss her sparkle, warmth, grace and elegance. Born in NYC, the only daughter of Julia and John V. Dunne, one of the first members of the New York Stock Exchange, Virginia was formerly married to Joseph Ridder of California and Honolulu, who predeceased her. Virginia lived a busy life travelling around the world, fascinated by history, art, architecture, antiques and interesting places. She enjoyed her life in New York, a longtime member of the Colony Club, bridge, and a particular love of the Metropolitan Museum, Central Park and its Conservancy and many philanthropic institutions both in New York and Santa Barbara. She passed away peacefully and suddenly in Greenwich Hospital and her remains will be interred at the Dunne Mausoleum, Cemetery of the Gate of Heaven in Mt. Pleasant. At Virginia's request there will be no services. Interment is private. 1/3

WANGH--Anne Wilson. (nee Wolfson), died June 7th. 97, ballerina, pupil of Michel Fokine, soloist American Ballet Theatre, founder Dance Library of Israel; choreographer, notably of "The Ballet Story," lecturer, dance therapist, master of Laban notation. Anne was an activist for peace and social justice. Married to Martin Wangh, psychoanalyst for sixty years. She is survived by sons, Stephen, Lawrence, and Mitchell and their wives, Suzanne, Katherine and Jo-Ann. The beloved Granny Anny of Jacob, Rebecca, Noah, Marina, Megan and Hannah and their spouses, Kate, Brice, Krace, Jack, and Deann and great-grandchildren, Alea, Ruben, Neva, Oliver, Lionel and Finley. Donations to the Dance Library of Israel. 1/3

NEEDELL--Gregory H.,52, of Carbondale, CO, formerly of Hastings-on-the-Hudson, NY died Tuesday, June 7, 2016 at Mammoth Mountain, California. Greg was born on November 14, 1963 in Livingston, New Jersey to Kathleen and Benjamin Needell. He was a graduate of Stratton Mountain School in South Londonderry, Vermont and St. Lawrence University in Canton, NY, where he received a BA in History, competed and was Co-Captain of the St. Lawrence ski racing team on the NCAA circuit. Greg had over forty years of experience in the sport of alpine ski racing. He was a U.S. Ski Team men's national alpine team coach for eight years and directed club programs domestically and internationally for many years, most recently with the Aspen Ski Club and Team Summit in Copper Mountain, CO. Greg was the creative mind behind the widely-read The World Cup According to Grande through skiracing.com and his own Alpine Race Consulting, which has been acclaimed by its avid followers for its technical and tactical insights, as well as its readability and wit. Greg is the beloved husband of Shannon Sohr Needell and is the loving father of Coen Needell. He is also the devoted uncle of Caroline and Harry Needell and Edith, Emily and Jane Hollander. Greg is survived by his sister, Claire Needell Hollander, of Larchmont, NY, his brother, Jonathan Needell, of Coto de Caza, CA, his sister-in-law, Christine Needell and his parents, Kathleen and Benjamin Needell of Pound Ridge, NY. A funeral service will be held at Clark Associates Funeral Home, 4 Woods Bridge Road, Katonah, NY 10536 on Monday, June 13 at 2pm. Memorial contributions may be made to Stratton Mountain School, 7 World Cup Circle, South Londonderry, VT 05155. 1/3

BABOULIS--Alexandra Rita. (March 19, 1969 - June 7, 2016) of Hawthorne lost her battle against cancer on June 7th at 7:52pm. She was a graduate of the Horace Mann School in 1987 and attended Barnard College at Columbia University. She acquired her Masters in Special Education and became a schoolteacher, where she devoted her time to teach underprivileged kids. She strived to make an impact in the world, and fought all ideas of convention. Being different is what she was good at, and she was loved and appreciated for that. She is survived by her mother Thelma, her sister Sharon, her brothers Philip and Paul, her nephews Richie and Jaxon, and her niece Stephanie. She was the godmother to Robert, Joel, and Johana, and friend to their mother Wendy, all whom loved her dearly. She was loved and taken care of by her boyfriend Richard, who was by her side till the end. On Sunday, June 26th there will be a reception at the River Palm Terrace in Fair Lawn to celebrate her life and remember her for the wonderful human being that she was. We ask that in lieu of flowers, the funds get redirected in the form of a donation to the American Cancer Society, to support those that continue fighting this arduous battle. Her spirit, her thirst for life, her unconditional love, and her genuineness will keep her memory alive in our hearts for eternity. 1/3

JABURG--Frieda, passed away peacefully at home on June 9, 2016. Beloved wife of the late Carl. Loving mother of Gary Jaburg (Susan) and Lauren Lese (Peter). She adored her late brother Jack Ankus, and his children Stacey (Chris) and Joseph (Stephanie). Frieda was crazy about her grandchildren Zachary, Jason, Stephen, Melanie, Stephanie and Laura. Completely unique, strong, charismatic and loving, anyone lucky enough to know Frieda was drawn in by her humor and character. She will be deeply missed. Services 10am Monday at "The Riverside," 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3
LEVIS--Arthur. 1936 -1991 Gone 25 years this week. Still loved. Still missed. 1/3
KUSHNER--Lester, Esq. 88, WWII Navy Vet, journalist, his intellect, concern for others will be remembered. 1/3

BREUEL--Brian Harold, 71, of Princeton, New Jersey, passed away on May 29th, 2016 surrounded by his loving family. Brian attended the Lawrenceville School and Princeton University, where he received a degree in Politics in 1966. At Lawrenceville he was President of the Alumni Association and a Trustee. At Princeton he served as President of his Class and was on the Advisory Board of the Center for Human Values and the Princeton Prize in Race Relations. Brian received a JD from the University of Florida and was a published author in the field of Wealth Preservation which was his professional field. He was chairman of the Board of D&R Greenway Land Trust and served on the Dean's Advisory Council of Westminster College. He enjoyed sailing, scuba diving, traveling, reading, music and nature. During the last year of his life Brian faced multiple, profound health problems with courage, dignity and grace and was optimistic to the end. Brian was an extraordinary husband, father, grandfather, friend, and mentor. He will be missed. www.fluehr.com 1/3

SULLIVAN--John F. The 3rd Musketeer of Faulkner, Dawkins & Sullivan now is gone! And with him goes another part of my life and the lives of many others who lived with or worked for him over the years. In 1955, I joined a predecessor company... Laurence M. Marks & Company... that was located at 48 Wall Street. Dwight/ Dick/ and John were there and all of us remained with that renowned investment research firm until 1959 when the surviving partners of Mr. Marks' company elected to be acquired by a West Coast retail brokerage house: Dean Witter. It was thus that Faulkner, Dawkins & Sullivan was created and the firm prospered through the 1960's and early 1970's. FD&S was acquired by Sandy Weill's Shearson Co. in 1977... at something less than 1/2 of Book Value. Three years later, American Express bought Shearson at a significant premium. Subsequently, John created an asset management firm... SuIlivan Morrissey & Mickle... that existed through the date of his passing on 23 May 2016. Even though we all had taken separate paths some time during the 1970's-1980's, I know that John continued to be respected by all in the investment community who knew and/or had worked with him. For those who built careers on Wall Street from the 1950's onward, "the wagons once again have circled ever closer." Nevertheless, John F. Sullivan will live on in all of our memories. Robert P. Colin. 1/3

ORESMAN--Donald. The Board and Staff of The New York Landmarks Conservancy mourn the passing, but celebrate the contributions, of our former Chair and longtime Board Member. Working with his great friend Brendan Gill, Donald was instrumental in early Conservancy preservation efforts. These include the fight to save the Biltmore Hotel, and successful efforts to save and preserve the Federal Archive Building, Peck Slip, the Fraunces Tavern Block and the Villard Houses. Donald was also close to the late Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, leading the Conservancy to embrace the Senator's goal of creating a great train station within the landmark Farley Post Office - an effort we continue to support. A consummate tactician, Donald urged the Conservancy to fight hard for preservation but to also work towards practical solutions, saying: "Never let the perfect be the enemy of the good." We will always remain grateful for his leadership. Our condolences to his family. Lloyd P. Zuckerberg, Chair; Peg Breen, President 1/3

BRINN--Claire, died June 7, 2016. She was the loving wife of the late Murray Brinn, adored mother of Robin and Shari Brinn and beloved grandmother of Jonathan and Laura Prigoff. We celebrate the life of Claire, the funniest and wisest woman in the world. Her selfless and loving nature made her larger than life. She will always remain in the hearts of the many who loved her. Donations in her memory can be made to the Alzheimer's Association, a cause dear to the Brinn family, at: www.alz.org. 1/3

SINANOGLU--Karacabey Levni. Died unexpectedly in his studio in New Haven on June 1, 2016. Sinanoglu was an artist and educator; a man of brilliance, creativity, humanity and passion. He was beloved by his family, professors, students, colleagues, friends, and the New Haven community. He graduated in 1989 from Hampshire College and in 1996 from Yale School of Art majoring in painting. At Yale he was the recipient of the Arnold Bittleman Memorial Prize for painting and the Alice Kimball English Traveling Fellowship. He held faculty positions at Yale University, Hampshire College and Gateway Community College. Sinanoglu was the son of Paula Armbruster and Oktay Sinanoglu, both retired professors at Yale University. He is survived by his mother, Paula Armbruster of New Haven, CT; his son, Ayuka W. Sinanoglu, of New Haven, CT; his sister, Elif S. Armbruster, of Arlington, MA; and his brother, Murat Armbruster, of Oakland, CA; his former wife, Saglar Bougdaeva, of Abu Dhabi and New Haven, CT; and a niece and a nephew. A memorial service will be held at Dwight Chapel, Yale University at 1pm on June 18, 2016. Gifts in his memory may be directed to the Karacabey Levni Sinanoglu Memorial Scholarship Fund at the Yale School of Art and mailed to the Office of Development at PO Box 2038, New Haven, CT 06521. 1/3

MATELES--Richard. Age 80, in Chicago on May 30, 2016. Richard, a member of the Sons of the American Revolution, was a descendant of Abraham de Lucena, one of the earliest Jews of North America, who settled in New Amsterdam in 1655. Richard is survived by his wife, Roslyn (Fish) of Chicago; three daughters, Naomi Karmi and Susan Spira (both of Israel), and Sarah Mateles of Buffalo Grove, IL; and seven grandchildren. A private burial was held at Congregation Shearith Israel's Beth Olam Cemetery on June 2, 2016. 1/3

EGELSTON--Robert B. December 31, 1930 - May 9, 2016. Robert Burnley ("Bob") Egelston passed away on May 9, 2016, in Oklahoma City, after a long illness. Bob was born in Kansas City, Missouri, to Sally (Carroll) and Richard Egelston and was the youngest of three brothers. Bob attended the U.S. Military Academy at West Point and upon graduation served in the U.S. Army. Later Bob obtained an MBA from the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania and was hired by the Capital Group of Los Angeles where he served in numerous capacities for forty years, including Chairman from 1982 through the late 90's. As a generous philanthropist, Bob supported many interests spanning the visual and performing arts to education, health, and humanitarian causes. He was an Honorary Life Trustee of the Colburn School of Los Angeles and the Founding Chairman of the Colburn Foundation. He served as Chairman of the Los Angeles Music Center, where he championed the project to build the Walt Disney Concert Hall and the restoration of the Ahmanson Theater at the Music Center. Bob was a twenty-five year board member of the Los Angeles Philharmonic and was one of its greatest fans. His interests in education were expansive, including serving on the board of the Claremont Graduate University and on the board of Art Center College of Design in Pasadena. He was Board Chairman for several years of CalArts (California Institute of the Arts). Bob was a longtime member of All Saints Church Pasadena where he served in several leadership positions. Surviving to mourn Bob are his wife Veronica, daughters Diane and Janet, son Peter, stepson Kelvin and beloved grandchildren. 1/3
EIPEL--Joy, died on June 9, 2016. For further information please go to: walterbcooke.net 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Fred B.,84. Beloved husband to Maren, father to Karin, Laura and Ed. Grandpa to Jordan, Jacob, Michael, Katie, Rachel, Alyssa. 1/3

BOER--Mary Veronica (nee Bradley), of New York City, died on June 10, 2016. Mary was a graduate from the Mary Lewis Academy and St. John's University. Her education included a brief stint at the British Embassy School in Ankara, Turkey where her father was on assignment. She joined Delta Airlines in 1973 and retired as Supervisor in 2004. Upon retirement, Mary and John Boer, traveled extensively, especially in Europe. In addition to her husband, John Boer, she is survived by her father, Francis J. Bradley, three brothers, Christopher, James and Kenneth and one sister, Margaret Hart. Mary's passing is grieved by many nieces and nephews. The family will receive friends from 2:00 to 4:00 and 7:00 to 9:00 Monday, June 13th at Krtil Funeral Home at 1297 First Avenue in Manhattan. The Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 10:00am on Tuesday, June 14th at St. Monica's R.C. Church at 413 East 79th Street (off First Avenue). 1/3
QUINN--Kenneth Marc. (1948-1966) Your presence on earth makes the universe a better place. Love, Jeanne and Gail 1/3

DIMON--Themis and Theodore. The child analysts at the New York Psychoanalytic Society and Institute record with sorrow the passing of Themis and Ted Dimon. A generous and elegant couple, they championed the cause of child analysis and the work of our members. They passionately supported our Institute and tirelessly brought others to understand the importance of our mission. Ruth K. Karush, M.D., Dean of Education Steven J. Wein, M.D. Associate Dean for Child Analysis 1/3

MIRANDA--Joseph C.,Esq., of Manhasset, NY, passed on June 10, 2016 at age 86. Beloved husband for 61 years of Joan, father of Neal and Gail, father-in-law of Robert and grandfather of Lindsay, Adam, Melanie and Jackson. Proud alumni of Regis High School, Fordham University and Fordham Law. He will be sorely missed. 1/3

GREEN--Joseph. Age 83, a former resident of Miami, Florida since 1979, born in Brooklyn, NY, September 6, 1932. A Korean War Veteran and a graduate of James Monroe High Sch- ool, Bronx, 1/50, and New York University BS/1956, MBA/1962. Retired internal auditor died peacefully on June 12, 2016. Devoted uncle of Alan Kafker (predeceased) and Arlene Kafker Beckerman. Also survived by cousins Barbara Cohen and Sheila Knapp, niece-in-law Miriam Kafker and nephew- in-law David Beckerman, three great-nieces and one great-nephew, and sister-in- law Shirley Kafker. Employed Dime Savings Bank 1961-1969, New York Life 1969-1979, Storer Communications (Miami) 1979-1993. Joe continued to be active following retirement. Worked at Lord & Taylor, Nieman Marcus, Bloomingdale and Magellan Health (two years). Was a life member of VFW Post No. 1966. Services will be held on Tuesday, June 14th, at 11:00am at Wellwood Cemetery in Farmingdale, Long Island. 1/3
NEWMAN--Debra S. Dear Debra, Happy Birthday. I love you and miss you. Hugs, Aunt Sharon 1/3

CALLEN--John Holmes, Jr.,83, of Vero Beach, FL and Dorset, VT passed away on June 9 in Red Bank, NJ. He was an Executive with Burlington Industries and Ward Howell International, where he retired as President. He is survived by his wife, Lyn, their four children, seven grandchildren and his four brothers. 1/3
