DIMON--Themis and Theodore. The child analysts at the New York Psychoanalytic Society and Institute record with sorrow the passing of Themis and Ted Dimon. A generous and elegant couple, they championed the cause of child analysis and the work of our members. They passionately supported our Institute and tirelessly brought others to understand the importance of our mission. Ruth K. Karush, M.D., Dean of Education Steven J. Wein, M.D. Associate Dean for Child Analysis 1/3

BERDON--Barbara Guggenheimer, of Scarsdale on June 11, 2016. Loving mother to Sharon Kristol (Todd Kristol), Allison Berwitz (Joshua Berwitz). Cherished grandmother to Zachary and Julia Kristol, Jacob and Hailey Berwitz. Funeral service Tuesday, June 14 at 11:30am at Westchester Reform Temple, Scarsdale, NY. 1/3

BORUCHOFF--Betsy, 82, of Riverdale, NY passed away at her home on June 12, 2016 after suffering from a stroke. Born on July 5, 1933 in New York City to the late Willma and Albert Musher. She graduated from Sarah Lawrence College in 1955 and earned a Masters Degree from Fordham University Graduate School of Social Work in 1979. She dedicated her life to helping others as a Board Certified Diplomat and Licensed Clinical Social Worker. She also worked for White Plains Hospital, the Phobia Clinic for 10 years, and graduated from the Psychoanalytic Institute of Counseling and Guidance. She was a member of Congregation Shir Ami and the National Association of Social Workers. Enjoyed travelling, Broadway shows, and helping others. She is survived by her loving husband of 62 years Leo, daughter, Nancy Orgel and predeceased by her daughter, Barbara (Boruchoff) Winer. She was the grandmother to Zoey and Evan Orgel, and Jeffrey, Hilary, and Alison Winer and great-grandmother to Mila and Haylie Piccoli. A graveside service will be held on June 14, 2016 at 2:30pm at the Kensico Cemetery, Sharon Gardens in Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in her honor to the charity of your choice. 1/3

BOER--Mary Veronica (nee Bradley), of New York City, died on June 10, 2016. Mary was a graduate from the Mary Lewis Academy and St. John's University. Her education included a brief stint at the British Embassy School in Ankara, Turkey where her father was on assignment. She joined Delta Airlines in 1973 and retired as Supervisor in 2004. Upon retirement, Mary and John Boer, traveled extensively, especially in Europe. In addition to her husband, John Boer, she is survived by her father, Francis J. Bradley, three brothers, Christopher, James and Kenneth and one sister, Margaret Hart. Mary's passing is grieved by many nieces and nephews. The family will receive friends from 2:00 to 4:00 and 7:00 to 9:00 Monday, June 13th at Krtil Funeral Home at 1297 First Avenue in Manhattan. The Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 10:00am on Tuesday, June 14th at St. Monica's R.C. Church at 413 East 79th Street (off First Avenue). 1/3

BLITZ--Maria, died on June 11, 2016 at the age of 98. Widow of Abraham "Munio" Blitz. Beloved mother of Leo (Lidewey) and Andrew (Laurie), grandmother of Brian (Yana), Abram and Efrem, great-grandmother of Benjamin and Samuel. She was a survivor of the Krakow Ghetto, Plaszow, Auschwitz, Stutthof, and a death march to, and massacre at, Palmnicken, of which only about 30 of 13,000 survived, and of which she was the last known survivor. She was deeply loved and will be greatly missed. 1/3

DIMON--Ted and Themis. It is with great sorrow we bid farewell to our special friends, Ted and Themis. Ted, renaissance man, and beautiful, intelligent and dear friend Themis. How much history, business, vacations we shared together. Those memories will be with us always. The time we spent together was indeed special. Our sincerest sympathies to the "boys", Peter, Jamie and Teddy, to their spouses, Judy and Tamara, and to the rest of this very close knit family. With love and tears, Joan and Sandy 1/3

KRISILOFF--Barbara. March 4,1936-June 12, 2016 Predeceased by her parents Joseph and Mary. A real New Yorker to the end. May her memory be a blessing. Graveside Service Tuesday, June 14, 3pm Old Montefiore. YFS, Love, Cousin Faith 1/3

PREISS--Henriette Blinder, age 88, passed away peacefully on June 2 with her family in Grass Valley, California. An avid world traveler and a devoted lover of symphony, opera, theater, art and literature, she never stopped reading the New York Times cover to cover every day. A highly respected and published pioneer in the field of teaching children with learning disabilities, she helped hundreds of children. Born and raised in Chicago, Henriette graduated from the University of Chicago. She married Abe Blinder and later married Fredric Preiss, and spent her more recent years with companion Jerome Barrer. Most of her adult life was lived in the Westchester County, NY area. She is survived by her two devoted sons Henry (wife Ruth) and Jon (companion Debbie) Blinder, and granddaughter Hanna; her sister Judith Genesen (husband Louis); as well as her loving step-families and many wonderful and talented nieces, nephews and their children. Henriette possessed a warmth, wit and an insatiable curiosity about the world, which inspires us and which we will always cherish and keep in our hearts. 1/3
HEELEY--Desmond, international set and costume designer for theater, opera, and ballet, passed away on Friday after a long illness. He was 85. A memorial will be scheduled at a future time. 1/3

JELLINEK--Barbara Ann, LCSW (Niemaseck), 63, passed away peacefully on June 12, 2016 at St. Peter's University Hospital, New Brunswick, NJ following a heroic battle with breast cancer. Beloved wife of Igal and loving mother to Briana, she was the cherished daughter of the late Edward Niemaseck and the late Jean Zawyrucha Niemaseck. She leaves behind brothers Don (Nancy) and Ken (Ruth), sister Kimberly Ann, stepmother JoAnn Landi, beloved nieces and nephews and great-nieces and great-nephews. A graduate of Rutgers University Graduate School of Social Work, Barbara was proud to be a social worker and was passionate about her profession, sharing her knowledge and gifts with those in need. Barbara lived her life with love, compassion and energy. She brought the best of herself to everything she did and everyone she knew, and is remembered with love and respect by the many people whose lives she touched. She loved life and especially her husband and their pup, Kira. The family is grateful to the dedicated staff of St. Peter's University Hospital and the special friends who cared for Barbara in her final days. As she led her life, Barbara fought her cancer with courage, grace and dignity and will be deeply missed. The funeral will be private; a celebration of Barbara's life will be held at a later date. Condolences may be made through Legacy.com. In lieu of flowers, if you would like to make a contribution in Barbara's memory, please consider either LiveOn NY, 49 West 45th St., New York, NY 10036 (www.liveon-ny.org) or St. Peter's Foundation to support The Monsignor James A. Harding Oncology Unit, 254 Easton Ave., New Brunswick, NJ 08901. 1/3

PETERS--Murray, passed away peacefully on June 7, 2016 in his 98th year surrounded by family. Beloved and cherished husband of the late Charlotte Peters and adored father of the late Jon Peters. He is survived by his daughter, Lonnie Resnick, son-in-law Norman Resnick, grandchildren Mitchell Resnick, Lindsay Resnick, Bruce Resnick, Jessie Peters, and his great-granddaughters, Carly Resnick and Kasey Resnick. He dedicated his adult life to his family and as an ardent supporter of Israel and the Jewish people. To the very end he had his wonderful stories and sense of humor. He is forever in our hearts and will be missed each and every day. 1/3

BERTCHER-- Robert W.,MD, passed away peacefully in his sleep on June 5, 2016. Dr. Bertcher was born on April 24, 1925. He attended the University of Pennsylvania as an undergraduate and received his medical degree from NYU Medical School. Dr. Bertcher was a Veteran of the Korean War, serving as a Captain in the United States Army. Dr. Bertcher practiced internal medicine in Lynnbrook, NY for more than 40 years before retiring to Gainesville, FL. He is survived by his wife of 47 years, Georgia; his brother Harvey, in Ann Arbor, MI and several nieces and nephews, including Quincy Thoeni, in Plant City, FL and Corey Bertcher, in Ypsilanti, MI. Memorial services have not yet been planned and will be held at the discretion of the family. 1/3
HEELEY--Desmond, international set and costume designer for theater, opera, and ballet, passed away on Friday after a long illness. He was 85. A memorial will be scheduled at a future time. 1/3

FISHER--Marjorie S. The Columbia School of Social Work mourns the passing of Marjorie S. Fisher. A philanthropic leader, she helped to establish the Fisher Cummings Washington Fellows Program, which prepares promising students for careers in public policy. We extend our sincere condolences to her daughter Julie and son-in-law Peter, and her entire family. Jeanette C. Takamura, Dean 1/3

DIMON--Themis and Ted. It is with great sadness that the Board, staff and membership of the New York Psychoanalytic Society and Institute and the Board of the Helix Center have learned of the deaths of Themis and Ted Dimon who were deeply committed and devoted friends of both institutions. We extend our heartfelt condolences to their family. Ian Buckingham, President, NYPSI; Edward Nersessian, Director, The Helix Center 1/3

SCHWARTZ--Lawrence. The Schragis Family mourns the profound loss of their beloved, brave, wise, witty friend, uncle, neighbor and travel companion. Always strong in the face of tragedy and adversity, we were blessed to have known him over 65 years. Our love and support always to his wife Selma, son Andrew, and grandchildren Ricky and Julia. 1/3

CHILDS--Sally Hillman. November 21, 1927 -- June 10, 2016. On Friday, June 10, 2016, Sally Hillman Childs died in Boulder, CO. A resident of Pittsburgh, PA, for 85 years and beloved wife of the late J. Mabon Childs, she is survived by her four children: J. Mabon Childs Jr. (Holly), Marguerite Hillman Childs Detmer (Tom), Laura Childs Saverin (Ken) and Sally Childs Walsh (Alec). She is also survived by 11 grandchildren: Frazer (Adam) Roche, Ellie (Tim Romano) Childs, Margot (Will) Stanley; Matthew (Jennifer) Detmer, Tommy (Leigh) Detmer, Emily Detmer; Hilary Saverin, Diana Saverin; Sarah (Thatcher) Martin, Mary Walsh, Alex Walsh. Sally leaves behind six great- grandchildren: Nathan Detmer, Landon Roche, Mabel Romano, Emma Detmer, Audrey Martin and Harvey Stanley. She was preceded in death by her parents, James F. and Marguerite W. Hillman, and three sisters: Constance Hillman Oliver O'Neil, Marguerite Hillman Purnell and Audrey Hillman Hilliard. Friends will be received at Calvary Episcopal Church, Pittsburgh, PA at 10:00am on Friday, June 17th prior to a Celebration of her life at 11:00am. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, Remembrances may be made to Lydia's Place (Renewal, Inc.), St. Aidan's Church in Boulder, CO, Calvary Episcopal Church or the charity of your choice. Services by John A. Freyvogel, Inc. Pittsburgh 1/3

SWIRBUL--L. Philip. Leon Philip Swirbul died peacefully on June 12 in Tuxedo Park, NY surrounded by his loving family. The cause was complications related to Parkinson's. He was 85. Known to his family and friends as Phil, Mr. Swirbul was born in Bay Shore, Long Island on February 19, 1931. His father, Jake Swirbul, was one of the founders of the Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation. Phil Swirbul was a graduate of the Lawrenceville School and Princeton University where he earned an A.B. degree in 1953. Following Princeton, he served in the U.S. Navy from 1953-1955 with the rank of Lieutenant Junior Grade (LTJG). During his 50-year career as an investment advisor to high net worth individuals, Phil was associated with several Wall Street firms including Reynolds & Co., A.G. Edwards, and Morgan Stanley. He was married to his loving wife, Serene, for 62 years. They established their home in Tuxedo Park, NY in 1968 where they raised four sons and where Phil gave distinguished leadership service to the affairs of St. Mary's Church, The Tuxedo Park School, and The Tuxedo Club. As a dedicated member of the St. Mary's Church vestry, Phil served as Senior Warden. He was also President of the Board of Trustees of The Tuxedo Park School. A life- long tennis player with a renowned backhand, Phil was Chairman of the Board of Governors of The Tuxedo Club. A beloved figure in Tuxedo Park, Phil will be remembered and missed for his devotion to his family, his commitment to the community and his love of sports. He was an enthusiastic supporter of the Mets and Jets. He is survived by his wife, Serene, and his four sons: Philip and his wife Malu; Paul and his wife Barbara; Mark and Jason and his wife Jill. He is also survived by his seven grandchildren: Mackenzie, Sarah, Justin, Madison, Caitlin, Tyler and Emma and a twin brother, William R. Swirbul of Perrysburg, Ohio. A memorial service will be held at St. Mary's Church in Tuxedo Park, NY on Friday, June 17th at 11:00am. 1

SIMON--Kenneth, NYC, age 93. Lawyer, judge, veteran. Graduated Georgetown, Harvard Law. Service at 199 Bleeker St., June 17, 11am. 1/3

SCHIFF--Ivy, 82, passed away on June 11 following two years battling cancer. Up until four weeks before her death, Ivy enjoyed a life rich with theater, opera, classes at the New School, myriad friends and loving family. After attending Brandeis and completing a master's in education at St Johns, Ivy was a New York City public school teacher and administrator. She is survived by her children; Robin Schiff (David Michaelson), Matthew (Rina), Claudia Eff (Tom), Jennifer Berg (Mitchell), nine grandchildren, stepsons Andrew and Matthew Berchuck, and her brother and sister-in-law, Mark and Muriel Graber. She was pre-deceased by husbands, Lawrence Robert Schiff and Irving Berchuck. 1/3

AVAKIAN--Anahid Ajemian, renowned violinist, born in New York in 1924, died suddenly at home Monday, June 13. Graduate of Julliard, winner of the Walter W. Naumburg, Distinguished Achievement Medal and Laurel Leaf Award; co-founder of the Composers String Quartet. Survived by her husband George, children Maro, Anahid and Greg, and two grandchildren. Viewing Thursday at Gannon Funeral Home, 152 E. 28th St., 6 to 8pm. Services Friday, June 17th at 11am, at St. Vartan's Armenian Cathedral, 630 2nd Ave. In lieu of flowers, kindly make donations to: Maro and Anahid Ajemian Scholarship, Julliard School, 60 Lincoln Center Plaza, NY, NY 10023 or Armenia Tree Project, 400 West Cummings Park, Ste 3900, Woburn, MA 01801. 1/3

TAYLOR--Dr. Jim. We are deeply saddened to announce the death of our beloved James Allen Taylor, 68, who died on June 5, 2016. He is survived by his loving wife Eleanor Taylor, and daughters Katherine Polley (Ray), Lana Goddu, and Yulia Goddu, along with his grandchildren Raymond, Lauren, and Patrick Polley. He will be greatly missed by his family and legions of friends. Considered one of the world's most respected marketing and branding consultants, Dr. Taylor served as Global Chief Marketing Officer of Ernst & Young and Gateway Computers. Prior to that, Dr. Taylor was CEO of Yankelovich, Skelly & White. More recently, he was a Vice Chairman at YouGov and a consultant on major education research studies. In 2015, he became a professor at Michigan State University (MSU). He held a B.A. in Rhetoric from Berkeley, along with a Master's and Ph.D. in Communication from MSU, where he was recognized as a distinguished alumnus. A memorial service will be held at 3:00pm on June 23, at Trinity Church, 651 Pequot Ave., Southport, CT. 1/3

MANNING--Constance. Constance Howland Manning, a resident of Smith Ranch Homes in the city of San Rafael, California, passed away peacefully on June 7, 2016, after an extended and difficult illness. She was born on June 12, 1927, the daughter of Horace Tomlinson Howland and Adelaide O'Connor Howland, of New Rochelle, New York. She grew up in New Rochelle and graduated from Barnard College in New York City in 1949. In 1952, while returning from a vacation in Europe on the French Line steamship "Liberte", she met her future husband, Ellis Manning, Jr., a lawyer engaged in the practice of law in Washington, D. C. They were married in 1953 and had four children in a marriage of almost 63 years. Connie was a devoted homemaker. She took great joy in being actively involved in her children's lives throughout their school days, and beyond. She is survived by her husband, by three of her four children, and by five grandchildren. Her surviving children are: Ellis W. Manning, of West Chester, Pennsylvania; Peter T. Manning, of Middletown, Rhode Island; and Elizabeth H. Manning, of Mill Valley, California. During her marriage, Connie and her family lived for 21 years in Washington, D.C. An avid reader, she enjoyed working at the Francis Scott Key Bookshop in Georgetown. She and her husband relocated to the community known as Scarborough in the village of Briarcliff Manor, in Westchester County, New York, where they spent the next 28 years, and were active members of the Sleepy Hollow Country Club in Scarborough. Connie had a strong interest in gourmet cookery. After her children were grown and gone, she pursued that interest as a post-graduate student at the Culinary Institute of America at Hyde Park, New York, and as the operator of a well-respected catering business for more than a dozen years. Connie and Ellis loved to travel. They made frequent trips with family and friends to western Europe, traveling extensively in France and northern Italy. In 2002, they retired to their vacation residence on St. Simon's Island, Georgia. Then, in 2008, they made a final move to San Rafael, California. Memorial services will be scheduled at a later date. 1/3
